articleText:
KOCKtlAntl'I'ON.

THURSDAY, APRIL 6, 1883.

WHATEVER differences of opinion may exist in the community of Rockhampton as to our future railway policy, there seems to be almost general unanimity as to the desirability of proceeding with the navigation improvements tn the Fitzroy

River. It is well for the town and district that this should be the case, because a disposition has been evinced in some quarters to suspend them till the Eupatoria Railway was completed. The

erection of the wharf at Port Alma will necessitate the construction of a railway, and as our politicians say, "it will come in time." Indeed, the time may come sooner than many anticipate, for a light railway would greatly facilitate the traffic in con- nection with our import and export trade ; and would afford ample accom- modation for all the requirements likely to be made upon it for some years

to come. There can be no doubt

it would expedite business, and prove of immense advantage to the inland dis- tricts. But it is only reasonable to anticipate that the time will come, when the immense trade, of which Rockhamp- ton is bound to be the port, shall exceed the carrying capacity of even a railway with double lines on the broad guage system. In America the railways, we are told, have superseded the use of steamers on the Mississippi, but there must be circumstances peculiarly favour- able to their having done so, because in other countries water carriage is most largely taken advantage or on account of its cheapness. Notwithstanding the existence of railways from London to numerous pants of the English coast, ttje shipping trade of the pont retains its magnificent proportions. Liverpool and Glasgow hive their deep-water ports, but the expenditure on the docks at Liverpool continues, and the dredging of the Clyde never ceases. Man- chester is not content with the railway service to Liverpool, though there are several routes, and a movement is on .foot to connect it with the Mersey by a ship canal. On the continent of Europe similar movements show, that there also water carriage can be conducted more cheaply than land carriage. It would evidently be a mistake, therefore, for the colony of Queensland, which has in the Fitzroy River, an admirable water-way to Rockhampton, to suspend the operations for the improvement of the navigation.

The contention of persons, who, from personal and interested motives, and without considering theirdutyascolonists, oppose the River Works, is that the money will be thrown into the river, both

literally and metaphorically. Some go so far as to say that it shall be found impossible by any amount of expenditure to make the river permanently navigable : while others admit that it may be done, but argue that the trade to be developed will never justify the expenditure, If the canny old Bailie Nicol Jarveis, who peered into the future at the beginning of this century, and saw the possibilities of the American trade, which has since made restrained by such doubts and fears, the Glasgow rich and great, had been city on the Clyde would not now have been the second in size and importance in the United Kingdom. We only require-to consider what these enter- prising and far seeing Scotchmen have

done to find a warrant for lavish expenditure on the Fizroy. In its infancy Glasgow conducted its maritime trade by means of land carriage and lightering, from Irvine on the Aryshire coast, and ultimately from Port Glasgow. The latter place was to be the Port Alma of the rising town, and there quays and docks were formed. It is not yet a hundred years since the first quay was formed at the Broomielaw in Glasgow. At that time the depth of the water at the shallows in

the river was little more than three feet

The town is twenty miles from the sea,

and there were no doubt croakers in

those days ready to declare, as are their successors now, that to attempt to deepen such a long channel, in which there were shifting sand-banks, was utter folly, and a waste of the -public money. Undeterred by the predictions of the prophets of evil the majority of the merchants raised money and proceeded with their river im- provement works. The result of the operations was that fifty years ago there was a depth of twelve feet at high water

at Glasgow. In 1840 the Harbour Trustees obtained an Act of Parliament to give them greater freedom in carrying on their operations. Consequent upon the latter, vessels drawing fifteen feet of water could go up and down the river in two tides. Now vessels drawing twenty two feet of water, by leaving the Broomielaw a few hours before high tide, can proceed right out to sea.

If we turn to a consideration of the means by which all this has been accomplished, we find they are quite

within our own reach. We are told

that "the rapidity of the deepening process has been due almost entirely to the powerful steam dredgers employed by the trustees, to the use of the diving-bell for blasting purposes, and latterly to the employment of steam drilling and dynamite." During the last thirty years twenty millions of tons of stuff have been taken out of the river channel. The cost of dredging alone in the Clyde has been upwards of half a million pounds sterling. Now, compared with this it is evident all that has been done in the Fitzroy is mere scratching. In fact, a systematic and sustained effort at dredging has never been made on a scale commensurate with the demands of the river and trade. On the

Clyde, not one dredge, like our coming Saurian, but many are con- tinually employed in deepening the water way; and each is attended by a fleet of steam tugs and hopper punts, With such appliances in active operation there is no reason to antici- pate that the Fitzroy may not be made available for navigation by ocean ships, and those steamers the Hon. Mr. Archer talked about in his speech to the electors of Blackall District.

But many who are prepared to con- cede the possibility of the improvement of the Fitzroy, maintain that it can only be effected at an outlay that will never be recouped, either directly or indirectly to the Colony. The merchants of Glas- gow had more faith in the future of their' town and trade ; and we wish the colonists of Queensland would only en- courage the people of Rockhampton to entertain similar feelings, Though the distance from Glasgow to deep water is only half that between Rockhampton and Keppel Bay, the amount expended on river improvements has been upwards of seven million pounds sterling. Com- pare this with the peddling outlay of .five thousand pounds a year on the Fitzroy. At this rate how long will it be before we have spent seven million pounds on our river. The twenty-five thousand pounds we have still in hands of the last vote will keep us going for five years.

Then, again, apart front the indirect advantages that would arise from the improvement of our river navigation, there would be a large direct revenue. The present income is not taken account of : no record of it is kept ; and the river is charged only with expenditure.

Some indication of the increase of

revenue that is probable may be afforded by that raised on the Clyde. Shortly before the beginning of the present century it was about two thousand pounds per annum : now it is two hun- dred thousand pounds. Observe, the work has been done. The annual expendi- ture will diminish rather than increase ; hut the income will go on increasing. Thus old debts will be liquidated, and aropie funds provided for the erection of new docks and quays, Jn the lighjt of {these facts, we may look with the utmost confidence to the uUtrqate results pf our river improvements, and if the Govern- ment cannot, or will not, give them the attention they deserve, then our towns- men must imitate the " Glasgow bodies," and take them in hand themselves.

THE Premier in one of his recent speeches referred to an anonymous pamphlet, which has been circulated publicly, on the Transcon- tinental Railway, and hazarded thc opinion that it will do him more good than harm. Probably it will, but in that event it will not serve the object of the author. At Boma, Hon. Mr. Griffith, in order to discount the insinuations in the pamphlet, frankly relieved Sir Thomas M'llwraith of the charge of acting from interested motives in his railway schemes. The Courier has condemned the

pamphlet, and has shown that the writer sup- presses facts to suit bis argument. Most of the Opposition journals quote liberally from it,

.nd work op itt pointa In their leading columns. Under Hit heading of "The {Sup- pressed Pamphlet * the figaro bat the follow ing j

." A few week* ago I reoeired a pamphlet, in a grey corer, with a f nnereal look abott it. It wai labelled, in double leaded type-

rai

LITEST ropmcAi, nines .

PARTITION! HQ QUEENSLAND

AMOKQ SPECULATIVE BIROS,

AND

IIB IXFOtCSI,

Thia ia just the thing for Figaro I thought, and I turned itt pages o Ter with aridity.

Figaro lires iu order ta) erpoao wicked derioes ' of all kinds ; and here, I thought, is a brother expositor-Let me bug him to my bosom. I read on, page after page, and long ere I had reached the end, I neared a sigh of admira- tion. 'Great Heavens,' I exclaimed, ' What an expositor I He exposes, no doubt, a most artful derioe, but he exposes himself. Ho« sad.' I saw it at once. I detected the un- mistakeable lineaments of the expositors. There could be DO mistake. There VDU no

mistake. It waa written in every line, between, above, and below every line. I looked for the ' name, for the names of the spéculative ring who had evidently inspired this expositor. I turned it over, behind and before, back side and front side, still no name I Was it possible-an utterance from a speculative ring, and yet the ring had no name! There was room here I immediately felt lor further inquiry, I determined to probe it to the bottom. The funereal pro- duction was positively alire with libels. It crawled with libels - artful libols. How delioioos, I thought - would that Figaro could approach this artful libeller-an art outside the law. I looked for the imprint. I

found it.

? Printed for the author, by Cleghorn Ac Co, B.'

Being friendly- -with Cleghorn «od Co., I «rent ?traight to their offioes. 'Are yon aware, dear friend,' aaid I, 'what you are in for?' 'Not ip the lent,' aaid Cleghorn & Co. ' What,' aaid I, ' not know that yon hare been circulating the most ferocious, though artful, libels whioh have ever yet appeared, though probably they are outside tue law.' ' What do you mean!' said Cleghorn & Co. * I mean the pamphlet, the funereal pamphlet. There are libels in it whole fathoms deep. Yon could not reaob the bottom of them.' 'Oh, nonsense,' said my old friends, 'it waa only printed for private circulation, quite in- nocent and oonBdential, we can assure you.' ' Nevertheless my dear friends,' I remarked, ' You have printed 2000 of them, and they have been innocently and confidentially cir- culated from one end of Queensland to the other. You ara in for it.' 'Do you think so I ' said Cleghorn and Co., ' we will recall them.' And they wera recalled, nearly, though not quite all of them. They were burned in my présenos, and Cleghorn and Co. now sleep in peace. They no longer dream of bottomless libels, mounting ap to untold thousands ip illegal costs. Bul the partition of Queensland among tpecutalive Rings was not to be disposed of in this way. The artful pamphleteer waa not to be deprived of his spoils. Another printer -my old mate Sandy Muir-was found for the anonymous production. The bottomless libels were omitted, and now The Latea Political Device appeara in a new dress -bright yellow. It has dropped ita funereal tog. Ten thousand copies, I am told, have been printed and circulated already. It ia to be distributed gratm'tonsly throughout the length and breadth of the land, and if 100,000 are required, 100,000 will be forthcoming, posted gratuitously to every station-owner in the country. I bm beginning to feel nneaay. Does thia betoken an approaching generat elec- tion ! There will be blasts, and counterblasts. I am prepared for almost anything, bat be assured that' I shall keep a bright look out indeed for ' Politisai Devioes ' of all sorts this among the number. And I shall refer to it again."

I A TELEGRAM rewired in town yesterday

stated Mr. J. E. Redmond was on board the Moreton, s.s., and is experted to arrive in Rockhampton this morning. We understand that be will deliver bia lecture in the Hibernian Hall on Monday night next.

DUMGREE RUN, says the Gladstone Obtener, waa purohased at an upset price of £2 per square mile for ten years, by Mr. J. S. Bell, of Dumgree, The sate took place before Mr. Graham, at the I*nnd Office, Gladstone.

THE ordinary quarterly sittings of the Centrai District Court wilt be held before his

Honor JudaJMRiller this morning, at ten o'oloek, Ks^p the civil bnsiness will be pro-

ceeded withy There is only one undefended oause on the list, and one defended cause that of James M'Key Lawrenoe and wife ». Henry Butcher and wife, for slander, damages

£200.

A CORRESPONDENT writes from Rosewood Crossing yesterday, and states there is an abundance of grass in that locality. The country looks Splendid after the recent raina. A mob of thirty fat bollocks from Thornby Station, on the Dawson river, passed on the 4th instant travelling. to Rockhampton for sale ; Mr. Robert Davey, owner, in charge. A small mob horses also passed same day bound for Bogantungan for aale, owner io charge. 1

SOMETIME »go a band lome oab ran into th« atand-pipe opposite the Post Offioe, and the enp, attaohed by a chain to the water tap, was destroyed. Since then the Corporation has not supplied a new cup. This stand-pipe appears to be a usual call for children oomiog home in that direction from the William-street schools and for other thirsty soots. Drinking from a brass-mounted tap is not conducive to the maintenance of the lips in a healthy state, and the missiasjl^iant should be supplied with- out delay. We have no doubt the Municipal Council will take the hint, and cup the tap.

THE Duke of Devonshire, s.s., 2023 tons, in command of Captain Long, sailed from Bowen yesterday morning, and at Flat-top Island had to disoharge si sty-nine tons cargo and forty immigrants for Mackay. She is expected to anchor in Fort Alma to-night. Her cargo for this port amounts to 326 tons, and the immi- grants 31. The launch Mabel leaves this morning at eight with Mr. B. Cribb, P.M., immigration agent, and Mr. Mills, the Cus- toms clearing offioer, to visit the steamer. In addition the lumpers to discharge the Rock- hampton cargo will be taken down. The three punts for the reception of goods are already anchored in the port.

, A MARRIAGE a la mode was to be celebrated on Tuesday night and the services of a brides- maid who resides in a certain hotel in town, were engaged to give eclql io the ceremony. The bridegroom arrived from the Booth recently, and arranged mattera for the marriage, including the attendance of the bride's friend as bridesmaid. Unfortunately the expectant happy man when directing a cnbman to call for the assistant

lady had forgotten the correct address. Trusting to chance he sent him to a hotel in East-street. The Jehu told bis mission, and the landlady rushed out to Ellen, who was busily engaged in her domestio duties after tea. Ellen, it appears, was engaged to be bridesmaid to a friend, so she quickly donned the requisite apparol, joyfully stepped iuto the cab F aud drove off. But ou arrival at a Denham-street hotel she found tho bride and bridegroom were total strangers to her. Naturally she returned crestfallen to resume ber domestic duties while the other damsel, the really engaged party. Bat for hours io full costume in another hotel lamenting the want of thought on the part of the "happy man." Despite the con trOempt the happy pair were made ono, bul to tbs great disappointment of two brides-

maids,

Taw cricket match yesterday afternoon, bet wara Elerana representing the Zingari «nd Early Closing Association Clubs, ended to a victory for the Zngari team by dre wiokets and 1 ran. The scores were not very large on either side, the bowling of Thwaites and Mac- pherson for the viators, and Fisher for the Association, being particularly good. Total .. ., tl .. .. 26 THAT English apples can be grown in the tropics, Madame Thozet has sent usa pleasing token in the form of a large rosy-cheeked .pippin. It was about half a pound in weight and beautifully shaped. The flesh was soft and rather mealy in texture, and was neither so well flavoured and juicy as the home-grown

fruit. Mr. A. Thozet thinks the smallness ofi the crop, and the raid made on the fruit by flying foxes would render the cultivation of apples in this distriot unprofitable. An evidence in support of this opinion is furnished by the fruit itself, for though the specimen sent ns was well matured it contained not the vestige of a seed. Mr. Pilot Haynes' pears showed tbe same want of reproductive power on the part of tbs plant.

Our selectors need not lament the circum- stance so long ss they can cultivate such fine fruits as the Chinese Date Plum, which is now in fruit in Madame Thozet'a orchard. It well worth extended cultivation, as it will prove valuable for preserving purposes, What the fruit preserving industry may come to appears from the following paragraph which we take from the Adelaide Observer :-Our

Special Reporter, who has concluded visiting the various jam aod fruit preserving feotones in the colony, gives the following figures to show the extent of the industry i-Number of factories. 13; estimated manufacture of jams and fruit io syrup for tho season, 2,760 tons ; value, calculated roughly at £50 a ton (a fair average), £137,600 ; number of hands employed-male 180, female 175. Probably about one-fifth of the fruit used was imported from Tasmania and Victoria ; but it Bbould be remembered that our firnit crop this season has been a partial failure, and the import is abnormally large. These figures take no account of the tomato-sauce and piokle-manu faoturiug industry, not of the fruit drying. It is not yet possible to give even approximate estimates in regard to these. In M. Thozet orchard there is ample evidence of what may be done io fruit cultivation in Queensland. The variety of fruits is very large, and the fact indicates to selectors new lines on whioh by patience, industry, and perseverance, prosperity if not opulenoe may be reached.

articleText:
KOCK HAMPTON.

AMONG the reckless and rash charges, made against the Ministry by the Liberal Press, is the statement that, during their tenure of office, they have not improved the legislation of the colony. With un I blushing effrontery it has been asserted,

that they have spent their energies and time, in devising and developing heroic schemes, and have not added any useful measures to the statute book of Queensland. Statements of this kind, made repeatedly, without regard to truth, are intended to disparage the Ministry, and if accepted by credulous people will doubtless accomplish their purpose. In this electorate, we feel con- fident, the Ministry will not be con- demned upon the hard sayings of political detractors. By their works shall they be judged, and their friends will gladly submit to their being arraigned on such terms. The defeat of the Douglas Ministry took place in January 1879, and on the 14th of that month the present Governmant came toto power. In that first session of Parliament they passed seventeen public Acts. Of course we can only notice some these. The first measure they passed was one providing that thc islands in Torres Straits, between Au- stralia aDd New Guinea, should become part of the colony of Queensland. Under this measure the boundary line of the colony starts from Sandy Cape opposite Bundaberg, runs north in a strait line to the 21st parallel of South Latitude, thence follows'the windings of the outside edge of the Barrier Reef, along the north east coast, sweeps close in to the shore of New Guinea, and embraces all the islands in Torres Straits not formerly acquired by the colony in a loop. By this Act the navigable channel inside of the Barrier Reef, was made British water. Another of the measures passed was the Electoral Rolls Act, under which the quarterly registration courts are now held, and complete electoral lists are made up at stated periods. An Act amending the Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1876, was passed, which provided for all exchanged lands in the Darling Downs District being set apart for homestead arcas ; and increased the size of homestead selections to 160 acres. The Licensing Boards Act legalises the system under which licenses are granted at present ; and the Divisional Boards Act is too well known to call for description or comment. Among other acts passed that session were those relating to the importation of mineral oils, to Life Insurance, and to Orphanages-the establishment of which was provided for.

In the Session of 1880, twenty public Acts were passed, the importance of which will appear upon our adverting to a few of them. Among the first was the Post Card andiostal Note Act, enabling circulars and open communications to be passed through the post at a low rate ; and facilitating the means by which

labourers and working men may transmit small sums of money to their families or creditors in all parts of the colonies. The Rabbit Act provides means

to prevent the colony becoming pestered i with these creatures; and the Duty on Cedar Act has gone some length in pre- venting this colony from being plundered of its most valuable timber. By the Pacific Island Labourers Aa the South Sea Island trade was placed under improved regulations, and provisions were made for the employment, pay, and humane treatment of Kanakas, In this session was passed the Railway Com- panies Preliminary Act, providing for the construction of railways by private enterprise, and on the land-grant system. It was under this statute that arrange- ments were entered into with the

I Warrego Railway Company, and the

Australian Transcontinental Railway Syndicate. Though the negotiations with them have failed, the Act under which they were made remains, and it may induce future offers from capitalists, which the colony may regard with some

favour.

Tho Session of 188 r saw sixteen public Acts passed. Among the most important of these was the Pearl Shell and Beche-de-mer Fishery Act, which regulates the conduct of persons engaged in a lucrative and important industry, prosecuted in the far north of the colony.

The result of it has been to teach lawless intruders that they will not be permitted to do just as they choose in Queensland waters; and to secure protection for Kanaka and native labourers. The Marsupials Destruction Act has been recognised as a most useful measure ; and from the report of the Inspector of Mines, a summary of which wc pub- lished the other day, it would be observed that the Mines Regulation Act, in the first year of its operations, has been the means of diminishing accidents about one-half. The,Fire Brigades Act repealed an unworkable measure, and gave us a useful one instead, under which ample provisions may be made for safeguarding our houses and streets from conflagrations. In the Sale of Foods and Drugs Act, provision has been made for the punishment of those who mix in- gredients injurious to the health with food. Convictions under the Act have already taken place, and its presence on the Statute Book will, no doubt, have an ex- cellent effect in deterring thc practices of those who would vend " doctored tea " and watered milk. The United Munici- palities Act was a corollary and valuable supplement to the Divisional Boards

Act.

In the Session of 1882 seventeen

Acts were passed. The most important of these was the Immigration Act. Under it favourable terms are offered to

intending emigrants from the United Kingdom; the Agent-General is em- powered to assist them to the port of embarkation ; and provision is made for punishing them if they attempt to leave this colony immediately after landing. In The Tramways Act legislative sanc- tion has been given to the construction of these aids to locomotion, either by Municipal Corporations or private com- panies. The Settled District Pastoral leases upon terms fixed by appraisement, and recognises the right of tenants to consideration for their improvements. The Indian Immigration Act Amend- ment Act, provides that no regulations relating to the introduction of Coolies, shall have the force of law till approved of by both Houses of Parliament.

Among measures, which have been introduced and discussed at some length, have been the Insanity Bill, and Liquor Retailers Licensing Bill. These would have been placed upon the Statute Book this session, had the business been carried on by the present Government. In condemning the Ministry for not passing measures of public importance, the Liberal critics forget that the Opposition have done nothing to stimulate useful legislation. If Mr.

Griffith and his friends saw that

certain legislation was urgently required, it was within their province to have intro- duced the necessary measures ; but they utterly failed to do so. Mr. M'Lean introduced his Permissive Prohibition of Sales of Intoxicating Liquors Bili in 1869, when it was rejected on the second reading. Tile Triennial Parliaments Bill introduced by Mr. Griffith in 1880, shared asimilar fate, and was introduced hut was not persevered will) in 1S82. The same gentleman got a Pharmacy Bill through the Assembly, bul it was

never returned from the Council. His

Bill to repeal the Indian Immigration Act was defeated. Enough has been said, we think, to show that the term of Office of the Ministry has not been barren of legislative results, and state- ments to the contrary should put the electors on their guard against those

who make them.

articleText:
TO THE EU1TOR OP TEE MORNING BULLETIN.

Sir,-I Bee by th« Capí icorman that the Rockhampton peoplo aro petitioning to have a railway made to Emu Park That such a railway ia most urgently needed for tho health of the townspeople there is not the slightest doubt I regret to say that the proposers of tho line mentioned in tho petition muBt know vory little about our coast district, or the route tho line should run to open up the country, and make trade for tho line To adopt tho route mentioned would be to shut out part of tho district with thousand of acres of really good agricultural land, and also cut off what must be, one of the greatest centres of mining industry, in the Rock hampton district Any one knowing what Cawarral and Mount W heeler are, know that they will bo the beat mining centres in the district Now, instead of the route named m the petition, the line should follow the mail coach road via Cawarral, thus running more into the agricultural and nuning centres 1 his route is ouly about two miles longer, and briugs the railway within reach of the Mount Hedlow district, aud within ten miles of Yeppoon with easy country to go through to that watering place at a future timo By adopting this plan it would give the selectors a chance of supplying Rockhampton and Emu Park with daily produce and fruits of various descriptions, that can be grown hero in any season I am certain it only wants to be known, the harm tho proposed route would do, to have it altered The distance between the two is little and there are no engineering difficulties in the way It would also pass through the Cawarral reserves making the land more valuable to Government.

>oure, &c,

AN OLD RESIDENT.
heading: TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.
snippet: Sir—I see by the Capricornian that the Rockhampton people are petitioning to have a railway made to Emu Park That such a railway ia most urgently needed for the health

articleText:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE M0RK1ÜO BULLETIN.

Sin,-I am of opinion that tho platform nttcranoca of tho Rev. Colin M'Culfock at tho

meeting on Tuesday cvoning, as reported in this morning's Pulktin, should not be per- mitted to pass unnoticed. I have always held that tho highest type cf man is a Christian, and n« such-no matter how poor, invariably a gentleman. I leave it to the calm and un- biased decision of your readers, whether it was Christian-whether it was tho act of a gontleman-of a Christian minister, to oller such a gratuitous insult to the Protestant ministers nf this town, as to convey the im- pression that they were a parcel of illiterate tailors with black ooats and " white chokers " and whose pulpit efforts were " sound without sense." It is well known that each of the denominations referred to possess oollogcs and theological institutes for training their minis- ters, ss well as the Presbyterians ; that many ot thoir clergy are hoad ana shoulders above tho Bcv. Colin M'Culloch, eitheras pulpit orators, platform speakers, or publio lecturers on soienoe or religion ; and not only this, but they are doing a work in bringing the Gospel to tho poor, in elevating the manes, in rescuing the perishing which the Kev. Colin M'Cullooh and his learned brethren do not attempt. It is,not at any rate a line gua non with the Methodists in their abundant evangelical labours, either among the masses in tho large centres of population in the distant bush, or on the outposts of civilisation that the money question should be a first primary consideration, hut tbe love of Christ constrains them. Mr. M'Culloch complains that Presby- terians are tn he fnnnd in tho congregations of Primitive Methodist, Wesleyan, and Congre- gational Churches; but he ignores tho fant that not only in Rockhampton, but in all parts of thocolony, reprosentativesofthesedenomina tions are found in almost every Presbyterian congregation in tho land, and their ministers in outsido places especially aro largely sup- ported by other than Presbyterians. It is not croditabto to Presbyterianism, and to its

much vaunted learned ministry, that the ranks of infidelity should ho so largely recruited from adherents of that Church ; and it would appear from the utterances of the Ber. Colin M'Cullooh that the minis- ters about to be introduoed into Queensland are to be raen trained Bpocially for the work of bringing back these infidel wanderers to the fold of Presbyterianism. Sydney Smith in his day wrote eomo pungent squibs about Carey, the missionary to India, This witty clergyman referred to Carey as " tho eonsc I crated cobbler," but Carey laid tho foundation

of a work in India which shall exist when Sydney Smith and his criticisms are forgotten and buried in the dust of ages. Livingstone, thc factory boy, became tho successful mis- sionary, another renowned traveller and explorer of Central Africa. Robert Moffatt, the gardener's boy, became tho apostle of Africa. It is a well-known fact that the divinity students of the Church of Scotland are not ns a rule recruited from the laird's mansion, but from thc shepherds sheding on the monutain side, and from the plough tail, from tho workshop and the counter nil honor to tho lads, if they possess the necessary qualifications, which were imparted to the hVlicrinen of Galilee and to Paul tho apostle, another tent-maker. I regret that instead of comino: amongst ns as a Christian worker, on a mission of peace, that tho lïcv. Colin M 'Culloch should bare instead, sown thc fieodftof dipcord in our midst, nnd injured tiic minda of many Christian people in tho town and dial rici of UocUhnmpton.

I rcinaiji, <*;c.

articleText:
TO TUE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIR,-I am glad that " Mercator " is of the earoo opiniou as myself concerning the money spent for the education of the masses. At the same time lam sorry my letter led "Mercator" to think I sneered at the employment of lads

in mercantile establishments. I donot for one moment think commercial life infradignitatem. A large number of people in any city must, from the naturo of things, give their time and abilities to commerce ; and as the old pass away, the young occupy their places. And where are these youths to come from (in this town) if not from "Our Public Schools." It is commerce that has made thc British Empire BO famous, and I should be miserably mean wcro I purposely to sneer at those who honourably follow such pursuits.

Since " Mercator " asserts he had " pounds in a bushel of corn " in his manuscript, I with- draw my criticism upon thc "calico and corn."

In the State Schools of Queensland special attention is devoted to "head work," and more time given to theory than to practice. I believe there are no technical schools in this colony, and that the Government is un- willing to spend extra money to. supply

a staff of mechanics to teach thc various

trades. For my own part thc desirability of having at least one such institution in each of the larger towns. Were " Mercator " to state that many of the teachers do not know how roany pounds are contained in a bushel I should not bc surprised, but most boys, from tho middle forms upwards, have learned at eomc time or other that SS lbs. make a bushol. In all probability moll}' of them tn thc course of a short lime would forget this fact ; but any small boy who has weighed out 50 lbs., or a bushel of maize, a few times, will most likely remember it as long ns he lives. Here bead and hand work together ; herc theory and practice are combined. All tho pupils of Bny school would know the "arith- metical tables " much better if thc authorities were to supply scales, weights, and a collec- tion of general merchandise amongst tho school requisites. This is not done iu a single school

in tho world, so it remains for teachers to inculcate the theory, and for "Mercator" to show some of our youths how to turn that instruction to practical use. I find my idea on teaching tables in such a manner supported by a well-known English writer on education, who says "For which purpose it is obvious that the teachers should have all the weights and measures of the country, and duplicates of many of them, amongst his apparatus." I suppose arithmetic is one of the principal subjects of the State Schools which receive a fair portion of time. The examinations teachers arc compelled to pass are a sufficient guarantee that their knowledge of that subject at least, is by no means below the standard. Now, if a boy who has regularly attended school till he is fourteen years of age does not know enough arithmetic ta answer questions such as those propounded by " Mercator," the fault lies not with the teacher, nor tho Educational Department, but with thc boy, who has no aptitude for mathematics, how- ever elementary. If parents' means are ade- quate they should not withdraw children under fourteen years of agc from school. If I mistake not, this is the agc stated in the so called Compulsory Act. Then, if a youth who has not reached that age seek a position in business, and, being tried in the balance, is found wanting, it is rather unfair to attach all

tho blaine to the State Schools for his

ignorance. At the same time a public

criticism will do no barm to thc schools if it bo carried on with moderation. I would inform " Mercator" that I am uot unaware of tho fact that " not a few employes, &c," com- menced business as cashiers, or errand boys.

" Mercator " presumes I am a teacher be- cause I reply to him on "Our l'ublic Schools ;" be might just as well say that I was a mesmerist seeing that I replied to Professor Armand that " too awfully utter " exponent of that art. A short time ago a local appeared in the Morning Hull Iii, calling attention to the fact that subscriptions were required to procure prizes for the Christmas distributions, at thc Boys' School, William street, under the charge of Mr. Potts. I have no doubt if " Mercator " were to wait

upon Mr. Potts, the latter gentleman would be most happy to receive a handsome donation, which might bc divided into a number of prizes to be styled "Mercator" Prizes for ¡ Arithmetic." Suggesting that others like

"Mercator" subscribe.

I am, &c..

Cnmc.

November 23, 188».

articleText:
I TO THE EDITOR OP THE MORNING BULLETIN.

Sir,-Por some years I havo toen acquainted with tho Hov. C, M'Cultoch, of linsbano, and have always regarded him as a minister whose chris tain charity rendered him superior to the more restrictions of denormnationaUsm and that good, whether formed in the Uglier ranks of Presbyterianism loading public opinion, or in thc denominations about which he speaks so disparagingly, would command the rcspcot and admiration of his generous nature. After reading his speech in this morning's Bulletin L with many othors, must come to tho conclusion that wo have, not only not correctly known Mr. M'Culloch, but have been in great ignorance of his real attitude toward the Churches of this oolony. I have read many addresses from men who wore proverbially exclusive, but I do sot remember to have read anything eo extremely narrow and uncharitable as the addroBS re- ferred to, If Hit. M'Cullqph cannot agree with tho methods adopted in other Churches, ho might quietly pass them by, or if he feols bound to eriticise their doings, he should do it fairly, in the right place and, at the proper time. I submit that the references made by him to other denominations in Presbyterian Church on Tuesday evening before a pro- miscuous congregation were not correct, un- less the exception rather than the rule is to govern. Mr. M'Culloch seems to overlook tho fact thst men of humble birth may oarry the light of the Reformation In their hearts, rise to the highest spheres of usefulness, and

wield an influence over their fellows that shall tell upon their best interests for ever. Tho groat Master himself was lowly in birth, and some of his apostles were fisher- men. Many of tho more able and useful men is later.ages wera made famous, not because of their parentage, plaoo of birth, or early advantages. John Bunyan was a tinker. William Carey a shoemaker, and John Kitto a mason. The spoech in question was exclusive and uncharitable. Mr, M'Culloch not only reflects on other Churohes, but asks with much assurance, " Who was it but the Presbyterians who had rallied round the throno of Victoria." Tho historian and public opinion say that tho honour of protecting Her Majesty's throne has belonged to no one Church, nor to any one class.

I am, Sir, tc.

WILLIAM POWELL.

Tho ParaonRgc.

bin,-The work of apuliation by the Cor- poration of South Rockhampton is going on merrily The aldermen are determined that the ratepayers shall pay dearly for their whistles 1 be salaries of the officials are in- creasing in a most alarming manuer from a ratepayer's point of \iew, and they amount now to the round sum of £3000 per annum. It is not long since the people were " dono brown " over the Assistant Inspector of Nuisances, and now we have to bewail the assessment job, for although the farce was gone through of calling for tenders, it is patent to everyone who has a grain of percep- tion that it was a foregone conclusion Mr. Dibdiu was to have the job I have nothing to say ngamst that gontleinan, and think if the ratipa)ers arc disposed to pay lum the high xaluebc places upon Ins services ho is quite ryht to take it, but I am of opinion that the ]n ice is cxccssuc, and that the Major nnd Aldermen have abnsed the trust plaeed in them by the ratepayers in voting linn the large sum of H00

.11.krm.iti M illiaiuion thought none of Hie tenders wuc suitable, aud mo\eil that fresh tcudirs be called for, and nae seconded by ^Murniau Kelly. AMcrniau Allen ino\cd an amendment that tho lown Clerk, with an assistant, bhuuld do the work and was st ni lui by Alderman Mnyli Qucrj -Did Alluiuiii \lleu in nuning lus amendment think to do the ratepayers 'brown" again9

vote bas done for Mr Dibdin If the rate- payers will stand this without protest they deBorve to be fleeced as often as the tender conscience of the Mayor and Aldermen dispose tbem to inflict the torture of the operation

From certain letters that have appeared lately in the press there seems to bo a growing suspicion abroad that all is not exactly right with the cnporation contracts There is a feeling that something is being done under the rose We all know that the law forbids any member of the Council from contracting with the corporation but if that law can be evaded then it would be much better that it did not exist, because it is demoralising m its action. If there was no restriction of the sort the

people would know when and where to strike at any growing corruption Of course I do not suppose that the members of our Town Counoil would for a moment think of evading the law , they are too honourable for that and I am sure they could all, from the Mayor downwards to the junior aldermen, place their hands upon their hearts, aud conscientiously declare they have never dcrlvod from theSpast, nor aro deriving from the present contráete any benefit whatever in fact that they have no interest, nor ever have had any while officiating as Aldermen Such is the innocent faith I have hitherto held in our Town Council, but recent events have much shaken this faith. The wharf extension for instance, in course of construction, the time for completion of which, as tendered for, lias expired, and at the present rate of construction it must certainly take as long again to finish. Now it ia a remarkable ¡fact that not one alderman seems at all conscious that this work is going on At their meetings no ques tions have been asked about it, and no one baa wanted to know the reason the work is not carried on more expeditiously or if there are any penalties for the delay, and if those penalties aro being enforced Of course if like the public baths, the con tract is not made out and signed yet, there is virtually no contract, and the penalties cannot be enforced The integrity of the Council has been impeaohed by one or more anonymous writers in the Press, concerning this wharf «x tension, and although my innocent faith in tho rectitude of the Town Council is not entirely destroyed, yet I think the majority of the

Aldermen are not endowed with that nice

sonse of honour which should actuate public

men

I am &o,

TIDDLY-WINK.

articleText:
THE TOTALISATOR.

TO TUB EDITOR OF TUE MORKIN'n nULLETIN.

Sin,-Having boon a speculator in thc totalisator owned hy thc Rockhampton Jockey Club, I would wish through your columns to make a remark, which I hopo will prove of

some interest and benefit.

Seeing that " New Moon " was scratched five minutes before thc time of starting, and that a rcfondment of the money has been applied for, but refused, I very much wonder how such sharp practice is permitted by the Club. Surely Bookmakers could hardly exhibit more hardiness of constitution ; and, although such behaviour might suit the pocket of an individual or two, yet it demoralises public confidence and engenders disgust in- stead of a recreative interest in the Turf.

I am, Sir, &c,

WM. CARRINGTON.

Cometville, December 29, 1882.

FLYISQ FOXES AND FRUIT.-Mr. William

Pettigrew writes to the editor of the Brisbane Courier :-The flying foxes not only eat the ripe fruit, but they destroy a great quantity besides. The way I have got rid of them for several years past is very simple. I take a light polo twenty to thirty feet long, and fasten eight or more fine wires to the top of it ; erect the poles ovor whero the fruit is that requires protecting, and then take these

several wires in various directions round about the pole and fasteu them to stakes or trees as may bc moBt convenient. They should not be tight, as when so they are more readily broken by the foxes flying against them. Brass or copper wire, 2i to 20 gauge, will answer the purpose. It will probabably break when struck in full force, but if so the flying fox, will not be inclined to repeat the experiment.

CHRISTMAS IN MELBOURNE.-Tuesday was observed as a general holiday. A great variety of amusements were provided for tho public, all of which received a full share of patronage. The Intercolonial Cricket Match attracted many thousands of persona, and the V.A.T.C. Summer Meeting at Caulfield was very fairly attended, despite the inadequate provision of the Railway Department for con- veying visitors to the course, The Tem- perance Gala was attended by fully 23,000 people. The trains running to various holiday resorts were crowded, and thc resources of thc Department were altogether too limited to

meet the demands. The usual marine excur- sions, in which, in addition to the ordinary excursion steamers, several intercolonial traders were engaged, were all highly success- ful. In the evening the various theatres and other places of amusement were largely attended. The Theatre Royal, where the pantomime season was opened, was packed to such no extent as to cause considerable dis- comfort to thc audience, and some disorder ensued in consequence. The Opera House, Bijou Theatre, and Princess were all well patronised, and at the musical festival at the

Exhibition there was au immense audience.

This morning thc third concert of the festival was given. A cantata, composed specially for thc occasion by Alfred Plumpton, entitled " Endymion," waa performed with much success. Tho cantata is founded on Keats' poem of thc same name. Mr. Armes Beau- mont appeared in the title character, and Miss Alice Roes as Diana. Both sang beautifully. Thc audience were enraptured with the per- formance, and encored portions vehemently. The second part of the concert commenced with thc Orchestra! Scherza, " La Siesta de Ia Senorita," by Furai. Madamo Polk sang the " Jewel "Bong, from Faust. The concert, as a whole, gave entire satisfaction to the

audience,

articleText:
KOCK ll A MITON.

MONDAY. FiîBRUAllY 19, 1883.

THE dangers to which the colonists of Australia are exposed from the influx of Chinese has been again prominently brought under notice by the arrival in Port Jackson of the Menmuir, s.s., with sixty Mongolians for New South Wales and ninety for Queensland. These objectionable immigrants have small-pox among them, and thc necessity for the utmost care being taken to prevent this disease being spread by the Chinese, puts tile Government of the sister colony to great expense. lt will be very apparent that under existing regulations these orientals will continue to emigrate from their own country into ours, and it is very extraordinary, after all the evi- dence that has been brought forward from time to time, to show how objec- tionable the Chinese are in any country inhabited by Europeans, that still legis- lature docs not grapple with the evil and remedy it. It is remarkable lo observe also how those disinterested patriots, wbo so loudly proclaim their intention of keeping Queensland for the white man whatever that may mean-we say it is very remarkable lu observe these philan- thropic individuals who love thc while man and the black (in his proper place) -employing the latter when it suits their own convenience. How pleasant it is to contemplate the sauve and pious Mr. Brookes, who is thc antagonist of the

labour traffic which he speaks of as the slave trade, himself superintending Kanakas and Chinamen cultivating his own garden. It is simply because there are so many men who profess themselves anxious to protect the country, and yet are wanting in sincerity, that we are still

liable to tile introduction of foul diseases from mongolian races. These men who so loudly protest against the introduction of Coolies into this country under pro- per restrictive regulations, are the very ones who would leave the portals open for a race infinitely more objectionable, less useful, and, from a sanitary point of view, absolutely dangerous. These very men who proclaim against the Coolie and the Cingalese, actually themselves employ Chinese labour;' and even go so far as to say that there is no necessity to import Coolies, for Chinamen can. work on the sugar plantations. Looking at the labour question fairly, it will surely be apparent that Chinese immigrants are dangerous to the white tradesmen, but the Coolie is not. The one competes with the whites as a cabinet-maker and storekeeper, and as an agriculturalist; whereas the other has no aspirations beyond a sufficiency of rice and moderate wages. Vet we find that the very men who are horrified at Coolies being brought here, who cry out that the white man's wages will be endangered, never do any practical good towards saving him from Chinese. Surely, if these gentlemen were sincere-surely if they were so tender-hearted towards the working man for whose vote they are fishing-they would long since have protected him. from the real evil in preference to assail- ing an imaginary one.

It will be seen that the only way to effectively restrict Chinese immigration,

is for the Governments of the various colonies to take united action. It is no use for one colony to institute restrictive measures if the others do not, for these people could come to the open colony first, and then make their way into the closed ones. Whether we have the power to exclude Chinese or not has been considered at some length by the legislative bodies of the various colonies, and it has been pointed out that Hong- kong, being a British colony, we cannot legally refuse admission to Her Majesty's subjects coming from that portion of her dominions, even if they are the almond eyed sons of the East. But it must be remembered that the mere fact of resi- dence in a British colony for a lengthened period does not constitute a British subject, and whichever way the question is viewed, it seems ludicrous to ever consider a Mongolian as an English- man-naturalised or not. Besides, if England did force admission into China, and established a colony there, it is rather hard that we should have to suffer. Whether England was right or wrong in her action towards China is not the fault of the colonies, and there must be some way to protect ourselves from the evils of Chinese immigration.

Not only has the case of small-pox alluded to above drawn attention to this serious subject, but locally there is not wanting proof of the objectionable character of Chinese residents. In

I several localities in Rockhampton there

are celestial dens that are highly objectionable. In the first place gambling goes on within them almost every night, and during nearly the whole of Sunday; and not infrequently other evils are germinated here to which even the mildest reference cannot be made in public print. The premises where these proceedings to which we refer are carried on are in every instance filthy beyond description, and the stench proceeding from them is pestiferous to a degree. Whether the Inspector of Nuisances (if there really is such a person, and it begins to be a matter of doubt) could take action against the occupiers of these abominable tenements or not. it is impos- sible to say, as the duties of that officer never seem to be tested, but certainly the police might be expected to to proceed against them under the Vagrant Act. This glorious act will fit them or anyone else, and why is it not set in motion. 15 Vic. No. 4 section 3 describes a vagrant as being a person found playing or betting at any unlawful game at or with any table or instrument of gaming, and section 13 of the same Act goes on to give justices of the peace power to grant search warrants for sus- pected persons-that is suspected oí vagrancy in lodging houses. There is thus clearly a way for the police to reach these Chinese gamblers, and rid us of their dens, since all these Chinese tenements are lodging houses. If there be a difficulty in obtaining evidence as to the actual game played, surely the production of the instruments of gaming, and the money that at any lime could be seized on the table, is prima fade evidence ol gambling, and more especially would it be sufficient, if evidence were produced of the fact that money changed hands in accordance with some rule of the table.

It appears to us that this Chinese Question has been allowed to sleep toa long, and remains still in far too unsatis- factory a condition. Herc we are allow- ing the ingress of a horde of the most most objectionable race, while in all directions is observable agitation about a much less dangerous immigrant. Sand is clearly being thrown into the eyes of the electors over the Coolie Question, and surely the bona fides ol thc anti-Coolie legislators should be questioned when they are supine about Chinese. The evils of the Mongolian immigration are apparent and unmistak- able. Their arrival endangers the health oí our communities, their presence under- mines the morality of the lower classes, and while they contribute a mere nothing to the taxes of the country, they from lime to time export the results of theil labour to their own country. They dc nothing to circulate money in oui country, and are a race calculated only to reduce the wages, more especially ol agriculturalists, mitlers, and domestic ser- vants. Here is a real and palpable evil-an evil long recognised, and not yet remedied, even though there are men in the Legislature whe

profess a determination to stand hand to band and shoulder to shoulder in the interests of the working man. When we see Chinese still swarming into our country, when we see the squatter's claims to cheap labour so cordially acknowledged by the friends ot the working man, we are inclined to wonder what, the working man is like, when his representatives rate his per- ceptions at so low a valuation.

UNQUESTIONABLY the trade of this port is out-growiug the accommodation of our wharves, for at the present time large quantities of goods ready to bo landed, are lying ia punts on the far aide of the ships already berthed, awaiting an opportunity to be discharged.

How Messrs. W. Howard Smith and Go. are to find berths for their steamers ia a rather difficult problem-every available foot of the corporation wharf being occupied. But while our oivio authorities slowly realise the neces- sity for action in the direotion indicated, there ¡8 surely no good and euffioient reason why the wharveB. as they now are, should not be pro- perly supervised. There is no regular wharfin- ger on the Corporation wharf, and vessels appear to berth themselves almoBt according to their own sweet will. The Town Clerk hos oontrol, we believe, of the wharves, but unmistakably he cannot be in attendance, and it is sometimes very diffioult to find him, as he i> about in all directions attending to his various duties. Thus/ it will be seen that delay and inconvenience must frequently occur in connection with the shipping. Tho goods now lying on the wharf are of almost every description, and are piled up in a formidable mountain extending almost the entire length of the wharf, causing we understand considerable inconvenience at times to consignees, who find it difficult to ascertain the whereabouts ot their goods; This matter of the necessity of increased wharfage accommodation has been so re- peatedly brought before the notice of the Municipal Council, as also the matter of the desirability of appointing a wharfinger, that it becomes almost tedious to refer again to it. Numerous complaints have been made, and accidents have occurred through there being no responsible corporation officer on our public wharf, but not even loss of life disturbs the placid self-satisfaction of Aldermen, who

know they have merited the respeot and sup- port of tho ratepayers, because their elections were unopposed.

WE have received from the publishers, Messrs. Gordon and Gotch, Pugh's Almanac for 1883. It is, as usual, a comprehensive end useful volume, invaluable to business men. The printing is remarkably well executed, and the volume is neatly and substantially bound

m cloth.

THE Planter and Farmer for the month of February is to hand, and reflect8 credit on Mr. Thorne, its proprietor. In it will be found very much of interest to agricul- turalists, and the sugar industry is largely dealt with. One of the most remarkable

features of this publication is its seeming favour with the advertisingpublio, there being thirty-two pases of advertisements to twenty pages of reading matter. The Minister for Lands, Mr. Perkins, also seems to consider it a valuable advertising medium.

IN Mr. Pagh'u time as Magistrate here a South Sea Islander was sent to gaol on several charges. For some he was 6 ned, and having paid the fines he could not understand why he was kept in gaol on a charge for which no fine was imposed. On being liberated he received the bilanoo due to him out of the funds he had when arrested, He evidently brooded over the subject and went to the look-up yeBterdayafternoontoaskfortheSergeant. The watch-house-keeper, Senior-constable Hardy, was absent at the time, and on being informed by Constable Balfour of thc fact, made a desperate onslaught on him with a club. Balfour managed to evade his assailant and fortunately the noise attraoted the attention of other membira of the force who, with Detective Clark vent to his assistance, secured tho enraged Islander and locked him up.

A ROBBERY is reported to have been com- mitted in the Commercial Hotol, Quay and William streets, on Saturday night. It seems an old man named Thomas Wilson who is a station bolder at St. George's Bridge was stay- ing in the Hotel and ocoupied a room in whioh two other men slept. In hie possession ho had a bag in which was a cheque book with a signed cheque for £136 drawn on the bank of New South Wales, Moree, New South Wales, another cheque filled up but not signed, a new silver lever watch with an Albert chain, a £10 and £5 note, a silk necktie and gold ring, a valuable telescope and articles Of clothing. About eleven o'clock Wilson missed thc bag, and also one of the occupants of the room who had been most assiduous in his attentions to him. The matter is in tho hands j of the police.

1 TnE Australian Skctclicr for February 14 is

a very well-exocuted journal, and it speaks well for our great Australian city that it can bring ont euch a weekly production. The illustrations are all full of "point," and the figures in them have life-two qualities not always observable in pictures. " Under the Cliff is a pretty sketch of seaside enjoyment, and following it are two pictures, one of a chess tournament in the Town Hall, Adelaide, South Australia-the pieces being represented by living figures-and the other of an aquatic entertainment at Emerald Hill, Victoria. "A Funk Established," being a eketch of the " next man in " of a side whose career

has been disastrous, is a good subject, but it is doubtful Whether the cricketer depicted il a black or a white man. There is a splendid portrait on page 24 of Dr. Kennion, tho new Bishop of Adolaide, and beneath it a rough sketch of figures at the Calico Ball. Tho illustrations of the serial, "Kit," aro both very good ; and sketches from Messrs. David Munro and Co.'s engineering works convey an adequate ¡doa of the extent of that firm's operations. " The Stud Farm at Bundoora Vark" and "Sketches on Board a Mail

boat" are both good. The lettcr-rpretB is carefully selected and well written, the publi- cation being, taken altogether, a most de- sirable one, as showing the progrcsB -of Australia industrially and socially. ~j

The adjourned meeting of gentlemen favour-

able to the formation of a joint-stock company to cultivate 1000 acres of sugar land on Mr. Broome's estate of Woodlands, was held in the office of Messrs. Brown and Risien on Friday afternoon. The chair was occupicd by Mr. John Ferguson, M.L.A. A letter was read from Mr. John M'Donald (late superin- tendant of St. Helena) reporting; favourably on the quality of the land, and the natural advantages offered for sugar-growing. After discussion, it was proposed that a company under the above title of the Yeppoon Sugar Company be formed with a capital of £20,000, in 4000 shares of £5. It was further resolved that the following gentlemen be requested to act as provisional directors:i-Messrs. John  

Ferguson, E. P. Livermore, E. K. Ogg, J. Geo. Tuson, Geo. S. Curtis, John Rule, J. M'Pherson, H. Macdermott, Wm. Robertson, H. W. Risien, W. Broome. Robert Ross, R.S.G. Macdonald, T. B. Robinson, Wm. Pattison, and James Atherton. A sub-com- mittee consisting of thc following gentlemen was appointed to draw up the prospectus and report to the provisional directors at an early date. Messrs. Livermore, Ogg, Tuson, Curtis, and Robertson. Mr. H. W. Risien was appointed secretary pro tem, Messrs. Aplin, Brown and Co., and Messrs. Brown and Risien were appointed brokers ; Mssrs. Lyons and Brumm solicitors to the company. From the interest that has been manifested in   the scheme, we have every reason to believe

the necessary capital will he quickly sub-

scribed.

'-THÍ^ustounccJleotions at this port, Itafe

the.l2th to the 17th instant, amoanterl t»< £3379 18s. «1. ;

THE Secretary of the Grammar Sohool Trost, informs us that Mr. William Mil wraith has been elected a member of the Board in room of Mr. T. T. Faunce, resigned. There was no

opposition.

* T/IK; Jthr: ;Mr. Maddern, our Wesleyan Minister, whose removal to Wallsend in thc Newcastle district, Kew South Wales, we recently notified has been finally appointed to that circuit. We understand the rev. gentle- man's successor, will be the rev. Mr. Williams from Ipswich.

THE Wide Bay A cm» bas been informed that sheep for fattening purposes are again being introduced in considerable numbers to the Burnett district. Mr. Thomas Evans lately arrived with G00O store wethers from New England at Ideraway, and Messrs. Davenport and Hooper, of Beeabah, have about 7000 Western sheep on their property at Beeabah. There are not less than 20,000 wethers now being fattened for butchering purposes in that

district.

AN advertisement elsewhere calls the friends

of Major Feez this evening for the'purpose of deciding upon some suitable recognition of the gentleman's serviros during his lengthened residence in this town. Mr. Feez is about to visit Ku ropo, and doubtless his countrymen, and most other townspeople, will join to dd

him honour before he leaves. Those who have alike had the gratification of experiencing the Major's social qualities, and have listened to his stories of the held of carnage will, with those who have experienced his kindly charity, wi.sh him a pleasant trip and a safe return,

"AMONGST the notable successes of tho Autumn (says the London correspondent of the Courier), I may mention " The Story of the Year," published by Cassotis. Almost any work issued by this marvellously enter- prising and wealthy firm, with its large staff of editors and contributors, is commercially safe, but it is seldom that a book like that referred to runB into a second edition within a month. It has been ' splendidly reviewed. The publication will be annual, And will to a great extent occupy' the place Of the more extensive "Annual Register," which is still published. The "Story of the Year" is written by many hands, the opening section, the chapters relating to the political and domestic affairs of Great Britain and Ireland being written by Mr. Ü. F. T. Jones' pre- decessor on the Queensland Hansard staff."

BEFORE the Police Magistrate on Saturday, John Deigau, on remand, was charged with embezzling moneys the property of the Singer Sewing Machine. Mr. Jones appeared for the prosecution and Mr. F. Milford for the accused. The following additional evidenoe was adduced. Florence Miller deposed she was saleswoman for Singer's Company ; prisoner sold sewing machines and took charge of the cash ; a machine came from Brisbaneios Alfred Bullussand was taken tonis bouBe ; Rulluss oame to the shop on the 27th December, and gave her a cheque for £3 which she put in a desk in the shop ; prisoner took it out to get it cashed and remarked, " I sm going to get it cashed ;" the receipt pro- duced was in prisoner's handwriting ; whoo she got the cheque prisoner was not present i she told prisoner BUIIUBB had paid £3 and would pay the remainder at the beginning of the year; as Bulluss only paid part of the tnoney she asked prisoner if she Bhould enter lt, and he told ber not to do so till Bulluss paid in full. In reply to Mr. Milford witness said money ought to bo entered as it came Into tho shop ; Bhe saw prisoner take the cheque out. James Carley, re-called, deposed that prisoner's duties were to receive all moneys and enter, them in the books, remit weekly reports to the Brisbane office of all transactions, pay all debts incurred and remit balances aB often as requirod, koop

duplicate weekly reports ; ho produced six re- ports ia prisoner's handwriting ; there may be one or two in some one else's handwriting. There was no entry of £6 10s. in the account as having been paid to prisoner by Mr. Lowry, nor of £3 paid by Mr. Bulluss. The money has never ' been accounted for.-In reply to Mr. Milford, witness said he examined the books on 31st January i he did not toll defendant he would allow him time to pay

by instalments, os he had allowed Noble.

Prisoner never denied receiving tho money ; he owned to doing so when taxed. Prisoner said something about not paying Bulluss' money, as it waa a cash transaction. Prisoner had a fortnight to find the money. He knew Mr. Fernie, but could not say if he agreed to accept security for payment of tho deficiency. Tho receipt was sent to witness by Bulluss. By the Benah: Prisoner was to pay all accounts, and remit the balance to Brisbane.

The amounts of £0 10s. and £3 were not so remitted.-Alfred Bulluss deposed to the pay mont of a cheque for £3 to Miss Miller, in the absence of prisoner.-At thia stage prisoner was remanded till this morning. Bail was allowed and forthcoming-prisoner in the sum. of £80, and two sureties of £40 each.

THE Brisbane Courier has been writing strongly on thc Early OloBing Movement, and concludes a leader ns follows :-By the co- operation of all classes-employers, assistants, and buyere-those engaged in our shops will soon be in a position to UBe the agencies now being established f>ir thoir advances in learning and for their training in intellectual and social life. An endeavour to provide these agencies must accompany every BhOrt hours movement. If an employer knows that bis men have no means of rational amusement or of mental improvement at. band, be will be chary, and rightly so. of flinging those who serve him into the way of temptation. If the public-bouse, the gambling saloon, or the streets be the main places for resort, then the best thing he can do is to keep his assistants or workmen hard at toil and savo them from injurious influences outside. But happily this is not thc oase in Brisbane. The School of Arts, with its classes of an evening, its library and reading room, ought to bo specially patronised by those who have escaped the bondage of long hours, and the promoters of the Karly Closing movement arc themselves seeking to provide suitable forms of evening amusement. The Young Men's Christian Association affords a capital opportunity for social union as well as fur useful work. This association, too, if it continues to grow as it has, might yet bo able, before the winter comes on, to arrange a judicious programme of lectures, concerts, and readings for thc long evenings. A beginning, too, might bc made by the men of influence in our city for the establishment of a free public library. In this, and in other similar ways, thc objection that short hours for certain classes mcau only an easy road tn evil habits and profligacy will be met, and mcu who now staud aloof from the early closing movemeut, seeing it allied with opportunities for moral «nd mental elevation, will heartily yield their sympathy and give eubstautiul help. Believing Ibat these two kindred efforts are both accessary for tho success of each, wo, with many others, re- joice at tho inception and growth, and wish them complete success,

ATTENTION is directed to the sale by Mr. G. S. Curtis of the cargo of timber ex Fawn, whioh will tako placo at eleven this morning.

SALVAGE or INFLAMMABLE LiQrins. When a fire breaks out in a Btore of inflam- mable materials there is usually very great loss. With a view to lesseniug this, an Italian professor bas devised an arrangement which he has shown in model at the regional Exhibition of Biela. The barrels of inflam-

mable liquids are placed on a bed of pebbles or sand. The floor is pierced with holes, which open into reservoirs communicating torough tubes with the outer air. The liquide from the burst barrels flow among the pebbles and are extinguished, the necessary air failing. Then they flow into the waar

voira, whence they ara recovered afterwards. ;

In the experimenta made *t Kala, it wu i shown that the reservoir» contained 95 per cent of the liquid need. The thing ia to 'fae tried on a larger «cale.

ALOEBIAN EXTKNSIOK.-The French Gov- ernment is (says the Home News) making Tery determined efforts to extend the limits of their Algerian colony, and have already annexed a wide territory adjoining it inhabited by Berber Arabs, The idea is to colonise North Africa, including the possessions along the Mediterranean littoral, as rapidly as

possible. This France essaya to do artificially ' and by State intervention, A sum of two [ millions sterling is to be Bet aside annually ; to encourage emigration. The money is to be ' spent, partly in providing passages for men who have finished their military service, and

partly in developing an elaborate seheme for ; making grantB of land. Several hundreds of villages and holdings are to be called into existence in the new districts, which will be allotted to immigrants on arrival, on easy terms. The paternal Government goes farther and promises to foster and look after the new colonists until they are able to run alone. The new villages will be located close to each other, so as to be of mutual assistance and support, thus ensuring the predominance of the Frenoh element. It may be doubtful whether even this liberal expenditure will materially develop the colony. Publio money is easily squandered and misapplied in such undertakings. But the chief difficulty with France ia to find, colonists of the proper, stamp. There is no redundant horne popula- tion; indeed numbers in France show a tendency , to deorease, rather than increase,. Another drawback is the strong love which

animates all Frenchmen for La Belle France.

Only a few establish themselves permanently in any new country, the whole aim and object of the expatriated being to save enough mopey, to give them An inoome to li ve on at home. .

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE.

THE NURSER T.

TO TUE EDITOR Of THE MORNING BULLETIN.

Sui,-As many people seem to bo commenting unfavourably upon the resolution, carried at the last meeting of the Ladies' Benevolent Society, to close the Nursery, I beg to make a few remarks upon the subject. The general impression seems to bo that the Society took advantage of Mrs. Stuart's departure to undo thc work which eho had laboured so zealously to promote. When I took the Secretaryship I had no knowledge that my term of office was likely to bc so short. It was from thc late Secretary herself that I first learnt that the Nursery could not much longer be carried ou as a separate institution. She had boped and believed that many mothers would bc glad to have a homo for their children during tho day, while thoy themselves

went out to work. Such institutions flourish

in England, and she saw no reaBim why they should not flourish hero. This, however, has not been tho case, The people whom thc Nursery was established to assist did not avail themselves of it, and though at thc com- mencement it seemed to promise success, yet iin spite of all Mrs. Stuart's praiseworthy

efforts, she had at last to acknowledge that it had failed to answer thc purpose for which it

was oriuinallv intended.

In my report («hick by some mistake, I presume, did not get published aa usual), I explained that, out of tile daily average of six cbildrcu who ute the Nursery, by far thc majority are per- manent boarders, lt ie only at intervals that we happen to got a child in for the day. Kow, as each of these resident children was costing Hie Society four times thc aiiuiuut actually paid by the parents, yon will at once ace the necessity of closing so compara- tively expensive au establishment, and re- moving thc children remaining in nur charge to places designed for snell cni-eu - thc llrnevu linl Asylum and thc Orphanage. From what 1 have said it is plain that no injustice has beeu done to Mrs. Stuart. She herself would

be the Erst to repudiate such an idea ; in fact

she confessed beforo going away that tbe above was the only coarse to be adopted. In addressing this letter to you, my simple object IB to set the public right in a matter where .there appears to be much misunderstanding. I had nothing to do with the closing of the institution, nod therefore speak without pre- judice.

Let me say in conclusion that all honour is due to tho late Secretary for the time and painB she bas expended upon her project, and no one regrets more thau myself that it was not attended with better results.

I aro, ftc.,

ANNIE S. DIGO ENS,

Hon. Sec. Rockhampton Nursery. Tho Rectory, March 14, 1883.

articleText:
THE HOSPITAL SURGEON.

TO TUE EDITOR OP THE MORNING BULLETIN. I

SIR,-My note calling attention to the ahecncc nf Dr. Thurston from the Hospital, on other professional duty than that for which he waa engaged by the Hospital Committee has been discussed by the governors of the institution. I should regret if the matter had been allowed to pass in silence, because, in directing attention to the subject, I bad but one desire, viz., to "nip in the bud," what appeared to mo an action likely to engender ill feeling amongst Dr. Thurston's professional confriret, and through that cause an injury to the institution, because there are times when other assistance than the Resident Surgeon's own services are required. Under such circumstances I need hardly say it is desirable that the local medical gentlemen should be on the best terms towards each other.

The discussion that has taken place will do no harm to anyone, but the next time that Dr. Thurston wants a holiday business need not be associated with pleasure, as in this instance appeared to be the case.

We have had ono big scandal in connec- tion with a medico of our hospital ; another

would not be desirable.

Yours, &c,

SUBSCRIBER.

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE.

RE SUGAR.

TO THE EDITOR OF TUE MOltNINO BULLETIN.

Sri:,-It may interest some of your readers to know that big things are bring accomplished in the North re sugar, where two years since the country was simply Australian bosh.

A friend writes to mo, " We are very busy planting ; we expect to get 700 acres in this year for next years' crushing. We employ 120 South Sea Islanders and thirty white men. Our stables are just completed. There is accommodation for seventy horses, which are cord-fed, and they consume twelve bushels of corn per day. We are about increasing our staff to erect tho mill buildings, for the recep- tion of the machinery to arrive in August. We are determined to try and avoid any ill effects from drought. I have just finished a scheme of irrigation for the plantation, and bave ordered in Melbourne a 20 h.p. engine, and two centrifugal pumps, each capable of lifting 6000 gallons per minute."

These few facts speak volumes. They are worthy of attention, for might not a similar

record be published applying here. I

Yours, sc., I

G. B. SHAW. April 16, 1883.
heading: CORRESPONDENCE. RE SUGAR. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.
