articleText:
KOCKMAMl'TON.

FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1883.

MR. ARCHIUALD FORBES, who has achieved some notoriety as the war

j correspondent of the Daily Nexis,

has honoured the Australian Colonies

I with a visit. His ostensible purpose j in doing so is to deliver a series

oí popular and personal lectures, to i make money, and to gather information

and material the while, it may be for lectures in Other countries. In carrying out such an enterprise, it ts of some importance, in order to draw auditors to his lectures, that the distinguished visitor's name should be kept pro ! minently before the public. The tactics 1 necessary to accomplish this he has , evidently studied, and he acts upon

them, apparently without much regard for the consequences, and without that I deference for the intelligence and judg- ment of others, which a sensible man in a strange country would exercise. This has been shown by the manner in which he has rushed into print wherever he has been in the colonies. He is a clever, skilful writer ; he has " the art of putting things ;" and is not under much restraint in doing so to suit his own purposes. When in Melbourne and Sydney he seized upon the public questions then and there under discussion, and wrote upon them with his accustomed vigour. His communications excited comment, provoked controversy, and attracted atten- tion : they were splendid gratis advertise- ments, in these circumstances we have not been at all surprised to find that as soon as Mr. Forbes got into the run of things in Queensland, he should have favoured us with a characteristic contri- bution to the discussion of the Trans- continental Railway. He found it the question of the hour : materials for an article upon it lay at his hand in the "defamatory pamphlet" and other pro- ductions; and he learned that men's minds were deeply exercised upon it. He had the columns of the Sydney Morning Herald at his disposal, and so he has come out with a long letter on the scheme. The subject and the style alike command notice, and people who may not have known much about Mr. Fotbes before, will seek to know some- thing of him now. His letter is being copied into all the Liberal journals in the colony, and the author's praises sounded as "the distinguished ready writer of universal truth." The value of all this to Mr. Forbes is so evident we need not dwell upon it.

The letter we have referred to deals

with the matter from an apparently impartial standpoint. Mr. Forbes knows it would be comparatively value- less if he thowed bins or prejudice, so these have been carefully concealed ; but it is quite evident that some observa- tions he has made in America have prejudiced him against syndicates. In fact, wegather from hisremarksthathe has

not much faith in large companies and combinations of capitalists. In discus- sing this Transcontinental scheme of ours he summarises the agreement, which has

been entered into between our Governor and the Australian Transcontinental Railway Syndicate ; notices the points which have been urged in favour of the scheme embraced in it ; and then epitomises the arguments used against the proposals. Having done this Mr. Forbes " goes for " the syndicate, whose pinions overshadow the land. He dis- covers three contingencies which may eventuate from its advent, dismisses two of these briefly, and, coming to " the third contingency of the handling of this unclean thing," he lays down his pen, wraps his prophetic cloak around him, and imagines himself a syndicate. That we may tremble at him in this guise he paints with all his skill a fearsome picture of the syndicates, which, he says, lord it over the great noah west of British America, and the south- west of the United States ; and then exhibits himself as the Australian Trans- continental Railway Syndicate, proceed- ing " with calm skill to make Brisbane my washpot, and to cast my shoe over Queensland." The manner in which Mr. Forbes describes his operations is singularly forcible and graphic, and may strike terror into the souls of timorous people. The picture he has so skillfully drawn has no terrors for us, because we recognise it as an improved portrait of the "bogey," with which our Liberal orators and squatters have been trying to frighten the community for the last twelve months. It is the same old scare- crow which Mr. Lumley Hill ex- hibited in the Courier the other day. If Mr. Forbes thinks the grim phantom with which he has confronted the colonists of Queensland, will turn them all into stone, he is very much mistaken. Mr. Forbes alludes in one part of his letter to " those who may be responsible for an able but venomous pamphlet" on this subject of the Transcontinental Railway, and says they have not helped the force of their reasoning by the impu- tation of discreditable motives to the official foster-fathers of the enterprise. Nevertheless, in acting as a syndicate in personating the persons who have entered into an agreement with our

r;",.o-n.n-i, it., ruioca represents

them as actuated by the motives and morality of such men as Jay Gould, and the Vanderbilts. "Hom soi gui mal-y-pense? The syndicate which desired to construct the Warrego Railway was composed of gentlemen belonging to, weil known, and respected in these colonies. The Australian Trans- continental Syndicate is composed of about sixty gentlemen, many of them already the possessors of property in the colony, and largely interested in our material prosperity. To compare them to tile "ring-makers" of the United States is manifestly unfair. We are not prepared, moreover, to accept Mr. Forbes dictum-that a syndicate has no con- science. The name syndicate is but another one for a company, and we know how much companies have done for the promotion of the mechanical and industrial arts in all civilised countries. Notwithstanding Mr. Forbes' fine phrases, about the power of the American syndicates, we have yet to learn that the material comfort, well- being, and independence of the people have been hampered by them. Peace- ful prosperity and freedom prevail to as great an extent in América as in any other country ; and the railways, which have opened up new territories and pro- vided homes for thousands of immi- grants, were made by syndicates. Without them America would not have been to-day su thickly settled and so pros- perous. Such a syndicate as Mr. Forbes' can imagine himself to be might act in the incoascionable, greedy, avaricious manner he describes; but we trust there are men capable of conceiving and dealing with their fellows in a more honourable, praiseworthy, and bénéficient fashion ; and we have no reason to doubt that there is a large majority of such in the Australian Transcontinental Railway Syndicate.

AT the Police Court yesterday before tho Police Magistrate, Thomas lieos, charged with drunkenness, was cautioned and discharged. He was also charged with indecent exposure, .pd sentenced to eight hours' imprisonment.

/TUE new wharf at Auckland Point (says the Qladxtom Obmrva ) now in course of erection, is making fair progress. Fifteen piles arc in their place, and there is every reason to believe the work will bo completed

within contract time.

A TELEGRAM has been recoived from Mr. Macdonald-Patorson, senior member for Itock hampton, stating that he will Ioavc Brisbane by the Ranelagh on Saturday morning for this town. Arrangements have been mado for his addressing the constituency in tho hall of the School of Arts on Wednesday evening.

TUE Theatre will again be opened to-night, when Messrs, Kellar and Cunard will appear io their wounderful Illusianisticentertaicmeot. They have a well-known reputation both in Europe and the colonies. In addition to conjuring the automata are said to be wonder- fully clever, and the whole performance is of a select end entertaining character.

WE learn on good authority that tho now steam tender for the mail service between Rockhampton and Keppel Bay hos not yet left Sydney. The A.S.N. Company, since purchasing the steamer, arc making such alterations as will cusure every convenience. Aa these will necessarily take a little time to perfect, the vessel is not likely to leave till

about next «eek.

A coKREsrosDF.NT of thc Aramac Mail

writes from the M'Kinlay Uiver that on the 28th April 806 primo fats left Beaudesert (Messrs. W. 1). White and Sons) for Mel- bourne, in charge of Mr. Jas. Hickson. They aro travelling down the Hamilton in two mobs, and will go via Wiudornh and 'J'horgomindah. On the Otb. May, IS!) fats left Strathfield (Messrs. Nesbitt and Bell) for Sydney, in charco cit Mr. liobcrt Milner. Tiley travel via Winton and Tambo. Messrs. Collins and Fraser, of Mount Merlin, arc »ow sending 14,000 cues to their "Eulolo" country ou thc Gilliatt, n tributary nf thc M'Kinlny. Anothcr correspondent writes us that 12.OO0UWC8 bavo arrived on Strathdarr fruin New .South Wales. Ho is greatly pleased with their quality. Ile says lhere have been fino rninB in that part of the district, Beven inob.es having fallen at

I Strathdarr. j

THE consolidated corps of Volunteer* met far drill in the Drill Shed last night. There vere about thirty members of both companies present, who were pot through their facings by Staff.sergcaut Pike. After au lioHr's exercise tho mon indulged in a pre- liminary bayonet drill. In this, their (¡rat attompt, they acquitted themselves favour- ably for a "first show." We were glad to notice the commanding offioer. Captain Mel- bourne, and other commissioned officers in attendance. Their presence on such occasions stimulates the men to further exertions, with a view of attaining the proficiency every citizen soldier should possess, Several of the non-commissioned officers of K Company were conspicuous by their absence. This is not likely to induce an apr it de corp».

The forty-ninth annnÀ report of the Bank of Australasia, issued on the 29th March, is of a most gratifying character. It ebows that thc not profit for the year, after providing for all bad and doubtful debts, and for a bonus of 10 per cent upon the salaries of all officers in the London and Colonial service,

amounted to £217,726 Cs. 10d. The directors 1 have also applied £32,464 9s. 7d. as provision for rebate on the bills held at the balance dato, thus bringing the accounts of the Bank iu that respect into harmony with the best modern practice. Through the extension of business, further expenditure on beak pre- mises has been, aud will continue to be, neces- sary, and tlie directors have, therefore, by tho transfer of £15,000, made more than usual provision on that account, After making these deductions, tbe amount available for dividend stands at £90,666 8s. 3d., of which the dividend and boulia will absorb £33,000. The dividend declared is at the rato of 12J per cent per anuuin, or £2 10s. per share for tbe half-year, which, with a bouus of 12s. per share, will bo payable, free of iucome tax, in

Loudon on the 30th March, and in the colo- j otes on such date as tbe Superintendent may

arrunge. '

TUE usual monthly meeting of tbe Hospital Committee will bo held in the Court House at four o'clock this afternoon.

TUE quarterly meeting of tho Central Queensland Rowing Club will be held in the Kockhampton Hotel st half-past seven this evening.

ROCKIIAMI» ION.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, IS83.

FROM all parts oí the colony resounds the clang of impending strife Political parties, after having been engaged m artillery practice at long range, arc now massing their forces for the coming struggle It will be seen from the report of the proceedings in Parliament last night, that those who anticipated a dissolution will not be disappointed The Premier has advised the Adminis trator of the Government to dissolve Parliament, and the latter has deter mined to follow such a course

With the impending conflict thus drawing nigh it becomes the electors of the Central District to bethink them of their own duties, and to consider the claims of those who ire likely to solicit their suffrages Some time ago we directed attention to the position of our Senior Member His connection with the community is now a thing of the past Mr Macdonald Paterson no longer resides among us His home and business are in Brisbane There all his interests are centred He cannot

help taking a lively concern in metro pohtan affairs, especially as he is allied with the Queen street party in Parlia ment That the lion Member would do anything to injure the interests of Rockhampton we will not assert We have too much confidence in his loyalty to his constituents But being resident in Brisbane, being in daily converse with those who regard ils inleresîs as of pic eminent importance, he cannot resist being influenced in Us favour Imperceptibly to himself the lion gentle min miy be led to neglect our interests in favour of those of the metropolis When they clash as the\ have sometimes done, he finds himself in a difficult position On one important matter that occurs to usât present, he give Brisbane

the benefit of his \ote we refer to the Torres Slrails mill service That ttis

clearly to the advantige of Rock hampton, even though the steamers were not so swift is could be desired )et our readers are awire how steadily Mr Paterson opposed the service In the past our Senior Member has estab

lished no great claim on the con , sideralion of the electors As he

promised he has acted consistently with the Opposition , but he has never shown himself so fully alive to the interests of

his constituents, as they had a right to expect from a representative of the first town in the colony

Our Junior Member has been most assiduous and attentive to his duties Not only has Mr Ferguson been present always at the opening of Parha ment, and remained till the close of the Session, but he has been regular in his attendance at debates and divisions In his services moreover, we have found the advantage it is to the community to have a resident representative, whose interests are thoroughly identified with those of the electors Owing to Mr Ferguson s intimate knowledge of local affairs and the influence he has gained in Brisbane the Municipality has been largely benefitted In fulfilling the promises made, to the electors the lion gentle man has been faithful and fair, and will be able to meet his constituents without any qualms of conscience At the same

time we must not overlook the fact that

he has taken up a peculiar position, and

it will he for the electors to consider

whether it may not destroy his usefulness |

in future When lie came forward i

soliciting the suffrages of the electors he declared himself, if not an advocate, at least not opposed to the construction of minais on the land grant principle He voted in support of it on the Warrego Rail« ay Bill Since then he has changed his views upon the land

I question, and has declared that he is

opposed to the total alienation of the public estate Giving expression to this principle he voted against the second reading of the Transcontinental Railway Bill. On this subject Mr. Ferguson's opinions have changed. He frankly told his constituents so, and as it did, not necessitate any change m his political action in Parliament they offered no objection. In the forthcoming election, however, it will be for them to consider whether the position he has assumed is one of which they can approve Mr Ferguson was not in the House when the principle of land grant railway construction was embodied in the Railway Companies Preliminary Bill, and cannot be held guilty of inviting offers from contractors, and then refusing to entertain the only one presented But, apart altogether lrom the considera- tion of railwajs, giving effect to his views

on the land question, will a* once put an end to the selection of land on con

ditional purchase, and the acquisition of it in fee simple on any terms If Mr Ferguson means to apply the principle, on Hhich he has taken his slind in con nection with the Transcontinental Rail

way, to politics in future there must be a revolution on the land question, or he will form a party by himself The latter is the most probable event, and whether it would conduce to our Junior Mem ber's influence is for the electors to con sid er

That our present representatives shall be returned without opposition seems extremely improbable Many months have elapsed since «e were told that a gentleman, with whom no fault could be found, politically or otherwise, would do the electors the honour of coming for ward to receive their support, when the proper lime came It seems to us the time has come Now is the hour, but where is the man ? As yet no names have been mentioned as probable candi dates for election, and we must wait with patience the course of events to bring

about a revelation

Except that a more than usually large number of electors ha» e put m applica tions with the district registrars, to hive their names put upon the electoral lists, there are few signs of political excitment in our country constituencies In onl) one electorate have we heard a whisper of opposition to the sitting member When Major Feez left for Eiuope several weeks ago, a most ungracious attack was made upon him, with the view of clearing the way for a proposed successor 1 he latter has since been announced m the same quarter, and Mr C B Dutton is the coming man Upon this gentleman's claims to the support of the electors we may comment when he has enunciated his views on current political questions He is a large landowner, and resident in the district, and on this account will be entitled to a respectful hearing The electors, however, will not overlook the fact that in Mr John Scott and Mr Albrecht Feez they have had two worthy members They have both established claims to the consideration of the elec tors, that, should these gentlemen seek re election, must not be treated with in

difference. The hon. Mr. Archer is threatened with opposition in the Black- all electorate, but it will require a. candi- date of greater calibre than the gentleman whose name we have heard mentioned, to supplant the present representative in the estimation of the majority of the

constituents. In the electorates of Cler- mont, Normanby, and Pott Curtis the present members stand well with their constituents, and whoever has the temerity to oppose them must be pre- pared to fight a stiff battle.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, 1883.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 18, »883.

AMONG the important questions in- volved in the discussion of the Trans- continental Railway Scheme under present circumstances, is that of the management of railways by thc State. Some politicians, and, if we mistake, not among that number is the Premier, are of opinion that the iron highways of trade and commerce are made most sub- servient to these interests, when they are in the hands of private companies. In proof of this they point to the. success which has attended the railway systems in the United Kingdom and in America, and the prosperity they have created and fostered in these countries. Others trace ihe monopolies and disabilities, from which the public in both these countries have suffered under the railway systems, to the fact that the lines have been in private hands. The general complaint, which is held to explain a multitude of minor grievances, is that the railways are worked for the benefit of the share- holders, and often to the detriment of the public interests. When the railways are in the hands of the Government they are worked for the public benefit. In the Australian Colonies the practice has been for the State to make and maintain the railways. That thc system has been attended with unquali- fied success we arc not prepared to demonstrate ; but, we do submit, nothing has occurred which should induce any of t,he Colonies lightly to relinquish control of their railways. Into the general question of the management of railways by the State, we do not propose

to enter at present, but would direct our readers' attention to the latest plan proposed for doing so. We have heard it advanced as an argument against the management of railways by

the State, that as soon as the Victorian Government acquired the private lines in that colony, mismanagement began and accidents happened. But we have repeated and painful evidence from the United Kingdom that bungling and blundering are too frequent on the lines there. Whatever faults lhere may have been in connection with railway manage- ment in Victoria, the Government seem to have determined to remedy them by the adoption of a new system of working. A Ministerial measure, about to be submitted to Parlia- ment, embodies the newest ideas, and most carefully considered resolutions on the subject. It embodies principals and possesses features characteristic bf the railway system of the United Kingdon. There the President of the Board ol Trade is responsible to Parliament foi the protection of the life and property ol the people, who ate under the necessity of using railways, from the carelessness of servants and the avarice of boards ol Directors. Under the new Act ir Victoria the intermediary between the railway managers and the Parliament is to be a Minister of the Crown. Im mediately beneath him, owing to theil appointments to the Governor in I Council, and holding office during theil i good behaviour are to be the members I of a corporate body to be callee

" the Victorian Railway Commissioners." While the Government are to provide funds for the construction, maintenance, and management of the railways ail the details connected with the formation and working are to be entrusted to the Com- missioners. In them all railway works are to vested. They are to appoint and be responsible for the conduct of thc subordinate officials, but must choose persons for appointment from a list ol those who have passed a prescribed examination, unless in very exceptional circumstances. They are also to have large powers to make byelaws and regu- lations. This scheme, it will be seen, has been drawn on principles similar to that which obtains in Queensland, with this essential difference, that lhere are tc

be three Commissioners. The body of Commissioners will occupy the same relation to the public and Parliament that the Boards of Railway Directors in the United Kingdom occupy to thc communities, which are served by their lines, and to the shareholders. There are few, if any, of these Boards composed of less than seven members. The number of Commissioners, therefore, which it is proposed to appoint in Victoria is not too large. In fact, the number might, with advantage, be increased. Of course lhere will be this difference between them and railway directors, that while ihe latter devote only a porlion of their time lo railway business, the former would give all their lime to the discharge of their duties. Three Commissioners who visit the new works ; maintain a close superintendence on th» lines opened ; and attend to the details of ir.iffic and mail arrangements will have their lime fully occupied.

Those of our readers who have perused the evidence given in thc recent railway inquiry in lliis colony, will, no doubt bc ready to conclude with us that some such managing board or Commis- sioners should be established in connec- tion with our railways. The time seems to have gone past when the management

of our railways should remain in the hands of one man. Some evidence that the present Government are of the same opinion may be found in the appoint- ment of Mr. Horniblow as superinten- dent of rolling stock on all the lines in the colony. With regard to thc supply of locomotives, carriages, and wagons, he will be responsible to the Commis- sioner, and he again to the Minister for Works. Now this is a perpetuation of a cumbrous system, and lt is quite plain that it would be much better, instead of having our Minister for Works rambling over the colonies with the Commissioner for Railways dancing attendance upon him, that there should be three competent commissioners, capable of managing our railways without troubling the Minister as to petty details. If the railway management were more inde- pendent of political influence than it is at present, the service would be carried on more cheaply, safely, and satisfac- torily, Should our Railway Commission, therefore, report in favour of a per- manent Board ot Management or Com- missioners in this colony, the public will have reason to rejoice at its decision, and should urge that effect be given to it.

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE.

BLACKALL ELECTION.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE MOItDINO BULLETIN.

SIB,-I attended at Stanwell to-day for the purpose of hearing the candidates for the elec- torate of Blackall, and with the intention of saying a few words; but Mr. Macdonald mona, polised so mach timo that I was not able to carry out my intention. I therefore request you to insert this :

I wish to remind my fellow selectors, who comprise the majority of the electors of Black- all, that is to Mr. Archer more than any other man, we owe the Land Act of 18G8. Let me recall the circumstances. In the latter part of 1807. or the beginning of 1868, a number of Rockhampton gentlemen interested in thc wel- fare of thc colony, being of opinion that no- thing could advance the interests of the colony so mnch as settling the people on the lands, requested the late Mr. Ilea (who was one nf thc number) tn make a rough draft of a Bill embodying their views on tho matter. Mr. Ilea did BO, and Mr. Archer, who was an- other ef the number, undertook to bring the Bill before Parliament. Being a new member, and unacquainted with the forms of the Mouse and methods of procedure, he ob taincd the assistance of Mr. Fitzgerald, and they, by good judgment and good argument, succeeded in getting thc Bili passed, not exactly in BO liberal n shape as they wished, but in the form of the Crown Lands Aliena- tion Act of 1868. Now, I claim for this Act that it was thc first which enabled a settler ia any part of Australia to obtain land for less than ono pound per acre ; and that it had the effect during thc time it waa in operation of settling a greater portion of thc population of the colony on thc lands of the colony, than any other Act in any of the Australian Colonies. Had thc Act been less liberal it would not have been so successful. We should not have done so well, and Rock- hampton would not bo so prosperous. Had it been less liberal the people would not so freely have selected, the pastoral lessees would have beld their runs for many years longer, possibly even to the present day, and those

who remember the difficulty Mr, Archer bsd j

to pas* the measure, roust know that, had he not exerted himself to the ntmost, the Act could not have been passed. The Act has been altered, I cannot say amended, and the alterations have had the effect of somewhat re- tarding settlement, for we find that most of the selections made under the Act of 1S76 were made by men who were already settled I upon lauds held under the Act of 1868.

It has been said that in passing that Act Mr. Archer wished to benefit himself, that bc wished to select, and that he did select. It is true that he did select, having os much right as any of us, hut he did not dummy ; and had he studied his own interest as much as he studied ours he would now be richer, and we should not be so well off. As

! regards Mr. Macdonald, I will say nothing

against his intelligence, for we oil know bow wisely he has ever managed hie own affairs ; nor shall I say anything against his integrity, for I believe that he is a man of his word (here let me express my astonishment and regret that he should to-day have expressed a doubt of Mr. Archer's word) ; but, Sir, I fear Mr. Macdonald is too intelligent to neglect his own business for the purpose of attending to that of other people ; that he is too wise or too sellish to waste his own time over publio matters ; and be has shewn this by bis atten- dance at thc Divisional Board, and by his entry into aud retiremeut from the Legislative Assembly. lu fact, Sir, he has ever shewn by bis actions that he considers his first and only duty is his duty to himself. Nor can I very much blame bim for seeing bow ungrateful the public are to their best servants. I am

inclined the same way, but contrast this con- j duct with that of Mr. Archer, who has

repeatedly and always shewn by his actions j that he considers bis public duties should toke precedence of hie private affaira.

HENRY BEAK.

Rockhampton, August IO, 1883.

articleText:
KOCK HAMPTON.

WEDNESDAY. AUGUST 15, 1883

HAVING discussed the speeches of the gentlemen who have been our represen- tatives in Parliament, it is incumbent upon us to notice those of the gentle- men who aie aspiring to the dignity of wearing Parliamentary honours Mr. Rees Jones made his bon to the public on Friday evening, and avowed himself a supporter of the present Mimstiy, but consideration of his speech must create the idea that he will be rather a weak knee ed Ministerialist He was careful at the outset of his speech to declare him- self opposed to the construction of rail- ways on the land grant principle, and to slate that he mil assent to the repeil of the Railway Companies Preliminary Act At the decided position thus taken up bv the candidate, we must ex- press our surprise, for it seems ij us ii Mr Join s had considered the possiuili

ties for yood enshrined in that Act in-

stead of directing his attention to those | inimical to the colony, he would have

entertained more liberal ideas m regard I to it We hold that it is quite within the powers of Government, acting

under that statute, to secure the con

struction of railways in such a way that the formation of Ur¿e estiles ma) be

avoided, that the influence of foreign j capitali5is shall not prove injurious to our ' colonial interests , that the country rmy be settled, and that the develop ment of us maten il resources may be greatly and beneficially promoted Mr Jones seems to have a horror of forcyn capitalists, lint the men who offered lo make the Warreno Railway upon the land grant principle were not

foreigners The most prominent name i

among them was that of Mr A Shan, Brisbane, and the other members of the svndicate were resident in or closely connected with the colonies We cannot help remarking, nevertheless, that we entertain less apprehension of the intro duction of foreign capital than that from Sydney and Melbourne Money can be obtained much cheaper in England than in the colonies It is the financiers born and bred to the American ways of business, which have created the dan gerous monopolies and rings in the United States On the coloured labour

question Mr Jones' views are equally decided, and hostile to the Ministerial policy At present the latter is being somewhat misrepresented The electors are led to believe the party m power are anxious to introduce Coolies But they have no feeling in the matter There is not a member of the Ministry a sugar planter All they want is to encourage the rising industry by giving those, whose capital is embarked in it, the kind of labour they maintain is most necessary for it They are not forcing the coloured labour question on the country, but they are doing what they deem necessary, in the interests of a rising industry of the utmost importance to the whole of Queensland Mr Jones is a strong advocate of the continuance of our main lines westward " to the

glorious countrv, which only requires

means of communication in order to put a population on it, and maintain it in plenty and affluence ,*' but looking to the political combinations with which we are threatened, and the

influx of Victorian capital and influence, the chances are that these lines may be taken advantage of to lay hold of this fine country, and form large freehold squattages Acute observers of the I signs of the times cannot help observing

[ the run of currents in that direction

Mr Jones complaint, about the dredge Saurian not arriving a year sooner, is one that is general in the town, but, as Mr Archer explains, the Government could not do impossibilities, they could not take the work out of the contractors' hands, and the latter declared they could not gel sufficient skilled labour to complete the vessel in the time stipulated To fine them for tue delay in such circum stances would have been a peculiar way of encouraging native industries On the emigration question Mr Jones seems inclined to favour the policy of the Opposition, and bring people into the colonv at a greater rate than they are coming at present The probable results of a large influx of labour, at the rate of forty thousand a year, as Mr Griffith proposes, must be considered If we stop branch lines of railway, cut donn expenditure on other public works, and limit our borrowing arrangements, the people will be forced to make work for themselves, or join the gangs in the canefields One thing seems pretty certain, if fifteen or twenty thousand people are landed at this port within the next twelve months, that labour will be more plentiful, and, therefore, cheaper On the other subjects touched upon in his soecch we do not feel called upon to remark

! In turning to discuss the speech de

livered by Mr Higson, in the School of Arts, on Monday evening, we cannot get rid of the feeling that it was not original The impression made on our mind in listening to it was that the facts

[ and their arrangement were not his

own Not for a moment, however, would we have it supposed that ne think Mr Higson did not know, and did not believe, what he was saying Credit must be given him for being thoroughly in earnest But I all his energy, and determination, and willingness to serve the community will not remove the opinion that to a large extent he is an instrument being played upon by some unseen hands He tells us himself he is unlettered uneducated m the general acceptation of the term , and that he is not a politician, but upon perusal of his speech, it is plain that it is not the production of an illiterate man, or a novice in politics The stock arguments against the Ministry are arrayed in fair order, are couched in pointed language, and, thanks to Mr Higson s retentive memory, were expressed with a nervous vigour and action that Mr Jones might emulate with advantage lo himself Now the conviction must be forced on the mind of every elector that, if Mr Higson can allow himself to be subjected to extraneous influences here in Rock hampton, where he is well known, when he goes donn to Bnsbme he will become a tool in the hands of others We do not for a moment mean to assert that he would not do his best to promote the interests of ihe town , but he would lose his individuality, he could not cini mand influence, or attention in the House, and would become a member of the party which has never done justice to this town and district Space will not permit us to comment on his speech in detatl, but in all the circum stances we think it must be plain, that he must possess more of the qualifies tions he now admits he lacks, before he can establish a good claim to the dignity of representing a large and intelligent constituency in Parliament

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1883.

WE think it not improbable a large num- ber of our readers woald share the feeling of astonishment with which we read the communication addressed to the Municipal Council by Mr. Edwin J. Smith, Chairman of the Board of Direc- tors of the Rockhampton and Northside Tramway Company, Limited. More than a year has elapsed since Mr. William Allen introduced the subject of tramways to the notice of the Council. At that time his proposals were deemed premature, and no more was heard of the subject. Now the community learn with surprise that a tramway company has been formed ; that plans, sections, details, estimates of costs have all been prepared ; and that unless they object a monopoly will be created in our midst, of which it is impossible to forecast the results or calculate the influence it may have on the social and commercial wel- fare of our citizens. From the memo- randum of agreement, &c., deposited at the office of the Town Clerk, we learn that "The object for which the company is established is the construction of a tramway for the conveyance of passen- gers and freight between the town of Rockhampton and the north side of the Fitzroy River, commonly known as North Rockhampton, the running of passenger carriages and freight trucks on the said tramway, the purchase and sale of real estate in connection with the above objects, and the erection of houses, offices, stables, dams, tanks, reservoirs, or other works, which may be neces- sary for carrying on the business of the company." The company has been formed under limited liability ; the capital is £5000 in one thousand shares of £5 each. Mr. Smith certifies that 956 shares have been applied for, and five shillings paid on each. The share- holders and their interest in the company

are as follow :—

Edwin J. Smith, architect. Rockhampton, 950 shares. John Ferguson, contractor, do. 1 " Frederick Kilner, Sub-Col. Customs, do. 1 " George Barnsley Shaw, auctioneer, do. 1 "   William Joseph Connolly, gentleman, do. 1 " Thomas Harrison Davis, clerk, do. 1 "   Albert Card, conveyancer, do. 1 "

Ample details are set forth as to the constitution, proceedings, and manage- ment of the affairs of the Company. In the specification for the line of tram- way the description of rails, kind of timber, manner of formation are all care- fully set forth. The tramway is to commence at a point in the centre of Denison-street distant 580 feet easterly from the intersection of Denison and Stanley Streets opposite the station of the Central Railway, and is to extend to a point in the Yaamba Road at North Rockhampton distant fifty feet south of

the intersection of the centre line of the   Yaamba Road and Elphinston Road, said point being in the immediate   vicinity of thc north east corner of   portion 70, parish of Archer, county of  

Livingstone known as Beda estate, and is to follow the route indicated on drawing No. 1 occompanying this speci- fication, and entitled " Plan of proposed tramway between Rockhampton and North side of Fitzroy River." On ex-     amining the plan we find the tramway is to start near the Central Railway Station, and run along Denison Street to William Street ; along it to East Street ; along it to Fitzroy Street ; along it and Fitzroy Bridge to North Rockhampton, and along the Lake's Creek road to where it   is joined by the Yaamba Road ; along it  

the tramway runs to Elphinstone Street -—a new thoroughfare to be formed some day at right angles to the Yaamba Road. The cost of construction is estimated at £1500 per mile, and the formation of the tramway &c. at £4250 made up as follows : Construction of road £3350 ; two carriages £400 ; buildings £200 ; horses £150 ; harness and utensils £150.

Some people may be disposed to laugh at the whole affair as a joke, look upon it as " tramway in the air ; " and treat it with contemptuous ridicule. There can be no doubt that one at least of the shareholders of this nice little company is in dead earnest, and that he will leave no stone unturned lo realise his scheme. It will not do for the Town Council to trifle with it. Under the Companies' Act, 1863, any number of persons not less than seven may form a company, and such a company the Tramways Act provides may be the "constructing authority " under it. This authority is bound to submit copy of plans, &c., to the Minister charged with the Administration of the Act, to the Council, and to the Gogango Divisional Board. This has been done, and it is most likely an application has been made to the Minister for an Order in Council to construct this tramway. Unless the Council petition against the

scheme an order will be issued, and powers may be vested in the company giving them control of tramway con- struction and communication in all time coming. It will be the duty of our aldermen to consider the memorandum, plans, documents, &c., which have been laid on the Council table, and determine what shall be done in this matter. If they look to the public interests, we apprehend they will feel it to be their duty to petition that the Order in Council sought by the tramway com- pany be not granted. It is apparent that the concession is not sought in the interests of a public company such as is contemplated by " The Companies Act of 1863." It stipulates that there must be seven members in a company, but of what weight would the six members in the tramway company be beside the Omnipotent Chairman. A glance at the share list shows that really he is the company, and the others have been let in merely to fill up. So far as we can make out the general public are to be represented outside the Directorate al- ready constituted by four five pound shares. As the relations of tramway companies and Councils under the Tramways Act are numerous, varied, and highly important we think the Council will not be acting wisely in recognising the locus standi of this com- pany, even though the Mayor has a five  

pound share in it. The scheme, more- over, is not one that will commend it to the public. It would doubtless, if carried out, greatly enhance the value of pro-  

perty adjacent to the Yaamba Road, in which the Chairman of the Company is interested, but it would not be such a convenient and useful scheme as others

that might be devised. A tramway on the Fitzroy Bridge would be an intolerable nuisance, and a permanent source of danger. Besides, there would not be room for it, unless other vehicular traffic were stopped. For these and other reasons that will occur to our Aldermen, we think the Town Council should unanimously petition against an order in Council being granted to this Rockhampton and North Side Tramway Company.

I waa perfectly cured. Ho should feel himself

wanting in gratitude to Providence did ho fail to bear testimony to its efficiency, and full it his bounden duty to stand forth as its earnest advocate, and lend it the aid of all thc influence ho could command, &c.t ¿c.'' The President of tho Scottish Curative Mcsmciic Association waa Dr. Gregory, Pro- fessor of Chemistry, M.I)., F.li.S.K; Vice president, General Sir Thomas Macdougall, lirtsbaue, correa poudiu g member of the Institute of France, President of thc Royal Society of Kdinburg, L.L.I). of Oxford, &c.

Why th cn i ld I dispute about matters which have long been established-perhaps not out here so much. Rut why should Australia not receive thc dawn of enlightenment ? And so it does, if only slowly, as in any young country. Thc Mesmeric Societies 1 have established.

and my extensivo practico during seven

mouths in ISrishanc, aro proofs of it. i Your correspondent is not aware probably, 1 Mint I made my debut tb etc before before an nsscmbly of thc lei tl i og scientific men and Kntishcd them. Of cou.sc nil people arc not like this. Ignoramus. They investigate and become convinced. This is au age of reason and investigation, and not of pooh-poohing. Of course it is usual for the Ignoramus to hiss at tile advance of science and truth, having thc instinctive fear that he will be obliterated thereby. Wc do not ask people to believe, but to investigate, provided they have sufli cient intelligence to do 60. My mission is to put them in thc practical way of doing so, aud as only usually some of thc leading personages interest themselves it shows there is something in it although your correspondent cannot grasp it. j Jo speaks about Mesmer. I do not think ho knows anything of his lifo. I doubt at all if he has a book in his possession of au authenticated biogrnphy, and as to those who condemned him, this is totally untrue if one only glances at thc Report of the li oyal Commissi ii, which upholds bim. What is thc usc, therefore, of disputing with a man who simply rails. I conquer by facts. Those are my successful pupils, my patients restored to health, and thci'sicem in which I and my science are held in thc South and liiisbanc. 1 came to Rockhampton with an introduc- tion from nu authority far more capable of judging and of more knowledge than thc mysterious correspondent can bc possessed of, whoever lie may be. Let thc Rockhampton people usc their own minds, and judge from merit. 1 have already given two successful private seances, and will give my last one on Thursday evening. Those wishing to he prêtent can apply to me, at tho Leichhardt Ihitel, any time before Thursday at J 2 o'clock, when L will close my list.

I am, Sir, &c,

I'ltOPKSSOR A KM AND. Rockhampton, 30th October, ISS3.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

THUESDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1883.

1 If consequence of the pressure ou our

columns by an accumulation of news our usual leading article ia lett over.

AT the Police Court on Monday before tho Police Magistrate, six individuals were charged with being drunk, and pleading guilty, were all admonished and discharged. I On Wednesday only two were brought before Mr. Cribb on that charge, and were also discharged. Another man pleaded guilty to using obscene language, and was duly cautioned

and dismissed,

OH Monday night a fire happened in an unusual way at the private residenoe of Mr. Saber of this town, who reaides on thc Bange.

It appears that word was sent to Mr. Saber at1

his place of business, that his residence and stables bad been struck by lightning and set on fire. On that gentleman proceeding home he found tho information was correct as regarded the stable, but the garden hoso was sufficient to extinguish the tire before any serious damage was done.

OWING to the lateness of the hour we were unable to inspeot the decorations at the Publio Baths on Saturday evening, in time for our uusual Christmas notes, hut we have since had occasion to admire the pains taken by Mr. Smith to recognise the festive season. Not only in front of bis coffee bar, but in the interior of the bathroom there are a plentiful display of fern leaves formed so as to represent Prince ol Wales' leathers, while in the former plaoe there were some choiae nosegays.

O WINO to the storm on Monday evening, the Rate Douglas Comedy Company did not inaugurate their series of entertainments at the Cremorne Gardens till last Light. They performed before a large and highly delighted audience. A neat convenient stage, with wings, baa been erected at the north end of the dancing room, and it is nicely lighted and furnished. Several light amusing pieces, The Dumb Belle, Irish Justice, and Paddy tn India were put on thc boardB last night, and went very well. The excellent acting of Misses Douglas and Duke, and of Messrs. Griffiths, Balfe, and Percy gave a go to the pieces, which made them thoroughly enjoyable, and kept the audience in excellent humour throughout.

AT the Theatre Royal last night, Mr. George Simms opened his short season with a comedy entitled, "My Wife's out, or the Husband outwitted." The gallery and back eeata down steirs were crowded, but thc front seats were poorly patronised. Wc are unable to-day to notice the play at length or thc ability of the actors, from want of time and space. Judging from a casual glance we thiuk lovers of the drama would be well entertained. A special feature in the programme waB a concert iuterludo, iu which tho various singers showed they were well acquainted «villi the art of rendering a comic song to tho satisfaction of an audience, testified in this instance by numerous encores. Miss (Jims sang "I won't romain a maid," tn which she had to repeat thc final verso. Mr. Simms' sou); of the " Brokcu-heartcd gardener " was well received, anil Miso Sims' other Bongs were met with loud applause. This young lady huB evidently a talent for burlesque acting. A piece entitled "Fayre Rosamond," written expressly for Mr. Simms by j. Courtney, ia which Mrs. Simms takes the part of " Ye Quccnc, Elenore," and Mr. C. Haynes .*Ye Kyuge Henrye of amorous memory," concluded a pleasing entertaintn-mt. To-night the "Laughing Hyena" comedy, and " liatber Suspicious," a burlesque, will lie performed.

CAPTAIN DuNi.or took an unusually large number of passengers for thc mail steamer on TucBday night, in tho smart little Bonito, and it was aurpriaiug li ow roany were accommo- dated in Uer for thc short trip without much inconvenience, tïhe started ns usual punc- tually at eleven, and reached the Bay at 3 a, m. yesterday, and anchored at Sea Hill, where eh« wau shortly afterwards met by the Kmily May, s.s. from Gladstone. The , lil em an c. owing to coutrary winds and tides i w.is, several hours late at the irti'h'zvous, and it j was nearly nine o'clock before she waa sighted j by thc eager passengers, most of whom were

ou holiday trips. The return tiip on thc I Bonito was a treat to those who were indebtod

to Captain Dim I op'a courtesy and hospitality for a pleasant way of passing a holidny, and shows «hat a pity it is there is no excursion steamer to take all lovers or fresh air and change of scenery fur a trip dowu the har- bour ou Holiday occasions. Unfortunately thc air was very hazy along the northern coast in thc morning, consequently ono could only obtain a glimpse vi the spot, where Emu Park, our future Brighton, lies, but ou clear days thc houses are distinctly visible from ¡Sea Hill. On tho suuthcrn side how- ever, the conditions were better, and a fine view of I'nrfc Alma was ohtatucd. IVo ininctit anions the improvements was tbs new wharf, which ia «ow being erected fur the B.I.S.N. Company's steamers. At present these vessels auchor three miles from thc shore, but tho Bonito only sails within five of Tort Alma, A few ventursome yachts wore

to be «eeo at the mouth of the river, while several patient anglers found amusement, if not sport, oh the banka of the stream. Some of the visitors Iud erected gnnyahs for the occasion, but the majority were without any protection from thc beat of the sun, and must have thrown away comfort for the nonce for the sake of practising Isaac Walton's Art.

TUR late holidays have afforded our staff an opportunity of giving point to the phrase " It is a poor heart that never rejoices," It is not often, even at such festive Beasona, that a second thought is given to the " poor Printer," except, perhaps, to anathematise bim for his supposed shortcomings and general "cussedness." However, there are exceptions to this, as to every other, rule, as the following " urgent " message received by one of our staff early on Monday morning last will verify :-*'Brisbane, December 24, 10'5 o.m. [ wish the staff of the Mominj Bulletin to drink my health in champagne. The com plimentsofthcseason to all.-WILLIAM FLYNN, Globe Hotel." Such an evidence of goodwill for the sake of "Auld lang sync "needs no comment. It is only necessary to add that Mr. Flynn's injunction was carried out to the letter, and his health drank with a fervour not often' exceeded, > general desire being ex-

pressed that bis " shadow might never grow

less." .

WE learn from our correspondent at Isisford under date 19lh instant, that the country is in a very bad state in that district. With the exception of Wellshot station, 40 miles from Isisford, on which there is both water and grass, the runs are destitute of either. At Mount Marlow and Avington, thc cattle and sheep on the former, and the cattle on the latter, have been better off, and arc travelling for crass and water to stations. Un the Jundah road deal cattle are passed every twenty yards or so, and the stock in thc sheep paddocks are simply rotting, On the road from Blackall to Pine Hill there are numbers of carriers going out and in, but as thero waa no grass until recently, and some stages of Bixty inilea without water, they hare been stuck, and it is probable that thc recent rain having caused a Bpring of grass, will tempt thom to remain longer spelling their teams. This road was so bad last week that the pas- sengers by Cobb's Coach had to walk about twenty miles of the road. Rations at Isisford are quoted, brown sugar, 10X, tea, 4s. Cd. per lb.; a two-pound loaf can be had for two shillings. Carriage from Pine Hill to Isisford £30 per ton. It appears that the townspeople at the latter place are dependent on one spring at a Chinaman's water hole for water for local consumption, for which they have to pay him 7s. per load, and as he has to take the

cart into the hole and bail it ¡uto the casks it is always thick and muddy. Tho inhabitants have therefore signed and sent down a petition to the Government to procure a pump for thc well. There is also a petition in circulation for signature throughout tho district for Govern- ment tanks to bo erected along the road to thc railway, os has been done on the southern and weBtern roads. The squatters are employing dam-makers and tank-sinkers in every direc- tion on their runs, so that contractors are kept busily employed.

BHO, MINMETTE, Dot Merrinotte ia Deputy Ruler of the Ileckabite Tent, and it has no official connection with thc SaturUay night

free concerts

MR. FRANCIS LAURIE, Compton House, East-street, favours his customers with pretty illustrated calendars entitled Wedding Gifts and Forget-me-nots. The former represents two young ladies examining welcomo presents, and the latter a sweet-heart biasing two hearts carved on the bole of a tree in a sylvan eceno, and with blue forget-me-nots baskettcd at her

feet.

AN alteration of consequence to an impor- tant part of the oversea shipping trade has just been made in the health regulations of Brisbane. Formerly vessels coming by way of Torres Straits, having been admitted to pratique at any of the Northern ports, were not subjected to any fresh examination in Moreton Bay. This is to be changed, and in futuro such vessels will have to obtain pratique at that port before communicating with the

shore.

His Honor Acting District Court Judge Mansfield, in the case of Petty v. Martin, has delievered a judgement of great interest to those who attend auction sales. The plaintiff, Mr. ll. G. Petty attended an auction sale in Bris- bane, where Mr. Gannon, oneof the defendants, read out the conditions of the salo, and put up a nest of three trunks, saying that the buyer would have the option of taking one or twenty nests at the same price, and one of the con- ditions was that tho highest J," jder should bc the purchaser. The pIaintiQust<t?6s. for the first nest, and this was the mgl.^|vbid ; but

the defendant passed them io, andrefused to knock them down to plaintiff. The plaintiff, at the lust sittings of thc Southern District Court, sued for breach of contract in refusing to sell the goods. His Honor, after hearing the ciBe, reserved his decision, which hos since, been given in favour of tho plaintiff for £11 10s., the difference between his bid of 2(is. per nest and the price at which the trunks could have been bought wholesale ; costs on the lower scale.

articleText:
-I

CORRESPONDENCE, j

MUNICIPAL MATTERS.

TO TBS EDITOR OF THE MOBNINO BULLETIN.

Sm,-Your contemporary, in hie issue of Saturday, takes some trouble ia trying to prove the legality of Ur, Wakefield's election, and the other extraordinary proceedings of tho Council. His views will not, I think, bo endorsed by many of the ratepayers, and was probably dictated rather by à spirit of opposition to your expressed views on that subject rather than by his own judgment. He says' Mr. Wakefield abandoned his con- tract, and the Mayor agreed to the abandon- ment. I would ask if the Mayor has power to make contracts without consulting the Council? and if not, how can he have power to absolve a contractor from his engagements ?

ThiB affair of Mr. Wakefield's doss not look like a bona fide giving up of his contract. Who has ho given the contract over tot Why, an employé of his own, who has been working in his shop for years, and is still working there. It looks very much like cases I have known of insolvent debtors, who nut the name,

of some Bi their clerks over the door to evade

the law, but who still pocket the cash receipts. In the case of the Returning Officer a complete muddle was made-the Mayor's name appeared to the advertisements. Mr. Sumner was appointed by the Council, but Mr. Williamson RCted in that capacity at the nomination, but on What authority I know not. The question will be asked-Who was the Returning Officer 7 The gentleman whose name appeared in the paper, the one who was appointed by the Council, or the one who officiated at the Council Chamber. By insert- ing this you will oblige

RATEPAYER. Rockhampton, January 29, 1883.

P.S.-If Mr. Wakefield had given his con- tract over to one of the plumbers unconnected with his establishment, there would have been no room to doubt, but this was not done.

WEDDING OF LADY CEKTIIUDE DODO LAS TO A BAKER.-Within the last few days (says the London correspondent of thc ifantlumter Guardian) several mysterious paragraphs have appeared in different newspapers stating that the sister of a well-known Marquis had lately married a man not only much younger than herself but also greatly below her in tho social scale. Thc facts of the case are simply these, the Rev. Lord Archhald Douglas a brother of the Marquis of QueenBberry and of Lady Florence Dixie, joined the Church of Rome some years ago, and after the usual course of study and probation was ordained a priest by Cardinal Manning. Since then be bas devoted his life and money towards the reclamation of boys, ' waifs and strays ' from the street, to whom ho gives a home, teaches them useful trades, and then starts them in life. At the institution which be has founded and maintains, and where he always resides, situated in Woodfield Terrace, Harrow Road, Paddington, there are some seventy or eighty of these lads, all of whom are being trained to be industrious working men. But the housekeeping, the eating, and drinking is naturally a source of atmety to Lord Archibald, and although greatly assisted by the subscriptions or his co- religionists and others he finds that the good old rule of 'waste not want not 'is not

observed hy those who havo charge of provid- ' ing for the wants of so large an establishment. lu order to put matters upon a more satisfac- tory footing, he invited his sister. Lady Gertrude Doughs, who ÍB also a oonvert to the Catholic Church, to live with him, and Bincc then some matters have been on a much

more satisfactory footing. Some three months ago Lord Archibald went to Canada, taking withhim iorty boys of the Home for the purpose of establishing them as farmers in the Far Weit. During his absence he received a letter

from his sister stating that shs wu about to marry a young man who bad been brought up by ber'brother, and who waa now acting oe head baker of the establishment. His lord-

ship was greatly taken aback by the news, and telegraphed and wrote from Canada' urging his sister at any rate to delay her intended marriage until bia return. But it was of no avail. The happy couple were

married off hand in the Doman Catholic Church at Hammersmith, and have gone to reside in that neighbourhood. Lady Gertrude

has some little means of her own. It is need- less to say that the - Roman Catholic com- munity in London has been not a little agitated by this marriage,. The lady is related to some of the most aristoratio families

in the kingdom, her own dating back several hundred years. Her busband is barely 21 years of age.

articleText:
KOCKIiAMl'TON.

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1883.

As the people of Rockhampton and the surrounding district consider the great influence the successlul promotion of the sugar industry is calculated to have upon the material prosperity of town and country, they will come to the conclusion, that only for the most obvious and substantial reasons should anything be done that will impede its growth. This will lead many of them to declare as Hon. Mr. Archer did, when last he addressed the electors of Blackall-that rather than obstruct the infant industry, they would assist in introducing Coolies. To his mind the case was clear : No Coolies-no sugar. The closer we are brought to the realities of the circum- stances connected with sugar culture, the more strongly must this convic- tion be forced on every mind.

Mr. Macdonald has informed us that to secure the success this season of the cane crop, now making a fair show at Pandora Plantation, about fifty labourers should at once be employed. White men might be employed ; but, like the Scotch piper, who recently spent a few days in the cane-fields, they will give up the work in disgust. We must have cheap and reliable labour. Within the last few days-and even in to-day's impression-we have had incontro-

vertible evidence that the soil and climate of the Central District are eminently suited for the growth of sugar- cane. What we now want is a class of workers fitted for the cultivation of the sugar-cane. Within the last week we have become better qualified to judge of the reasons why the people ol Mackay, Townsville, and other coast towns should be so anxious to have more cheap labour. Our condition now resembles theirs. The state of matters is

now so plain that "he who runs may

read."

In these circumstances the correspon- dence, which appeared in our columns yesterday, cannot havebeen read with other than the deepest interest. It will go a long way, we think, to show that the evils, predicted in connection with the intro- duction of Coolies, are not so dreadful as some persons, for political purposes, would have us suppose. Dr. Cunning- ham, who was asked by us to favour the community Jwitb information upon the employment of Coolies, is a gentleman well qualified to furnish it. He has become familiar with the Coolie

system of emigration ; and, from residence in the West Indies, he has gained, by personal experience and observation, an intimate knowledge of the lives led by Coolies, and their influence on the population among whom they reside. The questions pro- pounded to Dr. Cunningham being of a general character, his answers are the same ; hut it seems to us they assist to

settle some points on which there has j been much discussion. With regard to ]

the Coolies themselves, the testimony of Dr. Cunnigham is very satisfactory. Neither in engaging, transporting, working, or treating them generally, are they used like slaves. Indeed, the Imperial legislation is very stringent against their being abused in any way. Their time or tasks are allotted them, and when work is over they are free to cultivate their little vegetable gardens, and look after their poultry and goats. Finding in these pursuits, and in the companionship of their countrymen, ample occupation, amusement, and entertainment they mingle very little with white people. Intercourse between

the sexes of different races is un- known where Coolies are located, and with them instead of Kanakas as labourers, we should not have " scrub settlements " near our town, and a semi barbarous race growing up in our midst. Then, their only occupation is agricul- ture. For that they are engaged : to lh.it they are confined. Not till they have been ten years in the Wwi Indies are they free to remain there, The fact

is, however, they do not settle down io strange lands. As soon as they have made a little money they return to their, native villages, acquire land, and become tyots, or farmers on their own account. Neither temporarily nor permanently do they interfere with white labour. As for for their becoming mechanics and trades- men-such a thing has not been heard of. Instead of depreciating white labour their presence creates the demand for and makes it valuable. Managers, sub managers, field-inspectors - all are Europeans, and the Coolies would rather have them as any other. There is one point not touched upon in the correspon- dence, but upon which the Doctor is eloquent in conversation, and that is the circulation of money caused by their presence in a community. Their rations, tools, and numerous little requirements necessitate constant ex- penditure on the part of their employers. The Coolies themselves are also given to finery, and, from their scanty earnings, treat their dusky mates to something new and attractive in the way of dress. Dr. Cunningham is very decidedly of opinion,

that the introduction of Coolies into

Queensland would not be detrimental to the moral, social, and material interests of the Colony. He is not troubled with the fear, conjured up in many minds by Opposition orators, that this Colony shall become of an Asiatic type, with two grades of inhabitants, one being bloated white aristocrats, and the other mean whites and Coolies. The prospect of such a thing is so remote that it gives Dr. Cunningham no concern. His answer to the last question submitted brings us back to the point with which we had to deal at the opening of this article. We have the soil and the climate, but, our correspondent says, unless we have cheap labour he does not think it possible we shall be able to compete successfully in the cul- tivation of sugar, &c. with other countries where it is obtaiguble. His 'opinion has been formed after communication and conversation with those who have wit- nessed attempts made without success. It seems to us that, when the time comes for the constituencies. to decide this matter, they will follow the course their interests demands, and not oppose the introduction of Coolies. imperial statutes provide they shall only be introduced under stringent regulations as to their treatment and maintenance, so that nothing like slavery shall ever appear in our midst; and the present Queensland Government have declared that they shall only be employed in tropical agriculture, and thus they shall not keep down white men's wages. Unless, therefore our infant sugar industry is to be maimed, so that it shall not be able to progress for a century or more, we ,must have Coolies.

WE hare received an interesting letter from Mr. W, H. Robison on the Sugar Industry, but ita length and pressures on our space compel us to reserve its publication till Monday.

OSE of onr readers says that he bas been waiting all the week in expectation that some one would reply to our paragraph on tho ad vico of tho Wesleyan Conference in reference to attending theatres, &c* He is somewhat pleased with the paragraph in yesterday's Bulletin ou "gaiety tempered by seriousness " still ho thinks that more ought to be said, and asks us to write an essay on Romaus 12, I and 2, "I beseech you therefore brethren, by the mercieB of God that yo present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God which is your reasonable service. And bc not oonformed to this world; but be ye trans- formed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, nud acceptable, and perfect will of God." He thinks that there ought to be a difference between the church and the world, tho line should be drawn somewhere, but a Minister with whom he was talking some time ago, said he waB afraid it was rubbed out,

?favos the invitation of Mr, R. Ross, Taran

ganbah, and Mr. James Ross, Mulambin, Mr. Maodonald, manager Pandora Sugar Planta- tion, on Thursday, visited the coast areas of the above-named gentlemeu's runs. He found many patches, about 400 and 500 acres in extent, where the Boil was admirably adapted for sugar-cane. As many of our readers aro aware the country has a fine ex- posure to thc north-east, ÍB well sheltered by the Berserker Range from the cold west winds, and slopes gently towards the beach. Ross's Creek would naturally form the port of tho plantations that may be formed there, and it would be fouud very suitable and con convenient. Accompanied by Mr. Broome, Mr. Macdonald also visited the proposed plantation on Woodlands run. He ex- presses himself as highly pleased with the appearance of the cane there. The earliest plauted cane, which by the way, is ten, and not six montliB old, as we stated thc other day, he regards aB very superior in all respects. With the whole patch he was very much pleased. With regard to the land, he says lie has not seen better anywhere in the colony. Looking to tho soil, situation, permanent water supply, &c, he has not the least doubt a flourishing plantation may be established. Mr. Mac- donald proceeds to Brisbane to-day, and will return in a short time to take charge of Pandora Plantation, and superintend thc erection on the site for the crushing machinery, which has been ordered from England.

RESPECTING tho French arrivals who were

relegated to durance vile yesterday, wb learn that thc fifth man Geffroy states, be hired the boat in which lie and his companions embarked on their perilous journey. They Iud a rapilal of eighty francs, to purchase their outfit. Among tho provisious were three buttles of ruui, which lasted twelve days. When the boat struck ou a rock, as previously mentioned, Pulin was steering the craft, and the tiller swung round and severely iujured a rib : the effects of the injury he still feels. Tho boat was a whaleboat, thirty feet long, four feet deep, and ten foot beam. When she struck the keel was completely smashed. Gulh-oy describes himself aa a lirickmaker, and waa

employed by linux, a butcher. Ile says his employer owod him money, and as he could not get it, he attempted to steal a watch from him. With this intent he opened his employes bedroom door by means of a key, and while attempting the theft was caught by Kons. For this he received a eenteuce of eight years' imprisonment aud was sent to New Caledonia. He was highly indignant nt being arrested as a vagrant, as he thought England was n free country. He understood that after finishing his term' he was not a rogue, and would get employment on landing. Ile said Mr. Carden Collins was willing to engage him as a labourer, and had supplied him with money. I he other men took the decision of the P.M. in a quiet manner, on Mr. Martiu telling them from the Hench that tht-ir explanations would better bonefit them in Brisbane, to which place they would be sent.

BETÖRE (he Police Magistrate yesterday morning, a drunkard was cautioned and dis- charged. Gabriel Abadie, Pierre Desire Vallee, Jacques Pilin, Jean Baptiste Marius, Gibert, and Viotor Emile Goffroy, the recent arrivais from New Caledonia were sentenced to fourteen days' imprisonment in Brisbane gaol nnder the Vagrant Act. The charge against each was heard separately. Constable O'ltourke gave evidence as to tho arrest of the four first named men, and Constable Fahey deposed to having arrested Geflroy. Both these officers stated that to the best of their belief the men had no lawful visible means of sup- port. This is rather queer considering the meu had money in their possession and in- formed the interpreter, Ur. Martin, they had found employment at Mr. Collins*.

ADDRESS, Eev. Robert Hartley, the Par- sonage, Yaamba Road, North Rockhampton,

-AUVT.

ALBRECHT FEEZ has juBt landed, direct from home, CO cases superior Still and Sparkling Hocks and Moselle (in quarts and pints), equal in quality to the best brands of champagne, and at most moderate prices; also, 100 cases of Morbit's Patent Stopper Lager Beer (in pints). Inspection invited.

ADVT.

Tuc following is the state of the Hospital for tho week ending Friday, February 9 :-Ad- mitted during the week-Males 9, females 7 ; discharged-males 6, females 2 ; remaining io hospital-males 35, females 15 ; total, 50. Eight patients in the special ward. Acknow- ledged with thanks a parcel of papers from Mr. T. T. Faunce. Donations of old linen urgeutly needed.

CORRESPONDENCE.

ORPHANAGE CHILDREN.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN,

Bm,-I noticed in lin article which appeared in your to-day's issue regarding the Rock- hampton Orphanage, some remarks which might mislead your Cathplio readers-would you kindly allow me to inlorm them that no Catholio children need' be in the institution T There is at Mackay, a licensed Orphanage, where Catholio children of this district may be admitted on making applications to the legitimate authorities.

I am, &o.,

C. MTOLAT, P.P. - Bockhampton, Marah 2, 1883.
