articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, JUNE 19, 1883,

THE tug of war begins on this day week ; and a stout fight it will certainly be. If will present a grand opportunity for the leading men to exhibit their prowess, although the result of the stuggle seems to be a foregone conclusion. And then will come in the weak-kneed members, and the waiters upon Providence. They of course will have to waste some public time in setting themselves right with their constituents. There will be a perfect babel of tongues for a fortnight, when, if Ministers carry out their inten- tion to stand firm, there will be a sudden lull before the electoral storm. Only one contingency could save the Govcn nicnt. Tliey cannot themselves draw back, bul it seems just possible that the Transcontinental Railway Syndicate, if assured that the validating bill will »ot pass, may do so. We say may, though such a step seems highly impossible. There can be no question but the Syndicate

are in earnest, and actuated by honour- J able motives. To withdraw would therefore be to show the white feather,

and in doing so to invite abuse, both upon the members of the Syndicate and the members of the Government

Still the rejection of the agreement would not settle the question ol land grant railways. On the contrary it would quickly bring our politicians face to face with the hitherto insoluble land

and public works questions. If the Opposition will not have land-grant railways they must suggest something else. Then they will find that although a fool may destroy it needs a wise man to-build up. Possibly Mr. Griffith has some statesmanlike scheme in his in-

genious head which will secure the ap- proval of a majority in Parliament, and carry the ship of State safely into deep water. Or possibly that honorable gentleman's wisdom will be found to consist, like that of the owl, simply in his looks. He is attempting to look very wise at present, at any rate. He does not mean to slacken the construc- tion of public works, or injure the sugar industry, but he is adopting the most effective apparent method of doing both. The truth is, we suspect, that if the con- stituencies can but be induced to let the Opposition into power they will do as they did io 1876-7, coolly reverse their opinions with their coats, and appro- priate the policy of their predecessors. In 1876 the Thorn Ministry went to their constituents with a policy of rest and caution. But once returned they met Parliament with a policy of six new railways in a block. They went to the country with promises to unlock the lands for the benefit of the selecting class. They relurned to Parliament with a scheme for the wholesale aliena- tion of the public lands to large capitalists. History repeats itself; and so when Mr. Griffith says that the sugar industry will not die, even though it be deprived of suitable labour, he means that if he comes into power he will admit Coolie or any other labour-if he finds that the exigencies of the times

demand it.

What a contrast is furnished by Sir j Thomas M'llwraith's speech as delivered I at Dalby, to that'delivered by Mr. Griffith at Mackay last week. On the one hand the colony is furnished with a clear and definite line of policy, which shows at least a statesmanlike appreciation of the wants of the colony, and the glorious future which lies before it. On the other we have a policy of negations and evasions. " I will be your physician," says the Opposition leader, " but I will not prescribe until I am called in. I must have my fee before I feel your pulse. Give me security for ^1300 a year, and I will prescribe for and cure you of your com- plaint. You ask my qualifications? Well, I am an accomplished lawyer, and a cutting parliamentary critic. I know, ' although you may not, that I am also a

first-class statesman. You must take me at ray own valuation or not at all. That I was a grotesque failure as Minister for Works in 1878 does not prove I shall not be a brilliant success in 1883. Nor does the fact, that I 1 have been a very poor Opposition 1 leader, prove that I shall not be

. a . very-,-1-1-i-j^,. vr tire

¡ prospective coalition government-a

coalition comprised of the rump of the ' squatters with the tail ol the Radicals. ; I will give you all you want, if , you will but first help me to vanquish ' the M'llwraith Government, who have

had their innings and their full share of the victor's spoils."

We put it to our readers whether or not this is the proper attitude for a political

leader to assume. Sir Robert Feel is Mr. Griffith's authority for refusing to prescribe, but is an English Tory Minister of fifty years ago, speaking to a House of Commons composed almost entirely of representatives of the privileged classes -is such a Minister the model up to which the Queensland Liberal works ? Fifty years ago the masses of the people had no voice in the British House of Commons ; to-day the people of Queensland, enfranchised with univer- sal suffrage, make or unmake parties in our representative Legislature. We say, then, it is an insult to the people for a political leader to seek to palm himself off as the physician whose advice shall not be given until he is called in.

While disclaiming any wish to keep any set of men perpetually in office, we therefore contend that the constituencies should require from every candidate a distinct and unequi-

vocal confession of his faith. If he does not believe in thc Transcontinental Railway, does he believe in unlimited borrowing and increased taxation to pay the ever-accumulating interest on the public debt? Or does he believe in putting a stop to public works ? Or in destroying the sugar and engineering industries. It may be all very well for lawyers lo say that sugar can be pro- fitably grown with white labour : but that is not the opinion of sugar growers to the contrary effect which is very

much more valuable?

AT the meeting of the Council of the Royal Colonial Institute held on the 24th April, Mr. John Steveneon, M.L.A., Queensland, was elected a Fellow.

AN advertisement elsewhere states that the partnership subsisting for some time past, between Messrs, O'Xlourke and M'Sharry, railway contractors, is formally dissolved. This step is owing, it is understood, to thc advent in thc finn of Mr. Macrossan.

THE Government Gaz'lte of last Saturday notifies that Sergeant Patrick Bowen ia ap- pointed inspector of slaughter houses, and of cattle to be slaughtered at Bogantungan and Clermont ; Bernard Mullen, H. lt. Mayne, and P. II. ll. Turner, to be trustees of the Racecourse Reserve ; Albert S. Hartley to ho junior clerk in thc Customs at Iïockhampton, in thc room of G. Moran, promoted.

WE understand that some of the members of the Committee appointed at tho meeting of the ratepayers of No. 1 Subdivision of (jogaugo Uivi-jitmal Hoard ou .Saturday after* noon, have waited on Mr. John Murray, Chairman of thc Hoard, and he has consented to meet them at the Divisional Board's Offices on Thursday morning, at eleven o'clock. As many members of the Board as posai bio will bc present, and the matter will be talked over to see if it cannot bo settled without a petition being presented to the Goveruor-in-Council.

Mu, WOODCOCK, Clerk of Petty Sessions at Maryborough, bas rendered good service to the Clerks of Petty Sessions and others con- nected with our minor courts by issuing in a neat handy form, a plain guide to the duties of the Clerks of Petty Sessions in Queensland, It appears to have been very carefully pre pared, ooo tains a large amount of interesting, information, and Clerks of Petty Sessions will find it very handy and instructive.

MR, BLANCHARD, Glenmore Road, has sent to our office some oranges grown by him in his garden. The fruit are very clean, and aro well flavoured and full of juice. Mr. Blan chard's orange trees are very healthy, and are actually borne down to the ground by the weight of fruit. As the season is fast going by, there are only two or three trees covered with fruit, but ou some a second crop is coming, and persona who wish to see a good crop of fruit should visit bis garden at once.

AT the Police Court yesterday, before the Police Magistrate, two drunkards were cautioned and discharged. Joseph Robinson, charged with indeoont exposure, was fined £5 one month's imprisonment. Bessie, a South Sea Islander, was charged with having no lawful visible meaos of support, and sentenced to one month ic Rockhampton gaol. lu the case of George Lee . alias Hockley, for desert* ing from the Silvery Wave, there was no ap- pearance of complainant.

ADVAVTAUE «ill be taken of the half holiday to-morrow by the Early Closing Cricket Club, to ploy a match at North Rockhampton between teams representing the Seniors and Juniors of the Club. Play will commence at balf-past 2 o'clock. The follow- ing are the teams :-Seniors : G. W. T. Moffat (captain), W. Whitman, G. H. Church, J. H. Church, D. Macpherson, R. W. Holden, T. Higson, J. Higgins, W. Baird, F, Barton, and J, J. M'Dermott. Juniors : Cohen, A. Palmer, W. Jackson, R. Morrison, J. Bryan, W. Clark, R. M. Aberdeen, Sullivan, C. Steele, H. Prior, and M. Doolan.

. THE Montague-Turner Opera Company are

expected to arrive in the steamer Queensland I to-day, and will open in tho Theatre to-night in Balfe's charming opera-"The Bohemian Girl." The opera ia replete with many familiar airs, and as the vocal powers of the principal artistes are very strong the patrons of the opera can evidently rely on a musical treat. The

management have made such arrangements as ' will euBure the convenience of .the public, and having gone to considerable expense in bringing the company here they deserve to be rewarded. Their energetio endeavours in affording lovers of music ah opportunity of hearing operas never before performed in Rockhampton is worthy of general patronage.

A TRAVELLEU informe us be left Rock- hampton by special train lately and arrired at Springsure sixteen boura after leaving here. This included a detention at Stanwell, as the draw bar of the train was smashed, and repairs occupied three quarters' of an hour. The country between Comet and Springsure shows signs of a scarcity of moisture, and Rainworth Station requires rain. Orass feed is plentiful all along the road, but the creeks are bare of water, Generally speaking tho season is likely to provo favourable. The Springsure hospital is said to be )> a pleasant state, as there was only one innate at the time our informant visited the institution. Mr. W. A. Leigh, the new Secretary, as well as Secretary to the Divisional Board, has already become quito popular in the district.

TUE parents of pupls attending the Rock- hampton Centrat Sotools are reminded that this is the evening, vhen they are invited by advertisement, to afcend a meeting ia the Boys' Central School it eight o'clock, to clout a School Committee. It is very important there should be elected a vigorous committee to oarry out thc hsndsono, elaborate plans that have been prepared by the Education Department for the Boys'School, whose now

Wilding* are so urgently required both from the largo attendance, and bad condition of the presont school. The plan now furnished, if carried out, will supply the town with one of tho finest state schools in the colony. It will be an architectural ornament to the town. AH parents laving pupils in any of thl departments i> the Central School have Í voico in the elootion of the committee, and itt is boped thty will exercise their rights in cleating a committee that will secure for them I so desirable an objeot.

AT the Brisbane Police Court last Thursday Edward Victoreen, hairdresser, of Edward street, was Bummcned under section 1, chapter 7 of 29th Charles [I., for shaving a customer ou the Lord's Day, The offenoe was proved, and defendant wai ordered to pay 6s. The oasc was brouiht by the Hairdressers' Association. Mr. Pinnock said he and his brother magistrates considered that the Hair- dressers' Association vero trying to make the Police Court a vehicle by which they could enforce their own regulations. The bench were of opinion that thia was not the correct thing to do. The Act bad been passed to causo thc Lord's Day to be observed, Tbs bench also considered it very hard if a person, who probably arrived in town from the bush too late on Saturday night to go to a barber's shop, could not get a Bhave on Sunday. If the bench bad the power thoy would have dis- missed the case, or only inflicted thc fiuo of a farthing, but as it waa they had no option but to inflict a penalty. They hoped that tlioy would have to deal with no more prosecutions by tho association.

FROM tho Brisbane Courier we observe that a printer's apprentice named Patrick Ambrose Bree, bas been trying to free himself from his indentures by summoning Robert William Bermingham, for neglecting to properly instruct him in the art of printing. The evidence showed that on tho lat July, 1S80, complainant had entered into indentures with defendant to serve for seven years, in order that bc might learn tho art of printing. Tho case was dismissed, as the testimony adduced in support of tho charge showed that the complainant was fairly advanced in the busi- ness for tho two years and a-half bc bad been serving, and that in four years bonce he would thoroughly acquiro the art. Mr. Pinnock san) he could plainly see that apprentices in this town were doing all they could to evade their apprenticeships. Several cases of thc kind had been brought before him lately, and, as he had repeatedly said, they were casting to the winda the opportunities they had of

earning an honest livelihood, and gaining independence for themselves. They were altogether too independent, and would not

suffer themselves to be uuder-control.

WE are glad to see that the Volunteers seem to have every desire to become thoroughly acquainted with military tactics, so far as it ie possible to practice them with a limited number of troops, and in times of peace, It will be Been hy nn advertisement in another column that on Thursday next a mina turc sham fight will take place in thc moon- light. Upon inquiry wo find that the nfliccrs ave taking steps to conduct tho affair upon really eound principles, and thc following memo, being a general idea of the engagement, Ins been circulated for tho information of those who aro to take part iu the manouvre General plan of engagement : It is to he under- stood by officers commanding companies that thc attacking force bas landed aud is using Kockliampton as their Imse of operations. A parly is organised to mnko a reconnaissance in tho direction of Gracemere, the rising ground about which is held by large numbers of thc dclcndors. The attacking party proceed by thc eastern end of tho range, aud will require to cross the Ychpon Lagouu, through which runs Hie road to (iracomerc. Tho outpost of the defending force being extended alontf thc town side of thc lagoon, retire upon the advance of thc enemy, but will make au effort to defcud thc passage of thc lagoon pending the arrival of reinforcement* from their rear. The de

fending party will wear white helmet« and undress uniforme ; the attacking party un- dress uniform simply. The defending foroe will be allowed half sn boor to arrange the plan and soope of the defenoe. Blank cart- ridges will be issued.

THE Champion of Thursday last says ¡-Oar Isisford correspondent, under date June 5, says : 700 store bullocks from Warrillalla to Mt. Leonard, lower Diamantina, passed through here to-day. They are the property of Messrs. T. Foot and Son, and being in charco of Mr.. M. C. Madden, should make a speedy trip. - Our Jundah correspondent, under date Cth June, says : -2000 female store cattle passed through yesterday and crossed tho Thompson safely. They are bound for Barrow Creek, Northern Territory. Their route is via Connemarra, Tally Ho, Diaman- tina Gates, and on to thc Herbert Downs Sta- tion, from thence the vendor, Mr. Ridley Williams, will open a road to MeBsrs. Murray, Aldridges and Co. 's station, who are the pur- chasers of the cattle. With those oattle are 25 well-bred bulls. Messrs. C. and F. Lowes in charge. Mr. Kinnivan is passing through with 300 fat bullocks from Brighton Dawns, Hamilton Uiver, bound for the southern mar} I kcts ; Messrs. Griffith and Weaver agents.

A mob of bulls for up-river, and a mob of Bheep for South Australia are also approaching. Weather delightful ; a favourable winter may bo expected.

SOME time ago a sewing party was started in connection with tbs Baptist Church, and every Thursday afternoon the lady members assembled in the Church, and devoted the half-day to the making of some useful article, each doing that which she was best aoapted for. Having thus mado an accumula- tion of articles, it was decided to bold a kind of bazaar in tho Oddfellows' flail for the

purpose of disposing of them. The most of VeBterday was occupied in arranging the stalls, and st three o'clock in tue afternoon the sale waa opened. Two or three ladies took charge cf each stall, and tbey were indefatigable in their efforts to dispose of the articles, In the evening there was a very good attendance, and a large number of the goods were disposed of. One of the lady members presided at the piano, and excellent musió was rendered. The proceeds of the sale are to be devoted, we understand, to the ereotion of a dwelling-house in the church grounds for a church officer. It ¡B to be hoped the returns are such as to re-pay the ladies for their efforts, and accomplish the objects aimed at. Forty pounds at least waa taken. ' Some things have been left over which will be

sold at a future date.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, JUNE 19, 1883.
snippet: THE tug of war begins on this day week; and a stout fight it will certainly be. It will present a grand opportunity for the leading men to exhibit their prowess,

articleText:
KOCKIIAMt'TON

SATUUDAY. JULY 28, 18S3.

ALL who arc interested in the social welfare of the people will read with more than ordinary attention the progress report, which has hecn drawn up by the Royal Commission on Employees in Shops, and which has been published in the Melbourne daily newspapers. It is a most instructive document, and deals concisely and practically with the impor- tant points of the Karly Ciosing Question. The conclusion to which the Com- missioners have come, after hearing a large amount of evidence from both employers and employed, is that early

closing should be established by Act of Parliament j and that this object can be best ; accomplished by fixing the bouts in. an y one week during which employes' shall be called to labour, leaving to-^employers and employes the allocation of those hours, provided thal

the number shall not exceed forty-eight in one week. It will thus be seen thal after ' táking eviflfencrí oh the' whole matter, and considering it fully thc Commissioners have ho faith in moral moral suasion. However much some

of our readers may be inclined to dissent from this finding, upon reading the report they will readily admit that it is warranted. When men increase in number in any centre bf civilisa- tion, not only do the rich be- come more wealthy, and the poor more' abjectly miserable; but the wealthy become more powerful,'and the poor weaker. It is the unrestrained domination of wealth, and the gratifica- tion of the passion to acquire it, which have called forth this demand for the legislature to interfere on behalf of those whose only wealth is their ability to toil. The prominent fact pointed but in this report, is that, in the'eily of Melbourne, there are 20,000 persons who are subject to grievous hardships, and who live under a system of forced labour repugnant to every sense of justice and humanity. Hundreds of young girls, we are told, are employed at work daily from ten lo fifteen hours, under such in- sanitary conditions that their health in many cases has become completely

undermined. !

Among the discoveries made by the Commissioners was the complete failure

of the efforts made to ameliorate the

condition' of the employees by moral

suasion. Attempts were made to - produce a change by such means. An Early 'Closing Association wás formed, appeals were made through the press, lectures were delivered, entertainments were organised-in fact all the agents of moral suasion were set in motion, to induce the public to co-operate in1

the tcduclion of the hours of

labour in shops. The larger drapery establishments agreed to close at six o'clock' daily, and on Saturday afternoons; but the smaller and suburban establishments never cordially -concurred in the arrangement, and so far as they were concerned it fell through. A Sales- men and Assistants' Union was formed to take up the cause which had been abandoned hythe Early Closing Associa- tion. The former set: the engines of moral suasion in motion, and spent

¿£300 in working them. A newspaper j was run in the interests of the early ! closers, and bills and advertisements widely circulated. At last the efforts of the Union seemed to be crowned with some measure of success, and it was generally agreed the shops should be shut at seven o'clock ; but a few indi- viduals held our, and those weak links in the chain, caused by local and personal jealousies, and a spirit of competiou, led to the, collapse of the movement. In Ballarat/ Sandhurst, and Geelong the shops close daily at six, at ten on Satur-

day, and one half-day in the week ; but in 1

Melbourne and suburbs the long hour j

system still obtains.

On the grounds of expediency, justice, and humanity the employees, having exhausted the powers of moral suasion, now demand legislative interference for their protection. It is expedient, they contend, " because it is the youth of both sexes-the flower of the population

-that suffers most from the effect of the

system that prevails ; it is simple justice

to secure tor them the curtailment of the hours of labour, inasmuch as tradesmen for the greater part enjoy the blessing of the eight hours movement ; it is in the interests of humanity, because pf the tender, age of the workers, the character of the climate, and the defective hygienic arrangements of many work- shops and places of business." In support of these contentions the Commis- sioners point out that a limitation of the hours of labour does not lead to a

decrease of business. Experience, has

shown that where the hours have been reduced, the. same amount of business has been done. The same business, they assert, can be done as effectually in eight hours as in twelve or fourteen.

Strange as it may seem, most of the employers are as anxious' as their em- ployes to enjoy the benefits arising from early closing. The proprietors of large

establishments are unanimous on the subject. Among the smaller shokeepers an active rivalry in business is the chief obstacle to harmony. They are quite conscious that the long hours are injurious to health, and are wholly unnecessary, but they persist in them as

a matter of self-defence. A few talk of the restriction of the hours of business as interference with the rights of the subject, and contend that late hours are necessary to suit the requirements and and convenience of the working classes. The position of this class of objectors, the Commissioners maintain, is wholly ?untenable, and their arguments are based

on self-interest and indifference to the health and comfort of their employees.

The Commissioners have accumulated a large amount of evidence upon the injurious effects-physically, mentally, and morally-of protracted labour in shops. It is painful to read of. the mortality which prevails among shop- men. Few of them, who do not get into business for themselves, live beyond thirty-five or forty. Fine robust young men go in from the country, and long before they reach middle life, shop-work has broken them down, " so that they are unlit fur anything." Medical testi- mony is also adduced, and is most convincing as to the evils of long hours, especially on the health of the young women, and that of barmaids. The result is, as we have already remarked,

that the Commissioners have made out a strong case for the restriction of the hours, of employment in Melbourne shops. It is most likely legislative action will follow upon it. The com- munity of Rockahmpton is to be con- gratulated, we think, on the fact that legal compulsion is not necessary among our shopkeepers.

OPKjtiTipsa wjll -be cammeboei- at the Lake's Creek Woács oh tba K¡tb<inBtant to preps ra f rosen meat for £he Fiado, which is .to be loaded lhere eatjy iufieptomber.

TUB Ooseftwr say» r-The Fitzroy frozen meat works arc the most complete in thc colonies, and that the trade initiated by tho Fiado between Brisbane aud Java will, in consequence.<jf thc med!-.ency of the Queens I port works,Ac u'oucctbi th carried on between

KockUainptou aud Java.

I IN consequence of the congrégation, ol

Fitzroy-strcet Primitive Methodist Church, and the number of cliildren who attend the Sunday School being, on the increase, it has become necessary to enlargo the place of worship. It is proposed to erect wings on each side of the church, plans for which are

¡bein)? prepared by Mr. Wilson. Tho work

wilt be commeuced in a few weeks.

IN the Government Gazette of Saturday last is a list of tenders for the conveyance of mails which will bo received up till the 1st October. Among them we uotice the following :-llock hampion and Lake's Creek by coach daily ; Rockhampton and Yaamba, via Greenlake, Caual Creek, The (Jake, and Canoona Diggings, by horse once a week ; and brock- hampton Post Office and Railway Station, and the Post Office and the Wharf, by coach, to meet every traiu and ovary vessel conveying

mails, and clear nillkr.boxes.

SOON again tho time will come when thom who have friends in distant lands will bethink them of sending. Christmas greetings ta be there when the bells arc ringing. To meet thc wishes of persons so inolincd. Messrs. Gibbs, TShallard. áud Cor, Sydney, have pre 'pared very pretty Christmas cards. They not . only bear appropriate mottoes, poetry, and greetings, but charming rcprpscntations of Australian fruits and flowers. Those are

tastefully grouped ; ead .beautifully coloured, ? and deserve praise as works of art.

TUE Governor Blackall, e.a., which días ; been detaiued at Cooktown for several days awaiting the arrival of the Q.R.M.8. Chye- bassa with the English mails, loft Cooktown for thesouth yesterday. Aftercallingot Townsville she will continue her voyage to-day, and ia expected here on Sunday night. ' After ship-

ping produee at .Lake'« Creek, the lllackall. will bo despatched for Brisbane and Sydney on Monday, The English mails, tn thc event of the Chyebassa, arriving at Cooktown this morning, will probably be brought down tbe coast by the Elamang, s.s., which leaves Cooktown at noon to-day.

THE report for the Orient Steam Navigation Company for 1882 says the net earnings of the company .during the year, after paying all expenses,, including interest on the deben- tures, amounted to £43,139. Prom the net earnings there has to be deducted for reserre a sum of £34.827,beiog 43 per cent on the oost of thc steamers, which leaves a balance of £8312. Tho directora propose, to carry this balance to tho credit of revenue account for the current year, and not to declare a dividend on the present occasion. This conclusion is rendered the more necessary by considerations connected with the -serious misfortune whiob bofel tbe company ia the sinking of their new steamer the Austral. At : the anuna! meeting the shareholders agreed to

the proposals of the directors. ?

ON Thursday night it was reported to the .police that a little boy named Weber bad been - missiDg siuce half-past five in the afternoon. Every search was made by tho father, who is employed on "board the Heka, and by the police, but no tidings could be heard of tbe missing child. On the father proocoding to his work yesterday morniDg he found the little fellow fast asleep on board the Heka, it ap- pears that rather late on Thursday night he was met by some person on the'north side of the river, who asked him what was the matter with him, and where lie lived. He was un- able to answer the question, but pointing to tho Heka/ which ia moored at North Rock- hampton,' he said it was his father's boat. Thc stranger accordingly placad the boy po board,-where he was found as stated, having remained on board the vessel alone all night. -

AT the Police Qonrt yesterday before .'the Police Magistrate, Mary Burgs, who wai charged with making use of obscene language, was fined 40a. in default »oren days' imprison- ment. William1 Phillips, od' remand, wai charged with, wilful destruction of property, George Sam'wáTB deposed he saw the defen- dant about the race, time ^tasting billi over those of thc Zulu War, which were thut destroyed, but he could not Bay if they were torn. Thomas Morris' deposed he saw Phillips paste bills over those of the plaiutifTi near the Swan Hotel, For tho defence Thomas Lauderdale deposed bo gave defen dant permission to .put bills on bis stables Boroo time back, but not td pasto their over Mr. Thompson's; Defendant wai fined 10s., , with £2 2s. professional costs, Cs. Sd. costs of Court, £1 5s witnesses'expenses,-and £1 damages ; in de fault one month's imprisonment. Margarel King Veen was charged with making use of obsceue language. Mr. Milford ap peared for thc defendant, who pleaded nol guilty. Cnustablo Williams deposed he wai on duty about nine o'clock on Sunday last, and

heard the defendant make useoi obscene lan. guage ; bc saw Mrs. Sam Wah trying to take defendaut away from her husband, whom sile -was swearing at. \ .Tames Booth corroborated Constable' Williams' evidence with reference to tho bad language iiBed by defendant. For the defence, Delia Sam Wah deposed that there was a row between defendant and her husband about eight o'eldak'cn Sunday -last, 'but the language stated in the summons waa not used ; she waa close euough to hear all that was said

thc language could not have been made use of withoul'hcr hearing it. Defendant was fitted 10s. ; in default forty-eight hours in the cells. Tho case of Michael ltyau ti Martin Coughlin, for absconding from his apprenticeship, was adjourned for a week.

WE take tbe following election notes from late issues of the Brisbane Observer.:-That tho Government have totally abandoned the Kimber agreement, and will, if not defeated on their appeal to thc country, never submit tbe agreement to Parliament again. That the Opposition are wise in their generation in capturing any northern constituency which

will fall into their net. That the Government will be equally wise in netting any southern constituency which desires to display its independeuce of Queen-street. That Enoggera presents an inviting field for tho adventurous Conservative in the absence of its presont members. That Courtenay Spry means to fight Garrick for East Moreton in the Liberal interest. That if Spry's candidature is feasible, Garrick's constituents must bc more sick of their old member than most people have supposed. That Donaldson, of Mount Margaret, is likely to succeed Stevens for the Warrego. That Norton Will have to wake up his supporters if bc wishes to represent Gladstone again. That the declining electo- rate o'f Port Curtis is olleriug itself for conditional Bale, and that George Thorn means to free-eolect and occupy it by bailiff. Tbat Mr, Thoa. Finney, of Finney, Isles, and Co., has been asked to stand for North Brisbane iu thc general election. That ex-mayor John Siuclair cannot be induced to come forward for auy electorate. That Simon Fiascr and Jlcury Jordan, though running in doubl« harness, bearing thc hraud of the S.B.L.A., arc not both equally acceptable to tbe electors. That Kingsford is to bc denied a heariu^ should ho attempt a public address to his late constituents. That the Wide Bay constituencies contemplate sending five sitters on the rail to thc ucw Assembly. That I!. B. Sheridau and little Bailey will probably be elocted in the interests of the Opposition. That Speaker King's chances have been marred by his Transcoutiuental railway proclivities That Sheridan will run for Maryborough on the Orange ticket. That Wyndham Palmer

will, have the honour of giving placo to Arthur Rutledge as member for the lowers. UiaTí' the Towers people are '"fall" of Stanley, and are unable to find an acceptable tocal candidate. That Fred and* Gibson are

extremely^ unpopular at Port Dolarlas' and' Cooktown,; That Macrossan has been pro- misee! uuKcraal support in the north if he will take lils stand on the independent platform. That Mrv-lV. S. Sly, ot Ardoch .Station, near 'thargomindah, will contest either the War- rego or Balonne electorate at tho forthcoming election. Mr. Sly has had overtures from both electorates, but ? has- not yet .decided .

which he will contest.*

Tm monster radio took place in the Belmore

Arina ¡Hotel last night. Tb» pianoforte waa

won by Mr. Sala, af ter a tie, with 44 ; the gold watch, fell to Mr. W. Jackson as the lowest thrower, bi«, cast, being 18 ; Mr. G. H. Wild waB the winner of the Waltham watch ; the

fourth prize was the lot of Mrs. Swiff, of the ' Belle Vue Hotel i and Mr. ,J. J. Barnett, of Marlborough, .won the double barrelled gun. Champagne, was called for, and the toasts of the Tucky wiuuers drunk with musical

honours.

FRO» information kindly furnished by our Land Commissioner we notice that moat of the selectors in this district had paid their rents by the beginning of April. Only 47 had failed to do sb ; the area of land held by them being 19.05G acres, When the ninety days' grace allowed had expired, 38 out of the 47 had paid up. The total rent received amounted to £559 Os. <43d. Nine selectors failed to forwnrd their rents, and their selec- tions are liable to forfeiture. The amount received, waa £11,281 ls. Bi, oa 661-selec-

tions.

Á CONCERT anil fruit soiree will be held in thc Baptist Church, Denisoh-Btreet, on Monday, evening next.

IN another column will be found a list of thc services to be held by the Ministers of the Primitive Methodist Church at different places in this district to-morrow. .

THE usual monthly meeting of the Central Queensland Farmers and Selectors'Association will be held at eleven o'clock, thlB morning, in the School df Arts Committee Room. A paper is to be read by Mr. 6. Hallam with reference to the labour question.

TUE following is the etate of the Hospital for the week ending Friday, July 27 :-Ad- mitted during the-week, 3 males, 8 females; discharged, 4 males ; remaining in hospital, 27 males, 10 females ; total, 37. Nine patients in the special ward. Visiting Com mittee for the month of August-Messrs. Dibdin and Ferguson. Visiting Surgeon-Dr. M 'N eely,. Donations of old linen are urgently needed. Acknowledged with thanks papers per favour of Mr. W. Moffat.

.. MESSRS. W. Jaoksonand Oo. announce they will sell at the Queen's Hotel, this afternoon at three, on account of whom it may concern, the wreoked barque Deutschland with all in- ward cargo ; all gear and appurtenances will be given in, and the whole will be submitted in

one lot.

articleText:
1-hr Arning giiUetin,

KOCKIIAMITON.

SATURDAY. AUGUST 25, 1883.

THE WEEK.

THE general election ie now in full siring, and the returns from the several constituencies are awaited with much anxiety by active politicians. The first set, consisting of ten elections, took place on the 17th instant, and resulted in a gain of one to the Opposition. Aubigny. Blackall, Dalby, Mackay, Mul- grave, Normanby, Port Curtis, and Hock hatnpton retained their old representatives, except that Mr. Higson succeeded Mr. T. M. Paterson. In tho Logan electorate Mr. P. M'Leau, Minister for Lauds in thc Douglas Administration, has been ousted by Mr. ti. J. Stevens, Ministerialist. At Maryborough the Ministerial candidates have becu succeeded hy Mr. Hurley, who claims to be Independent, and Mr. Sheridan, an Oppositionist. Thc polling for thc second set of eight elections took place on the 21st inslaut. Enoggera returned Messrs. J. lt. Dickson and J. L. Bale; Oxley, Mr. S. Crimes ; Rosewood, Mr. J. B. L. Isambert; Bundanha, Mr. Foote -without opposition. Contests took place in thc Valley, Brisbane ; South Brisbane, Ipswich, and North Brisbane, but the only change made iu tho state of parties was the rejection of Mr. Kingsford, and thc substitution ol Mr. Jordan in South Brisbane. In these

clcctious an attack was made ou thc Opposi- tion stronghold, but it failed. Thc polling for thc third set of three elections was fixed for Toursday last. Bowen returned Mr. Chubb without oppositiou. In the Luicli

I hardt electorate Messrs. Scott and Dutton

have been returned, the latter gentleman supplanting Mr. Feiss. In Stanley electorate the Opposition candidates have both buen re- turned, and Mr. P. O'Sullivan has lost his Bent. Nominations for the fourth set of elections took place yesterday, when Mr. I (Jarrick was returned for Moreton with-

out opposition. Thc results of thu elec- tions so far have liccn that thc Ministry have gained ono scat - Logan - and have lost four-Maryborough (2), Stanley, and Leichhardt. Thc Opposition have n< !. been more successful in thur attacks on thc Ministerial positions than thc latter. With the exception of Mr. Ohubb'a all the Minis- terial seats were challenged. At Aubigny a fierce assault was made on Hon. P. Perkius'

seat, but he defeated his antagonist by a large

majority. Hon. A. Archer in Blackall tras . the subject of a concealed stratagem. The : allegiance of many of his friends was subverted, and canvassing against bim carried on long previous to the dissolution. Mr. Archer went about among his constituents, addressed them, and conversed with them on subjects of current interest. Mr. Macdonald only delivered cue speech-at the declaration of tbe poll. The majority for Mr. Archer shows that he still ^osseasos the confidence of the great majority of the electors. Con- siderable interest was taken in the l'ort Curtis election, because Hon. G. Thora is a clever electioneering tactician, and attempts had been made ia the local press to under- mine Hon. A. Norton's political reputation. Early in the contest it beoame apparent that the struggle would be a keen one, and the

reBult confirmed (fie anticipation. Mr. Norton

managed to hold his own with a few votes to spare, and Mr. Thorn is now seeking a seat from his old constituents at Northern Downs or Fassifern. Mr. Stevensau had almost a walk over in tho Normanby, Mr. I). S. Wallace's candidature, and that of Mr. W. S. I'auls, having been a mistake. The lessou taught those who organised their expedition, it is to be hoped, will not be without value to

them.

THE eleotions in tho urban constituencies show that it is in thom thc strength of tho Opposition lies. Mr. Morehead made a gallant attack on the Valley, but it was attended with complete failure. Part of this is said to have been due to the rowdyism dis- played at cue of Mr. Beattie'« meetings, and which it was said was organised. But similar rowdyism was manifested at one of Mr. Kingsford'* meetings, but little was said about it. The gain mode by the Opposition in South Brisbane is not great, as Mr. Kingsford was an Oppositionist. lie went over to the Ministry on the Steel Kaile Question. These elections are in- structive, as they show that Queen-street is still decidedly opposed to the present Ministry. At Bundaberg and Maryborough

the elections were not carried to a conclusion without Brisbane influence being exercised in many ways. At Maryborough the German vote was secured to the Opposition by the efforts of an emissary from the south. In the Maryborough election local influences were at work, and assisted to determine the result, Mr, Hurley, from what he has seen in America, is inclined to try the land-grant syBtem of railway construction under proper safeguards; but Mr. Sheridsn, like Mr. Jordan, has a crow to piok with the Ministry, and so sides with the Opposition. Party spirit entered to some extent into the contest in Rockhampton, but it was lost sight of in the personal claims of the candidates. This ia rendered sufficiently plain by the position attained by Mr. Ferguson at the top of the poll, for he was not by any means a party candidate. Should the Ministry put land-grants and Coolies in the Governor's Speech, then he will become an independent member, or perhaps he will join the coming coalition. Mr. Paterson as an Opposition candidate was as pronounced as Mr. Higson, and the personal claims or influence of the latter must have secured his election. Mr. Paterson claims that Liberalism prevails among the workiug men of Rockhampton, but while a liberal spirit does pervade their minds, it is not of the Queen-street typo he represents.

THE electors of Rockhampton of all parties ¡ are pleased to hear their rejected candidates are about to try for other seats in Parliament. Both are good men. There is something chivalric in Mr. Paterson's attack upon the squatting stronghold in the west. As au Opposition candidate he has many claims to support, but whether he would make an eligible representative of the Mitchell is a question the electors must consider and de- termine. Mr. Rees Jones' prospects of elec- tion for Clermont will depend on the action of Mr. D. S. Wallace. That gentleman has gone south, and should ho determine, aa is most i probable, not to go to the poll, then Mr. Jones

will have a fair chance of being returned. ' Though not in the strict sense of the word a

local man, Mr. Jones will make au admirable representative for that electorate. His long residence in the district, intimate knowledge of colonial affairs, business habits, legal know- ledge, and high position in this community, should commend him to any constituency in the Central district, and above all to that of Clermont and Copperfield.

MR. P. F. MACDONALD ÍB evidently very sore about his rejection in the contest with Mr. Archer for Blackall, and gave vent to his feelings in some peevish remarks at the declaration of the poll at Stanwell on Tuesday afternoon last. Ho indulged in a few of those vague and despicable statements which arc too characteristic of hts remarks, If Mr. Mac- donald wishes to impress the electors witli a sense of tho proprioty of what he says, he should follow up such accusations as he ie accustomed to make with proof. He blamed Mr, Archer for regarding Blackall as a pocket borough, aud never studying the interests of the electors while he was in Parliament, and with having taken his views on politics from a few parlous who live upon the Range, and constituted themselves the mouthpieces of the electora of Blackall. There is not thc slightest proof that Mr. Archer has treated Blackall as if it were a pocket borough. He has resided here the greater part of bis time, he has gone out and in among thc electors, he has inado himself inti- mate with their wishes, and has ever doue all that he considered best for their moral, intel- lectual, and material prosperity. He has uevcr failed upon auy occasion that wc are aware of to discharge the duties incumbent upon him as their representative. As to thc statement that he takes his politics from a few persons on the Bango, that implies a want of independence and intelligence on thc part of Mr. Archer, and conveys an insinuation anyone with a sense of gentlemanliness would be loth to made against another, unless he were prepared to substantiate it. AU the elec- tors of Blackall who live upon the Range do not exceed a dozen, and we do not think they possess such an influence over Mr. Archer os

would lead him to change his belief from what J he considered to be right to that which j was wrong. Mr. Macdonald spoke also about Mr. Archer haviug out paid canvassers, and herc again ho was unable to provo his assertion. His reference to the Divisional

Board dispute indicated clearly the use he has j

been making of that affair to alienate Mr. Archer's old friends. It is pitiful to have to allude to such things in connection with an election that on one side was conducted with the utmost fairness and propriety. If Mr. Macdonald would only believe better things of his adversaries, and make fewer rash aud inconsiderate statements, he would gain more credit and reputation among the electors.

AK amusing story is told of a Scotch worthy who got on thc sproc occasionally, and on returuiug from one of his bouts, bia roaster asked him what had been the cause of his

last escapade. "Oh, man," he replied, "did you no hearthat my grand whistling canary was dead." " Surely," said his employer, "that is no great excuse for getting druuk, and loBing several days' work.'* " Perhaps not," was the respouse, " but any excuse is good enough when one has an iuclination that way." Mr. .lohn 0'Shanesy seems to have been much in thc position of this drouthy individn.il, with respect trt the election fur Blackall. He excused himself for having to oppose Mr. Archer, beeitisc of that gentleman's lecture on thc dry-belt theory, which was delivered on the 5th Maruh, 1870. It seems strange bow Mr. O'Shanesy e.ouUl have goue about for thc lait ten years with this dry belt theory work in" in his inward*, and never summoned up conrane to speak to Mr. Archer upon the sub- ject, lt would hilve been much better had he *iime so, than to have rtregeuted himself in thc way he did, making that au excuse for his action, when the interests involved were purely of a political character. Any exouM,

however, is good enough for lome people who have an inclination one way.

A CASH, the circumstances ot which are auspicious, ia now the subject oí an iinqiiiry by the police turthorities. On 1Ion)lay .etoo ing last a disturbance was heard going on 411 a house ia Archer-street, sad a neighbour, being apprehensive that wrong was being done, weut to a policeman, and gave him in- formation, but he treated the matter lightly. Next evening, however, information was lodged with the police that a woman in the bouse in question had died suddenly. The body, upoo examination, was found to be covered with innumerable bruises, and she had evidently been the subject of much

violence. A man named Gardner has been j

arrested in connection with the caso. 1

ANOTHER lot of immigrants were landed hero from thc Dritish-India steamer Duke of Buckingham this week, and are meeting with rcadyemploymentatfairratesof wages. A large addition to the population of the town will be made by the arrival of tho Nebo, which has over 400 immigrants on board. They are ex- pected to arrive here to-morrow or Monday. The vessel has made a very good passage, and so far as we eau learn those on board are in good health.

A VESTRY mcetiug of the morabora of St. Paul's Church was held on Tuesday evening laBt. Among the business transacted was the election of a churchwarden in the place of Mr. li. Sexton, who has been appointed Traffic Manager at Maryborough. Mr. A. T. Wood was elected to fill the vacancy. The Rector, Rev. W. A. Diggens, brought before the meeting the ceremonies bo proposed to have in connection with the opening of the new church, which, in all probability, will take place

on the 18th October next. The matter was

eventually referred to a Committee, which will be composed of fifteen gentle- men, to deal with. (We may. also men- tion that the new organ for the church has been landed here, and will be examined by a Committee appointed for the purpose, who will use their disoretion as to whether they will purobase it or order another one.

Tuc hopes of many were raised cn Tuesday evening last about seveb o'clock when rain began to fall, and from all appearances it seemed as if it would continue for some time. This, however, was not the case, as after about three hours' steady rain it cleared off. The rainfall registered in Rockhampton was only 0 20 inch. Around tho town and in many country places it fell in greater volume, much to the gratification of the residents there-

abouts.

articleText:
KOCtvllAMI'TON.

WEDNESDAY. AUGUST 29. 1883.

THE latest advices from home leave no room for doubt, that the relations between France and Great Britain are, at the present, more strained than they have been since the days of the old Egypto-Syrian dispute in Mehemet Ali's time. The friendship with the French Republic, which the Gladstone Govern- ment has taken such pains to encourage, has of recent years been subjected to strains of more or less severe character.

It is impossible to close our eyes to the fact that among the various expeditions, in which the French are now engaged, the one that excites most enthusiasm in France is that which is supposed to be likely to be most injurious to England, and English interests. There can be no doubt, also, that the French are by no means pleased at the predominance of English influence in Egypt, which has been the result of the repression of the rebellion in that country by force of English arms. And they are equally jealous of thc attitude that has been taken by Great Britain, in connection with the construction of a second Suez Canal. Such being the case, it seems that, being unable with safely to find scope for her irrepressible energy in Europe, thc feels called to exert her- self in sending expeditions to thc remoter portions of thc jilobe. Thc enterprises to Tommin, Tunis, Madagascar, and on

the Coniro are not unnaturally regarded as évidences of a desire on her part to form lire linsis of a Colonial Empire, and to revert lo her Cnlonnl policy of overa cer.lrry ;II;H. I"nforliinaicly fur Fram.e, hov.'e\er. eeiiius foi culoni/.aiion does liol scciii lo I..- one of tho attributes of the French people. There is no need, whatever may be ilie desire for " fresh fields and pastures new," for increased

territory to sustain a large and teeming population, for in France there is room for all her sons and daughters at home. Her population increases very slightly, and in the rural districts, from which a class suitable for emigrants could be found, it actually decreases. The estab- lishment of French colonies must, there- fore, of necessity be a purely artificial one, and can be by no means an easy process. With England the case is exactly the reverse. For several cen- turies, her population has overflowed her borders, and still the cry is raised for increased emigration. Outlets for this overflow of population become im- peratively necessary, and then it is that English colonies have accordingly been founded, and are now flourishing in every quarter of the globe. That France can ever rival England as a colonising nation is obviously impossible, and in resorting to the experiments, which were carried on with such doubtful success by Louis XIV., and other French monarchs, she is merely finding a tem- porary vent for the aggressive sentiment, and the desire for la gloire, which still afflicts her, but which, at the present, she cannot safely exercise in quarttfs

nearer home.

In Tonquin, the French appear to have entered upon an undertaking of more magnitude and difficulty than they were probably aware of when they started. It seems hardly probable that China will quietly permit the French conquest of Anani, and though it is obvious that France is a more powerful military State than China, still the latter may prove no mean antagonist against the force of a European power, which would be far

distant from its base and from reinforcements. In the event of

China taking an active part in the Tonquin imbroglio, France would find herself with a long and exhausting war on her hands which must drain her

resources in men and money, and Tender her almost impotent in the event of any important European struggle taking place. In Madagascar, though the French will probably be allowed to do as they please, without provoking the intervention of any European Power, it seems that a considerable amount of force will have to be supplied, before they can induce the Ho vas to surrender their territory, and pay the expenses the conquerors have been put to in taking il from them. Of course it is possible that trouble may arise from the high-handed proceedings of Admiral Pierre, which culminated in the death of the English Consul, and the arrest of the Rev. Mr. Shaw, a missionary, for complicity willi the Hovas in their hostile movements. Butas we learn by telegraph that the French Government have found it convenient to disavow the proceedings of their too zealous subordinate. The ultimatum, which was addressed to the Queen of the Hovas after the bombardment of Masunca, and previous to the occupa- tion of Tamatave by the French Admiral, demanded-first, the recognition of the

1 French Protectorate on the west coast ;

second, the payment of ^60,000 ; and third, the settlement, in the French sense of the long standing dispute,

... a.. »="",,. nf landed pro- perty by Frenchmen in Madagascar. As a matter of course, their conditions were refused, and as the Hovas are a spirited and tenacious race, it is not un- likely that the French troops will have to occupy Tamatave and the surround- ing district for some time, before they are accepted. It is not unlikely, indeed, that the French, resenting the adverse criticism, which their action has called forth, in England especially, may annex the west coast of Madagascar altogether, but in the event of their doing so, those acquainted with the character of the Hovas allege that their serious troubles and difficulties will only then commence. In any case, the exploits thc French have already performed can hardly be regarded as a satisfactory beginning to a French colony in Madagascar. The only good that the French are likely to derive is a little cheap and vain glorifica- tion, if that can be described as a good ; but as a colonising experiment their operations in the island are worse

than futile.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1883

TUE WEER.

ALL thought of the elections DOW going on has dropped from the minds of people here, the more readily we daresay as it seems to bo settled that the Ministry will be in a minority when Parliament meets Next week the polling will take place in connection with the fifth and sixth sets of elections which will include-the former Burnett, Carnarvon, Warwick, Darling Doune, Drayton and Toowoomba, and the latter Balonne, Burke, Mitchell, Gregory, Kennedy, Warrego After these have been determined there only remains the Cook elec- tion, the polling for which will take place on the 30th October. Parliament has been ad- journed till the Gth November, and will probably meet a week later

A OATIIERINO of the Liberal party in Rockhampton was held in the Belmore Hotel on Saturday evening last, for the purpose of entertaining the Hen S W Griffith, and his henchman Mr Garrick It was intended to be a quiet prnate affair, but the indiscreet zeal of some officious persons has turned it into a source of merriment to outsiders We have already commented on the proceed lugs, and are only tempted again to rorert to them b\ a desire to call attention to a sug gestive remark made by the Hon Mr Griffith He declared it to be his belief that the respect and esteem of his fellow mon w as the greatest reward a public man could labour for

Without calculating the amount of such re- ward indicated by the meeting which he then

addressed, wc ina} be permitted to point out i that all the great reformers, who have made their mark upon the age in which they lived, cared less for the opinion of their fellows than tho consummation of their high purposes or the promulgation of their opinions Great men in science and philosophy have always been in advance of public opinion Had they depended upon it for the success of their schemes, or acceptance of their teaching they would never have been hoard of Every faith can count its martyrs From this state ment we may be led to infer that Mr Griffith is a mere popularity hunter He will court the favour of the crowd This is not an attractive characteristic of one who must lead the multitude The man who can devise

great and beneficial measures, without waiting for public approbation, it seems to as is mare *" ''". ~-jiriirrn_._ _

A MEETING of of the Town Council was hold on Thursday afternoon The official recorte from the IoBpector of Nuisances and his assistant showed what they have been doing to keep the town in a good sanitary condition The General Purposes Committee have re- commended the appointment of an inspector of ecateogtng Iucreasing at this rate the inspectors mil presently outnumber tho persons employed to do the work The Finance Committee reported upon the state ment of the auditors, and they do not concur in the views taken by the lattor gentlemen At the ssme time the Committee's report is not altogether satisfactory. They say, for instance, that no rates have been cancelled without the order of tho Mayor and for adequate reasons Now, we think it is not proper that the Mayor should have it in his power to cancel rates, and the reasons that may seem adequate to the members of the Council may be viewed in a different aepect by the public Several clauses in the auditors' report are discussed as having been satis factonly explained, and the Mayor, in pro posing the a loption of the Committee's report, I reflected upon the auditors for ignoring the

officials of the Council, and bringing up this report without consulting them We hold the auditors acted in this matter quite properly, and that it is f ir the Council, and not for the auditors, to listen tot lie explanation of officials We think the Mayor himself must see that an explanation niven to an auditor, and held by him to be quite satisfactory, might be thought very insufficient by the Council The auditors are bound to go by the books and documents submitted to tlloui, aud to have their opinion altered by meic \erbal representations would be altogether inexact and unbusinesslike Considerable time of the Council «as occupied in discussing tho tramway question, and much difference of opiuion was expressed, not as to the utility and benefit of tramways, which everyone admits but oa to the manner in which the BJ stem is proposed to be intro luced into Rockhunpton borne aldermen seem to think the tramway system should be accepted upon any terms, and thov are under the im- pression the interests of the Council arc snfii

cicutly safeguarded by the provisions of the Iramway Act 'Hare is a proNcrb about driwng a coach and fou- through an Act of Parliament, and train cars «c dare siy, will be drivcu as easily through one as the more cumbrous old-fashioned vehicle It is laid donn hy a political economist whose woiks arc attracting considerable attention at pre sent, that any work in the shape of a mono poly shoul 1 uot bo uu Icrtakiu by a company, and should be performed by the (,ot eminent Public opinion in the old country is setting very much in this direction, anil the lan 1 leasing mo; ement m the colonies is in indica ti m that the principle is being recognised here The tram« ay will he in the shape- of a monopoly, and it is, therefore, un loanable, if it eau be ii oidd, that it Bhould he placed in the hands of a company, cu n f r a time, especially as is the case when the company consists -is some of our aldermen pointed oui, oí une individual Altliounli the Couucil liai cn it determined on anything in respect to the tram« av, it is open to any ratepayer, or bo ly < f rati | ay ers, to petit i III agamst it, au 1 it rt mains for Al Iermau Williams in, and tin se «ho agree «ith linn to consider \\ hellier they eli mid II it let Hie (>o\ eminent hale an expression of public npuuou upon the proposed tramway scheme for RuckhauipLou

A meeting of the shareholders of the Gas Company was held on 1 hnrsday evening in the School of Arts It has been rcsoUcd to raise the capital of the company to £30 000, and to give the holders of ordiuary stock a primary opportunity of taking up the new sh ires An attempt was made to secure tho privilege of purchase on the same terms to preference shareholder, but the original shareholders dccliued to let the others partiel

pate In the discussion in the Council reference was made to the action of the Gas

Company ID tearing up the streets, and leaving them ia an unsatisfactory state till it suited their convenience to repair them This arises out of the powers and privileges con ferred on them by Act of Parliament, and the monopoly they enjoy of supplying the town with artificial light The Irani woy Act prov ides that the Council may purchase the tranway system after a time , and legal pro vismn has been made for them to acquire the Gasworks Ac It must be evident, however that the difficulty of propounding a scheme for the purchase of the works is one that only a bold, determined, and clever alderman will face Once let a public monopoly get hold and, Bathurst burr like it is difficult to eradicate Nevertheless gas works have been taken out of the hands of companies by corporations, and as in the caso of Dumfries, with the result that the price of gas to the public has been reduced fifty per cent When the capital of a company is inordinately in creased, and when the dividends are ex travagantly high, then it will became the duty of the Council to appoint valuers, fix the price, and buy out the GaB Company.

THE borough of North Rockhampton having been Gazetted, our Police Magistrate is taking the Bteps necessary in connection with the first election of aldermen An endeavour is beiug made in some quarters to stop the con stitution of the new Connell, but we are afraid matters have already gone too far for this being done Should the ratepayers not elect representatives, then it will be done hy tho Governor ID Council It is perhaps de Bimble, however, that those who have been moving in this matter should consider it more fully before further proceed logs are taken If they petitioned for a borough with boundaries which they described, and if the Government bave given them a restricted area, then they may have some grounds for asking thom to reconsider their judgment Unless, however, they take

immediate action the Council will be constituted It muBt he remembered, that they may then apply for amalgamation with Rockhampton, and perhaps the pro moters think they will he in a better position to come in if they are in the meantime inde pendent Single blessedness for a year or two may quicken the desire for union.

WE are pleased to learn good progress has been made with tbo collecting of money fur additions to tba boy's department of the Central School A new scheme has now been

devised, which we hope will receive the favourable consideration of the community and of the public At the end of tho block of land upon which the Town Hall isBituateii, there is a fine piece of ground, which was reserved for a Grammar behool, and as this institution has been ereoted upon another site it is thought that it might be avaded of for the boys' school An endeavour is about to be made to secure it for that purpose, and with every prespect of success, I he Committee have already collected upwards of £000 , the Government grant upon that will amount to £2400, so that £3000 will bo available for the erection of the new buildings It is a pity, wo think, that the amount contributed by the community could not be raiBed to £1000 and then the sum to be received from the Govern ment would be £1000 We might then bo able to have a first class boys' school and a building that would be an ornament and a credit to the town. We trust that the Com mittee will not abate m their efforts, and that they will be liberally supported by the membera of the community

TUE work of olearing away the rums of the debris of the fire at Lakes Creek has now been almost completed, and the reconstruction of the new buildings has been commenced In a shorter time than many anticipated flic works will be in active oporation With the present drought and scarcity of cattle much woi k could not have been done theagh the fire had not taken placo

THE weather continuos to bo very dry £cfreshingshowers have fallen in some parts of the colony, but they have not visited us

OUR cabio messages this «eck inform us that Sir Anthony Musgrave, the new Gol ernor of Queensland, left London on the 22nd in stant on board the Sorata, and will probably be here before Parliament meets A dreadful expl sion of rockets has taken place m an arsenal at Woolwich Ibey continued to go off for about an hour, and great alarm was created though much damage does not appear to have been done The Irish agitators are again ahowiug renewed activity, and the Lng líala Press is urging the Government to put down the Irish National League The examination into the circumstances attending the foundering of the Austral has resulted in the experts employed attributing the blaine for the disaster to the carelessness of the Pereons employed on board the steamer

ranee and China have not got their difficul

ties finally arranged, but are in a fair way of doing so upon the principle of division, China to receive one part of Anana and France

another

articleText:
KOCK HAMPTON.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 18S3.

MARYBOROUGH is sometimes regarded by Rockhampton people as an upsetting, bumptious place, with pretensions far beyond its importance. On the com- parative merits or the two towns thc residents in each are not perhaps the best judges. They are not without a fair proportion of that self-conceit, which

finds vent al limes in what in colonial

parlance is know» as blowing. It will be a pity, however, ii our little potty jealousies should load either to interfere with thc prosperity ol the other. Our objection to tin: sy'.em cf bundling members, which lins been advocated in connection with the Wide Hay electo- rates, is not lessened by the thought that

il will lead electors lo narrow the range of their political vision, and see less clearly the claims of their fellow colonists in other districts. There is every proba- bility that Maryborough, holding up to view ber own affairs, and regarding them from a near stand-point, will shut out the prospect of those of Rockhampton. A development of selfishness will be the natural consequence among the Mary boroughians, and the creation of enmity and antagonism among citizens of other communities. We are all members of one body politic, and

should seek to promote our own interests and those of the commu-

nity generally, without prejudice to either. When progress is brought about in a legitimate fashion we should all rejoice at it, for healthy activity in one part of our corporate system will not fail to act beneficially on every other. It is with great pleasure, therefore, we have perused a copy of the last issued Annual Report and Proceedings of the Mary- borough Chamber of Commerce. The borough on the Mary River, is an im- portant factor in our colonial progress and well-being, and this Report, our readers will be pleased to learn, shows that its commercial affairs are being managed by gentlemen of public spirit, enterprise, and business acumen and experience. Of all this the Report affords good evidence. At the annual

meeting, the Chairman, Mr. A. H. Wilson, while congratulating the Cham- ber on the amount of work done in the course of the year, stated that the trade of the town and district had improved, and was in a sound way. Now, it must give confidence to investors-and the eyes of capitalists in the southern colonies and the old country, scrutinise keenly the state of affairs in all parts of Queensland-to be told this by a gentleman resident in the locality, who holds a position of high respectability, and who, from his busi- ness relations, has an intimate and accurate knowledge of the course of trade and commerce in that district. From the Report itself we find that in the course of the year the Committee con- sidered and dealt with upwards of twenty matters of more or less public impor- tance. The town has been growing, and no sooner did the necessity for it appear

than the Chamber secured an extension

of the postal delivery. We noticed at the time they were made the efforts put forth by the Chamber of Commerce to bring Maryborough prominently before people in the United Kingdom, by issuing a pamphlet on the indus- tries and resources of the district, and large photographic views of the town and scenery in its vicinity, Specimens of the latter which have come under our observation are magnificent works of art, and could not fail to produce an excellent impression of the district wherever they were exhibited. It is something worth

thc while of our Chamber of Commerce lo know that these paid their own ex- penses. The money realised by the sale of photographs was ^146, and when all

the items of expenditure were summed up the deficiency in the account amounted to only ¿¿"5 17s. We have not the least hesitation in concurring with the remark made in the Report that this small sum would be more than compensated for by the benefits accruing to the district from the issuing of these photographs. Among other malters which received the attention of the Committee of the Chamber was the establishment of the telephone system of commercial communication. The Exchange was opened almost a year ago with thirty-two members, yet in less than eight months the number had risen to fifty, and we have no doubt it has since been increased. Here again, we have an evidence of business activity, and material wealth, that cannot fail to strike people at a distance, for in few places of the same population in the old country has the telephone system been established. The Report shows that the Committee have been keeping a sharp lookout on the progress of the river navigation improvements, and that if these are not so great

as could be wished it is no fault of the Chamber of Commerce. An important subject of general interest discussed by the Chamber, is the regis- tration of land. At present registration business must be done by the transmis- sion of papers, &c, to Brisbane. It is contended ilia*, great advantages would accrue to thc public and various com porate bodies, by establishing, in the principle towns in the colony, convenient offices for the registration of land. Among the most obvious of the advan- tages would be the prevention of delays which now take place. These in all localities, not in immediate communica- tion with Brisbane, are often exceedingly irritating and annoying. The Mary- borough Chamber have resolved to peti- tion Parliament on the subject ; and our Chamber ought to follow their example. The coastal mail service and its connection with Maryborough, the speed of trains on the local railways, the extension of the railway to the wharf, immigration, the inland mail service, the railway policy of the district-these and

other minor matters have also been dealt with in a practical business like fashion. If the minutes of our own Chamber of Commerce were gone through we are confident an equally interesting Report could be compiled ; and, when wc look at thc licit little pamphlet issued by the Maryborough Chamber, containing, besides the document referred to,

a great many statistics regarding the imports, exports, products, ¿.'C., of thc town and district, we ro^n't that llvs his not been done. Without :>ny intuition or iiistitiiliuc an invidious comparison we cannot help thinking our Maryborough friends luve taken the start of us in ll.is matter. They are ci iden:!)- keenly .-¡ive to the advantages of advertising themselves, and we have no doubt tile result is they rea]) the benefit in attracted labour ami capital. These ar;- th'.:;(;% which hive a considuubic ii:d .cure on the nialcriY.I prosperity of a community, and wc may congratulate thc people of Maryborough on having

in their midst business men on the alert and wide awake to the fact.

articleText:
KOCKM.WirrON.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1883.

I SOMB discussion has taken place in the

columns of our southern contemporaries on what we may call practical expressions I of nationalism, on the part of persons

resident in this colony. It has been excited hy the assertion that, in the general election just about over, the Germans gave a solid vo'.e fur thc Liberal Party. We will not co so far as a contemporary has done, and rcniaik " It is hardly an exaggeration to say that the Parliament now chosen is more representative of the German than the British section of the community, owing to the fact that the Germans hold the balance of power." That such a remark should seem warranted is in itself a mis- fortune. Without admitting that the Ger- mans itt our community hold thc balance of power lhere ran be no denying lite fart, that they possess a ronsitlerahlc amount ol nolilir.il influence, and that

they made it felt in the last election. Mr. Isamhert's scat fur Rosewood was felt to lie unassailable, and the political emisaties who visited several consti- tuencies, notably Maryborough and Wide Hay, fulfilled their mission care- fully and effectively. It is argued hy certain journals that the Germans have supported thc Liberal patty, because they had received no favours fur whir li lo thank the parly in power, lliuy Ind no sympathy willi the schemes of the pre- sent Government, and they desired to see a change of government. All these arc fair grounds of political action. If colonists do not approve of the politics of any parlv, it is clearly their privilege and their lunciion to ilismis'; th .-rn from powr. ll'it lint do s nut explain away the ciiciiat^tinces that

^ appeals were made to the Germans in !

their own language, and that they gave a solid, and, therefore, to some extent, unintelligent vote. There was a mani-

festation of nationalism above and

beyond party consideration.

Exception has been taken to a display of nationalism in another quarter. Il has been determined to bold a meeting of Irishmen in Melbourne, for the pur- pose of discussing Irish affairs, and bringing influence lo bear on the English Government in connection with them. Dr. O'Docherty, and Mr. Mac- rossan are to represent Queensland in this proposed convention. Of course, these gentlemen will find reasons for their conduct which will seem to them sound and good, and warranted by ex- perience and observation, and the principles of good Government Hut these reasons may not be so regarded by their fellow colonists of other nationalities. Indeed, they may seem far fetched, inequitable, and unjust to Englishmen and Scotchmen. Apart altogether from the reasonableness of the demands of the Irish for Home

Rule, comes thc question of the propriety of forcing it on public attention at present. Ireland has been thrown into a state of unrest and agitation ; blood has been shed ; and the material prosperity of the country sadly interrupted by the machinations of those, who have set themselves up to dictate on her behalf to the British Government. All colonists

may intend is to give moral support to their countrymen in the home of their nativity ; but the fact cannot be got rid of that such moral support has recently been utilised towards the accomplishment of diabolical purposes. Oulside of this, again, is the question as to the capability of colonists to discuss old county aff.iirs, and in doing so to appreciate at their true value circumstances that exist at the oilier side of the world.

From these remarks we think it must j be apparent that the display of nationa- lism is not a thing that ought to be regarded with favour in this colony,

or indeed in Australia. Men of all countries and creeds are here

engaged in forming a new nation. We have new interests lo study, novel physical circumstances lo deal with, and political institutions to found, and laws lo enact, which shall be productive of our happiness, and ihose who are to come after us. in this grand and majestic work it is the duty of every intelligent citizen to take part. Patriotism demands it of him ; public spirit calls upon him to sacrifice a portion of his means and his lime in it. Our duty to the colony commands, and should re- ceive precedence of all others. Though not so homogeneous as the nations of Europe, Australia occupies the position and possesses the interests of a nation. Our prosperity, if not our liberties and independence, point out to us that we should consolidate our national feelings and aspirations. We should strive to define and assert our individuality. That being so, it is clear thc manifesta- tions o! nationalism, to which we have referred, are objectionable. They must interfere with the great work we have on hand, and in which every elector is per- sonally interested. Whatever is calcu- lated lo mar thc harmony ol that work, in its progress or completeness, merits .reprobation. No one will deny that manifestations of foreign nationalism in a public and political manner will cer- tainly have this effect, and are, therefore, to be deprecated. They show an im- perfect comprehension of the magnitude of the work that lies before every citizen of this colony who think we should devote time and thoughllul

attention to the affairs of distant coun- tries, in Queensland we are the first generation of what we hope will be a great and powerful nation ; and we should let nothing come between us and our endeavour to make this country glorious and free-the home of a wise, prosperous, and happy people.
