articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

WEDNESDAY. JANUARY 31, 1883.

FROM late files of the home papers, we observe that the agitation among farmers in the United Kingdom, for the removal of the hindrances to agriculture, still continues. Judging from the earnest- ness and persistency with which the efforts for the alleviation of grievances are continued, a large number of gentle- men-practical agriculturists-still have great faith in the capabilities of the industry. They believe thal, under proper arrangements, the old country is capable of containing a large indepen- dent population. Landlords, however, display far more willingness than they were wont to listen to representations upon landholding in tenancy. Farmers and proprietors have discovered that in emigration there is a relief from the situation, when it is prejudicial to the

interests of the former. Factors cannot

now rudely domineer over tenants, because they have discovered the latter arc not afraid to leave their tenancies, and set out for Canada and the United States, in search of freehold farms. There can be no doubt thc landlords have given way to a large extent ; that the tenants now enter upon farms on more equitable terms, so far as they are concerned : and that the competion for land is not so keen as it was five years ago. Still the farmers societies are not relaxing in their efforts to make thc position of tenants as easy and comfoi table as possible. In the Agricultural Gazette of November i gib, wc have the report of a meeting of the Central Farmers' Club, at which the Secretary, Mr, Dmce, read a most in

teresting paper on Farm Tenancies. The English farmers have not that antipathy to landlords, which their congeners^ in Ireland display, and discuss the question of tenancies without once raising that of abolition. It is the conditions and mode of farm tenute, which are regarded as forming the foundation stone, not only of the farmers' individual prosperity,' but of his usefulness to the whole nation.

I Landlordism is not the hateful thing

depicted recently by a writer in the Victorian Review, and English tenants are quite content to hold land on lease, provided the terms are mutually agree-

able.

Among the principal points noticed by Mr. Druce, as forming ' the subject of differences between landlords and tenants, is the length of contracts. Should farms be held under lease for a fixed number

of years, or by yearly agreements ? This question he answered by advocating yearly tenancies. At the same time he mentioned a case in which, under the long leasing system, a farm had been held by one generation after another of the same family for nearly two hundred years. He gave it as his opinion, however, that the form of holding most popular among farmers is a yearly tenancy, with twelve months notice to quit.. The advantages of this system are that, as landlords and tenants dislike changes, they can go on easily under yearly tenancies. If hard times come, and the tenant is oppressed by a succession of bad seasons, he can enter ,into a new agreement with his landlord, or get rid of his farm without much trouble. In the case of a farmer's death, moreover, the tenancy can be at once brought to a close, and the farmer's affairs more promptly settled than under the leasing system, Modifications of the latter system have been introduced on some estates, which, Mr. Druce says, have operated well. On Lord Tollemache's property, for instance, the farms are let on a twenty-one years' lease; but may be terminated at any time by the tenant giving a year's notice. This shows how far landlords are now prepared to go, in order to propitiate tenants ; and under what favourable conditions farming may now be carried on in England.

Among the Statutes relating to agri- culture the law of distress has become exceedingly obnoxious. It gives the landlord power, when the tenant is in arrears, to seize the crop, stock, and implements on a farm, and sell them for the rent, regardless of the claims of other creditors. This law has been loudly complained of by merchants and machinists, because it has happened that a larmer, in apparently good circum- stances, has obtained manures, feeding stuffs, household necessaries, and implements on credit. Afterwards when the sellérs sought payment they have found the whole of their goods had been escheated to the landlord for rent. The result has been that farmers can only get credit to a limited extent. Besides, under: the obnoxious statute referred to, agisted stock, and hired implements on the farm could be seized and sold for the landlord's behoof. There is every probability that, owing to the manner in which this matter has been pressed on the attention of Parliament, the land- lord's right of distraining will be limited to one year's rent, and that agisted stock, and borrowed implements will not be liable to seizure. In these circumstances there will be a chance for other creditors

to get something out of a bankrupt

farmer's estate.

Another topic to which Mr. Druce called attention was " Restrictive Cove- nants." By this be meant agreements binding farmers down to certain systems of cropping. On some estates farmers had almost no freedom in cultivating the land. They were bound down to a rota- tion of crops, and had to cultivate, in a sense, by the book. In writing upon this subject we have pointed out that there was a time in the history of agri- culture in England, when the tenants were so ignorant and thriftless, it was good for them to have their work cut out for them. A change bas taken place within the present century. The tenants are among the most intel- ligent classes in the community, and know more about farming than the land- lords. With regard to the system ol husbandry to be pursued in cultivating the land, owners have had to give way, and though tenants cannot do just as they please with the land, they have a large amount of freedom. So long as he does not impoverish the farm, and spoil it for another tenant, the farmer can grow what crops he pleases. Where long leases exist the tenant is free to follow any rotation of cropping he chooses, till within four years of thc end of the term. In these years he must not sell off hay, straw,. chaff, ot roots to the detriment of his holding.

Another matter in which thc claims of tenants are meeting with recognition is the right they have to unexhausted im- provements. The obstacle in this matter has been the difficulty of estima- ting the value of unexhausted capital left in a farm. It seems to be concluded that with care and attention a class ol valuers may be created, on whom everj reliance could be placed. Every out- going tenant, it is contended, should have absolute security to be com pensated, in respect of every improve- ment he may have made upon his farm or, in other words, in respect of every- thing he may have done on or to the farm which may have increased its letting value as a farm ; and that the measure of such compensation should be the value of the improvement to the out- going tenant's successor. From this it will be seen that the landlords' profits from their farms are being reduced to the bare rent. The " extras," on which many of them relied lo assist them in their contracts, will nut be available ir

future.

The course of agricultural agitations and movements in the old country can only possess a secondary interest to fanners in this colony. Here every one is his own landlord. But land-letting has already commenced ia our more

cultivated districts, and it is of some consequence that the evils which have pertained to iï in the United Kingdom and'ilreland, "and have been the source pf many troubles, should be carefully avoided.- This will be done, if our farmers, from time to time, consider the points under dispute in the home countries.. i° ' » . > .'

AT the criminal aittings of the District Court, in Rockhampton, a eonditiou of de- pravity in the Drummond Rango neighbour- hood was disclosed that* is by no means gratifying. From this looality uo less than two cases of malicious wounding were brought up. In one instance-that of the man Paap -it ie impossible any one could fail to observe an amount of depravity that, in a supposed moral community,, is disgusting. It would seem that this unfortunate man is possessed of a wife to whom he may attribute being branded as a criminal. This woman evidently was upon terms of improper intimacy with the complainant Jones, which had aroused the feelings of jealousy in her husband that led him to commit tho offence of which he was found guilty, and which might have brought him to the gallows. Paap a cripple-goaded to desperation,-made thc attack upon Jones, who admitted the criminal intimacy existing between himself and the prisoner's wife. There was something that appealed to the sympathy of all honest men in Paap's plea to the jury-the man Jones had openly endeavoured to persuade his wife to leave bim, had struck ànd. mal-

treated him, atad lie had no power to rid him- self of this ruffian. This contains the pith of the whole occurence. His Honor, as au administrator of the law, was bound to look upon the offence with severity. "The law," ho observed, "must protect life and limb," but how hard for the weaker man to keep within the law, while every feeling that renders the words home, ohildren, brother, sister, the loving ties upon which happiness depends, was being outraged before his eyes. Still moro brutally heartless is the wife's con- duct to willingly become the paramour of her husband's persecutor and prosecutor while that husband was io prison. The other case from the Drummond Range did not present the same features, but exhibited an amount of dastardly cowardice on the part of the accused, that is more aggravated when it is remembered that he and his victim are fellow

countrymen-Swedes. We think there is ' room for missionary work about Drummond Range. The conditions of daily life are not what they should be.

A WOMAN named Mrs. Fairhurst was ad-

mitted to the Hospital yesterday suffering from Beverat severe scalds in different parts of her body. She was employed as cook in the Victoria Hotel, Denham-street. Whilst lifting a boiler containing hot water her foot slipped on the boarding and the contents of the boiler were upset on her.

BEFORE the Polios Magistrate yesterday morning, Peter Buckley pleaded guilty to having assaulted Joseph Cully, and was fined £1 with £1 6B. Gd. professional and Court costs. A similar oharge, of abusive language brought by T., Vf. Foley against defendant, was withdrawn. Mr. JoneB ap- peared for Cully, and Mr. R. A. Brumm for

defendant.

TBE notorious James Keogh waa again arrested last night, and will appear -before the Police Magistrate this morning, While in a state of drunkenness he used most filthy language, to the annoyance of residents io Quay-street, and forcibly resisted his arrest. Constable 'Livingstone >was assisted by some oivilians in securing Keogh, who was stripped to the buff, and as the weather was somewhat warm the delinquent was a somewhat slippery customer to bring along.

WE noti.ee that Messrs..W. Howard Smith' and Sons' steamship Derwent, is in command of Captain W. Hill for' this trip, Captain Bristow having been granted leave of absence; Captain HUI was for many years in the A.S.N. Company's service, and was almost' Continuously .engaged in : trading to this port. During that time he became very popular with the mercantile community, ^shippers, and passengers, who will doubtless be glad to see him once more in command of a steamer.

THE Mastodon Minstrels' repeated their second programme last evening. There was a fair attendance in all parts of the house except the front seats. The various items offered were rendered in the Company's usual style some of the vocal selections being well applauded, and the farces provoking consider- able mirth. The farce " Put up your.thumb"

was very fairly rendered and the clog tourna- '

meut aa usual was well executed and received. An entire change of programme is notified for this eveniog when among other novelties the " Sand Jig Tournament "will he offered :

UNDER tho auspices of the Half Holiday Association the brass band of the Mastodon Minstrels will perform choice selections of music in the Cremorne Gardens, this afternoon. They will also play dance music, so that those who delight in the light fantastic will have an opportunity of enjoying themselves in the mazy dance in tho rotunda. Prizes will he given for boys' and girls' races, and a special match at quoits has been arranged. The amusements will be tinder the personal super- vision of the Committee, so that the publio may rely upon the company being select. A small charge for admission will be made, and those who visit the grounds in the afternoon will have the privilege of entering at night, when the gardens will be illuminated.

TUE examination of candidates for Grammar School scholarships, being pupils of State Schools under the Department of Public Instruction, was held ou the )9th and 20th December last, when eighty-eight boys and thirty-one girls were examined. Scholarships, the currency of which will terminate on the 31st December, 1885, have boen granted to thirty boys and nine girls. Thcro was only one girl from Rockhampton competed in tho examination, Hud it does not appear ehe was successful. Wo understand the reason why no boys went forward was, that in presenting them, thc teacher who duos so must declare

that he believes thc pupil is qualified to pass, and that he will accept the scholarship gained by him. This latter affirmation some of the teachers could not make, because the boys would not have accepted the scholarships, having offers of remunerative situations in shops and offices. But for this counter attrac- tion several boys might have passed. I

-^THE ship Melpomene, 1308 tons, in confix

rnihsd of Captain Bridges, cast anchor at the mouth of the river yesterday afternoon after a voyage of 106 days from Plymouth, which port sho left on the IC th October last, Messrs. Walter Kcid and Co., thc agents of thc vessel, received a telegram from the ca|)taiu containing thc cheerful news that "all was well ou board." The Melpomene left homo with 440 immigrants, eijual to 3S3", statute adults, under the charge of Dr. Cunningham, as Surgeon superintendent, and Mrs. (jaudin as matron. We published thc classification list last week. Among the new arrivals are eighty-two female domestic servants, 132 farm labourers, and a number of mechanics. Of theso there

are ßixty married couples, 130 single men, and eight-eight single women. In the present state of thc labour market, the immigrants Bhould readily meet witli engagements. We understand Dr. Harricks, thc Immigration Agent (Mr. H. Cribb, P.M.), and the repre- sentative of llic ship's agents were to leave in thu Bunyip last night, and would tranship into the Fitzroy Bteamer for the purpose of visiting the Melpomene, Should the immi

grant! >p»s«'th« lunal impaction they will, probably bo brimght to town in theßovenn,»

mentateamer this afternoon. . i¿¿ r/^PB reader* will t» pleaaed to learn bhiV Mr. Wm. Pattison, Chairman of the Gogango''. Divisional Board, has been putting our aouthern contemporaries right regarding the payment of the dinner to the Premier. After ?noticing the- (nieleadiog statement in the ' Toowoomba' ChrinieU, Mr. Pattison says :

"I have the honour to be the Chairman of the Gogango,,- Board, and agreed ito defray one-half of the expenses of the banquet given to Sir Thomas M'llwraith, the Mayor of Rockhampton paying the other half. The members of my Board hare never refused to sanction the payment of the account, for the simple reason that the account has nothing to do with them,' and has never been brought before thom' in any shape, nor was it ever

intended that it should be. The accounts

were promptly paid by the Mayor and myself as soon fes rendered, each paying onr 'half sa arranged. I am pleased to Bod that Rook hampton properly enjoys the reputation of being hospitable to all visitors, quite setting aside party considerations, and I hare yet to learn that any disputes have ever taken place in regard to payment Sir Thomas M'll- wraith is not the first Queensland Minister that has been entertained by the Chairman nf thc Gogango Divisional Board, and that not out of tho Board's funds, but in every case out of the private purse of the Chairman." Mr. Groom, M.L.A., editor bf the Chronicle; hos no remarks to make on Mr. Pattison's letter-not even an apology for his insinua-

tion.

, IT will be seen by advertisement elsewhere that Mr. G. S. Curtis will offer for. sale at ¿is rooms to-day, some valuable blocks of land fronting thc Upper Dawson Hoad, in which, aro a comfortable cottage, Blacksmiths' Forge, and large Bhopl The remainder of the apletiid assortment of manufactures of Irish Art will also be put up without any reserve.

ALDRKcnr, FEEZ has just landed, direct from home,' 60 cases superior Still and' Sparkling Hocks and Moselle (in quarts and pints), equal in quality to the best'brands of champagne, and at most moderate prices; also, 100 cases of Morbit's Patent Stopper Lager Beer (in pints). Inspection invited.

articleText:
KOCKIIAMI' TON.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1883.

FROM the recurrence, at short intervals, of discussions on the alienation of the public lands of the colonies, we think it may be inferred that public opinion on this' question is undergoing a change. Already the people who have not are looking askance on the people who have land, and the question is being asked why should the land, which istlie common inheritance of the people of Australia, for all time coming be shut up in the hands of a limited number of individuals ? The subject of land-holding is of widespread interest, and its importance will increase with that of population. The axiom is being laid down-that no generation can claim the right to deal with the land so as to prejudice the claims of succeeding generations to its enjoyment. Though this seems a proposition, of which the truth will meet with general recognition, it is not one that can be recognised in practice, unless the people are to be content to wander about the country like blackfellows. If the prin- ciple involved in the saying were strictly carried out there could be no mining, because every ounce of gold, for instance, taken out of the land by one man, and spent by him for his own gratification, would be prejudicial to the interest of the person who succeeded him on the land where the gold was

[n*\r\A_XJxo lntfrrtr jauld - -pnan.My

get any advantage (rom the gold which had been appropriated by his prede- cessor. In iike manner, if a man cut down, and consumed the timber on a piece of country he would by that act be touching theclaims of his successors. The farmer who crops the land heavily, who robs the soil of the elements essential to the production of certain crops,

makes the land of less value to whoever comes after him, From these considera- tions it will be apparent that it would be impossible to deal with the land at all, without some prejudice to the rights of

others.

Viewing the land as a heritage, it is argued, handed down to us by the last generation in trust for the next, we can fulfil that trust only by handing down to them the same power of dealing with their heritage as we have, and we cannot do that if we alienate the land. If the land were disposed of without an equivalent value being received there might be some force in this reasoning But that is not the case. The land is not dystroyed. Its capabilities of yielding food for the occupants is unimpared by a change of owners, and if the State which parts with it owns less ¡and, it perhaps owns instead remunerative public works of general utility, and the benefits of which accrue to succeeding generations. In this connection it is contended there can be no personal ownership over that which cannot be produced by personal labour, and land being of this charhcter,

cannot become property. But we can- ] not produce minerals by personal labour, and if this argument is to be recognised, a man has no right to alienate the iron ore ol which machinery is formed, or part with the stones and lime with

which houses are built.

It is impossible, however, to regard with indifference the advantages it is said would be derived by the adoption of the leasing system as applied to all public lands. At present the bulk of the lands in New South Wales, it is alleged, are owned by persons who are paying the banks seven, eight, nine, and even ten per cent, on borrowed purchase money. That revenue has been diverted from its proper destina- tion- the public treasury - by land dealers. If the land of the parent colony were leased at threepence an acre, it is calculated the annual income from that source would be £1,650,000, instead of about £272,053 as at present. The area of Crown lands leased in Queensland in 1881 was 273.7Ú3>933 > and if we could obtain bul one penny an acre of rent the annual revenue therefrom would be upwards of one million pounds sterling, and nearly as much as we at present realise from taxation, and the territorial revenue of the Colony. Were the lettini; value increased a penny an acre the proportional annual increase in revenue would bc upwards of a million pounds. If lo this revenue were added the income from public works, such as railways, the necessity for imposing cither direct or indirect taxation would be completely obviated, As the

popution/ increases the demands oí

the Government shall increase-the. public expenditure must naturally grow greater; but at the same -time the value of the land will rise rapidly. Land, instead of letting at a few pence an acre, will bring some shillings. The area of the. colon)' is 668,224 square miles. Suppose thal

400,000 square miles were let at one, penny an acre, or fifty shillings a square mile, the annual revenue would be a million pounds sterling. But if the rent : were increased to twenty pence an acre, : the annual income would then be seventy million sterling. With such an income,

added to the revenue from remunerative: public works, there would be no neces- sity for either local or general taxation.

Tim apparent inability of the British I Government to. interfere in the labour traffic

that has been going on in the New Hebrides is to be regretted, as nothing is more likely to prevent the possibility of obtaining labour from there, under proper regulations, than permitting indiscriminate emigration. So long as the natives are fairly treated they become useful labourers, and a great acquisi- tion to a semi-tropical country -, but if kid- napping is permitted the result will be to prevent the Kanakas coming of their own free will. It will be remembered that not long since, a Committee of, the House ol Commons, was appointed to inquire into the outrages iu

the South Pacific, but apparently so far no ? good result has been obtained. The several

instances in which thc Islanders cruelly. butchered whites some months' ago will bc fresh in the memory of our readers and sn inquiry into the nausea that produced their treachery would have been watched with interest. Of course some attempt was made to punish the natives, but there is no guarantee that the actual perpetrators of the crimes wç£gM£he ones who really suffered, Seeing ho ^satisfactory the statement of Lord Dertj is with reference to thc New Hebrides, and hearing nothing of the Com- mission of Inquiry into the outrages, it seems the prospect of affairs in the Pacific beiug

ameliorated is rather remote. The Kanaka

! is of great importance to Queensland. The men have been found good workers and con- tented, and the difficulty in obtaining them is not on account of the treatment they get in this colony,-or at the hands of our Govern- ment, but on the account of the way in which unscrupulous persons-principally seeking

labour for South America-treat them.

TUB Customs collections at this port from the 1st to the 10th inclusive, amounted to

£2633 Os. 4d.

AT the Police Court on Saturday morning before the Police Magistrate, a drunkard was cautioned and discharged.

PROFESSOR and Madame Lorenski gave an entertainment iu the Theatre Royal on Saturday night. The place was nearly empty.

DURING.Saturday and Sunday the weather was exceedingly pleasant, though in the after- noons heavy thunderstorms came up from the north-east. On Saturday there was a rery good downpour, the rain-gauge registering 0 47. On Sunday the Bbower was not nearly so heavy. At Marlborough, on Saturday, a terrific storm was experienced in tte after- noon, as much as 4'31 inches of r»in being registered. The country around Rockhampton looks very fresh after the showes, and the crops will be greatly benefited.

MR. F. JOHNSON arrived ia town from Banana yesterday morning witt sixty head of

horses for Messrs. Rutherford Brothers. While at Banana he marched the well-known w.. Ki, «I the Ring agaiust Mr. F. M'Lean's Scratch Gravel for £25. Tho dis tance was H mile; owuera up. The King carried 10 st, 10lbs., and was easily beaten by bis opponent, carrying Oat. 10lbs. Judging from the performance, tho King has fallen off in pace.

As a caution to drovers travelling the Raglan road with stock, we may mention that Mr, E. Crois very nearly lost a valuable mare on Thursday night through an attack by an alligator. lie had turned a number of mares and foals into a paddock. One of tho marcB went down to tho creek to drink, and au alli- gator made a grab and severely injured ber eye. As she wheeled round thc saurian tore her shoulder, but luckily tho animal got

away.

A CORRESPONDENT write« that Mr, C. White, of Wooroona station, leaves for Rockhampton next month with a mob of oattlo. Mr. Wright is mustering fat cattle at Nulalbin station for Lake's Creek, and intends sending three lots down. The country on the other sido of Fairfield r station looks

well, and station-holders are satisfied with the

condition of their stock. Several heavy gales of wind have been experienced in that neigh bouihood, succeeded by thunderstorms.

THE Leichhardt s.s. arrived yesterday, in charge of Captain E. Jeune, who has command of her during Captain Cottier's absence on a visit to Sydney, Captain

Jeune states the tide at Gladstone on Friday was the highest known for the last twelve months, and washed away the Gladstone Floating Baths. The Leichhardt made two attempts to come up the river on Saturday night, but owing tn tho vivid lightning she had to anchor till yesterday morning. She loaves this morning at eleven, taking the the Dorunda'a maila for Bundaberg aud Maryborough.

MK. GOEBEL, who not long since brought in some fine samples of a peculiar fruit, known as the " rose apple," has again favoured us with a specimen of the " whampee." Having neglected to ask Mr. Goebel whether thc fruit was iuteuded to be eaten, we tested some of it, with resulta satisfactory from an experi- mental point of view, but we are unable to decide whether tho fruit is unripe or our taste a little wrong. To any person who acquires a taste for " whampees," we think they would bo very nice, and possibly he would caro for no other fruit. The real mission of this pro- duction is evidently to be preserved,

TBS immigrants per tho Dorunda arrived in town yesterday afternoon, having been brought up the river in the steam launch Mabel. Mr. Cribb, the immigration agent, was in attendance, and on arrival at thc wharf thc new-comers were conducted to the depot, where they are at present awaiting employ- ment. There were 50 immigrants in all-10 single men (of whom one has gone to Bi isbauc end one not in depot), 10 single girls (two going to Brisbane), and 9 married couplus (two tor Brisbane). One girl got off at Mackay. Generally the new arrivals seem a very desirable lot, and should soon meet with engagements. There are besides these in the depot about 18 couples aud C Bingle girls remaining of the Melpomene contingent, but thc girls are not for hire.

AuDiUist, Rev. Robert Hartley, the Par- sonage, Yaamba Road, North Rockhampton.

Ai.DittcriT FICKZ hos just lauded, direct from home, 00 casca superior Still and Sparkling Hocks ami MoBelle (in quarts aud pints), equal iu quality to tho liest brands of chain imune, and at moat moderate prices; also, 100 casca of Murhit's Patent Stopper Laj;cr Beer (iii pint«) Inspection invited.

AIIVT.

d .--.naKS Pol-L-LiTION AND EMIQKATION.

Considerable attention ii being drawn by

statisticians/to the great rate of increase both of the population and emigration throughout Germany. The population ot Prussia, in- creased between 1816 and 1801 from 10,350,000 to 19,260,000, while up to 1875, inclusive^ had mounted up to 21,500,000, or 105 percent in sixty years. From 1875 to 18S0 the popu- lation of all the German States has been in- creasing at about 525.000 per annum. At the 'lastjcensos, in December, 1880, the number of

inhabitants was 45,250,000, which, if main- tained at the same rate, would be 00,000,000 in 1900. The increase, as compared with! that of France, is very remarkable,

the French population during the last' five years showing an increase of only! 389,000; while the increase of the Ger-1 man population daring the same period was . 2.000,000, the birth-rate in the latter country 1 being 3 91 per 100, whereas in France it is : only 2'47. There is also this great difference between the two, that in France the increase

has been almost entirely in the large towns, 1 whereas in Germany the increase is general throughout the country as well as the towns. The number of immigrants that have left Germany during the last silty years is over 3,500.000, of whom the greater part have

taken their departure within the last thirty : years, the Ignited States having absorbed in 1881 no;less than 248,323. Dr. Friederich Kappe estimates the amount taken away by each emigrant at no less than 450 marks, or '£22 10J., eo that the «apital transferred to fche^nited States during last year amounted directly to £6,587,267. And this, it should be remembered, ¡8 not returnable to Germany in the ordinary ways of trade or commerce, aa, iopoint of fact, the German emigrants to the United States become Americans, and, consequently, competitors with Germany in

agricultural and industrial pursuits. Dr. Engel considers that the cost of bringing np a young person of the lower or middle classes to the fifteenth year is about £200, and he estimates that thc loss to Germany during the emigration of the last sixty years, in cash and valuables taken by each emigrant, at over nine milliards of marks, nearly twice the amount of thc war iudeinnity paid by France in 1871.

CLYDE SHIPPINC.-The tonnage of shipping launched from the shipbuilding yards on thc Clyde during November, 1882, amounted, tho Scotsman states, to 47,310 tons, and largely exceeds that of any previous month, being 5500 tous over the output in June (41,810 tons. ) As compared with thc tonnage launched in the corresponding month in 1881, Novem- ber, 1882, shows an increase bf 14,944 tons, and as compared with the previous ten months' average, the increase is 17,456. For the eleven monthB the total of 345,845 tons is 64,044 tons over that of the Esme period last year, and more than double that of' 1879, The eleven months' output of the year ie 13,977 tons over the aggregate tonnage built during the whole of 1881. Of the vessels launched there were 15 steamers, 1 hopper dredger, 9 sailing ships, and 3 iron flats. The sailing ships .lauuehed reached in. all 15,266 tons-nearly three times the total pf any other month of 1882. Two of the steamers aggre- gated 10,100 tone, and five others 11,800 tons. The average size of the vessels launched in November was 1700 tons, and during the eleven months 1360 tons, as against 1200 and 1320 tons respectively for the pprreaponding periods last1 year.- The number of vessels in course of construction is ,133, a decrease of 'seven as compared With the number at the close of October, and 21 less than at the close of May.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE TELEPHONE

SYSTEM.-The marvellous growth of the tele- phone system during the six years (nearly) that have elapsed since that instrument was brought out is well shown by statistics recently published by the Compagnie Internationale des Telephones, and relating to telephonic systems throughout the world at the beginning of October, 1882. The compilation is neces- sarily incomplete somewhat as regards small and distant places, but the value of the main results is not thereby much impaired. It is in America, of course, where telephony is freer than on this side, that the development has been greatest. New York counts 4060 subscribers ; Chicago, 2726 ; Cincinnati, 1880 ; Boston. 10,325 ; San Francisco, 1300, &c. Some of these figures refer to May. There are now in the United States more than 100,000 subscribers, and cortain small towns, with population less than 1000, have yet thirty to lifty telephonic subscribers, some even more, As regards the absolute number of subscribers, Paris comes third, after New York and Chicago ; it had on October 1 no fewer than 2,422 subscribers, while London had only 1,900. Amsterdam 700, Stockholm 672, Vienna 900, Berlin 581, Brussels 450, Turin 410, Copenhagen 400, Mexico, 300, St. Petersburg 145, and Alexandria 118. While the annual subscription is 600 francs in Paris, 500 francs in London, and 409 francs in the provincial towns of France, it descends to 300 francs and 200 francs in Belgium, 135 francs and 130 francs in Italy, and only 120

francs in Switzerland. A calculation of the ratio of the number of subscribers to that of

inhabitants for each town reveals a goodly

number of small towns in America where

there is a telephone for every twenty inhab- itants ; in Chicago and in Zurich, the pro- portion is about one per 200 ; in New York, one per 500 ; in Brussels, one per 800 ; in Paris, about one per 1,000 ; in Berlin, one per 2.000 ; in London, one per 3,000 ; and in St. Petersburg, only one per 4,000.

TUE STATE OF IRELAND.-A correspondent writing to the St. James's Gazette, December 8, describing a short visit to Ireland, says, " Though a native of the Green Isle, and having Bpent forty years of my life there, and therefore well acquainted with its people, I

do not remember ever to have found intelli- gent and enterprising Irishmen of all classes and creeds eo hopeless and dispirited,' I speak not of landlords and agents, but of manufacturers, merchants, professional men 'men of light and leading,' whose future is bound up with the country. The lawyers, it is true, are reaping a harvest. The land laws are occupying every solicitor and solicitor's derk, in some places night and day ; but everything else is at a standstill. The labourers are unemployed. All improve- ments in land have ceased. In the fairs and markets you see ragged peasants driving fat pigs to bc sold ; the pigs aro fat, but the men

are half-starved. Graziers and cattle dealers

also fl'iurish ; but thc potato crop is a failure,

and thc fuel is unsaved. To usc a common ex- ¡ pression, God only knows what is to become of thc poor. Another Arrears Bill will he wanted next year. I will give you two or three facts of another kind, which will show the effect of this reign of terror and plunder. First, property purchased 20 years ago with a parliamentary title, and costing 27 years' purchase, cannot now be sold for 17 years' purchase. The tenants will not buy ; they are better off as they are. Capitalists will not buy. There is no settled and civilised state in tho world where property is not more securo than in Ireland. Secondly, I have applied to several assurance companies to assure mills and other property in Ulster, and all have declined risks in Ireland. Thirdly, mer who have bad, or thought they had, pro- perty in Ireland formerly had no difficulty in raising a moderate amount (say one-third the value), on mortgage ; now one of the largest dealers in trust funds in Lancashire publicly stated that he would no more invest money in Ireland than bc would in the Turkish debt or Zulu bonds, if there were such securities. What is to become of my unhappy country Î At thc present time there is not a single gleam of light."

REMARKABLE CASE or MISTAKEN IDENTITY. -A most remarkable case of mistaken

identity took plitce in connection with the suicide which occurred on the tramway in Elizabeth-street, Sydney, on the 16th ultimo. For some time after the occurrence the deceased remained unidentified. The city coroner, on the ISth instant, commenced an inquest on thc body, aud a woman, giving the name of Jane Fowler, and describing horself as a dressmaker living in Goulhurn-street, who had viewed, the body of the deceaned in thc Sydney Hospital morgue, was called to give evidence. She swore positively that th« body was that of ber husbaud, and tendered other testimony with regard to his identifica- tion, Sis name, one «aid, WM John Fowler,

and be had been living apart from her for the last two years. Her evidence waa taken down in the customary manner by the coroner, and at the conelnsion -of the inquest the jury found that the -aaid John Fowler had committed suicide by throw- ing himself in front of a tram motor. The deceased was buried in due course. To the

[ great astonishment of Mrs. Jane Fowler her

husband presented himself iu the flesh at her house yesterday. She was so astonished at first that she could not account for the circum-

stances at the' time, but ultimately She dis- i covered that she had mistaken the deceased i for her husband, and had unknowingly sworn to his identification. Io appearance tho

deceased very much resembled the individual1 for whom the wife of the latter had taken. him. The matter was made known to the

coroner yesterday afternoon by a visit to

that gentleman's office ot Mr. and Mrs.. Fowler, accompanied by their son, who was Srepared to bear testimony to the fact that

is mother had altogether mistaken another. man for his father on the occasion referred to.

Up to the present time it is not known who '

the deceased man is. j

1 CORRESPONDENCE. j

¡ POLICE REGULATIONS.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIR,-Not being acquainted with the above regulation«, will you kindly inform me and the general publia if the police in the oonntry districts and elsewhere are allowed to trade in horses, cattle, sheep, 4c, and also to devote a large portion of their time to looking after their own stock, thereby neglecting their official duties. In some places they have been known to carry on butchering, selling opium to the aboriginals, and otherwise oarrymg on busi- ness. This is a loss to country storekeeper« in different districts. I have, always been of the opinion that a constable could not do ao, bnt it is being carried oa daily. I have observed it in my travels thrangh the country. Now, if such a state of things is allowed, I think it would be as well to revise the Police Regulations at once, as it is of great impor- tance to business people; and if it is not allowed by the regulation« a stop should be pat to such proceedings st once, as we do not want constables to be horse-dealers, store- keepers, sfeo. Kow, Mr. Editor, if you will kindly gi ve me some information reía tir o to the above question you will mnch oblige.

.tours, so.,

IOXOBAUVS.

Bookbampton, June 22,1883.

[Send the nemes of the trading constables to the Chief Commissioner of Police, and you will aoon oesse to have cants of complaint. EB, Jkf.A]

TO THE EDITOl! OF THU MORNING nUIXF.TlN.

Slit,-I wish to take exception to a letter in the A rori*, in which thc writer stigmatizes the cahmeu as flash men. On behalf of the respectable licensed drivers, I wish to mention that we do our best, to act in accordance with the stringent clauses of the Municipal hyc

lawa, and when a breach is committed, any- 1 ene is quite at liberty to initiate step» to punish the offender,

No donut, aa in other indattries, there are cabmen «ho misbehave themselves, and surely when one of larrikin propensities does so, Civii would not have respectable Knights of the Whip blamed. With reference to the horses I can say they are not such poor miserable brutes as Civia represents them to be. ; Yours, fcc.,

A CABDRIVER.

^hf^UvniHjifuUcti»,

ROC li I IA M I' ION.

MONDAY. JULY lo, 1883

-^

IN any scheme of land nationalisation, which may be introduced into this or any other colony which draws us popu lation and civil institutions from the United Kingdom, one of the strongest antipathies required to be overcome will be to the payment of rent What our new land hw reformers aim at is tbc reten tion of the soil of the country in the hands of the State, and its permanent inahenation They would not allow another acre of the public estate to be sold, so as to become a private freehold, devoted to the uses of one individual These proposals already meet with con stderable opposition, and tor various reasons Among these is the objection to land leasing, even from the State Landlordism by the Government, when

».."_ J *-t *.*».- .* w ""ti i?attt

sans, against a political enemy, it is said, may be made the means of oppression and wrong It is unfortunately the case that the experience of tenants under the leasing system has led to a general aver sion to it Immediately that it is men boned, the conditions of leases present themselves, and the difficulties of carrying on agricultural pursuits pro gressively under them, become the the subject of animadversion But they speak too much, we are afraid, from ex penence of a perverted system, and not from dispassionate consideration of the capabilities of the leasing system No European country has had a fair trial of land leasing by the State Under the feudal system, the land was alienated by the Crown to the most powerful warriors, who became in consequence the large landlords They entailed their eslates, confirmed the possession of them in

their families, and rendered a system of land letting the only one consistent with the practice and progress of husbandry When the landowners became dependent

on the income from their estates for the means of keeping up their rank and state, they had to devise means by which this might best be accomplished Then leases were derived In framing these the tenant had no part. I hey »vere drawn by the landlord or his agent, and entirely in his interest No one was compelled to accept the lease unless he chose But those who had devoted their lives to farming had no other resource, and rather than be driven from reaping the fruits of the ground, which bad been .occupied by their father* before them, they agreed to the covenant In this way farming has been brought to a poor pass in the United Kingdom, and the desire to hold their own land in fee simple, has caused so many farmers to emigrate to America Hence also the feeling they entertain against land letting in any shape or form

It will appear, however, uoon con sidcration that leases, drawn by the best minds in an intelligent coinmunit), for fur the purpose of making the land secure the greatest good of the greatest number in the community, would he very différent from those under which farming has been carried on in the United King dom 1 he element of time, for instance, would be looked at in a very different aspect from what it has been under con tracts with private individuals In 1 ng land and Ireland the lands were let for one >ear only, so that if there was an improvement in the condition of the farmers affairs, the landlord might have an opportunity of profiting at once by the circumstance It has long been a ground of complaint among Lnglish far mers, that they had no inducement to improve their methods of husbandry as

tin ir effoits in that direction never met nith adequate reward As soon as they used improved implements, applied arti ficial manures, and secired an increased return from the land, the proprietor was ready to demand an increased share. Ia Scotland the leases were

made longer, and extended in some cases to twenty-one years If the tenant got his land cheap at the outset he had a chance of making a little money before the close of the term But he had always to make up his mind to pay an increased rental in order to secure a a renewal of the lease Rather than lose their holdings farmers took the land at an increased rental, which, upon trial they found it would not afford, and then

came ruin There could not be much

difficulty, we think, in arranging better periods of leasing in this colony Pastoral leases, for instance, might range from ten to twenty years, according to the position and conditions of the run Where fencing and water conservation is required to be done, the tenant should have an extended lease, in order that he might be able to recoup himself for any trouble and time he might spend on the improvement of the property An agri

cultural or a horticultural lease should be much longer, at least for many years to come, than a pastoral one, because a considenble time must elapse even in the most favourable circumstances, before either the farmer or the gardener can obtain the full rewards of their labours in sowing and planting In such cases leases should range from twenty five to forty years

In connection with Scotch farming the s> stem prevailed of payment by results The rent was graduated to the yield It was done in this way the tenant gave a certain ratio of the crop yielded by the land each year, so many bushels per acre, with a certain number of live stock, including fowls This mode of payment in kind, «as superseded by a system under which an equivalent in

money was paid. What are called Fiars' Courts are still held, constituted of farmers, land agents, and grain dealers at

which evidence is taken as to the current

prices of grain of various kinds An average is struck, which becomes the Fiars' Prices for that year, and on these rents are paid There can be no doubt that in principle this system is the most equitable. Landowner and tenant are alike affected by the variation in prices Good and bad years tell their story to each He who has practical knowledge, and can show how such a graduated scheme of rental would apply under the leasing system by the State, will make an important contibution to the dis cussion of this large question

THE Government Gazette of the 7th instant announces that Messrs Edward Aloysius Leonard and Falconer Hutton have been

licensed to effect surveys under the provisions

of "The Crown LindB Alienation Act of 1876 "

MR. J. ABRAHAMS' boree Sauntorer was offered at auction by Mr J. J. Macdermott, on Saturday and passed in at 140 guineas

Mr. Abrahame informs ua that the horse was Bold privately to Mr. J. Williams for 200

A Mair named Henry Vallentine arrived in town on Saturday by tram from Capella with ins arm broken It appears he was travelling from Rotro Station to Capella, when ho fell off a dray, and the wheel passing over his arm broke it He was taken to the Hospital, where every attention waa paid to him by

A DO\ named William Plume was arrested yesterday morning and charged with being a neglected child Tho boy, who is about thirteen years of age and partly paralysed, tells a very pitiful tale, and if true it is better bo should be placed in tho Reformatory He will be brought up at the Police Court this

morning

THE afternoon performance at the Thoatro Royal on Saturday afternoon waa largely attended by children, who were much pleased with the viewe of the Zulu war, and especially

so at the pri7ca they received at the con elusion of the entertainment In the evening there waa a good house, especially for Satur- day night aud the samo interest an over was taken in the description given by Mr Thomp

son of each view

THFHE was a large attendance of JUA enites at the Saturday nftornoon performance of DecoDoeLi's Circus Troupe, and the youngsters were much pleased at the autics of Young Queensland, the aboriginal clown In the evening the attendance was not so large though the performance n as carried through in its entirety To night is aunounced to be the last night of the troupe's appearance in Rockhampton

AT the conclusion of the service at St. Paul's Church yesterday morning a large number of the congregation visited the new church at the invitation of tho Rev. W A. Diggens It is fast approaching completion, most of the stained glass windows having been placed in position All the seats are in the church, and m about six weeks it is antici piled that the building will lie opened by Bishop Hale, who intends holding a confirma

tion Bervice on that occasion

THE Govet nment Gazette of the 7th instant notifies that the following gentlemen have been appointed the Committee for the Rockhampton Stato Sohnol -Messrs William Davis, John Ferguson, Alexander Meikle, Robert Shurples, and labez Wakefield Now that the Com mitte has been gazetted we hope they will use their endeavo ira to have the improvements effected in the Roys Central State School plans for which have boen prepared, and which we a Ivcrtcd to some tims back

Ov Saturday aftcruoon soma amusement was afforded the sporting contingcit from tho south and a number of visitors to the course A Connthian raco was arranged for, and about three o clock there was upwards of one hiludred persona on the courae to witness the amateur riders displaying their prowess Mr F Comley was ou thogrounl, and worked tlio t tilnat ir with success Tor the Corinthian

there were six entries. The distance was ouo mile welter weight for ape Mr James Moss1 Rainbow was installed first favourite at even money, and Mr. E P. Roger's Marmion wa« next in favour at 5 to 4. Tile wagering was pretty free, as the ring u as w eil repre- sented lVty-tvvo tickets vveie tikeo on the tntalisator, which give a dividend of £2 12s on the Binnet Rufus ni dj all the running, climely followed liv Mirmion and Rainbow and won very OJMIV fioin the two named who were suceivilwl by th' otlieia in straggling order iiutuithstainliiij the professional talent was lu the pigskin ou several likely looking hacks Mr

E P. Roger's Trooper Ivanhoe, and Carello also started. Distance 1 mile lime, 159. A succpsUko of £1 each;

MB JOHN STEVENSON, M L A , on his way from England in the P and 0 Co 's s s Siam, met Mrs Hay and the other passengers of the Bulimba, at Colombo The propeller of the latter ship had been broken, and she had to put into Colombo for repairs She had then been eleven days at that port, and the passengers did not know how long they might

A CORRESPONDENT informs us a disgraceful scene took place on Sunday evening at the " Rookery " in Kent lane A man whose name is known commenced beating his para mour, a notorious prostitute, and the screams( curses, and foul language, all screeched out at the pitch of their voices, were audible all over the i eighbonrhood Cannot something be done to abate this nuisance Is not the landlord responsible for the behaviour of bis tenants? There are three humpies all joined together, one occupied by the party referred to, the middle one by three prostitutes aud the other by a Kanaka who has "done" six months for vagrancy, and who le cohabiting with another man's wife

THE settling over the Rockhampton races took place on Saturday evening, at the Criterion Hotel. There was a very large muster of sporting men, and the business of the evening was carried out in a pleasant and

harmonious manner The chair was occupied by Mr A W Jardine, the President of the Club, who handed the following cheques to winners, making a grand total of £962 5s

Mooney, Jost and Rutherford Bros ," saying that he did not so much regret the bulk of tho money going to the "foreigners from the south, as it was an incentive to local sports men to get belter horses thereby improving racing generally The toast having been duly honoured, Mr Moouey said it was such an unusual thing for him to be included amongst the winners that he could hardlv find words to expreBS himself It had always been the aim and ambition of the gentleman with vhom he was con- nected in the ownership <f the horses, to win the Rockhampton Handicap and after many years of non success be had at last Bceom plished his object by the assistance of the speaker A few days before the races it was very doubtful whether Riiter woul 1 ever see the post, indeed all the horses here, through the hardness of the racng track, were more or less "dead " He was very proud of winning the Rockhampton douile, in conjunction with Mr Flynn Mr Vooney concluded hy offering five guineas towtrds making a proper training track on the leckhampton course Mr Jost said he was \eiy seldom a winner at

race meetings He was very satisfied with the result of the racing and when next he came to tl»a city he hoped to be ah!« to «.tu RocfchamuHon Handicap There being no response to the call for Mr Rutherford, Mr P Duff made some remarks with reference to the very email prise attached to the Hurdle Race which had been so successful the past two years He would like to Bee a more valuable prize given for snoh a race If the Club would have a Hurdle Race-or Hurdle Race and bteeplechase-each day next year, he would be happy to contribute five guineas towtrds such an object Mr R Lyons and Mr W Higson also promised fivo guineas eack for the same purpose The Chairman nex proposed " The losers coupled with the name of Mr J Williams " That gentleman not being present, Mr J Abrahams respinded Though he bad received no cheque from the Club, lie was happy to Bay he was the greatest winucr at that meetng having backed tlie two Rioteis with all He local bookmakers, and ho waa vxry plcasid at having taken " them all dow» ' He concluded a good speech by saving he hoped to bring a good horse to Rockhampton next year, when he would try if he could not break up the fatality that seemed to follow his animals hero Mr Mooney in a eulogistic speech, proposed the 'Officials of the R J C , couplcc* with the name of their President. Mr Jardine' The toast was received with musical honours and great cheering Mr

Jardine thanked them for the very cordial manner m which his health and that of hiB confreres had been drunk Hu own dsties were comparatively light, fiom the perfect unison in which all the Committee worked. They all desired to give a better programme in future years and it was intended to improve the running track as much as possible, and to have it ia giod order by next year With that objoet the Com mittee had started a special fund, which had already reached £70 lue improvements, &c , made to the course had been very expensive, but the Committee intended to give a better pro

gramme next year Mr Gösset (chairman of committee) also responded to the toast The term of the present Committee n office expired Bhortly, and he felt sure he waa expressing the feelings of all « ben he said they were amply rewarded for what they had done by the great satisfaction given. Some digressive conversa tion then took place with reference to the course bein); open for traiuing purposes all the year round Mr Jardineoouldnot make any definite promise in the matter, but they might rest assured the Committee would do all in their power to meet the wishes and requirements of horse owners "The Visitors, coupled with and \V riynu," was then proposed by the Chairman Mr Johnson was astonished tho names of Messrs Johnson (Bundaberg) at the great impiovement made to the Hool

hampton course and was very pleased at the way he bad been treated during his stay in town Mr Flynn Bald he was verj gratilicd lu having at last accomplished a mission of eight ycais, as he bad by aid of Mr Mooney, at length w on the Rockhampton Handicap Ile alvv i> s did all be could to encouraci racing ind woul I continuo to do so The Rockhampton C lab wen. furtunate in having such a cipital Committee If they hal a similar Committee in Brisbane lie woull guarantee there would In. a B isbane Cup of £1000 Mr Duff as a visitor, had always beca well treated m Rock lia upton Mr Abrahams pioposed the health of tho Secretary, \li \V O Jackson, who I .lil nindi I wards making the Club

known in the southern colonies Die toist was received with enthusiasm Mr Jackson disclaimed auy special merit, tho bucccas of their annual meetings beim; duo to the excellent Committee the} had, all of whom did thur utmost to make the affair go o(f well Mr Dunne proposed the Uandi capper, windi was respouded to by Mr Ila)girth, who whilst having to fiulhl a ralli< r thauklcsss duty, was grateful for the ern«! Gration he received from the RocUhamp 1 >u Picas and public 1 he "Iramers and j ickeys, tiavingrcccivedattoution.audMessrs Abrahams and Colley responded, Mr W Pattison proposed, "Our next merry meet- ing," coupling with it the name of Mr, Jar»

diño, who had devoted so much time and attention to the services of the Club The

I toast was received with great applause Mr

Jardine responded, promising to continue to devote all his energies to the advancement of the Club and the furtherance of good straight racing, anything having a tendency otherwise would be rigidly sat upon The meeting then dispersed

A TELtORAM waa received in town last week by Cantain Melbourne stating that as no suggestion had been made as to the drills to be held during the ensuing financial year, orders would he issued for the same on ¡satur day last The proposed drills were published in our columns a short time ago A circular dated the 9th July has also been received by Captain Mclbo irne, which orders the officers commanding corps armed with the Snider rifle, immediately on the termination of the annual course of musketry, to call m all arms ia their possession, an 1 baud them over to the staff eergcints of each corps for conveyance to heaIquartcrs Martini Henri rifles will be Issued without delay on tho return of the j Suidor rifles to Brisbane

articleText:
KOCKU Ull'ION

FRIDAY. AUGUST 3, 1883

Tuosr electors who are men ol indepen dent minds, ind grasp the political situition in connection with the present General Llection, must have come to recognise the question of land grant rail wajs as the one of pre eminent impor tance It is the leading question of the hour-beciuse it is the one on which the Government perilled their existence, and hive been compelled to appeil to the country, because it is pregnant with issues in connection with ihe progress of the colon\ , and hecmse its acceptance or lejerti n sh 11 maik the beginning of an important ipoch in tilt hlsloiy of the col jil) 1 e elect irs cannot too oflcn turn the suljixt ovir in their own minds, and examine it thoroughly in the light thrown upon it lit the election addresses and speeches now 11 ckcring in news paper columns One thing must be apparent to every elector that the con sutuencies are only being now roused

up to realise its vast importance Prac- tically the issue is-Shall we or shall we not have land-grant railways ? In fact the late Parliament answered this in the affirmative The Railway Companies Preliminary Act, about which we hear so much, settled the matter. It provides that the Governor in Council nny make an agreement with contractors for the construction of a railway in or through any part of the colony, and determines that Crown Lands may be granted to

the contractors for the execution of the work Iner. are numerous details in

the measure^and this important clause -" rivery (ujgreement made subject to the provisiuis of this Act shall, as soon as practicable after the execution thereof, be laid before both Houses of Parlia ment " When that measure was brought before Parliament the land grant prin- ciple was thoroughly discussed, and, notwithstanding Mr Macdonald Pater son's slaloment to the contrary, it met with the approval of the Assembly In the discussion on the second reading the only member who decidedly opnosed the Bil! «as Mr Groom We have for- merly piotcd in our columns the words, in which the hon. gentleman sitting on the front seats of the Opposition benches, approved of the principle of the measure Uley could not shut their eves to the fact that it would be greatly to the advantige of this colony, insteid of selling land lo pay interest on money borrowed to make railways, to give the land for the railways It is due to the Opposition to mention that they pointed out the dangers that might arise in con- nection with the land giant system, and Mr Griffith's references to liaron

Erlanger, and allusions to scveial shady cases in connection with syndicates and land grants, were legarded as neither ill tuned nor unnecessary At that time the great consolation of hon members,

who did not lake time to examine into

the miller, was that the measure did not commit the colony to any particular scheme, and that Parliament retained tue power of approving or disproving of any scheme contrived under the Act

The law having been made, under which contracts might be formed for the construction of land grant railways, the Warrego Railway Syndicate and the Australian Transcontinental Railway Syndicate carne forward, and offered to

make lines on terms «Inch the Govern ment deemed favourable The Assembly was of a different opinion, and rejected both schemes All the constitutional

powers of the Ministry «ere exerted to pass the agreements, but ihev were defeated They have accepted their defeat and appealed to the country It must be clearly understood, however, that it is not the character of the agree ments that is now at issue, but the existence of the measure under which

they were made The Opposition now condemn the measure to winch they gave iheir consent, and some of their allies, who are candidiles for election in ihe Central District, declare that it should be repealed The electors must bear this in mind, tint the measure is not responsible for the terms of the agreement It provides how the land may be given in -payment or a railway, but it does not condescend on the quality, estimated value, or amount

Nor it does not follow that because the Government, in their anxiety to gi\e the land grant sjstem a trii!, entered into whit has been con demncd as a bad bargain, only similar igi cements may be made under the statute One of our candidates would repeal the Act in order to take from my Government the power of entering into such an arrangement m future But in doing that he would ilso deprive the Administration of the power of accept mg an offer, that might be highly ad vantageous to the colony Besides, the electors have unmtstakeal le evidence of the fate of an Agreement that the colony condemns Whatever ihe merits of the Transcontinental Agreement may have been the electors hate not had an oppoi tunny of discovering fairly

The Premier accused the Leader of the

Opposition of discussing it in Commutée before Parliament met, and tint wis really done The terms ot the Agree ment were reviewed at Roma, Mackay, and Bnsbane When the House met the usual course of sending a lli'l, of which the principle had been approved, into Commute was not followed On the second reading it was condemned

Whit Parliament lias done on this occa

sion it ma) do on any other occasion it miy reject an objectionable agreement without pal le) feo long as it possesses that power the interests of the colony are sifeguirded ignnst the imposition of an unjust agreement There seems a determination on the part of some poll

ticians opposed to the Ministry to smother the land grant system of rulwiy construction in this colony If they succeed the progress of the colony mil be greatly impeded We must construct our railways on borrowed monej, if we can get it A large amount of foreign capital mil lie precluded from emplo)

' ment in the colony What will be ihe

result ? The Go\ eminent will be forced to resott to land sales, and that is alwi)s an untoward circumstance But then will arise the opportunity ol colonial capitalists Then there will be some chance of Mr James Tyssen gettirg for one million pounds sterling four million acres of land of his own choosing Let the electors, therefore, keep this clearly before them-tint the land grant system of i iii« ay const! uctton is (nught with immense idv^ntiges to the colony, lint it is in the power of Parliament to prevent Us being eniplo) eil to the dctn ment of the colong , ind tint it is a grand counterictuc of the schemes of rings of land sharks

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 4, 1883.

THE WEER.

THE thunder of political strife now rever- berates in all parts of the Colony. From Brisbane in the south to Caps York in the far north, preparations for tho General Election are going on, aud candidates and their friends are busy and excited. Side issues and local objects are being dwarfed by the growing prominence of the great questions on which the constituencies are to be called upon to deliver their verdict. Considerable iuterest has been displayed in this electorate in the political movements in Brisbane. Last Satur- day the hon. Leader of the Opposition, issued an Address to the constituency of North brisbane, in which be anncuncod his scheme for carrying on railway construction in the colony. At Mackay, it will bo remembered, the hon. gentleman said he would act tho part of the physician, and not prescribe for the better management of public affairs till he was called in to do so. He considers an invitation has now been issued to him, and he comes forward with his prescription. It is that instead of paying for the railways with liud-gronto, «ba oolany should guarantee Interest on thc money used in their construc- tion. Till we have the Address in full, and the hon. gentleman's exposition of it, wc are not in a position to comment upon thc pro- posal ; but it seems to us that it implies the

introduction of that horrible creature, born of a limpet on a rock and a horse-leech whose name is Syndicate. It may be neces- sary, therefore, for the electors to consider whether the syudicate ie deserving of all the hard things which have been said and circulated about it by the Opposition. A most notable event h SB been there-appearance of Mr. John Douglas, C. M.G., on tho political stage. He has oome forward as a candidate for the suffrages of the electors of North Bris- bane, not so much because he is anxious for Parliamentary honours as that he is desirous of pointing out the inutility of Mr. Griffith's scheme to meet the requirements of the country. It is a desperate blow to the Liberal canse, when the Premier of the laBt Liberal administration turns round, and condemns the policy of his former colleague and successor. Mr. Douglas must be very firmly convinced that Mr. Griffith is wrong, and must be alarmed at his proposals, when he can take suoh a decided step.

THE Hon. A. Archer, Colonial Treasnrer, ia oar only candidate who has addressed his con- stituents, and a report of his speech, which we have given at length, is deserving of care- ful perusal. Above all others, the points of particular interest in it are the decided opinion the Hon. gentleman has that we shall not be able to go on borrowing more money to construct public works. With peculiar emphasis he remarked that the last loan was not a successful affair, and such an observation, coming from the head of our financial depart- ment, is deeply significant. His exposition of the manner in which the land-grant system is to be employed in preventing a re- currence of those timcB of depression to which thc colony has been exposed, is singularly in- teresting. Electors canuot consider the matter, as expounded by Mr. Archer, too carefully.

IT is aim oe t needless to remark ti) at a good doa) of excitement haa sprung up in Rock- hampton. At the beginning of the week it seemed as if Mr. Ferguson was to bo allowed a walk over, but there are now a number of candidates in thc field. Mr. Ferguson lias not iesued an address to his constituents as all the other candidates have done, but wilt make a speech in the Hall of the School of Arts on Monday evening. Mr. Macdonald Paterson is again a candidate and in a brief address forwarded from Bris- bane, intimates that be will be with the electors in a few days. A very interesting and carefully prepared address bas been issued by Mr. L. F. Lauds berg, but we ore afraid that gentleman may spare himself the trouille of expounding it before the electors in public meeting assembled. Mr. W. Higson, who opposed Mr. Ferguson at the Inst election held in Rockhampton, is again ia the field as a candidate ; and bas i86ned an excellent Address. Of course wo do not agree with Mr. Higson, but ho has put his views before thc electors in a form which placeB them beyond the reach of misinter- pretation. In Mr. Robert Lynns *' thc well known and popular solicitor " wc recognise thc candidate so h»ng ago promised by our contemporary. Thou e; h he announces himself as a native of Australia-tho only pure merino in thc wlioh: urowd-he is a somewhat piebald politician. Hu is opposed to land-grant railways, but#will permit Ihe introduction nf Coolies for sugar cultivation. A KedislriWinu of Si-nts lütt is now due in Parliament, and will be introduced hy what- ever party is itt power, so that Mr. Lyons plays a safe card iu turning that up. Mr. Hoes Jone?, in answer to a most respectably signed requisition, has intimated his willing- ness lo become a candidate, and will issue his Ad?!ress to-day. Il ia possible the number of candidates may bc increased, as there is not a tloeidcd Ministerialist among them. In the sifting process that is certain to take place next week, some gentlemen may find them-

selves eet aside.

AT th« meeting of the Municipal Council on Thursday last there waa an unusual amount of business disposed of, although it was got through very quickly. Among the cot res- póndenos was a letter from the Under- secretary for Lands, who forwarded the Attoruey-Generat'a opinion on the alignmout of the town, reoeutly carried out by Mr. Wood. From it we gather that the reasons it I has not been confirmed was owing to ignorauce

of some point ol law on which, however, the Council were informed hy the Town Clerk, the viewa of the officials had been set right by Mr. Jones. It is satisfactory, however, to know thatthemethodof survey adopted by Mr. Wood is considered to be suitable for the town, and that it has been prepared with care. Areply was received from the Secretary of the Gas Com- pany to the request to make a reduction in the Corporation account for the last three months. The Company were willing to take five per cent off it, but this was not considered satisfactory by the members of the Council. The most important letter received was that from Messrs. Howard Smith and Sons, in which reference wa« made to the "lifting" of valuable packages of goods from the wharves. As a remedy for this it was suggested that the Counoil should erect au enolosed shed at the lower end of the Cor- poration Wharf, the cost of which was estimated at £1000. If tho improvements were carried out, they would be willing to pay 10 per cent per annum on the cost of construc- tion, and enter into an agreement to that effeot. The matter was favourably received by the Council, and referred to the Wharfage Committee. The advantage of an enclosed shed on the wharf must be apparent to all, and it may be anticipated that the Committee will recommend the carrying out of the work as soon as funds are at thc disposal of the Council. We had thought the site for the (dring of the ti<nc-gun had been fixed, hut from what was said at the Council meeting on Thursday it appears that thia was not the cass. Only one tender was received for tho work, that of W. J. Cumming for £1 a week, which was accepted. Though the site where it is to be fired from was left in thc hands of the Works Committee, it was evidently understood' by the Town Clerk that it was to be fired from the Quarry as he inserted that in the specifica- tions, but the tenderer suggested the Ferry Reserve at North Rockhampton as a suit- able place.
