articleText:
?ROCKHAMPTON.

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1683.

TWP arrniintc iwtii-K <-»~ t" = nave reached us, as to the continued ill- ness of the Cornie de Chambord, have at last culminated in a telegram an- nouncing his death at Frohsdorf on the 24th ultimo. Born in Paris on the 291h September, 1820, the latter part of the life of this prince was one of perpetual exile, and was a strange contradiction to the splendour and pomp which attended his earlier, years. As grandson of Charles X, and son. of the Due de Berri, the heir presumptive to that monarch, Henri Comte de Chambord was the rightful and direct successor to the throne of his ancestors. His birth, indeed, took place under rather excep- tional circumstances, for his father, the Duke de Berri, who was mur- dered in February, 1820, left only a daughter, and the joy was great when seven months afterwards his widow give birth tn a nrinrp. «An received the tule of Due de Bordeaux, his tide-of Comte de Charcbord being derived from the Castle of Chambord, which was subsequently presented to him. He was baptised amid circum- stances of great pomp, with water brought by M. de Chateaubriand from the river Jordan, and received the appel- lation of " the Child of Miracles." On the .abdication of Charles X, at the Revolution in 1830, this prince named the youthful Due de Bordeaux as his successor, but the people insisted on the elevation to the throne of Louis Phillippe, the citizen Kling, and the elder branch of Bourbons were consequently banished

into exile.

During the subsequent changes that took .place in the Government of France, the Comte de Chambord always main- tained an inflexibleattitude.lhatof king by divine right, and refused to comply with any conditions, the acceptance of which might at one time have secured him restoration to the throne of his ancestors. The now famous proclamation, in which he demanded that the white flag of the Bourbons should replace the tricolour as as the banner of France, alienated from him a large section of his supporters, and Marshel M'Mahon is said to have made the shrewd remark, that the Chassepots of . the soldiers would go off of them- selves, if they were to hear of the sacrifice of the tricolour. With the death of the Count de Chambord the direct line of the Bourbons has ceased to exist, and henceforth the Count de Paris, tht Orleanist .claimant and the representative of the line of Louis Phillippe, unites ir Iiis own person the claims of tlx . Legitimist and Orleanist houses to thc

throne. Whether indeed this wil be any further advantage to the Conn ?de Paris remains for future event: to decide, but undoubtedly he will nov

hp able to reckon on a verv Jaree ant

powerful addition to his supporters, and will also have at his badi, the whole strength of the Catholic Church, which was before accorded to his cousin the late Comte dc Chambord. The French Republic, therefore, will now have to face one powerful opponent, instead of two jealous and antagonistic pretenders ; and already the telegraph tells us of placards appearing on the walls in varions parts of Paris, favouring the claims of the Comte de Paris to the throne. Whether any active attempt to put for- ward will be made his claims must at least be doubtful, and he will most likely bide his time and wait on circumstances. Any chance he might really possess must come from the action of the Republican Government. If that Government had seriously damaged or disqualified itself in tile eyes of thc majority of

Frenchmen, and if there were an evident

desire rm their part to try a new ex- periment, then cine might imagine there would bc a good opportunity for the Connie de I'.iris to step in, and poiot to the advantage of a settled monarchy, on a thoroughly popular basis,

which would also combine with it the prestige of " king by divine right," Such an offer might not be accepted, or if it was, might not be put to a very pro- longed trial. But in any case it would be necessary, as a preliminary condition, for the French nation to be thoroughly dissatisfied with the operation of the Republican form of Government. At present such a condition of things is nowhere visible in France. The Republic has, of course, enemies at home as well as foes abroad, and has therefore both external and internal dangers to guard against But for all this, there appears not the slightest 6¡gn that the majority of the French people have any desire to give up the Repub- lican form of government in favour of any new experiment, nor can it be supposed that they will relinquish the Republican system for the sake of trying once again an old experiment, already tried and discredited. The Comte de Chambord was, during his life time, looked up to by the Legitimist party as a sort of tutelary deity, and his dignified retirement at Frohsdorf, and the un- yielding attitude he maintained with regard to his claims to the throne, com- pelled some measure of respect from men of all parties, There is, however, nothing particularly fascinating in the careers of the Orleanist Princes. Living under the Republic, and until recently holding commissions in the Republican army, they have as it were recognised its authority, while in reality they were plotting and attempting to destroy it, and the discovery of these attempts led to their exile. There is nothing in this to appeal to the feelings or sensibilities of the French people. The Count de Paris has as yet rendered no services to the nation, and has 'performed no action which has called forth their admiration and applause. Even if France were

now crying out for a rung or ümperor, at the present moment there is no claimant for the throne, whose personal position and qualifications fasten the eyes of all men on him, and make the voices of all exclaim, " This is he." If Gam- betta had lived, he was the one rpan to whom the French nation would have turned in the hour of doubt and adver-

sity, but the Comte de Paris possesses no such claim to the respect and admira- tion of the French people. After all ikcu li ac boan oaid from time to time, about the levity of the French nation, it cannot be said that they ever changed a dynasty or form of Government merely for the sake of a change, but there was always some crisis which made it practically impossible for things to con- tinue as they were. There is nothing of the kind in what is now happening in Europe. The death of the Comte de Chambord will make no real change as far as France is concerned. Whether

the Count de Paris calls himself king of France, as the legitimate heir to the Crown, or king of the French as the representative of the citizen king, everything in' France will go on as before ; and will continue to do so until the French people become convinced that the Republic is a failure. When this will occur, or whether it will ever occur, is a problem which time alone

will snlvi».

AT the Police Court yesterday, before the Police Magistrate, one drunkard was cautioned and discharged. John C. Hayes for a similar offence, was fined 40s. ; in default forty-eight hours in the cells. Thomas Murray appeared on a similar oh argo and was fined Ss. with the alternative of twelve hours' imprisonment.

-I^MANY w¡|] D0 doubt wonder why the time

gun was not fired as UBual at one o'clock yesterday. On inquiry we learn it was taken away for repairs on Tuesday, but they were not completed before ono o'clock yester- day. We may mention that Messrs. Slater and Co's contract for tiring the (»un terminated on Tuesday, and the work will bo taken up to-day hy Mr. W. J. Cummings. It will he tired from the Ferry Reservo at North Rockhampton.

THE usual monthly meeting of the Rock- hampton Benevolent Society was held in the Committee-room of the School of Arts yester-

day afternoon. Present :-Mesdames For- ¡ gason (in thc chair), Dixons, 'J neon, Hartley, Browne, Hutton, Thomson, Meikle, Jackson, and Mills, Mr. H. Milla, and the Rev. Messrs. Dig tren s, Hartley, and Williams. The follow- ing district reports wort read :-No. 1 district, relieved 8 adults 25 children, expenditure £8 I3s. fid. ; No. 2 district, relieved I adult» £1 3s. £d. ; No. 3 district, relieved 6 adults 14 children, £6 ls. ld. ; No. 4 district, re- lieved 2 adults, £1 14s. 4d. ; No. 5 district, relieved 7 adults 13 children, £5 2s. 51.; No. G district, relieved 3 adults 4 chill reu, £1 8s. Od. .The report of tho Benevolent Asylum eh nw (id that tho number of inmates during the month was 21 adults and 1G children ; admitted, G adults and 5 children ; dismissed, G adults and 5 children ; number of inmutes 31st Au gu nt, 15 adults and 13 children. There had been two births and

two deaths during the month. The expendi-

ture amounted to £38 18s. 7d,, and tue re coi pta to £2 8s. 6d. The Committee had to acknowledge with than kB a donation of one guinea from Mr. Beardmore, of Tooloombah, and of clothing from Mrs. J. E. Drown and Mrs, Cooper.-After a few words of explanation in reference to relief given in BO me districts, thc reports were adopted on the motion of Mrs. Higgens, seconded hy Mrs. Browne.-The correspondence consisted of three letters from the Colonial Secretary's Office intimating that that £100 had IM PU placed to the credit of thc Society in the Bank of New South Wales for the relief of women confined in the Asylum ; £200, first moiety of grant for 18S3-4 to the .Society ; and .?200, ii rat moiety of grant for 188.1-4, to the Asylum.-Mrs. Ferguson re- marked that thc £100 was what they had asked for, and asimilar amount promised them would he placed on the Kati matea. They would then soe if it was granted to them.-Mr. Mills, with reference to the fencing of tho Asylum grounds, explained that it was extremely difficult to get men .at the present time, and Urge contracts had been out, but no tender bad been received for them. He hail asked

Messrs. Wilpy, Holmes and Go. if they would tender for the fencing they required, and they had sent in a tender for 20a. a rod, the work to bo completed in two months. There were about 124 rods to be dunc-Mr. Higgens thought that £124 was quite enough to pay for the work, and Mr. Mills was nf opinion that if they could get it c.med out for £100 it would bc as little as possible.-Mrs. Fergu son wa8 in favour of leaving thc matter over uutil the next mooting, and in the meantime call for fresh tenders,-Mr. Diguens asked if it could not ho left to the sub-cow mi Ute to carry out the work at a cost not exceeding £100.-Mr. Hartley th night it hhonM be left to the discretion of thc gcutleincn comprising the Committee,

and after some discussion he moved that thc matter be left to the sub-committee to deal with, which was seconded by Mrs. Tuson, and agreed to.-Mesdames Diggens and Tuson

were appointed the Visiting Committee . for the month.-Mn. Ferguson stated the next business was the appointment of the grocer and chemist for the next four months. She thought that the Society might patronise Messrs. J, M'Gregor and CV, who had newly Started in business.-Mr. Hartley concurred <io what Mrs. Ferguson said, and moved that the firm alluded to be appointed grocers to the Society for the ensuing term of four months.-Mrs. Bartley seconded the motion. -Mr. - Diggens thought it would bo -well to take the tradesmen in alphabetical order so as to prevent soy misunderstanding, and Mr. Hartley explained that they were patronised in regular order. The motion was then carried.-With regard to the appointment of a chemist some discussion took place, in the course of whioh it was mentioned that eeveral persons in the town objected to Dr. C. F. Cripps reoeiving orders from the Society, he not being a tradesman, lu con- sequence of this it was decided, on the motioh of Mrs. DiggoDB,seconded by Mrs. Meikle, that Mr. lt. Paynter be appointed chemist for thc period mentioned.--Mr. Diggens mentioned that a woman who was receiving benefit from the Society had a sewing machiue wiiich had become so old that she was unable to work with it, and several ladies bad been collecting to assist her in paying for a new one. He thought the Society might give ber a contri- bution, and he moved that £2 be granted to ber out of the fuods. - Mr. Mills seconded the motion, which was agreed to. The meeting then terminated.

I A TKLEGRAM in the Goutier of Thursday laat I

announces that the Right Rev. Dr. Stanton, Bishop of Northern Queensland, arrive! at Normanton on Wednesday last, lie is the first clergyman who has visited the place.

THE second monthly meeting of the Rock hampton Permanent Building Society was held in the offices of the Secretary (Mr. R. L. Dibdin) last night. Messrs. H. Vesperman and J. Williamson presided as directors. The amount received was £109 12s. 6d. Twenty three investing aud 113 borrowing shares were

taken up.

THE Martini-Henry rifles promised to the members of our local volunteer corps have arrived, and will be issued at a parade to bo held this evening. It will be no'iced from sn advertisement in another column that fifteen recruits are required to complete the establish- ment of the corp«, and liantes will be taken on Tuesday evening next at eight o'clock.

WE have received a,copy of the seventeenth annual report of the Rockhampton Benevolent Society, published io pamphlet form. It con- tains all the information useful to members and subscribers, including listof officers, boundaries of districts, rules and regulations of the Society and Asylum, annual report and balauce-suect, and the subscription list.

A LETTKB ia the Gawler from its Cairns correspondent Btates that a new industry has been started in the district - the cultivation of the tobacco plant. A selec- tor there has placed five acres of bis land at the disposal of some competent tobacco growers, who state that everything required for the growth of the plant is to be found in

the olimate and soil.

, A SOUTHERN paper, in calling from our I columns a paragraph in reference to Mr, Lachlan's success at the University in Eng- land, stateB that gentleman is a son of Mr. T. Lachlan of tba Cremorne Hotel. Our contem- porary bas made a slight error. Mr. Lachlan, of the Cremorne, ia unmarried, and states he is not aware he ever had a son. The Uni- versity graduate is his brother.

THE Singer Sewing Machine Company bare hit upon au excellent plan of advertising by issuing eheets, on ono eido of which is a map of Queensland, and on the other illustrations of the differeut kind of machines made by them. At the foot of the map is a list of the branch offioes establisher! in Queénsland, and a view of the Singer factories in Glasgow and

Ifew Jersey. ^

THE well-known Emu Park Hotel, which

UM WOT TO «»»., OTI-lVv«. ., .. .j_

Fulton for the last seven years, has changed hands. The purchaser is Mr. F. Williams, of Bogantungan, and tho price, we understand, was £2000. The new proprietor has success- fully carried on the hotel business on the Central Railway line, and in bis new venture lie will probably meet with a due amount of

patronage.

A GOOD story is told of a strong supporter of a successful candidate for Parliamentary honours. So elated was he with the return of his candidate that ho issued invitations foi forty of the free and independent electors tc partake of a redwxehi. dinner to celebrate thc event. The dinner was held iii a hotel which could not accommodate thc whole company, and consequently only about twenty of thc guests were present. Thc other twenty arc now congratulating themselves on not luvim accepted the hospitality of the olatcd sup porter, as that gentleman bas Bent billa lo tin invited forty charging them thirteen shilling! and sixpence each for thc dinner. This is aol a bad joke-for the twenty feeders.

SOMETIMES we havre accidento at our wharves, and a case arising out of oue at Mel* bourne will be read with interest :-An action remitted from the ¡Supreme Court was tried in j tho County Court, before Judge Cn|>e and a

special jury of four. William Croak, of Little Nelsnn-street, Williamstown, an employé "f I the Board of Laud and Works, sued the Vic ! torian Stevedoring Company for £300 for I injuries caused to him while working nu thc

Breakwater Pier, through the negligence of the company, while unloading a ship. It was alleged that a hook used by the stevedores in their unloading became unfastened and.struck the plaintiff on the head, causiug him to bo laid up and unable to attcud to his duties for three weeks. He had been receiving 8s. per day, and had a small doctor's bill to pay. The defendants alleged that the injury was caused by a pure accident, the tackle nsed in unloading bring in good order. The jury returned a verdict for thc plaintiff for £7 7s.

FOR the last two days large hush fires have been raging on the Berserkers and other range«, and at night the hills presented a very pretty sight. Thiswascspeciallysoon Tuesday uight, when three columns of fire were tt> he

Been in a parallel line from thc bo Un in to thé

summit of Mount Berserker, ' The fires have

not, we are B-»rry to say, only be n confined to the hills, as we were informed yesterday that the grasB in the Town Co in mon had been on Gre finco Monday, but tho fiamos were being got under. What extent of country has been burnt we are unable to state, but it is rumoured sever.il li ea i of cattle, possibly Bim ein avery weak condition, were destroy ea. How the flames were set going is not at present known, but probably it was c.used hy some thoughtless persou passing through the paddock throwing down a lighted match after lighting his pipe. This canuot but be regarded as a misfortune, as iu thc present state of the country the Commonage was almost the only place to which horses could bc

sent to graze.

articleText:
UOCKllAMVTON.

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1883.

No sensible person would object to the giving to Mr. Griffith of a party dinner attended by partizans, and honoured exclusively by three representatives of the party Press. Mr, Griffith will shortly bc thc most powerful man in the colony, and most politicians, both local and general, are prone to worship the rising sun. Gratitude has been cynically de I fined as a lively appreciation of favours

to come rather than of favours conferred, and it is not unnatural, perhaps, that the I winners of an election should attempt

to grasp so much of the victors' spoils as might be gathered from personal and ' individual recognition by "the finest

man ever produced in the Australian Colonies," although this may be Mr. Garrick's euphemistic method of describ- ing a colonist born of parents at the moment ltvinginthe landof Taffy,and still entitled to alt the rights and privileges ol a Welshman. However, this is a poinl on which it would be ungracious to quarrel, as Mr. Griffith's nationality is not very material to the genera1 reader. What we do object to, how ever, is that the partizans of the " fines! man " should have taken advantage of ? speech delivered by him confidentially to a few admiring adherents, and hav( exposed some sentiments at least whicl might have proceeded from the mos vulgar of third-rate politicians.

The burden of Mr. Griffith's speech so far as the public can judge by thi partially lifted veil, was that the missioi of his party, should they get into office would be to discover marc's nests. Om would have thought that the finest mai Australia' ever produced would hav already discovered the unprofuabli nature of this proceeding. He went ti England to find out improper things and on returning it took him sevei hours in the Assembly to tell all he hai found out during his seven months' toui And those who read the Hansatd repoi of that unparalleled speech, ¿ul revised and corrected by the authoi could never discover that anything ha been actually found out except thi "the finest man ever produced in th Australian colonies" had proveda veritabl pigmy in his intellectual encounter wit Sir Hatdinge Giffard. Still every candi person must admit that a lavvyer-pol tician who could keep up the interest ( the Legislative Assembly for seven coi seculive hours while he said nothini was a creditable specimen of th sophistical man, wherever through som freak ot nature he happened to have bee "produced." However, it is evident! Mr. Griffith's chief aim to fiud out an expose something discreditable about h opponents, rather than win moral suppo by evidencing his possession of a masti mind, and a well conceived policy. Tl: authorities in parliamentary practic reprehend this fishing for corruption, an stigmatise as undignified and in ba form the public reflections of a Ministi upon the peccadilloes of his predecessoi It is held that the legitimate way I parliamentary confidence is not ov blasted reputations, but by showing tl capacity as well as the disposition

drive the state coach over a practicab road to its proper destination. But tl finest man in Australia has evidently code of honour exclusively his own, ar j apparently feels that his best chance

enjoying a protracted term of office Ii in his ability to demonstrate that tl

j other party are irreclaimable scoundre ' who must at all hazards be kept clear

! the Treasury benches.

I Mr. Griffith wants no foreij [ " partners," but above all things desir

the aid of foreign capital. This mear I we suppose, that when the Brid money-lender hears that the Queer land Liberals are in power, he will lei the colony fabulous sums free of intere: I Rings are not wanted here, says N Griffith, and so say we. But we wa the term " ring " intelligibly define We hold, for example, that the lef profession in Queensland forms a ve exclusive, rapacious, and pernicio ring, who make a practice

subordinating every public intcn to their own professional and cir interests, On the other hand we lie that the limited companies engaged legitimate trading amongst us ha opened up broad avenues for the fr introduction of British capital into t colony, and while prosecuting their o< corporate interests under the cover ol beneficent statute have conferred in timable benefit upon the community. ^ their useful associations have be stigmatised as corrupt rings and syn eales whose object is lo eat out l vitality of society. But by whom ?

it not chiefly from chartered libertii who batten upon the misfortunes

the litigiously disposed among l people that these smoky insinuate and inuendoes proceed ?

Hear Mr. Garrick, fur example. T gentleman is a politician who was usu so long as he remained poor. 1 becoming the holder of lands and hon in Queen-street he grew rich while slept. The " unearned increment " a not frugality or hard labour filled

pocket, and converted him from a nee solicilor into an indolent plutoci Ki ve years airo Mr. Garrick was

Ministerial oliice, and what was i universal verdict arrived at by ¡ public ? ^"as il not that he did noth to assist his colleagues in debate, a that he allowed the Lands Dcparimi to run alone ? As a maller of f Mr. Garrick steadily refused to sel any departmental question which

volved thought or responsibility. 1 did anyone ever hear that he neglcci to draw his Ministerial salary ? I even his political friends deny that was the drone in the Ministerial hi

What Iben is this precious moralist re- ported to have said at Saturday's ban- quet ? Why that the present Ministerial party worked to promote their own pri vale interests while the Liberals neglected theirs-that " he knew of no person who had not left the Ministry a wealthy man." We know two cases in which persons left the Ministry because they were not wealthy men and could not afford the expense of official life. And we know two lawyers who left the Ministry for a seat on the judicial shelf with the emolument of ^"2000 a year for life. We know also Ministers who were comparatively wealthy men when they assumed office, and who have grown rich through the enormous expansion of values which has followed the adoption of their own policy of bringing Queens- land practically nearer to the London markets. But the wealthy men who have left the Ministry arc mere creatures of Mr. Garrick's imagination.

There was but one important state- ment in Mr. Griffith's speech, which was that he would preserve the colony exclusively for the white man, and that even the labour of the much abused Kanaka must not be relied upon in future by the sugar-planters. The " finest man ever produced in Australia " is evidently submitting to the dictation of Mr. William Brookes, and has adopted the motto " White labour and no sugar 1" But we doubt if he will lind power tenable on so reckless a policy.

articleText:
THE TIME GUN.

TO THE EDITOR OF TUG MORNING BULLETIN.

SIR,-Having read several complaints in your columns about the unsuitability of the time gun, which seems to have becomo a general nuisance to the nervous public, as well as by concussion causing damage to buildings in the locality, I take the opportunity to suggcBt as an efficient and practical means of overcoming the difficulty, and at the same time securing to the public the advantage of a time standard, that the Municipal Council provide a pow crful Bteain v. lilBtle, which by arrangement might be attached to one of the local steam engines, v. hen it could be worked at a trifling cost.

The dropping of a tinte ball from the flagstaff of the Post Office would hardly replace the gun since only those anticipating the time, and in the locality could take advantage of it.

I remain, sir, &c ,

Tims. O CONNOR.

Rockhampton, September 28, 1883.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

THURSDAY, OCTOIHÏR 4, 1883.

THERE are three requirements in con- nection willi our national system of education, which the Government ought to aim at realising in the public interests, and in order that it may accomplish the work to be done. These are that it should bc available lo all classes, that it should be cheap, and that it should be efficient. From the remarks made by us on this subject last week we think it will be conceded that wc have plenty of ?schools. Wherever a score of children can be gathered together there the Stale sends a teacher, so that the little, ones may not be utterly neglected. At the end of last year lhere were 361 schools in operation, and 929 teachers on the roll of this branch of the Civil Service. If the children are not educated the fault lies in the main with the parenis, who neglected their duly in not sending .them to school. Some blame may rest ion the authorities for not enforcing the compulsory clauses of the Act in our towns. In one sense education in Queensland is cheap. Indeed, those whom we may call thc consumers could not expect to get it at a cheaper rate. All our nalion.il school doors stand open, inviting the attendance of the coming race. Except the cost of a lew books education is fae to those imme- diately interested. Hut though not paid for directly, thc cost of it bas to be met in another w.iy I'", very minne often, every c.ike of tubarco, every n'ass of spirits necessities .ind limn ¡es ave taxed lo a certnin extent lo j.roviJe funds to carry out our education.'.', sy-.lem. Our ni ist numerous consumers ol commodities are our largest taxpayers, and as they belong to thc working class they are really thc best supporters of the system. They pay for the cduraiion which their rhildren apparently receive gratuitously. They have a good right to know, there

ii-.; v.¡icítiL-r thc cost of teaching is not :.Miiiv.i!;aiUly h'gh. We lum in vain )-.er the leave* of the Anmnl Report if the Seneiny fir l'uhlic Insiruc ti in, in search of satisfactory informa li m on this point. We learn thai the gross exendilure on Primary Kducj

ti in in Slate and Piovision.il Schools

during the year amounted to ,£112,060.

That is a large sum equal to a tax of nearly los. a head of the whole popula lion. Instead of education being free, it is costing each of us a considerable sum. Details are given of the cost per head of children enrolled, and in average daily attendance, during the seven years ending the 21st December last, from which ive see that it has fluctuated, but at the end of the period it is larger than at the beginning. This doubtless is due to the ample provision that has been made by the erection of school buildings, and constitution of an

efficient staff of teachers. We are in- formed, however, the average cost per pupil throughout the colony during the year, based on the average daily atten- dance, exclusive of the items for scholar- ships, Grammar Schools, and Orphanages w;ls t2S- °j£d. " Taking the average attendance of pupils at 21,610, and the gross expenditure on primary education at ¿¿112,060, the average cost per pupil is found to be ¿Q$ 3s. 8d. It is undcrsood that the annual average cost per pupil in other Australian colonies is calculated on a basis similar to this, and thc sum named should, therefore, be taken when comparing the annual cost per pupil in Queensland, with the annual cost per pupil in the other colonies." It is, perhaps, no part of the duty of the Hon. Mr. Archer to tell us the average cost per pupil in the other colonies, but had he done so it would have added greatly to thc interest and value of his report. For such information we must resort to the

Education Reports of these colonies, which are not so easily available to the community as they are lo him. Un- fortunately for the discussion of this

point, we only know what the cost

is in Victoria. There it is set down

at £4 ts. 7d., or £1 2s. 1 J¿d. less than in Queensland. Why this difference exists ought to be explained. In the older colonies the school buildings have been completed, and. the salaries of teachers are not so large ; nevertheless, upwards of one pound sterling a head of difference forms a large aggregate sum.

Thal the education communicated in our schools is efficient does not appear prominently. Evidence on the point is wanting. The Chief Inspector says the reports of the Inspectors show that the schools are in a fairly satisfactory slate as to discipline and proficiency. Now, with all deference to Mr. Ewart, we submit the public ought to have distinct evidence 011 this matter. We have repeatedly pointed out that the number of children presented for examination, the number which pass, and the per- centage of marks they make, should be given in connection with every school. On these points thereports of Mr. Platt and Mr. Shirley alone contain information. The former gentleman gives a series of of tables, showing the results of the examinations in all subjects taught in the primary schools. In none is the value higher than 75 per ccnl; but we advance in efficiency has been made. Such details as Mr. Platt gives in table C of his report ought to be furnished regarding every school in the colony. Mr. Shirley's Examination Results are useful as far as they go, but are not sufficiently complete. Proof is wanting, therefore, that the education given is up

to the standard of other colonies and of European countries. Without the returns which we desiderate our educa lion Report will continue to be incom- plete and unsatisfactory.

articleText:
THE ASSESSOR? WORK.

TO TUE EDITOR OP THE MRNINQ BULLETIN.

SIR,-A letter appeared in your last Mon- day's issue, signed " Tiddy Wink " re " the assessment job" as be oils it. For your information, and also for tlat of the public, I will give an idea of thework to be done in I assessing the town

For the years 1884 6 it s expected that the number of assessments wil be 5500 Each of these has to be correctly sade In order that this may be so the proper^ must be personally inspected and valued The No of sub division, allot, and sec , the area, street, and ward, the liâmes of tbeocospier and owner, with occupation and reslence, have allí o be entered ; and if a wrongunount is entered or a wrong valuation or nana given, the assessor is between two fires-blase from the Corpora- tion on the one hand, and rom the ratepayeron the other, who has the lower of appeal In the latter event the assesor has to sustain his valuation-by bringing m other valuators, who have to be paid out <i the fee. To enable a correct list to be mad out, all the changes in the land market baveto he watched- and

the value of properties hanging hands when no record is given can olly be ascertained by inspection at the Regicrar General's Office Brisbane The expensa of this comes out of the fee No assesso- can visit every house and allotment in the Municipality without a large outlay for bnggi hire, which also comes out of the fee Thee are many other items to bo paid before aiything is left for the assessors pay Tho detract price for this work was £200 being it the rate of 9Jd per assessment For nvkmg out notioes in duplicate and delivering same I receive £100 When I mention thattbere will be 11,000 to write out, and 5500 tidehver it will be patent that there is plentyof work for the money To enable «ne to iniehjthe work in the time, I shall have to employ a number of bands, who must wite out the notices, and deliver them simultaneously with my making

the valuations

In conclusion I think it only fair that persons who wish to attack should do so openly, and not ahild themselves under the wing of the Bullum

Tours fee. '

1!. L. DIBBIN.

Yours, &o., RATEPAYELR. [We understand that the contract with the Gas Company is to the effect that the lampe ehall be lighted for not more than ten hours twenty nights in each month. They are sup. posed to be kept lighted from dark to sunrise when there is no moon.-ED. M..]

articleText:
KOCKIIAMl'TON.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 23, 1883.

THE Opposition Press are indulging in peans over the safe return and marvellous squatting conquests of the adventurous brace of politicians who have just com- pleted a flying trip from Townsville to Charters Towers, Hughenden, Winton, Muttaburra, Aramac, Blackall, Charle- ville, and Roma, to Brisbane. They have discovered, among other wonderful things, that every able-bodied man in the western country is appalled at the astounding wickedness of the Trans- continental project. There was, in fact, no one outside Brisbane capable of say- ing a good word for it. The squatters naturally drêaded the cutting up of their runs, and the working classes feared that the railway, instead of being carried out by the Government whose pay was sure, would be undertaken and worked entirely by " foreigners " and imported labour. The Syndicate, in fact, including French bankers as well as English aristocrats, had no interest in the country, and wanted simply to plunder it. They would not only bring in foreign labour, but would exercise such unbounded in- fluence over the Government, and Parlia- ment for the time being, that they would, despite the wishes of the constituencies, fill the country with coolies and Chinamen, andcompletely drive out the present white inhabitants, The colony would then be

inhabited by three classes-proud off- j shoots of the British aristocracy, a few greedy French bankers, and some millions of " voteless serfs." Mauritius or Jamaica would then be respectable by comparison with the degraded although now rich colony of Queensland. This is the kind of talk in which the Canny Men have indulged out west, in the hope of thus securing the allegiance both of the squatters and their men. If Messrs. Grilfith and Dickson get into power, not only will there be no Transcontinental Railway, but the western squatters will have indefeasible leases, and voteless serfs will be kept forcibly out of the colony. With such inducements as these held out, it is not surprising that the people of Western Queensland have dis- covered the good policy of transferring their loyalty to the rising sun.

The returned travellers appear to have acquired an exhaustless stock of informa- tion during their rapid trip. Indeed, it will be quite useless in future for the squatting members to attempt to instruct the leading Liberals upon northern and western local peculiarities. Messrs. Griffith and Dickson have spent a whole month in exploring the Never-never country, and they are chock-full of the latest information respecting its physical and climatic characteristics, as well as the "".,u, Idiosyncrasies, ana wishes' or tts inhabitants. By the date when Parlia- ment meetr, they will have had ample time to digest and assimilate the mass of knowledge, which has been crammed into them by Cobb's coach-drivers, while on the road, and by hospitable innkeepers or squatters, at their nightly camps. They will, indeed, be perfect cyclopedias of information on western topics, and will be quite competent soon to under- take the piloting of the ship of State. No more shall they be reproached with ignorance of aught save Queen-street politics, and not again shall Sir Thomas M'llwraith expose the shallowness of their geographical criticism. And their party will gain a still greater advantage in having established centres, from which the battle shall be waged with the M'llwraith Government, in the very middle of their entrenched camps.

THE humilating failure of the Victorian four million loan has had an important effect upon the .colonial money market. Almost suddenly it is discovered that capital is scarce, that the bank screw must be put on, and that no advance must be made to any person for the pur- pose of assisting him in the acquisition of land. It is said that some of the Brisbane banks are giving as much as six and a-half per cent for deposits, although six is still the current rate for twelve months' fixtures. The mortgage rate too has considerably advanced. A few months ago money could be easily got on first-class eily properties at even less than six per cent ; now nothing less than nine per cent is mentioned, and an enlarged margin is demanded. The man who tries to borrow on unimproved 5ulnirban properly, even in Sydney and Melbourne, is laughed at for his pains. Certificates of title to such properties are forlhe time being valueless, and thc worst of the case is that thousands of persons, who a short time since bought allotments at fabulous prices under the exhilarating influence of champagne, now find that the payments already made represent far more than the intrinsic value of their purchases, while their six, nine, twelve, and eighteen months promissory notes for the balances, are still maturing. This is a very uncomfortable condition of affairs for many thrifty persons who invested hard savings, and pledged their prospective earnings for almost valueless land ; but they have no one to blame but themselves. The man who lives upon his salary, or whose business capital is limited, is not justified in buying land purely for speculative pur- poses. The man who has a hundred pounds in thc Savings Bank, and prefers investing it in allotments, is free to do so. He may lose by thc speculation, bul can afford it. But he who renews his paper to raise the wind, indulges in the fiscal operation known as " kite- flying," or pays to the auctioneer money due lo his storekeeper, commits an immoral act, which will almost certainly lead him into trouble. These practices are, in fact, speculations with other people's rooney, and that usually without

their consent The effect is to create fictitious competition, illegitimately swell current values, and inflict loss upon bona fide masters and dealers. The land mania which has just been rudely suppressed by a tight money market, will leave its bad effects upon the com- munity, long after the event has been

forgotten by the general public. . Money 1 so sunk is capital diverted from legitimate business and industries and to a. great ex- tent destroyed. It is well that the banks have at length tightened the purse strings, and dispelled the halo of ex- aggerated values, which, for the time being, had invested landed property of every discription. But are, the banks entirely without fault in this case ? They must, or ought lo have known, that their rapidly swelling advances were not legti mate. In Queensland alone during last year the debts of the public to the banks increased by close upon two millions sterling, or in the astounding ratio, of nearly forty per cent. The banks ought: to have known that the increase of population, trade, or wealth by no means justilied this inflation, and they must be held largely responsible for the bad con- sequences that ensue. The moment a bank assists its customer to enter into land buying for purely speculative pur- poses, that moment it creates a fresh competitor and unduly inflates market prices. And when a bank assists one of its customers to speculatively compete against another, or against the customer of a rival bank, then it does such customer mischief, which is often irremediable. We shall be to'.d that our

reflections now are equivalent to locking

the stable door after the steed has been

stolen. Perhaps so, but it is impossible for persons outside financial circles to judge when speculation is legitimate, and when it has become an incipient mania. It is in the bank parlour alone that the knowledge is available which would enable reckless speculation to be kept in salutary check.

IT would seem according -to our telegrams received last Saturday, that there is auother giganticTranscontincntalrailway scheme under consideration besides our own. Mr. Anthony Hordern, of Sydney, N.S.W., representing a Syndicate of London capitalists, has offered to construct a railway from Albany iu Western Australia, to Cambridge Gulf on the north- western coast of Australia, on tho land-grant system. Presuming this to be a genuine offer, we here have evidence of capital being available for the purpose of de- veloping the resources of Australia, but it is worthy of our careful considera- tion, that this capital may become speedily absorbed. Should, say, £10,000,000 stalling be speculated in Western Australia, it is not unlikely there may be some difficulty in getting the capital required for our Transcon- tinental line on anything like reasonable terms. The line proposed for Western Aus- tralia would extend over about 2000 miles of country, and in the construction of it some £10,000,001) is proposed to be spent. It may be that in the Syndicate now offering to Western Australia, will be some whose capital would be valuable to us, and it may turn out that after Queensland has been the first colony to moot the principle, it will be thc last to derive benefit therefrom. It may be that while we are wasting our energy on party politics others will outstrip ns in the London money market. There is one feature about this now Syndicate's proposal especially worthy of notice, and that is-besides the land given by the Government to the capi- talists, each immigrant they bring out will receive 1G0 acres of land. Now, as one of the chief arguments in favour of tho land grant railways IB that they will cause the country to become settled, it would be perhaps a good thing to introduce this system of land-orders into our contract. If it were done, one great grievance of tho anti-monopo lists would vanish.

BEFORE the Police Magistrate yesterday morning Frederick Garvey pleaded guilty to oharges of drunkenness and making usc of obsceno language. He was fined in all fifteen shillings, which ainouut he paid.

LAST Saturday's Government Gazetten notifies nuder tho Marriage Acttbe removal of Rev. John Peart, from Rockhampton to Bogantungan.

1000 acres on thc Landsborough river, and 1000 acres, Eversleigh and Albion Runs, Mitchell, have been reserved for camping and

water.

ON Saturday morning last (says the Clarence Examiner), while galloping on tho

course, tho racehorse Warlike Glee bolted off the track, and came in contact with a log, which dashed his brains out, His rider, a little boy, son of Mr. Fielder, who was train- ing him, had a miraculous escape, as ho was thrown oa the log, but, with the exception of having his face skinned slightly, was un- injured.

AT tho meeting of tho Shareholders of tho Crocodile Creek Alluvial G-ild Mining Oompany held recently in Melbourne, tho permanent Directors of the company and officials were elected and appointed. Many who aro watching tho progress of tho Company will bc pleased to hear that thc whole of tho necessary machinery and appliances required on thc Creek arc now on their way and operations will soon bo carried out that will prove the value of the field.

-i-TnK children from the Orphanage are still enjoying themselves at Mackenzie Island, Quarantine Station, where Captain Hunter again visited them last Sunday. All thc youngsters wore found well and happy, apparently enjoying themselves immensely. The Captain returned to town carly yesterday morning. It is expected that thc little holiday- makers will return by the Fitzroy, steam tug, on next Saturday.

TUE Queensland Monthly Postal and Tele- graph Guide for January has, amongst other information, tho following :-Post Office dis-

continued : Lake's Creek. Post Office estab- lished : Boyne River, near Gladstone ; and Capella (in placo of receiving office), which has boen discontinued. ^Receiving offices estab- lished : Avon Downs, near Clermont ( Cania (Mount Perry); Drynan's, near Bundaberg j Honeycomb, near Rockhampton ; Kynuna, Diamantina ; Lake's Creek (in place of Post Office) ; Nive Downs, Services increased : Capella to Yamala, from twice a week to three times a week ; Aramac-Muttaburra, from once a week to twice a week. An electric telegraph station has been established at Capella,

AT thc meeting to bo held on Thursday of the shareholders of the Queensland National Bank tho report and balance-sheet for the half year endingSlst December, 1SS2, isperhapsthe most satisfactory ever presented to the share- holders. The dividend to be declared is twelve per cent for the half-year, being two per cent above any previous rate of dividend declared by this Company. It will be shown by thc report that thc reserve fund has been increased by thu addition of £15,01)0 and now amounts tn £105,000. In congratulating the Company on this success, wo would point out that nearly all tho prurits of this large establishment, are distributed throughout the colony.

THE Town Band performed a very nioe «oleo tion of mnsic in tho vacant gronnd in William and East atreeti yesterday evening. There vrae quite « gathering to enjoy a performance.

TUE weather out west, the Blackall Clutm pion of Friday says, has been wet. Good showers had fallen for two or three days. The country looks magnificent ; and nothing ¡l¡kéi(¡lias ciar been experienced by pastoralists

before.

AT the meeting of .the Committee of dele- gates from the different Friendly Societies, held last night in the Club Room of the Palace Hotel for thc purpose of reading correspon- dence in reference to the appointment of the

medical officer, a deputation was appointed

to meet tho Doctor that had received the appointment. Thc meeting then adjourned.

MR. W. P. MELLEFONT, proprietor of thc Gladstone Observer, *vho was a passenger by the s.s. Leichhardt, informed us ( Wide Bau News) on Friday that news has been received from London as to the result of a trial ship- ment of 51 tons of manganese taken from the Auckland Point mine, Gladstone. The price obtained was £3 10s., which, after paying all expenses, gave a nett profit of £30 on the whole shipment. The news has, we understand, caused no small excitement in Gladstone, and manganese ie now regarded as containing thc elements of its future success.

WE understand that Mr. Stuart, Inspector of Police, has received twelve months leave of absence on half-pay. Inspector Stuart has only had two months holiday since he joined the Queensland polioc force fourteen years ago. During his sojourn in the northern districts he waa attacked by fever, and has never thoroughly got rid of its effects, A long sea voyage and entire change of climate, it is thought will relieve him of that troublesome disease, and accordingly he purposss, in com- pany with Mrs. Stuart, making a trip to thc mother country, leaving here on 1st March next. We trust Mr. Stuart will return to his official duties with renewed health.

TrtE following resolutions, containing an ex- pression of opinion by the Medical Society of Queensland with regard to the Brisbane Hospital management, have been formally adopted by that society : - "1. That the visiting staff of the Brisbane Hospital shall consist of six legally qualified medical practitioners. 2. That they shall be appointed by the committee. 3. That the resident staff shall be subordinate to thc visiting staff. 4. That the visiting medical staff shall form a committee for the medical management of the hospital. 5. That the visiting staff be appointed for three years, and be eligible for reappointment. G. That à copy of tho lore going be sent to the honourable the Colonial Secretary and to the Hospital Committee."

WE have been favoured by Mr. Broome, Woodlands, with a very carefully compiled register of the rainfall at Woodlands in the year 1882. It is tooelaborate for thc columns of a newspaper, but the following particulars will no doubt prove interesting ;

Month. Dat!» min fell. Inches. January . 4 .. 0010 February . 20 .. 17-240 March . 17 .. 24-735

April . IS .. 2-87S, May . 6 .. 0 717 .lune . 13 .. 0012 July . 6 .. 6-280 AtlEUst . '.. 7 .. 0'280 September. 8 .. 0 473 October .? 17 11-980 November. 13 .. 4-160 December. 21 5-847

Total.145 .. 81-812 Tuc annual examination in connection with State exhibitions to universities began at Bris- bane on 4th December, 1882, and ended on the 12th Deoembor. Tho written papers have (says the Courier) been valuod in Sydney, under the supervision and direction of the Senate pf the Sydney Univcreity. by whom,

also, the questions were prepared. Fivscandi-i

dates presented themselves for examination,' and the following three (whose names are given in the order of merit) have been recom- mended by the examiners as being of sufficient merit, namely :-James Alexander Hay, Bris- bane Grammar School ; James M'Nab, Brisbane Grammar School ; and Percy Lang- ford Townley, Ipswich Grammar School. The first two were holders of scholarships from the Central Rockhampton and Central Brisbane Strate schools respectively.

IT is understood (says the Courier) that the omnibus proprietors have obtained tho ear of one or more of the aldermen, and that strong efforts aro to be made to prevent the construc- tion of the proposed tramway, cither by thc council or-by a joint-stock company. It is alleged that under the provisions of the Local Government Act a special rate must be levied as soon as the loan is advanced, aud that one third of the ratepayers will have power to forbid the loan. But this is a mistake. The proposed tramway loan will not bo a loan within the meaning of the 22Gth section of the Local Government Act. By section 88 of thc Tramways Act, the advance would bo made under the Local Works Loan Act, " notwith- standing any restriction or limitation impose/! hy any otlier Act." Hcnco, if the Governor-in Council and Corporation agreed that the tram- way should be undertaken, thero would be no difficulty in thc way. It would be absurd to allow one-third of tho ratepayers in the municipality to practically Bay that a tramway should not be constructed in Woolloongabba

or Booroodabin.

MANY complaints have reached us lately from merchants and others of thc inconvenience caused by carriers delaying to deliver loadiug. From an exchange we find that two cases have lately been decided at the Blackall Police Court against carriers for thus *' wilfully delaying to deliver loading." Io ono case where goods had been sent by Mr. Curtis, of Rock- hampton, toa client, Mr. Ahnfcldt, in Blackall, the way bill bore date of June 2, 1882, and delivery did not take place till thc September following. The defence set up was that the carrier had been delayed by bad weather at Springsure where he waB compelled to remain for four weeks. The Bench Hued the defen- dant £40, in default levy and distress ; if not sufficient warrant, one month's imprisonment in Blackall gaol. In another case n storekeeper proved loss to thc amount of £100 through n a carrier's delay, and a fine of £45 compensation and £4 ls. 2d. coBts was imposed with thc same alternative as in the previous case. From this it will ho seen that njerchants and store- keepers are not completely in the hands of the carriers, and thc very heavy fines inflicted on thc two examples made at Blackall, should have a beneficial effect in causing a little more care to be taken by a very independent class.

WE have been favoured by Mr. B. Cribb, P.M., Acting Immigration Agent, with tho general summary of immigrants by thc ship Melpomene. With tho exception of a few trifling omissions thc list is somewhat similar to that previously published. Thc Melpo- mene, 1303 tons, iu command of Captain Bridges, sailed from Plymouth for thia port direct on 14th October. She is, therefore, 100 days out and is daily expected. No anxiety need by felt by thoBe who have friends on hoard at tho lengthy Voyage the vessel is making, as the ships lately arriving at Brisbane have encountered baffling winds, and made protracted voyages. The Melpomene brings 446 immigrants, equal to 383$ statute adults, under thc charge of Dr. Cunningham, as surgeon-superintendent, and Mrs. Gaudin, as matron- Miss Bridges is a saloon passenger and Mr., Mrs., and Miss Everley, Mies Kate tioulding, aud Mr. John Slice steerage passen- gers. The particulars of thc immigrants are

as follow:-Nationalities: SIC Kntdish and 130 Irish. Classification; C full payers. HI assisted, and 329 freo. Occupations : 82 fe- male domestic servants, 132 farm labourers, ll labourers, I gardener, 3 miners 1 cooper, 2 blacksmiths, 6 bricklayers, 1 eugiueer, 7 car-

penters, and 17 others, Social condition i CO

«married couplée, 130 single men, 88 single wemen, 36 malo and 55 female children, and

17 infants.

A-CENERAL meeting of the'members of the, .Early'Closing Association is notified to be held this evening at the Drill tilled.

articleText:
ROCKHAMP'TON.    

FRIDAY. FEBRUARY 2, 1883.

POLITICIANS who have been watching the course ot events ia Victoria will not be surprised at the announcement that the Ministry there have resigned. To many the wonder will be, not that they have resigned now, but that they have continued to cling to office so long. Only a very strong sense of utter inca- pacity and inutility could have led them to ky down the reins of office, and issue such an address as that of which we have

' received a summary by telegraph. With

I apparent coolness and complacency the I Ministry declare their own incom-

petency. They have asked for a disso- lution of Parliament, on the ground that it has done nothing in the way of useful legislation for the last eight months, and there was no prospect of an improvement during the remainder of the term. In any other body such action, upon the grounds professed, would be looked upon as senseless and ridiculous, bul in that of the Ministry of a large and wealthy colony it appears to deserve to be charac- terised as highly culpable. Their conduct is condemnable not in that they have resigned now, but that they did not con- sult the country long ago- At the outset the Ministry was of an experimental character. It possessed a coalition con- stitution, and its- longevity could not be looked for. In the face of continuous

and varied opposition, Sir B. O'Loghlen and his friends have retained their posi- tion at the head of affairs. Long ago they must have become convinced of the fact that their tenure of power was retained on sufferance. We will not do

them . the indignity of supposing they

were not conscious of their weakness

and helplessness. The discovery they profess to have made only recently was apparent to others long ago. They declare that they have been unable to cope with the opposition to which they have been exposed during the last eight months. Such opposition was to be anticipated, as it was well enough known that the Premier did not possess the con-

fidence of the members on either side of 1 the House. Repeatedly, in the course of business, he has had this fact im- pressed on his observation, but he proceeded, regardless of it, till he could go on no longer. The force of public opinion had become too strong for even Sir Bryan O'Loghlen to withstand its influence. For a time the Ministry were tolerated, but latterly they have been assailed by all sections of the press. Their conduct of public affairs, having merited, has met with general condem- nation. Instead of waiting lill com- pelled to retire amid the condemnatory diatribes of journalists, they ought to have tried to preserve some little dignity by resigning or appealing to the country months ago. In that event they might have enjoyed the respect of a section of the electors, but the result of the elec- tions, we fear, will show they have neither the confidence of the Assembly,

nor of the constituencies.

Those who are opposed to the practice of paying members for their Parlia- mentary services, will probably point to the present political crisis in Victoria as due to that cause ; and there can be little doubt, we think, that had the sweets of office not been luscious, and the emoluments of membership acceptable, the constituencies would have been consulted some time ago. Neither the Conservative nor Radical party was prepared to take office. The laaders of each waited, watching the current of

events, and in no haste to bring matters to a crisis for fear of offending the rank and file, who were doing little, and drawing their salaries. The arrangement was too good to last, and now it has been been brought to a most humilating conclusion. The Ministry are mostly to be blamed for it, but the members of Assembly are equally culpable. For the administration recently in office thebulkof them had little sympathy. They tolerated and kept the Government alive. Weak though it was they gave it the amount of vitality necessary for its existence. At any time they might have terminated its career, and thal they have allowed the Ministry, after eight months of com- parative idleness, to commit suicide, is not at all to their credit. It is possible, indeed, that, by the condemnation their conduct is certain to receive, the Ministry hope to profit. We shall be disappointed, however, if the electors, in their condemnation of the Parliamentary farce that has been going on for the last eight months, do not overwhelm both ministers and members with confusion.

How far the failure of the Govern- ment to float the recent loan has had an effect in precipitating the dissolution it is difficult to determine. Many will be ready to come to the conclusion that the want of rooney has led to the change, and the reverse is not clear. At the

beginning of last month the colony had at its credit in the banks upwards of .£920,000. In anticipation of the floating of the four million loan, the associated banks had placed ,£2,000,000 at the credit of the Govern- ment. The consolidated revenue, it was anticipated, would produce ,£3,000,000 at June next, which, with the balance on hand and loan, would have made an aggregate sum of ,£8,000,000, The ex- penditure not exceeding ,£4,000,000 would have lett the Government with

£4,000,000 to meet interest, liabilities,. &c. As the loan has not been floated, the bank advance will add to the burden of debt; arid the amount available for carrying on the Government &c, will be less than £6,000,000. Then, another loan of nearly four millions will require to be floatedat the close of this year. Thus

it will be seen that the financial affairs of the colony are not in a healthy state, and that circumstance, as much as the hostility of members in Parliament, has probably led the Ministry to seek a refuge from their troubles in a disso-

lution.

ON inquiring at the Police Office yesterday we learned that Rebecca Dobson, the young woman who was missing from her residence in Alma-lane tbeprevionsday, had returned home, having probably altered her miud as to drowning herself.

THE second anniversary of Court Maid Marian will be celebrated by a banquet in the Foresters' Hall, North Rockhampton, thia evening. The opportunity will be availed of to present Mr. F. Linthwaite, P.D.C.'Ranger, with an illuminated address, which has been tastefully prepared by Mr. J. Coker.

ANOTHER of the Mackay Cingalese, by name Elias, arrived by the coast mail steamer, and was lodged in gaol on Wednesday. He is under sentence of three montbB for having etolen property in his possession. The Maokay Bench is apparently determined upon forcing these very undesirable characters upon Rock- hampton.

ON Saturday last a man named Francis Heffernan, who was staying in the Royal Hotel, East-street, missed a tent and fly, and reported the loss to the police. Two miles, named Miles Dempsey and Walter M'Nicol, have been arrested at Emerald for the theft, and arrived in town yesterday evening in

charge of Constable Canning. They will be brought before the Police Magistrate this

morning.

A GREAT disturbance occurred at the Immi- gration Depot last night, owing to the single women raising an alarm that someone was attempting to effect an entrance into their quarters. The screams for a time was deafen- ing, and for over half an hour it was im- possible to pacify the girls. On examination no evidenoes of an attempt to break into the compartment were discovered. MoBt of the immigrants were more or less under the influence of liquor. Up to a late hour last night several of the girls continued hysterical. Several police were speedily on the soene, and did all that was possible to maintain order.

THE Mastodon Minstrels repeated their second programme last evening to a fair house. The various items were received by the audience with signs of approval, and consider- able merriment was produced by the laughable sketches. The band of the Company, which Slays outside previous to the performance,

eserves a word of praise for the able manner in which it renders excellent selec- tions. To-night an entire change of pro- gramme is announced, when the screaming burlesque on the favourite operetta "Pina- fore" will be performed under the title cf Pin-A-i. This piece is, we believe, the best performed by the troupe, and is spoken of by the Bouthern papers as excessively amusing. Doubtless there will be a good house to wit- ness it.

JAMES KEOGH, on remand, was brought  

before the Police Magistrate yesterday morn- ing, charged by the Police with drunkenness and disorderly conduct, using profane language, and resisting Constable Livingstone, who arrested him. There was a further charge preferred by Mr. Francis H. Nixon for having wilfully destroyed certain property in the complainant's premises in Quay-street. To all these charges the defendant pleaded guilty and would have been dealt with at once, but the complainant asked for a remand to permit of his solicitor, Mr. Melbourne, attending. The Police Magistrate could not see the utility of such a proceeding, as he was aware of the circumstances connected with the charges to which defendant had pleaded guilty. Mr. Nixon, however, strongly pleaded for an ad- journment till Saturday, which was granted. A vagrant named Elizabeth Helaion was sent to gaol for seven days.

The remainder of the immigrants per the Melpomene arrived by the steamer Fitzroy yesterday. Thc vessel towed apunt upin which the luggage was conveyed and also a number of the single men. On arrival the new comers were conducted to the depot where they were crowded together in anything lint a comfortable manner. The Superintendent of the depnt having no assistance is placed in a very difficult position, and certainly he should have at least oue man enpnged to take charge of the gate. Most ol the single men aro strong and of a serviceable stamp, the single girls are also a desirable lot, though apparently very inexperienced; most of them we are informed have already been engaged at wagoe ranging from eight to fifteen Shillings per week and application for thc remainder must be made early by those desiring to obtain them. One married couple was engaged at £70 per annum for station work. The whole of those now in depot will be available for hire to-day.

W« learn f rom tn old resident on the Croco- dile Goldfield that very favourable weather hal been experienced there lately, and every-

thing in the locality is looking flourishing. ' Mr. J. Muir, the old manager of the Burdett Coutts mine, is in oharge of No. 2 claim again, and states it is looking better than ever, and the average crashing np to date waa half an ounce to the ton, and good returns are pre-

dicted.

ALBRECHT FIIZ has just landed, direct from home, 60 cases superior Stiff and Sparkling Hocks and Moselle (io quarts and pints), equal in quality to the best brands of champagne, and at most moderate prices; also, 100 eases of Morbit's Patent Stopper Lager Beer (in"p!nts). Inspection invited.

ADVT.

articleText:
ROCKÍIM'JPTON.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 4. 1883.

OUR readers will doubtless have noticed an advertisement appearing ; in our columns, to which is appended the signatures ol most of our merchants and importers, and offering a reward for the detection of those who 'are guilty of pilfering the contents of packages landed, here Irom import vessels.' We'are. not

aware that this inducement has had the desired effect up till the. present time,

and are inclined to think the subject is. of sufficient importance, when considered : in all its bearings, to engage the attention . of our Chamber of Commerce. À dis- cussion recently took place at a meeting of the Sydney merchants on, a subject, which it seems to us has a close relationship to the evil, from which our towsfolk desire to free themselves. The meeting in the so'ufhcrh metropolis was convened to consider the terras and ' conditions inserted in Bills of lading, which are supposed to specify the nature. of the contract between the ship. and shippen. Complaint was made, and we think not altogether without just cause,' of ' ;the stringent conditions ihsis'ted.urjp'fi by some . lines of steamers, as the only terms iipon ; w)>jph' uiey" will ^contract foi flie'.çpri

veyance of goods ; and instances were cited/showmg how disadvantageous was thejr .operation upon, the generally, understood . -rights , and {recourses Of consignees. 1 An impartial examination of- the i cases- involving claims upon vessels,'employed to'convèy 'merchan- dise to the rnbie' fretrüerited SyuYhern potts, would doubtless disclose many instances in which claims, even of a debatable nature, had been recovered at the last momeut by putting into force the extreme., measure of arresting the vessel on the eve of her departure ; but, on the other hand, many just demands for redress have been resisted by over zealous shipmasteris and othert, who have perhaps been : improperly biassed by the assumption that the defaulting vessel would not again come inte

contact with the. injured parties'. Excesses of ibis' kind, Whether com- mitted by ship or consignee, cannot however but be considered as unfortunate, and tending to increase the tension already and unavoidably existing between ship and cargo. The old style of slow-going but money-making sailing vessel is how almost extinct. , The lading and discharge of such craft occu- pied a considerable time, and was con- ducted in a leisurely and very pains- taking, if' somewhat costly, fashion ; but there can be little doubt goods reached their destination then without such severe traces of thc exigencies of travel, as they frequently betray nowadays. Steam and speed haye revolutionised this, as well as most other things. Competi- tion lias led to successive reductions is freights. Steamers,are how'coritent with

rates that were ¿a lately paid' freely to

sailing vessels, and the only way in which oversea ships can now be made to pay,1 it is said, is to

increase the despatch with which their cargoes . are handled, and lo keep them always at work. In ports possessing the accustomed facilities, it is expected, that in a day.300 to 500 tons pf goods should pass out 01 into the hatchway. Under such circumstances, no proper inspection of a vessel's lading is possible, and the excess of speed tenders it impossible, for the consignee, as well as the ship, to detect the plun- dered packages from the host of .others by which they are surrounded or entombed. Merchants naturally com- plain that by this means they frequently accept goods they ought to refuse ; but, on the other hand, shipowners say we get so little freight, and are compelled to. drive our craft at stich speed that we will accept nothing more than a responsibility, for transit. We are i only paid for rpnveying the goods from

port to port, arid little enough for that. \Ve are not paid to protect or preserve the merchandise, and the packages

should be strong enough to stand the wear and tear to which they are likely to be subjected, and to-preserre their con tents from any mishap likely to overtake them. This determipation is surely sufficiently disclosed by the stringent clauses, in bills of lading adopted by nearly all steam lines, and if goods are intrusted tb their conveyance, under such conditions so. Well known and expressed, we question mitch whether those are who in reality parties to thc contract, can justly complain of ships taking advan- tage of the impunity that lias already been conceded to them by shippers, who are the accredited agents for the consignees. If the contention of ship- owners is tenable-that by participating in the benefits of cheap freights owners of goods acquiesce in the condition it is sought to establish - viz., that ships arc merely paid freight for conveyance, and that the speed and despatch with which cargo are now of

necessity handled, dispels the presump- tion that pillages (most of which show from careful measures adopted to restore exterior packages to merchantable appearance, that time and undisturbed opportunity are at thc disposal of the plunderers) do not occur while the cargo is under the charge af the conveying vessel. Then thc rleterminntion of the

Sydney importers, to lake jrrojter care to protect llicir goods from theft after landing, is a wisc one. In fact thc admission that, while remaining upon the wharves in Sydney, goods are insufli ciently protected from pillage justifies, to some extent, the position assumed by shipowners! and we would strongly urge

¿hatííhe jolpt committee, appointed by our Municipal Council and Chamber of Conjiperce,1 fchoilld take this phass of "ihevqucsUnp; into their; consideration in

framing their recommendations to \he Municipal authorities. It certainly seems ridiculous that the protection which would be afforded by enclosing 'the wharf w|ÜTáo:cipen feñpe shojíld npt have'been provided ere this. It would be po hardship upon' people' having occasion to visit the wharves after night-, fall, .that they should require fo enter and depart through a wicket, which might'be in charge of the night watchman;and we feel sure our merchants would appreciate such an assistance in preventing tbe' recurrence of the pilfering, ; and -the annoyance 'of which they complain.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. WEDNESDAY, JULY 4. 1883.
snippet: OUR readers will doubtless have noticed an advertisement appearing in our columns, to which is appended the signatures ol most of our merchants

ROCKHAMPTON.

MONDAY. AUGUST 13, 1883.

.THE Costóme collections at this port from the 1st to the Uth instant amounted to £360 4s. Wi.

SENTOR-CONSTAJILK CAHILL left town yester- day by the You Yangs, s.s. for Maryborough, in charge of a man named Poilsen, who was arrested at Emerald last week for the larceny of a saddle and bridle, the property of Mr. Baker, of Maryborough.

DR. LYNN, with a small company, will open a short season of three nights at the Theatre Boyal this evening. Amoug tho performers we notice the names of Miss Amy Blanchard, well known here, and Mr. Willie Lynch, a member of tho Lynch family of Bcllrinçcrs. Miss Blanchard will appear in here usual foats of clairvoyancy.

A MEETING of the friends and supporters of Mr. John Ferguson was held in Messrs. Green and Co.'s offices on Saturday afternoou, when an influential committee was appointed to endeavour to secure his return. A meeting

will beheld in the offices of Messrs. Jones and ' Brown this afternoon to appoint a committee to act in the interests of Mr. It. B. Jones.

CONSTABLE QUINN arrived from Blackall on Saturday in charge of a lunatic named Paul Linda, who was sentenced to a menthe' con- finement in the Rockhampton Reception House. Constable Gleeson also arrived here

the same day escorting a prisoner named James ' Badcock, who waa arrested at Winton on a j charge of wife desertion, and remanded to Yeulba.

IT was reported to the policB yesterday by Mr. .1. H. Smalley that a maa was camped about eight and a half milos from town on tho Yaamba Road sinoe Friday morning, and was supposed to be of unsound mind, tie had no blankets, food, or clothing with him, and was about a mile and a half from any water. On Friday evening he was observed standing over a heap of wood and leaves, as if he thought it was on fire. Mr. Smalley believes if the man is not removed he will wander into the bush and be lost.

AT thc Police Court on Saturday, before thc Police Magistrate, a female, charged with drunkenness, was cautioned and discharged. Denis Crouin, charged with being drunk and disorderly, was fined £2 ; in default forty eight hours' imprisonment. John Long was fined a similar amount for disorderly conduct. Martin Coughlin, charged on remand with absconding from his apprenticeship with M. Ryan, was discharged, as the Police Magis- trate held he had nc jurisdiction.

A TELEGRAM in the Courier of Monday last, dated Townsville, August 5, states that the Right Rev. Dr. Stanton, Bishop of Northern Queensland, preached to a large congregation in St. James' Church that evening. During his discourse he urged the building of a cathedral church at Townsville. After the service a moeting was held, and a committee appointed to raise the necessary funds and make arrangements for the erection of the Ereposed edifice. Over £1000 has already

een subscribed for that purpose.

CONSIDEKAIÍLJ: interest waa taken in a double sculling race on Saturday afternoon between Messrs. 15. R. R. Coar (stroke) and G. Shaw (bow) aud Messrs. 1\ O'lteilly (stroke) and \V. O'Neill (bow). The first named crew allowed their opponents a start nf two boats lengths tu a mil«, ami thc contest waa pulled up tho river with the tide. The match was expected to be a very close one, but it proved otherwise, as O'Reilly and O'Neill increased their lead with every stroke, finally winning iu the most easy maimer by about six lengths. Time, G inins. 15 secs. Messrs. W. Schmidt aud K. M'Clelland wore starter and judge respectively.

A SM isii occurred in Bul so vcr-street early on Saturday morning. A horse attached to a buggy was left standing in William-street, and during tho absence of the owucr the animal bolted down the street, and turned into Bolsover-struet. After running very noar to thc fences around the trees along thc side of thc Btioct, it at last carno into collision with one near thu Hibernian Hall, snapping a corner post in two, and takiup; off ono or two palings, besides breaking off tho shafts of thu vehicle, which overturned and one of thc wheels came off. Thc horse ran up the street with part of the shafts attached to him, but was afterwards recaptured,

Mu. WELD BLONDELL'S valedictory address to the electors of Clermont appears in last Friday's Peak Downs Telegram. An intended lengthened absence from Queensland has led him to resign his seat. Mr. George Hislop, Arcturus Downs, comes forward as a Minis- terial candidate. He is opposed, however, to land-graot railways and such a Btream nt emigratiua as Mr. Griffith proposes. He is in favour of increased pastual rents, and larger areas for aeloction. Mr. W. H. M'Kean, Clermont, having been requisitioned I has consented to stand as an independent

candidate. He will oppose coloured labour, and do all he can for Peak Downs' interests.

THE third anniversary toa meeting of the Primitivo Methodist Church, Yaamba Road, North Rockhampton, is announced to be held to-morrow evening.

ATTBNTIOX is directed to the sale to be held by Mr. (J. S. Curtis at his rooms at eleven o'clock this morning, of the properties of Dr.

Harricks and Mr, Abrahams.

THE electors nf Rockhampton are reminded tbat Mr. W. K. HigBon will address them in the School of Arts to-night at eight. To- morrow night Mr. Ferguson will speak in the North Rockhampton State School, and Mr. Roes R. Jones at Allenstown. The latter will also address the electors in tho School of Arts on Wednesday night and at North Rock- hampton on Thursday night. Mr. T. Mac- donald Paterson will meet the electors in Allenstown State School to-morrow night, and in the North Rockhampton State School on Wednesday night.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, AUGUST 13, 1883.
snippet: THE Customs collections at this port from the 1st to the 11th instant amounted to £360 4s. 10d. SENIOR-CONSTABLE CAHILL left town
