articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1883.

' ÍN the course of the recent political j

struggle in the colony, references, were

frequently made to the code of honor, I and no man has been more frequent in his allusions to it than the Premier-the j Hon. S. W. Griffith. When addressing his friends at the Ipswich banquet he pointed out several instances in which, in his opinion, the Ministry hM violated this unwritten statute. He stated, in most pointed language, that his op- ponents had "exhibited themselves to the Australian colonies, and to the world, as setting at defiance, and trampling under foot, every rule that was in other countries laid down and recognised; because there were in politics, as in private life, certain unwritten rules of honour, which Wen were supposed to observe." On that occasion he also declared :-" His party would do no wrong, if they could help it, but they would do all they could to right the wrongs that had been done." One of the wrongs the hon. gentleman referred to was the appointment to the Commission of the Peace of men " of

whom he had DO hesitation in saying, if he had any voice in the matter, they would not remain on that commission after the ist January next." Upon reading these words it must seem most extraordinary to our readers, that the gentleman who uttered them should have called upon the Legislative As- sembly of this colony to elect as its President a man who was described as " a thrice convicted lelon." We put it to our readers whether the Premier has not been guilty of something more than making a serious mistake, as thc Courier says ; whether he has not been guilty of flagrantly and of set purpose, infringing those unwritten laws of honour, which he so recently argued deserved and commanded observance among men of honour. It is of the very essence of the unwritten laws, to which thc Premier appealed, that honour should bc given to whom honour is due. Thc position of President of the first assembly of

gentlemen in the colony is one of

honour. "Thc tradition of thc chair (says the Courier) takes its risc from the earliest dawnings of the Parliamentary history of our race. The Speaker of an English Assembly has always been a man before whom every member, how- ever highly born, however elevated in character, could bow down in obedience and respect. He has betMi spoken of as tlie first Commoner, and the dignity and thc character of the whole representative body is in a manner centred in his person. The minor offices of the House,

seats ia the Ministry itself, may perhaps be occupied by men of indifferent repute, placed there by the furce of I circumstances ; but, to the best of our

belief, it has never before happened that a Legislative Assembly, elected by any of the English-speaking race, has delibe- rately chosen as its Speaker arid mouth- piece a man whose history is not free ¡rom notorious taint." Upon evidence

of this character we think it is indis- putable that the code of honour, "the unwritten rules of honour,

which men were supposed to observe "- I demanded that the office of Speaker

should be held by a gentleman of '

unblemished reputation, and whose character should command respect Nevertheless, the Premier brought for- ward a man who did not possess such a character. It was pointed out that his reputation was not unblemished. As Sir Thomas Mcilwraith put it " he had been told by the judges of hiscountry that he is unfit to have the ordinary liberty of a citizen." Mr. Archer protested against the appointment of a man " who had suffered as Mr. Groom had-a man who has not shown by his conduct that he had in any way altered his character." He called upon " all honest men who love Queensland and love its honour " to protest against such an appointment. Other hon. members spoke strongly of the dishonour that would be done. In fact, they appealed to the unwritten laws which Mr. Griffith had declared so recently were entitled to respect, yet their words fell, as it were, on deaf ears. To show that their hostility was not of a partisan nature, the Ministry submitted the name of a respectable member of the Opposition for selection, but it was rejected without hesitation. It is perfectly clear, therefore, that the hon. gentleman at the head of the present Administration has openly, and in the face of indisguised opposition, been guilty of breaking the code of honour. It does not mitigate, but rather aggra- vates the offence that he has done so to

I meet the exigencies of party. He has j sacrificed hoDour to party. Upon the

first occasion when he was called upon ' to chose between observance of the

unwritten laws of honour, and the recognition of the claims of a political j adherent, he has disregarded the former

to satisfy the latter. Whatever may be , thought of the proceeding by men in I this colony, and by those in other

colonies, is not of so much, practical importance to us as the abrogation of the code of honour. If it was to be re- garded as a calamity that the late Govemmefit had trampled the unwritten laws under foot, what hope is there for the people of Queensland, when the members of the new Government com- bine to violate them in the manner we have demonstrated. In the conduct ol the business of the country as in the

relations of life, there are a great many unwritten rules, which men of honour must observe, and it is on the under- standing they shall do so that hon. members have positions of honour and trust conferred on them. Let these rules be disregarded, and as a matter of public safety we must enlarge our List of statutory penal offences. That seems to be the extremity to which we are being driven by the action of the Premier, aad it is one which there is great reason to deplore. The man who is knowingly guilty of an act, pregnant with such con- sequences, does more than make a mistake : he commits an offence that deserves to be held in universal public reprobation.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1883.

articleText:
ROOK I IA M!'VON.

WEDNESDAY. MARCH 21, 1883.

MR. MACROSSAN will have the satisfac- tion on his retirement that his worst enemies have al length paid tribute to his indefatigable industry as an adminis- trator, and to his power as a public debater. The Brisbane Telegraph, naturally enough, could not join in the universal tribute without following it up with some unworthy inuendoes and insinuations, but that is characteristic of the Telegraph in dealing with the political opponents of the parly which it serves. Some of our southern con- temporaries have not yet spoken on the subject, but the cordiality with which most of them testify lo Mr. Macrossan's good qualities proves that if he has not been a popularity-seeker he has won that which is far more valuable to an honest and strong-minded man-appreciation and esteem from opponents as well as friends. The public man who subsists upon the thoughtless hurrahs of the crowd will never become robust upon his fare. Mr. Macrossan was a real working politician, and, after his ten years of assiduous labour, lie lus cer- tainly earned the privilege of the retire- ment without existing detraction.

Our business now, however, is chiefly with his successor. Mr. Norton, a most excellent man, bas had the misfortune to represent the constituency of Glad- stone, which is guided by a few property owners who want their port made a big city at the public expense. If anything

bas tarnished the brightness of Mr. Norton's political career, it is the_ too conscientious representation of the wishes of his selfish constituents. It was his repeated and exhaustive speeches tn favour of the Gladstone pier and har- bour, and his unceasing denunciation of the Fitzroy "ditch" and Eupatoria

"mud bank" that lost him for a con-

siderable time the ear of the House. ( For members of the Assembly will not be bored with a grievance, or allow one man to continually thrust his opinions down their throats. And yet it is reported that in seeking re-election now he has accepted office, Mr. Norton will be opposed, and possibly defeated. From one point of view we should be glad to see this happen, for there are several constituencies in the colony who would be delighted to secure Mr. Norton's services at the general election. He is far too good a man to be worried by the political wire-pullers of his present constituency.

The Census returns show that the electorate of Gladstone is absurdly over- represented. In May, i88r, it contained only 571 adult males, including 42 Chinese and Kanakas. Compare this with the adult males in the other central electorates. In Rockhampton they numbered 1653 ; in Mitchell, 2825 ; in Leichhardt, 2180 ; and in Blackall, 1331. It is unreasonable, therefore, on the part of the Gladstone people to expect their ? member, who is only one in fifty-five, to

compel attention to and seek the redress of his constituents grievances. Cer- tainly by rejecting Mr. Norton they would not advance their cause, foi of necessity he must be more in- fluential as a Minister than he possibly could be as a private member, and infinitely more influential than any other member that the Gladstone people . would be likely to command,

s On the whole, therefore, we doubt i \ Mr. Norton will meet with any rea! i opposition, unless for the purpose o \ getting money spent. We do no fc suspect the new Minister for Works o . the -folly of buying his way into thi

Cabinet. The game is not worth th< candle now that the end of the Parliamen r is so close at hand; and Mr. Norton ii a toa conscientious a gentleman to descent . to such an unworthy proceeding in an; } event. Still some Opposition man ma;

possibly be encouraged by great Libera promises and Queen-street money ti 1 make a flutter for the seat. Even if Mt t Norton were thrown out the catastrophi I would not break the Government ; When it was less strong in the consti i tuencies than it now is, its Attorney ? General was defeated, and it has nov - lived nearly four years since that even! ? The Government have yet other member ¡ to fall back upon, we have no doubt

. and 'if Mr. Norton should be de

S feated the country would suffer loss, bu [ Gladstone would receive much injury

A constituency which gave a powerfu ' political party such a slap in the face a i to throw out its Minister for Work

before he had been allowed a fair trial would incur the enmity of that party fo a long time to come. In the meantim the Fitzroy improvements, the Eupatori wharf, and the Port Alma railway wouli be briskly pushed on, and poor Glad stone would be sitting in sackcloth am ashes. Taking all these things into cor sideration, therefore, we can hardl; anticipate that Mr. Norton will hav much trouble in getting re-elected. H is one of the most respected men in th House, and can put his case forwan with great ability. Those who knot him most intimately trust him mos unreservedly ; and foolish as we believ our Gladstone neighbours to be, we car r not believe that they will cut their owi

throats, as they unquestionably would di by rejecting Mr. Norton.

, CAN the prosperity of a country b

demonstrated by the progress of it [ banking institutions ?-is a question tha ! presents a variety of considerations, an ? is not so easy to decide as a large nura

ber of people suppose. According ti ? the London Economist these finaseis

institutions in the colony have beei making grand strides, and it is certaii that of all Britain's Colonial possession; the Australias have in this direction gon ahead the most. As will be known b. all commercial men, a large quantity 0 English capital is laid out in shares ii Colonial Banks, and thus the raaterU advancement ot these is a matter c very great interest to a large body c speculators in the London Exchange Hence it will be seen that it is eminentl to the interest of these capitalists t maintain the credit of the Colonies t the utmost, and all actions on their pai to exalt our assets, and prove our rc dundancy and stability, must be receive with the utmost caution. The journ: above referred to, quotes the follow-in figures as evident of the expansion c prices in the Colonial money market .

-Market Prices-s

Dec., 1882. Dec. ISSI. Gail

£ * per cen Bank of Anstrslnsia SSI ,, 80 Ul

Bank of South Aus-

tralia .. S9 .. 3U

Bank of N.S. Wales 00 62 OS flank nf New Zealand ZO : 26 4 Bank of Victoria ..SS .. 80 .. bk EnElish,Scottlsh,nnd

Australian Char-

tered. 281 .. 25 .. 14

London Chartered of

Australia .. .. 22§ .. 21 8 National of Austra- *

tasia.81 SJ

National of New Zea-

land .4 ,. 4

Queensland Na-

tional .. io .. ol fi.

Union of Australia.. OOJ 02J e\ From this it will be seen thal every on of these banks shows a rise, and tha lhere was durin-; the past year an increas of six per cent in the value of money ii

the Colonies.

Now does lin's increase in the value c money in the country indicate ou prosperity ? First, we would point to i report hy the Rev. \V. M lyew on th state of the agricultural classes of Knj land, anil we find that gentleman rc porting the tenant fanner and sim landholder were heilig driven gradual) but surely to poverty, while in Hie sinai and large towns lawyers were Imildin large mansions, and Banks and Ir, surance companies were erecting magn ficent structures. Here is evidence thu the advancement of Binking Institution

was marked by a corresponding deterior- ation in agriculture. Again turning to Ireland we find that, year by year, as the Bank continued declaring magni- ficent dividends, the peasantry, and in fact the bulk of the population, was being driven to absolute starvation and again we ask does the progress of Banking institutions, mark the advance-

ment of a country?

In looking into the operations of these financial syndicates-for such they are to a great extent, if not entirely. We find that their actual interest lies mainly in the speculative proclivities of their clients. The man who establishes a business upon bills has to work day and night, and rack his brain and constitu- tion, in the effort to meet these bills. Very frequently he is unable to do so, and this actually tends to the advantage of

the Bank that has accepted his ; paper so long as he can' pay in- terest, and show reasonable assets to insure the safety of renewals. The larger number of clients of this class that a bank possesses the better for it ; but the larger number of these in a country shows that in developing its resources' and advancing its industries, the people generally do not progress they merely work for the Banks. But as another evidence almost conclusive of the fact that the advancement of the Banks, is not a certain indication of a country's progress, we quote the follow- ing figures again from the Economist, showing the value of imports into the United Kingdom from Australia :

1832. 1881. mo. 187».

O month! ..22,400.000 24,000,000 22,257.000 19,«80,000 ¿dd «old.... 2,283,000 8,(72,000 1,007,000 2,603,000

Totals ....21,778,000 28,182,000 23,804,000 22,499,000

This exhibits that, while in 1882 the Banks could declare increased dividends, the exports from the Colonies had de- ceased. Of course during this period tie crops in different Colonies had fitted ; and this fact at once shows that the failure of the crop compelled the agriculturist to seek accommodation, and hence his disaster proved the

benefit of the Banks.

Lately, however, we have had un- mistakable proof that the Banks are not inclined to accommodate to such lengths as hitherto.' They realise that to allow their clients to go on borrowing to pay off interest, and to continue endeavouring to cheat the inevitable result of agri- cultural disaster must end in bankruptcy, arti before the assets have become too ' diminished, it has been decided to put

on the break. What effect this will hate generally it is impossible to tell, but very fortunately a most prosperous season in several colonies - more especially in Queensland-induces the hope that one year of plenty may make amends for the years of famine. Certain it is, however, that a vast amount of unhealthy speculation will be pre- vented, and real estate at all events will assume its true value. From this condi- tion of affairs the legitimate trader has nothing to fear, and it will only be the gambling speculator that will grumble. Undoubtedly values will be fixed upon a sound and reliable basis, trade will be conducted upon genuine principles, and we shall really know our exact position. The hard facts that are forcing them- selves upon the public, with regard to the colonial money market, may be unpalatable, but it is far better to realise that there are breakers ahead, than to proceed on blindly, and suffer wreck upon the unseen rocks.

WE understand that the Government have assessed at £60 the improvements on tho pieoo of grouod purchased by the Rev. Father Comerford at Westwood.

THE Festal Guide for March notifies the Aramao mail service has been extended from Wostlands and Tooal, and Rockhampton and Springsure, ta Tambo. Time tables have been altered.

As is usual at holiday times, there are to bo sports at Emu Park on Easter Monday. This time, lioworer, a programme hos been pub- lished, and from our advertising columns it will be seen that there are seven events. Only horse races are mentioned, but we havo no doubt there will be foot races and other amusements as wolL, as them has been at such soasons for the lost few years. Should the weathor keep fine, a large number of people will no doubt visit this favourite watcring-plaoe, and an oujnyablc time will bc spent.

L*ST Saturday's Government Gazelle notifies the appointment of Mr. Justice Harding os Acting-Chief Justice of the colony during the absence on leave of Sir Charles Lilley. Mr. A. J. Richardson, district surveyor, Rock- hampton, to bc an appraiser of runs; Mr. G. W. Young, acting recording clerk at Rock- hampton, to be acting land commissioner and acting land agent for tho Rockhampton land agent's district, during Mr. Wodehouse's absence on leave. Certain lands will bc thrown open for selection on and after date appended ¡-Springsure (laud resumed from Clifton run, around town of Bogan tun nan, area ten square miles), 24th April, and Glad- stone, 24th April.

Mr. PARSONS, Minister for Education, South Australia, who was recontly on a visit to thiB polony, since MB return home has boen giving an account of what he saw here of Í(articular interest. He has described at groat ongtb the sugar industry in Mackay and neighbourhood. At the close of his article be says:-"There can be no doubt whatever that the future prosperity of the northern portions of Australia depondB mainly upon thc introduction of suitable labour. Those who are interested in or propose entering upon tropical agriculture in the Northern Torritory may rest assured that the best, tho most economical, and reliable labour is placed within their reach by the Indian Immigration Act, which has recently received the Royal

assent."

A VERY neat programme has beau issued by the proprietors of the Cremorne Zoological Gardens of prijeR to be competed for on Kastor Mond-iy. There are in nil fourteen events, theprincipalonebeingthoCromorne Zoological I Gardens Handicap. It is to bc ruu at three

distances, viz . 100. 150. 200 yardi, and is tn decide! hy p-iinls-5. 4, and'3. There are prii.es for the first three men, that fir the winner heine, five gulngai. At night the grounds will he decorated, and a special prize nf a silver ineñSí .vid £| note has been given hy Mr. H. M.iciree f"r tho best pair ot waltzers. Thu lady receives the medal and the gentleman the note. Thc gardens should bc well attendeil, as there is now a fair col- lection oF animals nn I a cosmorama of the world on view. We wonl I remind those who intend entering for the big handicap that they i must send in their names to the proprietors j not later than aeren o'clock this craning.

WE understand that Mr. E. K. Ogg hu bean nominated to 611 the position ol Grammar Sohool Trastee, whian, was rendered vacant by the resignation of Mr. T., T. Faunae. Aa there is no opposition, he nae been elected, and it is ta be hoped will aooept the position.

REGARDING the f rozon meat trade, the New- castle Baily Journal of January 5 says : " The 'East Indies ¡are turning to Australia to supplement their supply of animal food. As a pioneer boat the Fiado, e.a., -of Sunderland, is now being supplied with the necessary apparatus, and is to run between the North of Australia and Singapore and Calcutta. She is expected to leave London in ballast for Australia early this month. This steamer has hitherto made most successful voyagea."

ANOTHER, illustration of the : manner in which our road repairs are exoouted, was fur- nished yesterday in one of our most pnblic thoroughfares. As Messrs; Rutherford's brake was being driven along Fitzroy-street one of the bones in it swerved and ran into a bed of clay which was placed to form the side of the stroet. It sank about a foot, and being unable to extricate itself, fell. The other horse was taken out of the vehicle, and it was only after a great deal of trouble and exertion that the fallen animal was got out of the trap.

ONLY a light shower fell on Mouday night and another yesterday afternoon. The rain has extended ooastwise bat with the exception of St Lawrence and Mackay, only tight showers are reported, with cloudy weather at other northern towns. Rain fell at Isisford during the night and at Gladstone it woe showery. Telegraph advices report that nine day's rain visited Jundah and the Thompson River was a bauker, but subse- quently the weather cleared. At Windorah

wo hear tho residents had to oart water six' miloB, but since then light showers have tallou. Up till a late hour last nighc the appearance of tho Bky predicted fine weather.

WE have on several occasions referred io the palisading surrounding tho Roooption Honse BB being insufficient to prevent an in- mate from scaling it. And last night: another instanoo occurred which affords ample re- flection for the authorities to take steps to prevent a recurrenoe of escapes. The South' ' Sea Island Jimmy, who re- cently furiously assaulted Mr. W. J. Connolly, made good hie exit from the cell

from which he was about to be taken to another. He made a rush past the warders and cleared the enclosure very easily. The police were informed, and they are on the alert. Any information .concerning the lunatic's whereabouts will be thankfully re- ceived by the Senior-Sergeant. The Islander is described os being 5 ft. 2 in. high ; haa blaok bushy whiskers, and was dressed ia a striped shirt, moleskin trousers, and wore a grey felt hat.

AN attempt was made yesterday to arrango a match for this afternoon between tho Eleven clioseu to play against Brisbane and an lîigk toen All-comers. It was subsequently, how- ever, considered inadvisable for the match to como off, several of tho Eleven being unable to get away from business in time. A scratch match will probably take place at North Rock- hampton between members of the Early Closing Association, at the usual time. The Eleven will practioe aa usual in Egan's paddock, com. mencing at half-past four sharp.-A match will be played at North Rockhampton, com menoing at half-past two o'clock, between the City and Stanley Clubs, the following being the players chosen :- City : W. Nash (captain), Minnie, Phillips. E. Goddard, W. Eaton, W. Sellars. F. Nurcombe, C. Nurcouibe, Charlton, H. O'Neill, and Curley. Stanley : J. Wil- liams (captain), Clancy, J. Bryan, Price, G Hunt, S. Hunt, Clark, Gibbous, Morrison, Dickson, and W. Jackson.

IK connection with tho proposed annexa- tion of New Guiaea by Queensland, we may

mention that the St- James' Gazette has

directed public attention in England to thc fact that somo of the isUuda iu the Pacific which the French have threatened to annex, as well as others already appropriated bj them, may beoome powerful strategic position! on the various routes betwuen the Aus tralasian colonies and America; three ol which routes-to Panama, San Franoisco, anc to the future Pacific terminus of the Canadian railway-traverse the Pacific groups ii different directions. In view of the fact tba' ooaliug stations or armed harbours of refugi will certainly be required in the future for thi protection of British commerce in the PaciSo it is important to remember that at preson Great Britain does not possess a singh " rock " of any kind in tho wide oxpansi betweeu New Zealand or Fiji and tho coast o

America.

A CORUESPOVDKNT says .--\ bunch of dato has bceu hanging in Mr. Wright's window foi some time, which was deolarcd by all whi notioed the fruit to be no good-the fault ii neither that of the date nor of the climate, The fruit had been pulled before it wai ripe, even before the stone was formed Tho true is thc Pluaiix Spinosa, a nativi of South America. It ¡8 a stemlesi Palm, well adapted to this climate and haB boen successfully grown by Mr Coker on tho north Bide of tho river. Th< fruit, now nearly at maturity, has tho appear ance of a small plum, very handsome aw saccharine-thc stouo being small and per fectly formed. The tree, liko all tho palms is highly ornamental, occupies little space, and ia well worthy of cultivation. Of course the specimen in Mr. Wright's window was nol grown by Mr. Coker, tho fruit from h¡B pain being four times tho eize.

WE have had an opportunity of glancing al the plans of a very Gae block of buiMiuge about to be erected by Mr. Walter Cook on the ground in East-street wheru he so loiif carried on business. Tho edifice will be 13! feet long and 32 feet high. It will bo tw< storey, with five shops on tho ground floor, and suiteB of chambers, suitablo for In« officcB, A.c., on thc first floor. The front wall will bo of Stanwell sandstone, and tho remaining walls of brick. A great outset to the lower end of East-streel will be formed by the completion of the build tag. Is the centre of the lower «torey will be a handsome arched doorway, giving access to the stair leading to tho upper storey. It and the shop doors and windows will be orna- mented with moulded sidos and heade. Tb« range of windows in the upper storey decorated in similar style will have a fine effect. Above them, supported by ornamental brackets, will be a moulded cornice and open balustrade. We wish thc Town Council would uso its in

fluonco to induce proprietors in East-street tc form nil new building* two storeys high and with ornamental frontage.

OOH telegrams .announce thc death of Cap. tain Frederick Charlee Standish, a well known Victorian, at Melbourne on Monday, of heart disease. Heaton'* Australian Me. tiomry of D<i(*s says : - " Captain Standish was a son of the I.ito Charges Standish, ol Standish Hall, Wiiian. lancashire, and was born in 1824; was c lucatod at Prior Park College, and then entered the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich ; obtained a commission in the Royal Artillery, in »hieb lie served for nine years, and retired with the rank of Captain. He came to Victoria in 1S.V2. and in 1S54 was appointed AssUlint-Coni'm-isionor of liol.lnVMs at Rand hurst, ni) I in ISIS Chinóse Protector. On thc rctiitrnntinn of Sir Charles .Macmahon ho was undo Chief Commissioner of Police." This iipjioiiitniriii bc b_-U np to last year, when lie n.-Kli!iic-'l, partly in ,-ons. qinm-e nf thc n.lvorse ti|iiui"n« of thu Co'nmissiim a-.-p'tmtc.l to inquire into certain allegations re*prclin»¿ mea. sures taken for the suppression uf the Kelly Bans. Tho deceased gentlemau was on the Committee of the Viotorian Itaoing Club, in the inausgemeut of whose affairs he evinced a lively interest,

WE hoar that Mr. J. Costello, of Cawarral Station, has recently purchased 1000 heifers from Banksia station, and twenty bulls from Mr. Wilson, which be intends sending to one

of bis stations out west.

THE Bulimba's immigrants were released ' from quarantine yesterday, and brought up to town in the Fitzroy, a. last night. They arrived at the Depot about nine o'clock. There are oighty-six for this port and forty seven for Mackay.

IN answer to a telegram sent by Mr. Follett Milford to Mr..J, Neeson, the Secretary of the Stanley Crieket Club, that gentleman replied from .Maryborough yesterday to the following' effdot :-" Will play on Saturday and- Monday. Leave here to-morrow (Wed- nesday) morning." Consequently the first match will bc played on Saturday next.

AN open mooting of the Excelsior Lodge of Good Templars was held in,the Oddfellows' Hall last night, when there wera about fifty persons present. Thc chair was occupied by Mr. D. Kilpatrick, who opened the meeting by an excellent address on the advantages of temperance. Kev. 1). Mossop delivored a a very impressive address, and addresses were delivered by several other .gentlemen present. Mrs. Wilder gave sorao excellent selections of music on the piano, and como songs were sung by members of thc lodge with great spirit. The evening's proceedings were much enjoyed by those prescut.

A PA.RADE of both Volunteer Companies, in full dress, is convened for this afternoon at five, in the Drill Shed, preparatory to leaving for Stanwell by to-night's train.

THE annual fortnightly sittings of the Small Debts Conrt will be held this morniug, at ten o'clock. There are seven undefended and throe defended oases for hearing.

ATTENTION is directed to the sale of the assortment of Crockery and Glassware, to be held in Mr.' R. L. Dibdin's Crockery store by Messrs. A. E. Alexander and Sons, this morn- ing at cloven. Such a varied collection should command a ready sale.

IMPROVEMENT IN IRELAND.-Another and most significant sign, of reconstruction in Ireland (says the World) is the election, without, pledge or oondition, expressed or implied, of the O'Conor Don to the Kildare street Club; generally closed to Catholic candidates. It is evident the most cultured

forces of both creeds are resolved on a wise ' rapprochement for the defenoe of social order and the rights of property. Snob a union of the best Irishmen, without distinction of creed or political colour, is in itself a strong guarantee for the future of the country. The ' Conservative and Catholic element are be- ginning to see they have more in oommon than in ascendancy days, and the result will be a certaiu degree of social fusion in Ireland never previously attained.

NUISANCE CASE.-A oasé of considerable interest bus been concluded at tho Nowton Police Court. Some months ago, in consé- quence of a petition signed by a number of inhabitants of Camperdown complaining of the uuisanoe occasioned by the smoke pro- ceeding from the chimneys of a gloss manu- factory owned by Joseph Ross, a prosecution was instituted against him by the police. The case has been occupying the attention of the Newton Police Court, presided over by Mr, Dillon, 3.M., from time to time during the last two months. A great many witnesses were called by both sides. For the prosecu- tion, a number gave evidence that they suffered a great deal of annoyance and dis- comfort from the smoke and soot omitted by tho establishment, and several stated tbat at times there was a very disagreeable smell proceeding from the works. For the defence, a number of residents living near tho defendant's premises deposed that thoy had suffered uo inconvenience whatever from the smoke, end that it was in no way a nuisance. Mr. Dillon considered that the case was one for a jury to decide, and he accordingly committed it for trial at the ensuing Quartor Sessions.-,?. M. Herald.

YoüTiiriJL BURGLARS. - Five boys named James Wilson, John Peel, John Ward, Samuel Hornsby, and Thos. M'Ñamara, wore charged atthe PoliceCourtOluues, on 9th March, with attempting to enter a house at Glendonald, near Clones, owned by a miner named Sheriff. The boys drove up to the house at two o'clock on Thursday afternoon in a bnggy which they had hired from Ballarat Sheri was asleep, but the noise the youthful burglars made by breaking through the glass and lifting tho sash of tho window awoke him. When tho boya found that they were discovered they made nff in their buggy, but wore fullowod by

Sheriff in another vehicle. After a chase of

three miles the fugitives were captured and brought to the Clunos police station, where they were locked np. This morning the magistrate remanded them till Wednesday. Ward says that his father lives in Little Lonsdate-strect. Molbournc, and Peel affirms that his father is a man of means living at Collingwood. The others have been in the industrial sohool aud reformatory. The young vagabonds appeared to bc very hardened, and were exceedingly impudent when looked up.

FATAL- SAWMILL ACCIDENT.-A terrible and fatal accident happened to a man named Thomas Clifton, at James's sawmill, East Wardell. It appears that whilst engaged in his duties about thc engine that drives a small circular saw, through some causo ho fell against thc flywheel, which revolves with great velocity, mid was literally torn to pieces. His death in such a horrible manner has cost a feeling of gloom over the district, as he was respected by all for his quiet good-natured disposition. The deceased had frequently stated that his duties were too numerous, and that he was in constant fear of an accident. Another fatal aocident in the same mill less than a twelvemonth ago, while breaking of limbs and other accidents more or less of a serious character have been very frequent. Groat dissatisfaction was expressed by tho inhabitants and workmen at no coroner's inquest being held on the last fatal accident, as it is asserted that it wonld have revealed an absence of caro and proper management for the protection of tho workmen. Young boys of ten and twelve years of age arc said to have been put in charge of circular Baws, working from six in the morning till six in the evening. A correspondent euggests that a Government inquiry into such a state of things should be imperatively domanded in the interests of common humanity.-Sydney

Num.

RUSSIAN MANNERS.-After much discussion the committee of a certain club in a remote Russian town has drawn up the following set of rules for the guidance of its members. Thc code seems to be as Draconian as it is original: -"1. No one shall onter the club with dirty boots. 2. No one shall wear his workaday clothes if they arc impregnated with unplea- sant smell, such as a scent of fish, leather,

pitch, &c. 3. At thc club dance black cloth

is laid down as tho corrcr-t dress. 4. In bnd weather, when the streets aro muddy, all members of tho club must wi ar slippers, so as not to dirty thc floor. 5. Whoever shall dare to put in an appearance nt a club ball in & velvet waistcoat or a green cravat reader* him- self liable to a fine of a rouble »nd a half, to lie put aside for the benefit of thc musicians. C. (a very stringent rule this), lt is expressly forbidden that any member, in tho course of a soiree, damante, shall use tho ballroom curtains fur a pnekcthand' crchi"f ; if he dues he will bo ignominiously kicked out. 7. Tho man who smokes (also at R soiree daiuaiile) in thc portion of the duh sot aside for ladies shall be instantly fined twenty-five kopecks, to go towards the purchase nf powder or eau dc Cologne for tho Mic*. 8. No member who may happen to be exhilarated, no matter bow late in the evening, shall bc allowed tn intro- duce thc can-can in a sot of quadrilles." The other rules prescribe that no one who is tipsy '* beyond tho bounds of decency " shall re- main in the ballroom. The buffetier shall be responsible for sueb persons. Every drunken maa »ball be fined toreo roubloi-.the prodnot

taiga to the formation of a library; and in ease of a dilpnte at billiard!, the disputant» are warned against using the eues to bask their opinions, under a penalty of forty kopecks per blow.

RUNAWAY HORSE,-An alarming accident happened on Friday evening to Thomas Salis- bury, a farmer residing near Samsonvale. He had just taken tea at a fruit shop in Brans wick-street. Fortitude Valley, kept by Mr. Bellmore, and taken bis seat in his spring oort with bis son, a child ten years old, when the horse, through some unknown cause, took fright and bolted in the direction of New Farm. On passing the Royal George Hotel, in Ann street, the cart was brought into violent contact with a telegraph post, which instantly upset it. Salisbury full head foremost on to the hard road, and was picked up apparently lifeless. The son fortunately escaped unhurt beyond a few scratohes and a good fright. The polioe secured the boree before any further mischief was done. Salisbury was conveyed to thu hospital tn a oab by Constable Kerr, and it was then found that he had sustained a severe concussion of tho. brain. He remained in an unconscious state up till a late hour at night, and his condition is regarded as most

critical.-Courier.

NEW BUSINESS ARRANGEMENTS.-A some- what curious light (remarks the Pall Mall Gazette) is thrown upon the way business is now conducted by tho official particulars of the failure of Messrs. Cavill and M'Koan, who became bankrupt the other day with liabilities

of nearly £300,000. So wide was the ramifica- ' tion of thiB firm's business as merchants and shipowners, that it not only traded in London, bat in Liverpool and in Newry, Ireland, as well os abroad under other styles. Mr. Patrick G. Cavill, one of the partners in the firm, we are farther told, also carried on busi-

ness in partnership with Joseph Connor, in^^* Birmingham and Loudon, as Connor and Co.; ' with R. Nairn, at Bristol, as R. and P. Nairn ; with J. Gilbertson, in Loudon, as Gilbertson Brothers; with j. Crawley, at Rostrevor, Ireland, BB the Forest Brook Linen Company ; with Arehibald Lindegreen, in London, as A. Lindegreen and Co.; with R. Wakeham at Liverpool, as R. Wakeham and Co., and with W. Peacop as l'oacop and Co. The debtors were also described os of Sydney, ' San Francisco, and other plaoes abroad, trading in partnership with various pereons and under various names, This ia "enterprise" with a vengeance.

FATALLY BURNED-Mr. Henry Shiell, J.P., ooroner, held an inquest at the Prince Alfred Hospital on the body of Mary Cranwiok, 14 years of age, who died in that institution on Thursday last. It appeared from the evidence ' that deceased was in the employment of Mr.

Hugh Robinson, of Summerhill, as housemaid. Last Tuesday night, about eleven o'clock, that gentleman was aroused by hearing screams, and on proceeding upstairs found the poor girl on the landing with her olothing in flames. Miss Burr, the housekeeper, was endeavouring to extinguish them. Mr. Robinson told de- ceased to throw herself down, which «be did, and he then threw a baise curtain over her, and so got the flames put out. Dr. Deok was called in and dressed the injuries, and next morning, on his advice, aha was removed to tho Prince Alfred Hospital. Deceased told Mr. Robinson that she had been sitting on tho bed working by the light of a candle, and becoming sleepy, had laid down, This was all the account ehe could give of the occur- rence. Her neodle, and cotton, and work were found on tho bed after tue accident. After evidence in corroboration of Mr. Robin- son was given by Miss Barr, sud Dr. Byrne, medical superintendent of the institution, had deposed that death was caused by shook con- sequent on the injuries by burning, the jury returned a verdiot in accordance with the evidence.-Evening Neos.

. AUSTRALIAN COAST/NO SUSAMIIRR-Messrs. Howard Smith and Sons ire making large additions to their fleet of Australian ooasting steamers. The Buninyong (originally named the Ballarat), a large steel screw steamer, was launched lately at Barrow-in-FurnesB. Her principal dimensions are-280 ft. between per- pendiculars, nearly 300 ft. over all, beam 38 ft., 20 ft. ter the main deck, and 27 ft. to the upper deck. She is estimated to oarry 2700 tans of cargo, and her engines of 300 horse-power nominal iudioate from 1,600 to 1800 horse-power. The saloon ia fitted with solid walnut and satin-wood. The dining room is 36 ft. by 24 ft., and contains four tables, seated with revolving chairs. The cabins each contain two berths, sixty in all. A smoking-room and a ladies' boudoir, elegantly furnished, are on deok. The whole vessel is lighted with electricity, and is fitted with all modern improvements to render her acceptable to the public, both as a passenger and cargo boat. She has been built by MeBsrs. Caird and Purdie, and is classed 100

Al. Her engines are by Messrs. James Jaojc ??, and Co., of Liverpool. Messrs. John ITiifHL «nd Sons, of Kirkcaldy, are building a sister ~ ship to the Buninyong, to be oalled the Gabo, and she will be launched next month ; also a very fast steamer named the Burmah, for tho Sydney and Brisbane trade. Messrs. Dobbs and Co., of Glasgow, ore also constructing a steamer for Messrs. Howard Smith and Sons. -Af Argut.

MILK AND OIL IN DISEASE. - Dr. W. W. Townsend, of Philadelphia, publishes the following letter in the Scientific .American ot December 2 :-"I notice in your paper of the 14th of October an article taken from the statements of Dr. Benj. Clark and Dr. Alex- ander Yate in favour of the use of milk as a diet in dysentery and typhoid fever. They give no dates os to when they commenced to uso it. I am now in my seventy-fifth year, and have witnessed several epidemics of dysen- tery, typhoid, scarlet, and relapsing fevers, smallpox, measles, Ac, and have used milk in every case coming under my caro for nearly forty years in every stage of tho disease. I will uot say it ie a cure, for I do not believe in the so-called ' cures ' and ' speaifios,' Milk ie the natural food of all mammalians. It not only sustains life, but promotes the growth of every part of the system. No other article oontainB all those ingredients. It is the recuperative power of nature that performs the oure ; and he who studies bow to assist it by sustaining the system is the best physician, and milk is one of the best agents that can ba used. In dysentery I prefer fresh butter-milk, and all the patient wants is perfect rest, and discard all irritating cathar- tics and purgatives. Mercury in any of its preparations is poison in dysentery or scarlet fever, and the physician who gives them will never be very successful. If his patient re- covers it will be despite his treatment. I will add that in small-pox and scarlet fever I anoint the patient from head to feet with olive oil by means of a badger brash, and repeat as often as it disappears, thereby allaying the heat, keeping open the poreB of the skin, pro- ducing quietude, preventing congestion of the capillary circulation, and obviating tho neces- sity of anodynes. I have practised tho greasing for thirty-five years, and was sneered at by my medical brethren for it and tho milk treat- ment. Now, I believe, it Í9 in general use

with thc best results."

l'oRiiiDin: AND Marc.-Dr. J. Batty Tukc, F.R.C.P., F.R.S., recently delivered a lecturo under the auspices of the Edinburgh Health Society, taking for his subject ' Tho Estab- lishment and Maintenance of llrain Health.' In the course of his remarks tho lecturer said lie bail met with many cases in whiuh the Bole ascertainablc cause of nervous symptoms in young children was their beiug too long suckled. But the mother herself must bo well fed ; and this brought him to the con- sideration of another question. In same respects bc believed the food of the working class in Scotland was improved, partly because wages were higher, partly because in the new workmen's bouses the means of cooking were better, and partly because new articles of diet had boen introduced into tho market. But bo also believed that it bad become de- teriorated in a very important item-porridge

and milk-for which had been substituted a much loss nutritious, and in itself a some- what deleterious, article of diet-tea aud hread. The physiologist would tell them that porridge and milk was a 4 tyical ' food that wai, that it contained alt the necessar" constituent» of food in th« mott r.»"*

portions. Ha bad nothing to tay against the «taff of Ufo so long as lt was sound lu quality and well fired, except that it was not euch a typical food stuff aa oatmeal, and, weight for weight, and did not possess an equal power of nutrition IIB porridge. It was the constant use of tea that bo would moet strongly deprecate. He boped his teetotal friends would not be very angry with bim if he said that it was quite -open to argument whether the teapot or the winsby bottle exercised the'more baneful effoot on the public constitution. He did not think, tile quettion had ever been fairly worked ont. ' He advised all working men, whether they worked in the workshop, in the office, or

in the study, to feed themselves, their wives,

and their children at least once a day on thu most perfect form of food which dod bod given thom-porridge and milk. ,

articleText:
(Thc 3#«cinuMij ^uUctin,

K OCKM AMJ'I'ON.

WEDNESDAY. APRIL 17, 188Ï.

THE internal affairs of religious bodies are not usually considered fair subjects of criticism on the part of thc press, ex- cept in those relations in which they touch the interests of other sections of the community. Happily all the sections of the Church in these colonies, are equally separated from the state. None can claim precedence or privilege as, even in a modified sense, the Established or State Church, and all are alike free to pursue their own path and objects, so long as they infringe on no civil right enjoyed by other members or sections of the public. The numbers belonging to any sect, or the personal qualities of its ministers, may secure for it a larger measure of public attention than is accorded to other sects, but it is only in exceptional cases that the affairs or interests of any one denomination become public property in the way of discussion. Such exceptional cases do from time to time arise, as, for example, when a religious party-demands, that the views which it holds should guide or modify the course of legislation ; or when by challenging public attention to its proceedings, it invites the criticism of those whose atteution it has sought. It can be only on the latter ground that we call attention to an event which has been made the subject of comment by^ the press of Victoria. We refer to the opening of .the 19th session of the Theological Hall of the Presbyterian Church of Victoria ; and the ground on which we think the attention of our readers may be called to this is, that thc Theological Hall of the Church named is part of the (.etching machinery of Ormond College-an institution which, though under the management of the Presbyterian Church of Victoria, is yet open, in regard to some of its classes and scholarships, to students of any de- nomination whatever. Ormond College is one of the great institutions of Mel- bourne. Willi the Church of iMnIand College it stands dose by the buildings of the Melbourne University, and is nut dwarfed by either. Its erection has been due mainly to thc munificent liberality of Mr. Francis Ormond ; bul his original subscription of nearly .-£23,000 has been supplemented by other subscriptions, which bring up the total to about ¿¿jS.ooo, exclusive of .£10,000 given by the same gentleman for the erection of a boarding-house for thc students. If we mistake not, this same Mr. Ormond, though a loyal member of his own Church, has offered the sum of ¿£25,000 towards the completion of the Anglican Cathedral of Melbourne. As might be expected, a public ceremonial closely connected willi a great institution, founded by a man of so broad and en- lightened sympathies, attracted some measure of attention at the hands of the Melbourne Press ; and the utterances of the chief speaker on the occasion, the Rev. Dr. Macdonald, of Emerald Hill, one of the Professors in the Presbyterian Theological Hall, could hardly pass

without being freely canvassed. We do not intend to review the somewhat sharp criticism to which the rev. gentle- man's address has been subjected by the Melbourne Argus. The Doctor is evidently a theologian of the old school, and yet for a man, who has been in the Ministry for over forty years, he is as evidently a man of no little advance- ment of thought. He discoursed to the assembled students, clergymen, and others on " The Origin of the Church," endeavouring to show that this world exists for man, anil that the whole process of its formation has been carried forward, to make it the theatre for the accomplishment of

the moral and spiritual constitution | of man. We are not disposed to say j that the speaker made the most skilful |

and successful use of the materials at his hands ; nor are we prepared to say

that the criticisms passed upon his I ! remarks by the Argus are free from that

narrowness of view with which it charges Dr. Macdonald. There is scientific narrowness as well as theological nar- rowness. The sciolists of science are, in their way, as unreliable teachers as the dogmatists of theology ; and when narrowness is conjoined with vagueness, as is not seldom the case, the value of its teaching becomes very slight indeed. It is easy to write such sentences as these: "Christianity remains to us, but it is viewed somewhat ditterently troiu what it was when the middle-aged amongst us were young. It is useless for clergy or laity to revive the dry bones of some of the old dogmas, which were once accepted without question, and implicitly believed ;" but it is by no means so easy to say how much, or how little, the writer means by them. And in this very vagueness we see one of the strongest arguments for that which Dr. Macdonald desiderates -the more thorough training of clergymen than has hitherto prevailed, not only in literature, philosophy, and theology, but also in the science of the day. Ii the studies and the daily reading of clergyman enable them to reason only on the premises, which were patent to their grandfathers, or their ancestors of two or three centuries back, they will soon find themselves left behind even hy the humbler and less informed portions of their flocks. On the other hand, science, to be worthy of the name, must be definite and specific. Science is facts ascertained and systematised things known by themselves and in their mutual relations. When, therefore, scien- tific men, taking their stand on a certain class ol facts as firmly established, pro- ceed to the denial of certain other hitherto supposed facts, they must be prepared to show that the logical con nection is beyond question, and to define how far their negation extends. It is easy to concede to the truly scientific man, fo the man who rigidly adheres to scientific, that is logical, methods, the position of an Agnostic. His science deals with those things which come under his observation ; and of those which do not come within this sphere, he is content to say, " They be beyond the ken of my science : I simply do not know them." On this ground wc can conceive of a scientific Agnostic being a devoutly religious man. But this is ground which we find only the masters in science taking up, and strictly adhering to; while no such restraints limit the argu- mentative flights of not a few of their followers If there is any truth in these remarks, the churches have need to look well to the training which they provide for the rising ministry. New South Wales is not behind Victoria in the machinery, in buildings at least, for this purpose. It has its Angelican, Presbyterian, and Wesleyan Colleges, affiliated to the University; hut there isno evidence that the course of study ranges far beyond the limits that were prescribed in the theological schools of half a century ago. Queensland is still in her infancy in these matters, None ol the churches possess any institution in which their candidates for the ministry arc re- quired to undergo any specific training. There is an institution in Brisbane knoivn as " Divinity Hall," but it seems to be matter of dispute, whether it has any connection whatever with the Pres- byterian Church, whose name it some ! times seems to assume ; and so far as

any published evidence goes it appears to afford a literary training, which does not come up to the standard of the senior forms in our Grammar Schools. We believe that the several churches have a standard of attainment fortheirministry, more or less defined, but, we fear, often very elastic, and in some cases wonder- fully low. The prospects of the churches, in respect to the qualifications of their future teachers, cannot, therefore, be said to be very bright. We know well that not a few of the abler and belter educated clergymen amongst us are deeply alive to this, and it will not weaken their hands to paint out the urgent and growing need there is for the broadening and deepening the training which their successors receive. If, as the Argus says, " Christianity remains to us," it requires expositors, who not only know wh.it it is in itself, but who can show thc relations in which it stands to those other departments of human knowledge which overlap it, or impinge upon it: expositors who, if not scientists themselves, can yet follow up, and appreciate thc results of scientific inquiry, and comprehend the character of the evidence on which these results rest.

AT tho Police Court, yesterday, before Mr. Ci. W. Young, J.P., Annie Marsden was fined Sa. with the alternative of twenty-four hours in the cells, for being drunk. Sim was also ordered to pay 2s. for cab fare.

Tins afternoon a cricket match, will be played at North Uockhainptou lietwceu teams of Married and Single : wickets to be pitched at thc usual time :- Married : K. Fisher (cap- tain), W. Whitman, K. Cross, .). Davis, T. Higson, fi. Church, J. Church, V. Comley, I). Macpherson, <!. Lyons, t¡. W. Parker. Single : A. Palmer (captain), H. Prior, IV. Jackson, F. Donleavy, \V. Clark, A. M'Cul- loch, W. Kami, E. Schwarten, J. Bryan, J, B, Morrison, J. Williams.

Tun Civil Sittings of the Supreme Court aro ' ?ct down for to-morrow, when the following cues wilt be «ailed :-K. 8. G.. Macdonald ». C. Dallon ; J. Ahern v. Central Qucemlaiul j Time* ; and L. Green t>. G. M. Leigh. The

two first-named are to be tried by a jury, and

tho last without.

TUK annual meeting of the Licensing Coort, that was to have been held yesterday morning, was postponed for a week in consequence of the sittings af thc Supreme Court, many ol ? the publican) having to be iu attendance

there. Messrs. J. Biown, F. Kilner, and J. Thomson were the justices present ; and a general auctioneer's license was granted to

Mr. I!. L. Dibdin.

THE nominations of candidates for the representation of Kos. 1 and 3 subdivisions of Gogango Divisional Board must be iu tho hands of thc Returning Officer, Mr. John Murray, Chairman of the Board, not later than 4 p.m. on Friday «ext. The scats, it will be remembered, are vacant by the resigna- tion of Mr. I'. H. Hobler and Mr. A. Ander- son, the latter of whom has gono ou a trip to Scotland. Nominations will be declared on Saturday at neon.

TUE spectacle of loaded coal trains arriving at the Maryborough railway station (says a local journal) is very gratifying, after many years of anxious expectation. About 200 tons of good-looking coal have been conveyed by rail from thc coal mines of Mr. Robertson and Mr. Walsh, on this side of the Burrum River. Some oj it has been delivered at Yengarie, some at Antigua, and the remainder absorbed by Maryborough consumers.

Wim reference to our remarks respecting the difficulty of procuring drovers to travel to Lake Nath Station, a journey of 1000 miles, with the Banksia heifers, we are assured by Mesare. \Y. Jackson and Co., agents for Mr. J. B. Brooks, of Banksia, that there was no such difficulty as reported. Several drovers applied for the job at different prices, but Mr. Brooks preferred engaging Mr. James Hutton at a stated salary, and supplied him with tho necessary plant.

Tun pedigrees of thc draught horses lately purchased far Messrs. Archer aud Co., and which were lauded here on Monday, have been furnished us. From them we gather there arc three Clydesdale mares, bred in New Zealand. Ono is Bess, a four-year-old filly, by Hero (imp.), out of a prize mare wliicb was never beaton when exhibited. Another is Maggie, a cbesuut filly, rising three years, by Jack's tho Lad (imp.), out of a mars whose dam was imported from Scotland ; and the third is Moris Meg, four years old, by Campsey 3rd, dam by Model Black Legs. Tho fonrtli is a black stalliou named Black Prince, four years old, brod by Mr, A. Town, of Richmond, N.S.IV-, by Young Gladstone (imp. ), from a Truo Briton (imp.) dam.

Tuij immigrants by tho B.I.S.N. Company's steamer Duke of Buccleuch reached Rock-

hampton last night. They were brought up by the steam launch Mabel. There are ninety-eight in all. Ou their arrival at thc wharf they were met by the Superintendent of the Immigration Depot, Mr. Beasley, who conducted them to their present quarters, and attended to their wants to the bust of his ability and means. The immigrants by the ship Ravenscraig ere detained on board that voBsel, as she has been placed in quarantine. Several coses of typhoid fever have occurred among the single girls, and though none are ill at present some little «icknoBS still prevails. Or. Harricks, Acting Health Officer, is in telegraphic communication with tho authori- ties in Brisbane, and will bo advised how to act in the case,

A VERY largo number of our readers will be pleased to learn that a Christian Home for emigrants has been establehed by private sub- scription noor Dlackwall docks. It will accommodate between 300 and 400 at a time. Few emigrants for America and the colonies passed London until the last year or se, as most of them sailed from Liverpool and Ply- mouth, but now that several shipping com- panies have weekly lines of large steamers from the Thames, the number of emigrants from thc Continent and from various parts of tho United Kingdom has increased so greatly that iu 1881 26,90.1 passed through the port of London alone, end there is every piobaliility of n yearly increase. The Brunswick Hotel

has boen fitted and furnished as a homo at a i

cost of £1500, and it is estimated that between j 7000 and 8000 persons will UBB it annually. 1 The charges will be very moderate, about I 2s. 3d. per day for boarding and lodging adultB, and for children about ls. Cd. per day.

THE Supreme Court sittings began before His Honor Mr, Acting Chief Justice Harding yesterday morning. The case of Archibald Macmillan and Agnes Connolly was the first called on. The prisoners were committed by the Blackall Bench for trial for the murder of the female prisoner's husband ia November last. They were charged yesterday with the leaser crime of manslaughter, and the trial lasted all day. As the male prisoner is well known in Rockhampton,

the evidence was listened to with keen interest. So far only two witnesses were examined, and it is very evident the hearing is likely to last over to-day. Messrs. C. N. Birkbeck and O. Ryan, were excused from attendance as jurors through illness. Mr. Mr. Forward applied for exemption, as be was a Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons. He was informed by his Honor, that he should have applied to the Jury Court of revision to

have Ins name struck off tho roll. The juror« were taken to the Cremorne Hotel for thc night, as there was no hotel Accommoda- tion available in town. Tbe Court rose at 5J45 p.m. and sits at ten this morning.

A CURIOUS case of illegally pawning is thus reported in the Melbourne Age :-A case was before the Emerald-hill bench of magistrates yesterday, (April 4) in which a man named Ralph Lewis Robiuson was charged, under the 34th section of thc Pawnbrokers' Statue, with illegally pawniug a gold locket and chain, thc property of one George Jessop. Mr. Daly defended the accused ¡ Inspector Toohey prosecuting. Thc case appeared to be that the accused lived with prosecutor, as lodger, at Rockhampton, Queensland, in December last. During that month there «as »quarrel in the household. Tho prosecutor left Rock- hampton, and afterwards went back, lu tho meantime the prisoner and Mrs. Jessop bad removed to Melbourne, afterwards finding their way tn Kmerald-hill, whore they lived together as man and wife. It was alleged by Helena Jessop, the wife of thc prosecutor, that her husband agreed that she should take certain articles of furniture as ber share, at the timo of the split up in Rockhampton, and also some jewellery, among which was the gold chain which was alleged to have been illegally pawned by accused. I'roscentor subsequently met his wife and thc accused at Hmerald-hill. He accosted them, and inquired about the jewellery which he bari found had been pawned at the Hmcrald-hill

branch of the Australian Mont dc IV-U'-. A

conversation ensued, which appeared to have been of a semi-friendly nature. On another occasion, prosecutor, his wife and two children met in Melbourne, and, as they approached thc corner of Collins and Queen streets, Con- stable Bysouth was referred tn by prosecutor. 1'he countable said lie could not taite Robinson in charee on the information then afforded. Subsequently the police of Emerald-hill were communicated with, and a warrant issued on which the prisoner was arrested by Senior ooiistaMe R.igcrs. Tho pawning of the jewellery by defendant was proved by Francis c »'Farrell, the manager of tho pawn shop. Tho gond*, which were sworn hy thu prosecutor to in- of the va'ue of £J I«., wero pan ned for '2'x. The case occupied sume timo in hearing, ami resulted in thc accused being committed for trial at the next Crimipil Segeion«,

GOOD work ii being accomplished ot Mr. Booker's Oakland« meat preserving establish

ment (says a Maryborough, contemporary). - The steamer Derwent took away a few days ago 800 cases of tioned beef for the south. Thc fact that none is offered in the local market is probably due to thc absoucc of demand for the preserved article while fresh meat is so cheap aud everywhere procurable. When Mr. Booker's freezing machinery, which wo understand has just arrived from Knglaod, is at work, local facilities for procuring " fresh " meat will be even greater than at

present.

Tuc: usual monthly meeting of No. 7 Building Society will be bold in thc Secretary's, (Mr. K. L. Dibdin's) offices to- night at eight o'clock.

TitE usual fortnightly sittings of the Small Debts Court will be held this morniog, when there will bo ten undefended oases for hearing.

Tm: cargo of timber ex Borealis wil ho sold at auotion by Mr, G. S. Curtis at eleven o'clock this morniog on the wharf. Such au opportunity, ecldom offered in Rockhampton, of purchasing some really good Kauri pine should not be lost sight of,

MARCH OF SCIENCE-The Queensland Mail service is causing a revolution in the direct Importation trade of the district. A splendid collection of the latest designs in gold and silver jeweller; is now being displayed in the windows of Messrs. Saber Brothers, East

street.-All VT,
