- -= 1

KOCKIIAMl' ION. j

THURSDAY, APRIL 20, 1883.

EDUCATION is becoming an art, and the question which must present itself to the minds of many intelligent parents is -whether there is not a tendency among teachers to become dilettanti artists, rather than earnest, anxious, faithful instructors of youth ? A cardinal fact, that should always be borne in mind, when thc subject of education is under consideration, is that the re sponsibility for the proper up-bringing of the young rests on parents. It is a duty they owe their offspring to see they are so trained and taught that, in intelli- gence, they shall be able to take their place with credit among their fellows ; and, in general knowledge and attain- ments, be able to assist in the good government of the community in which they are placed, and in advancing the moral, intellectual, and physicial con- dition of the human race. To the State parents also owe it that their childrtn shall not grow up pests to Society, and propagators of moral and social evils. Willi thc view to assist citizens, in their efforts for ihe accomplishment of these aims, the Governments of nearly every country have provided systems of education suited to the public require- ments. The result is that parents lose sigh t of their individual responsibilities, in regari! to the education of their children. They seem to think that their duty is sufficiently performed when ihcy make

their children attend school. As a con- sequence those immediately engaged in the profession of leaching, have been left to do very much as they liked, and the result, as wc remarked al the outset, has been thc growth of a disposition among teachers to theorise, experiment,

and reduce their work to the smallest

amount. Like other workers they strive to sell their lil>oiir al as good a price as they can get for it, .ind it is lo be feared many of them are not so thoughtful as they should be of (he dangers to the Stale, that are certain to arise from l'ic careless and perfunctory discharge

of their duties.

In connection with this state of

matters, we may he permitted to call

attention lo the amount of tasks allotted lo children f<ir performance at home. The number, variety, and amount of home-lessons, especially in connection willi higher-class education, form a serious tax upon the time, and physical and mental powers of pupils. If the teachers are spoken to upon ihe subject, they are ready with the response that the demands nf modern high-class educa- tion ren ier hume - lessons necessary. They tell indignant parents that the ex- tent of human knowledge is such pupils must be at their work late and early, in order to leam the ways of access to the

numerous branches into which it is divided ; and that the most teachers can do is to direct and supervise the labours of youth. Behind technicalities and professional jargon they sheller themselves, and with plausible argu- ments throw up a rampart to protect them from criticism. We must not shut

our eyes to the fact that the multiplica- tion of home-lessons is becoming a serious social question ; and there are many points in connection with it which demand the attention of intelligent parents. With the latter rests the remedy of evils which may arise, for the manipulation of School Boards and Trustees by teachers is becoming a part of the science of education from the

tatters' point of view. The prominent question, which should engage our atten- tion, as it is doing that of communities farther south, is-whether the hard.work of teaching is not being expelled from the public school to the domestic circle ? Boys and girls alike are burdened with exercises. The performance of these occupies all the hours they are at home, and leads to an invasion of the Saturday holiday; indeed, it may be questioned, if it does not give rise to Sabbath dese- cration. Where the classes are at all numerous the teacher can do no tnore than hear the pupils repeat their tasks. Under such a system there is a great deal of learning hy rote without intelligent comprehen- sion. Education imparted in this fashion becomes an annoyance to pupils, and instead of being a stimulus is a sedative to the acquisition of knowledge. Youths when they leave school throw aside their books with a feeling of joyous relief. Only in a few cases is there a spon- taneous desire to drink deeper at the wells of knowledge, or acquire literary or scientific distinction. It is a question, indeed, whether the revulsion of feeling created is not highly detrimental to the

interests of true education.

A great objection to the extravagant system of home-lessons is the time they occupy. Pupils have no leisure for i recreation and relaxation. Play, so

delightful, and, we may say, necessary to the young, is denied them. If it be indulged in, and some task forgot or neglected, the punishment inflicted is more home-work. For an hour's

romping with companions the wearied one has perhaps to sit up, after all the house has gone to rest, writing out an array of meaningless sentences. Some of the penalties im- posed by teachers in this way, we are charitable enough to suppose, are in- flicted without thought ; otherwise they would display an absence of a knowledge of human nature, and almost inhuman cruelty, highly reprehensible. Besides, when the time of children is engrossed by home-lessons they are deprived of that moral and social education, which, silently and unobtrusively, it may be, is always going on in every family. It is of great importance that children should be courteous, kindly, affectionate, loving, and forgiving to each other : that they should honour, reverence, and love their parents ; that they should be hospitable, attentive, and well-bred to strangers : but how or when arc tiley to be gently and easily taught the duties of demeanour, if their time is to be always taken up, their attention engaged, and their tempers broken and made irritable by a haunting, horrible sense of irksome tasks to be performed. Fine manners without learning should be avoided, and, on the other hand, so also should learned impudence and

boorishness.

We have made these remarks without intending they shonld have any local point or application : if they have the fault is not ours. Tile subject, however, has attracted attention, and is exciting considerable discussion in Victoria at present. Commenting on it the Mel- bourne Argus says:-"Things have now come to this point-parents must

either assert themselves or endure in silence." We are most desirous that in connection with our educa- tional institutions there should be no call for parental assertion. That such an unpleasant necessity may be avoided rests with the School Trustees, who sanction the curriculum, and the teachers who have to act in accordance with it. It is for the public, however, to observe what is going on elsewhere ; to remem- ber that teachers form an influential

class iu the community : and that there is a growing disposition to shift a large portion of the work of teaching from thc school-room to the family parlour.

Tire southern papers contain details of several colil blooded murders which have been committed in Tasmania. Tiley are intercstiug because they seem to illustrate the fearful depravity into which the larrikins of that colony have fallen, and thc dangerous class that is growing up among us. A workman on thc Tasmanian main lino, who dwelt in a cot tage with his wife, four childron, and a lodger named Mrs. Boram, retired to rest about ten o'clock on Monday, the 9th instant. The family were aroused by large stones being hurled on the roof, and WÍIBOU went to the door to learn thc cause of tho disturbance. Immediately bis wifo heard a shot, and he returned crying " My God, wife I am shot." He staggered and felt dead. Two men then appeared, and demanded admittance, or they would hurn the house down. Ât once they set about carrying out their threat. They gathered dry sticks about it, and set fire to thc house in three places. Tho poor woman and children were driven out by thc flames. Thc ruffians took nil thc punr woman's money, threatened her daughter because ehe knew' «ne of them, aud fired at and wounded thc lodger. Neighbours whose aid was Boiiçht refused to render any

assistance. Thc house and its coutents were completely consumed ; the woman and children were left in their nijjht clothes ; and tho men got clear off. On the Wednesday following, the police who were on thc search for the murderers, heard of a man being seen lying on the road Bide near lapping Forest. On foina thither tiley found a mun named Alf. Hulmán, driver of a lemonade cart. lying at the point of death in the scrub, He bad been shot without any warning, when driving along the road. Following the track of thc cart, which bad been taken through a slip-panel, the police came on the two men they were in search nf, regaling themselves willi lemonade. Tiley ran, but when the police fired over their heads they quietly surrendered. They were nt once taken to Campbeltown, and placed in the lock-up. It is not to be wondered at that they were in

dangar of being lynched by the way. They were fouud to be toe culprit« in both murders, and are two young,men named Mahoney, alias Sullivan, 191 and 'Ogden, 20. Having been badly brought up, they acquired no trade or steady mcausof livelihood, and loafed abuutlow public houses in Launoestoo. Their victims were quiet well-doing industrious men, with wives and families. Mow the serious aspect of the cases is that the perpetrators of these cold-blooded murders had no motive for them, and their utterances since show a most heart- less levity. They evince not the slightest desire to justify their conduct, and glory in their crime, as if it were something to bs proud of. Who will be ablo to feel safe if mon of this type increase among as. The very thought of such a tbiug creates a feeling of uneasiness, and cases of this kind show that as a matter of self-protection larrikinism must be put down.

WE have been asked to call the attention of our scavengers to two odorous pools of water near tho side walk between Mr. Iogham'a shop and that of Mr. W. E. Higson.

A GENTLEMAN arrived yesterday from Broadsound and reports Waverley Station to be ia splendid condition, in fact the feed has never been excelled. The road to Rockhamp- ton is Baid to been in good order for travelling cattle, (grass and water being plootiful.

Tuc adjourned sittings of thc Small Debts Court was held in the Court House yesterday morning. Thc undefended caso of I\ Uctmett ti. W, J. Harrison, fdr gonda sold, £1C 15s" was adjourned for a week. In thc case of J. 8. MalliBton ». B. Labahn, in which the plaintiff claimed £3 ls. for work done, a ver- dict was given for £1 19s. M., «¡til ISs. costs.

IT will be interesting to Bettfers in tho coast district bctwocu Rockhampton and Mackay

to learn that Mesara. Rutherford Brothers are sending a mob of about 180 horses to tho latter town for sale. Of course purchases by the way may bo made by those who are in need of working horses. Theanimals arc nearly all draughts, and among them is a good entire and several useful mares. They leave at thc end of this week, and will proceed through Marlborough and St. Lawrcuce.

THE Q R.M.S. Bulimba, 2600 tons, Captain G. D'Arcy Clarke, left the Brisbane bar yesterday on her homeward trip, via the usual ports, and is expected at the Port Alma anchorage this evening about seven o'clock. The Mabel, laanoh, leaves at nine to-night taking the mails and passongcrs. Among tho latter we notice the names of Mr. and Mrs. J. Headrick and Mrs. A. Hay and- Mr. A. Hay junr. The Bulimba only takes 442 bales of wool and a few casks of tallow from this port. Letters for or via the United Kingdom, bear- die customary lato fee, may lie posted on board thc Mabel at the A.S.N. Company's wharf up till nine o'clock to-night.

WE mentioned some time ago that a mob of female store cattle had left Glenmore for Mr W. Pattison's Fanning Downs Station, near Charters Towers, in charge of Mr. John Jack» sou. Tho cattle, numbering 1137, were de- livered at the station on the Cth instant, after a trip of eleven weeks under favourable auspices. Tho route was by way of Marl- borough, St. Lawrence, Nebo, Fort Cooper, Havilah, Strathmore, Strathalbyn, Wood- house, Ravenswood Junction, and thence to i Fanning Downs, twelvo miles from Charters Toners. The station is reported to be looking well, The track from Strathalbyn to Wood- house is an nosurvcyed ono. We mention tho route beoauBC it is reported that all slong the road the grass was in splendid order aud water in abundance. TbUB the cattle arrived at their destination ia fine condition.

- AT the Police Court yesterday, before tho Polioc Magistrate, P. Hardwaring, a Cinga. lese, was charged with drunkenness, but the case was remanded in order that thc prisoner might he inspected by tho medical officer. R, Thomson was chargoil with assaulting the police, hut pleading guilty he was discharged, as he bad been iu tho lock-up siuce Saturday night. He was also charged with the Iaroeny of a piece of ham from tho store of Kelly and Co. in Dcnhatn-etreet. M. Kelly deposed that thc prisoner came into witnoss' Btore on Satur- day last, but when be left he found a piece of ham which was on one side of the counter, missing. Ho ran after the prisoner, who was drunk at the time, and found the ham, which he valued at Cs., in his possession. Constable M'Caffrey deposed to the arrest of prisoner on Saturday night on tho charge named ; prisoner was drunk at the time. The prisoner pleaded guilty, and elected to be dealt with summarily. He was fined 5s, or forty-eight hours' imprisonment.

Hts Honor Judge Noel opened tho District Court sittings at Mackay on the 18lli instant, Mr. W. T. Daly prosecuting for tho Crown. William Ball was sentenced to five years' penal servitude for stealing a* horse from Mr. J. E. Davidson at Mackay on 12th March. Nelly Kilgour was charged with having forged and uttered three cheques of thc respective sums of £15, £30, and £10 in tho name ot M. Christian, of Willangie Station. Thc accused waa discharged, as the cvideoce was somewhat weak.* Throe Chiuauicn were charged with unlawfully wounding a brother Celestial at Mackay. Ah Pat received a sentence of eighteen months' impriBomneut, Ah Queo was acquitted, and Hang Geo was tined £25, with the alterna- tive of three months' imprisonment. William Chamberlain was charged with stealing a watch, the proporty of W. J. Siughjtou. Thc prisoner was arrested on information afforded by Detective Clark and the steward of tho Bunyip. We before referred to the particulars of thc case, and th? trial at Mackay resulted in the acquittal of the prisoner, as the Crown Prosecutor threw up thc case, Singleton giving his evidence in such an un- satisfactory manner. The witness was subse- quently fined £2 2s., with the alternative of twenty-four hours in the cells. Andrew H. Waddell received a sentence of twelve months' imprisonment for stealiug boots aud skirts from Mr. J. H, Sharp's store.

»if WE have before us a copy of the report for 1 1882 of the Rockhampton Presbyterian Church, which has just been issued. It con- tains a large amount of information with reference to the congregation, which will, no doubt, ho interesting to the members. In an address the Session inform the members that the twelve mouths which have just closed have been marked by satisfactory progress. Fifty-four inombcrs have been placed upon the corainuuiou roll in the course of the year, and ody ten removed, so that there has been an increase of forty-four in tho uoinbcr of communicants. There has aUo been an in- crease in thc number of adherents, but a correct record of them the Session canuot furnish. The attendances at church have been larger, and the recant enlargement of thc church has provided increased uecossary accommodation. Thc number of cliildrcu baptised in the course of the year waa seventy five; of these forty-eight wcro tho children of parents living in tho town, and twenty seven of parents living in thc couutry. Thc Sabbath School continues to prosper, tho number of scholars on thc roll being 226, and thc average attendance 165 - a great incrcaso nn thc number of recent years. Thc receipts iu connection with thc Sunday School amount to £32 14s. 2d.: after paying for library books, upwards of £10 for picuic expenses, magazines, books, &c,, there remained a balance of Od. 4d. The Committee of Management also report that the last year has been one nf progress and promise. There has been an inórense in thc total ordinary income of £56 11s. 8d. The outstanding liabilities of the congregation, exclusive of debt on the Manse, now amount to £0 3i. 4d. There also remains in the hands or thc Onmmittcc £32 I2H. 4d" to which ie to lie addvri, of seat rents and stipend fund, the sum of £55. The cost of the enlargement and painting of the church amounted to £163 8s,,

which bas been entirely defrayed by means of subscriptions received over and above the ordinary contributions of members of the church. The amount of debt upon the Manan ¡8 £398 16s., but towards tho removal of this liability subscriptions have been prumisod to the amount of £137, which, if full/ realised, will reduce the debt to £251. V

ALL the single girls by the Ravenscrag have found engagements at good wages. The majority of the single men have also met with employment, and some of those who have not have gone up the country in search of it. There is still little demand for married couples, but four of them left the Depot yesterday for the country. The four single girls who were in quarantine on board the Ravenscrag on account of their having typhoid fever, were brought to the Depot in a cab about half-past twelve on Monday night, and had to be placed among the single girls for a short time. They were kept there for about an hour, until an order was procured from Dr. Harricks for their admission into the Hospital, whither they were driven in a cab at about half-past one in the morning.

A TRAVELLER from Townsville informs us

that many persons were disappointed at not obtaining passages by the Quiraing, s.s., for Rockhampton. The Townsville agents of the A,S.N. Company declined to grant tickets to those, especially commercial travellers, who were burdened with a large amount of luggage, as they could not undertake its delivery in Rockhampton. The inconvenience thus caused to travellers is due to the fact that since thc Bunyip was disabled the A.S.N. Company have taken no steps to place a steamer in the river cmnmcusurate with thu increasing trade with this port The Mabel was chartered to run the contract mails for the company after the Fitzroy was Jaid up, and as her cargo carrying capacity is of a limited naturo the coast agents wisely decline to grant tickets to this port for anyone with a large amount of luggage. Consequently the commercial tra-

vellers whose business necessitates a visit herc will have to call in at Mackay aud there await a boat for this port.

A CRICKET match was played at North Rockhampton yesterday afternoon between scratch teams under the captaincy of Messrs. Fisher and Geo. Church. The game resulted in a victory for Fisher's team by six wickets and two ruoB. M. H. Marris (23) and 0. C. Macpherson (22), for their respective teams, carried their bats right through tho first innings. The scores follow :

A BRUTAL assault was oommitted yesterday afternoon upon an old woman named Mary Firth, aged eighty-four, by a Kanaka named Willie, who has been in the habit of going about cutting wood for different porsons in the town for the last couple of years. He went to her residenoe, next the Royal Exchange Hotel, just before four o'clock yesterday afternoon, whoo she asked bim ns usual to cut some wood. As ho did not wish to do thc work just then, but wanted to have a "spell," when asked to cut the wood he took bold of tho axe, and without saying a word struck her in the ribs. She fell to the ground, and the brute then commenced to kick her. Luckily for tho poor old woman her granddaughter happened to be at homo, who seeing what took place, at once screamed for help. Two young men who were passing at the time came to her assistance, and the kanaka observing them, desisted his attack, dropped the axe, and cleared over the fence of the next yard, from whence he got into the street. Hero he was pursued by a largo number of people who had by this time col-

lected. Ho went in the direction of tho Church

of England, and from there he was fol- lowed by a man in a lorry to near the Victoria Jlotel, where he was captured by tho man, assisted by the police, aud brought in the lorry to the lockup. Tho woman has been examined by Dre. Poland and Harricks, who found that her right side was bruised, and one of her ribs splintered, but so far as they can ascertain no bones have been broken. There is also a slight cut in the middle forefinger of the left hand, and two small cuti on thc back of thc elbow of the left arm. AB the woman is of such a great age there is no knowing what may be the conse- quences. Urs, Firth is one of the oldest residents in Âlma-strect, having lived there siuce 1830, and at one time she kept the Alma boarding-house.

A QUAND concert of sacred and secular music was given by the members of the choir of St. Joseph's Church, in tho Hibernian Hall last night. Thc attendance was not so largo as was anticipated, seeing that we have had very few public entertainments recently. Those who have the good taste to patronise the concerts given by St. Joseph s Choir are always certain to bear good music rendered in effective style. Tho auditors last night were not disappointed in that respect, as the selections of muBic were choice and varied, and they were faithfully and tastefully rendered. In tho singing of tho sacred pieces tho expression was clear and distinct, tho notes of joy being full and sweet, and those of confidence and hope, melting in their tenderness. The choir was not so strong os usual, but on this account tho balance of parts and harmony of voices were all the more per- fect. The opening piece was Haydn's "Credo " chorus, and was followed hy the solo " PaniB Angelicus," which MÍBB Coffey ren- dered with her accustomed taste and skill. Mr. Rredfeldt, who lias a fine clear tenor voice, sang the solo of " Laúdate," and the choir came at the chorus with excellent effect. In thc suiting of " Ave Maria," " Regina Codi," " Pro pecatis," and "Tantum ergo" much taste and feeling were manifested, as well as the results of careful study and practice. The secular part of the concert was opened with a lively set of Irish Quadrilles, played by four young 1 dies on two pianos. Mr. Gerahty's song, "The Little Hero," was heartily encored ; and Messrs. M'Mullan and do Schilstel were loudly applauded for their fine rendering of the "Sailor Sighs." The choir bas recently received a notable accession in Mrs. Cripps, who haBa magnificent soprano voice, which she has cultivated and exercises with fine taste and skill. She sang "Golden Love " witli great sweetness, and, on bciug recalled, drew down thc house by lier charm- in!; rendering of "We'd better bide a wee." Thc audience were not content till she repeated a verse of it. Mr. Milford gave creat pleasure by his happy and sprightly rendering nf thc motto song, " Second thoughts are best," and "Over the garden wall " Miss Morrin, a woe performer not much higher than the piano stool, played a selection from " Lucrczia Borgia" with wonderful exactness and manipulative ability. Other selections fol- lowed, and an excellent concert was concluded by a fine march played on tho harmonium and piano. Altogether the entertainment was a most enjoyable one.

THE usual fortnightly meeting of tb« Town Council will be held this afternoon,

A MEETING of the Trustee! of the Grammar School will he held in Messrs, Jones and Brown's office at four o'clock this afternoon.

THE celebration ol the third anniversary of the Viotoria Lodge of Oddfellows takes place ia the Oddfellows' Hall this evening, com- mencing at half-past seven o'clock.
heading: The Morning Bulletin. ROCKHAMPTON. THURSDAY, APRIL 26, 1883.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

THURSDAY. JUNE 21, 1883.

" DEFENCE, not defiance " is the motto of the Volunteers, and it seems to be one peculiarly adapted to colonial rail- way policy. Our leading men are more fully recognising the fact, that the care- ful development of the railway systems of Australia, is desirable for the pros- perity of the colonies, individually and collectively. By pushing out lines (rom the great centres of commerce and trade, it is felt that the latter may be increased and extended, with advantage to the State immediately interested, and also to others brought into communica- tion with it. Railway extension, it has been argued, will hasten the time when the communities of Australia will be

united in one grand confederacy ; but, though anxious to promote such a con- summation, politicians, in the meantime, direct their efforts to make their railway policy contribute to the welfare each of their own colonies. On the 9th instant the Great Western Railway of New South Wales was opened at Nyngan, and the proceeding was made the occasion for some speechifying. Sir Patrick Jennings, vice-President of the Executive Council, in reply to an address presented to him by the inhabitants of Nyngan, made a short speech, which is noticeable for its suggestions, and for the clear light it throws on the railway policy of the sister colony. He laid it down as an axiom, the truth of which all would ad- mit, " that nothing the Government could do tended so much to open up the country, for the beneficial occupation of all classes bf the colonists, as the exten- sion of railways into the heart of- the country, thus giving facilities to transit, that would eventually lead to the country being populated and rendered in every way beneficial." From this it will be seen that the speaker is not an advocate of merely political railways-lines made to gratify the clamourous demands of the residents in some particular district. He does not believe in waiting till there are people to cry out for railway exten tension ; but he would push out lines wherever people should bc settled and trade created, and thus make railways the pioneers of progress. His conduct in this respect contrasts with that of some of our politicians, who make it an objection to some railway extensions " that nobody ever asked for them." It must be plain, if the policy of the latter is to prevail among us, that we will presently have a net-work of lines in the districts near Brisbane ; population will be massed and starved there ; and our fine outside country will continue in the possession of the squatter and his flocks.

Sir Patrick Jennings rejoices in the prospect of New South Wales and Victoria shaking hands, " bound by an iron chain across the Murray." He

considers it will be for the advan- tage of the two great centres to be connected in that way ; and is not troubled, seemingly, by jealous fears lest the one colony should exercise an undue influence on the trade of the other, when the -highways between them are free of obstacles. His belief seemingly is that the greater the facilities for inter- course between the colonies, the more rapidly will their prosperity be advanced, and the happiness of the people in- creased. He is not ready, however, to let the adjoining colonies steal the traffic which naturally belongs to his own ; and so he contemplates the extension of the New South Wales railways to the Queens- land border at Stanthorpe and Bnrringun. It will be seen that the defensive policy

he advocates is to counteract the in-

fluence of Queensland railways. Bar- ringun is in the Warrego district, and the trade of it will be secured to New South Wales, if Sir P. Jennings' plans are acted upon. "As the Queensland Government" he says "had encouraged a land-grant railway system down the Warrego to the border of New South Wales, it would be our duty, in order to secure our share of the traffic, to extend our Great Western Railway system to its extreme limits." It will thus be seen that while desirous of shaking hands

with sister colonies, Sir Patrick Jen-' ninçs is determined they shall not lay their fingers on trade he thinks does not belong to them. While watchful of the approaches of Queensland on the north, Sir Patrick Jennings would

also have the people of Neiv South Wales meet the approaches of South Australia, which is stretching out her railway system to Mount lirovvn. " It would be the duty of the Government to connect that distant part of the colony with the proposed railway to Wilcannia."

The railway policy advocated by Sir Patrick Jennings, it' will bc seen, differs in its essential features from that which appears to find favour with a consider- able number of people in this colony. Should our Government give effect to the latter, our main lines will be carried out into the back country, and while they may be highly useful in promoting settlement, they will not be effective in protecting our trade from the growing

influence of South Australia on the West, and of New South Wales on the South. When we glance at the maps of the sister colonies, we see that the number of what we may suppose to be political railways is small. The lines

in New South Wales and Victoria irradiate from the principle ports Sydney and Melbourne-towards the borders of the colony ; and in South Aus-

tralia the main line runs north from Adelaide, with branches to the ports in Spencer Gulf. In the latter colony we find short lines of only local importance, but the policy of constructing these has' been abandoned by the present Adminis- tration, which is projecting intercolonial lines towards Victoria, New South Wales, and along the Queensland border to the Northern Territory. That our present Government have adopted a bold and strategic railway policy for Queensland we have argued repeatedly, and it is not without considerable ap- prehension we look forward to that which may bs adopted by their suc- cessors. The danger is that, while we go on making railways near our towns,

the trade of our border districts will be

appropriated by our neighbours.

A MOD of 260 fata, from Mr. W. Broome, Woodlands Station, crossod the Fitzroy Bridge yesterday morning, and arrived at Mr.

W. Pattison's works.

MR. L. J. SMITH was appointed pound keeper for this district for tho ensuing twelve months. The only other application waB that of Mr. A. E. Birkbeck, which was bold by the Bench to be informal.

IT is probable a supplementary mail for the United Kingdom only will be despatched by the Polly for shipment to tbe Quetta, s.s., this morning. In such case due notice will be given at the Post Office.

CONSTABLE HENNESSV arrived in town on Tuesday from Emerald, escorting a prisoner named M'Houll, who was sentenced to three months' imprisonment in Rockhampton Gaol for obtaining money under false pretences.

THE Yaralla, s.s. from Mackay, arrived late last night. When near the wharf a prisoner who had been senteoced to imprisonment here jumped overboard, and after swimming ashore made up the river bank and cleared off. Wo presume the police aro in search.

TUE sixty-sixth monthly meeting of No. 7 Building Socioty was held in the offices of the Secretary (Mr. R. L. Dibdin) lost night. Messrs. R. Sharples and H. Vesporman pre- sided as directors. The interest and sub- scriptions received amounted to £64 2s, 8d. No advance shares were sold.

A QUANTITY of gold came into town from Cania says Tuesday'e Oladstone Observer. The field ¡B said to be looking up, and Mr. O. C. Bretlin, who is well informed in mining there, states that the na rober of miners are increasing. The Tableland gold-field is also improving.

IN recognition of the services performed in the Queensland police force for the last thirteen years nine of which have boen spent in the Rockhampton district, constable Peter Glackin has been raised to the rank of senior constable and leaves for Blackall to-morrow. As a mounted constable here Mr. (ilackin worked assiduously and from what we know of him bis promotion has been well oarned.

GRASS and water are reported to be scarce on the Crocodile goldfield, and owners of stock running there are getting anxious as to future prospects. To make matters worse, some one set fire to the grass last week on the moun- tain, and it burned downwards to the flat country. A heavy dew fell during tho night, and stopped the further progress of the

destructive element.

AT the Police Court yesterday^ before Messrs. W. Thomson and J. Thomson, J.J. P., P. Hardmarning, a Cingalese, was again charged with drunkenness, and fined 5s. or twenty-four hours. Heinrich Flügger was charged with deserting from the barque Ariadne. Gerald Casseboom, master of the vessel, deposed that Flügger deserted on the 8th May, and ho had not seen him since that date. The case was adjourned until this morning for the production of the ship's articles.

MR. S. SHARWOOD, Aramac, in his weekly report, says :—"Mr. J. Firth, with 95 horses from Warwick for Mount Surprise, passed on the 1st instant ; Mr. Echlan with 42 horses from Bundaberg to the Cloncurry went through on the 10th. At my auction sales at the Aramac Show on the 6th instant Messrs.

Williamson and Thornton's Towerhill yearling bulls realised £20 per head. Mr. W. M'Millan's Roving Lad draught colts, bred at Maneroo, averaged £29 10s. per head. And I sold hacks and stock horses at from £7 to £20.

TUB Gladstone Observer says :-Tho Govern- ment have given orders for the survey of a township at Ulani, and thc site chosen is on a favourable elevation betwen the Six and Eight Mile Creeks, on the Gladstone and Rockhamp- ton road. The survey is being carried ont by Mr. F. J. Byerly. Near the township is a large saw-mill, the property of Mr. Kgan, of Rock- hampton, and when the works are completed a very largo number of hands will bc employed. Already it has a lively appearance, nnd the steam whistle can be heard from thcGladsbonc

road ; it is also in close proximity to a favourite camping-ground, well-known to Gladstone ovcrlandern on account of tho grass and water. Mr. D. Smith is about to erect a hotel at tho new township, and ns that gentleman is well known to all tm vetters on that road he should command a lucrative trade.

RESIDENTS at thc southern end of tho Bange must prepare themselves to smell powder to- night, and have their oars assailed with thc rattle of musketry. To-night Rockhampton will bc in possession of an invading force con- spicuous on thc field by their undress uniforms Cur own voluntoera meanwhile will bo col- lected in force on the rising ground beyoud Scrubby Creik. The latter will make a reconnaissance to ascertain the strength nnd position of the enemy. As soon as their white

helmets appear among thc trees beyond the' Ycppon tho skirmish will begin. Favoured by local knowledge the party may steal round the end pi the lagooa and gaining a command- ing position in Miss Macfarlanes paddock outflank their adversaries, and cut off their retreat to town by the Dawson Road. The affair will be lively aud interesting, and we hope will not bs accompanied by any accident.

Tas Mesar», Rutherford's racehorses arrived safely from Mackay by the Yaralla last night.

MB. KOCH, who was lately in the Rock- hampton branch of the Queensland National Bank and went to the Blackall branch, writeB under date 15th June to Mr. James Mackenzie, P.C. Secretary of the Rockhamp- ton District, respecting the revival of the Oddfellows' Lodge at Blackall. The lodge ' there is named thc Loyal Barcoo Lodge, No. 10, of the Mauoliester Cinty, and the business in connection with the lodge has been in a dormant state for some time, owing to the want of energy displayed by some of the members. Mr. Koch opened the lodge in the Court House on the 13th instant. In this ho woo assisted by' Bro. Wedgewood, of Queanbeyan, N. 8. Wales, aud nineteen working or full benefit members and four honorary members were initiated, and the fees received amounted to £28. Mr. Koch gave a short address, and pointed out the necessity of exercising due care in the election of the first officers. The nominations resulted ia the appointment of Bro. C. W. Sargeant as N.G.: Bro. R. WV Miller, Y.G.; Bro. C. J. James, E.S.; Bro. R. M. Harvey, Financial Secre- tary ; and Bro. T. H. Slater, junr., Treasurer. The installation took place shortly after the election. Other mattera in connection with lodge business were transacted, and from the tenor of Mr. Koch's communication it is evident the order of Oddfellows ÍB likely to flourish in the Blackall township. A good start has been made, and it only rests with the officers of the Loyal Barcoo Lodge to make the far western branch a snccess.

_. IT is with very considerable satisfaction we

have to announce that the whole of the

capital of tho Yeppoon Sugar Company has now been subscribed. The remaining shares were taken up yesterday. This shows an amount of coufidence in the sngar industry of this district, which is most cheering. It was on the 6th of February last, that a preliminary meeting was held in the Criterion Hotel, at which the proposal to form such a company was discussed. A week later pro- visional directors were appointed and a prospectus issued. About a month ago it was resolved to float the company, and now the full amount of capital required has been sub scribed. The capital is £20,000 in 4000 shares of £5 each. Of these 3600 have been sucscribed

for by the public, and the remaining 400 allocated to Mr. Broome, Woodlands, in part Ïiaymcnt of the 1000 acres of land which is to

orm the plantation. A meeting of the Directors was held yesterday, at which the pleasant prospects of the Company formed tho theme of congratulation. It was resolved to have the survey of the plantation ground at onoe completed, and to advertise for a manager capable of forming the plantation, and attending to all the details of breaking up and planting out the ground; erecting machinery; and carrying on the work. The prospectus contemplated the erection of machinery, capable of manufacturing one thousand tons of sugar in the season, and as soon as the manager is appointed, it will no doubt be ordered, so as to be in readiness for crushing operations this time next year. Tho directors and the community are to be con fratulatud on the great start that has thus

eeo given to the sugar industry in the Central Distriot. }

THE annual tea meeting of the Gracemere Protestant Church was held last evening, when a large number sat down to partake of the abundant and varied supplies provided by the ladies of the congregation. At the publio meeting aftea tea, the Rev. T. W. I'Erson presided-' ' All hail tho power of Jesus name " was sung, when the Rev, T. Jones offered prayer. The Chairman called on Mr.

Watson, in the absence of Mr. Risien, to present the report. Ho complained of not being able to get a special train for less than £10. The remaining debt on thc building is £16, and a hope was expressed that the proceeds of this anniversary would extinguish it. The Chairman contrasted the present favourable state of things connected with Gracemere Protestant Churoh since he first knew it. The Rev. G. Slade dwelt upen the varied mercies of God, the satisfying character of godliness, and the happiness and joy which it will surely produce in its possessors. Mr. W. Davis spoke of the religious advantages of dwelling in the " bush." The bushmen of old times had religious enter- tainments, as they held communion with God and his angels. Mr. Redstone gave a reading very effectively. Mr. T. Jones urged a realisa- tion of the great end of life, and the impor- tance sincerely, earnestly, and believiugly of each ono working out tho pur- pose of God in our . history. Rev. D. Mossop gave a very interesting chapter in his early missionary life, illustrating the principle that godliness is profitable to all things, having promise of the life that now is,

and that which is to come, and that ho that soweth bountifully shall also reap bountifully. Kev. R. Hartley dwelt on the advantages of public worship. Several appropriate sacred songs were sung at intervale. The children are to have their treat this afternoon.

THE new punt, which has been in course of construction by Mr. E. Hollingsworth on the north side of the river, will be launched at eleven o'clock this morning.

MR. CURTIS' land sales to-day are most attractive to speculators and others. A block at the corner of South and Bolsover Streets, not far from the Deep-water Wharf, should command the attention of commercial men. A large number of town allotments, between Archer and Fitzroy Streets, on the Range ; and allotments on the Yaamba Road will bc offered, besides a building sito at Emu Park ; a block in George-Btreet ; and a cottage and land in Denham-etreet,

articleText:
KOCKIIAMPTON.

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER ll, 1883.

THAT is a very good custom which they retain in Victoria, but have departed from in this colony-for what reason we

have never been able to discover-of putting descriptive preamble to Bills in Parliament. The preamble, when well drawn, sets forth clearly the aim and purpose of the measure with which it is connected, so that before starting lo consider a Statute, the student has a f.iir idea of thc ends sought to be accom- plished by it. This appears from thc preamble of a Hill, upon the introduc- tion of which the Premier of Victorialately made a great speech. The preamble in question recites that " it is desirable to repeal the present Civil Service Act, and make belter provisions, which will apply to and include all departments of the public service, not heretofore provided for by any act of Parliament, and it is

expedient and highly desirable to abolish patronage in appointments and promo- tions, and cstalish a just and equitable system, which will enable all persons, who have qualified themselves in that behalf, to enter the public service without favour or recommendation, other than their own merits and fitness for the position." From these few sentences we learn that patronage in the appoint- ments and promotions lo the public service, under the old system, have been inequitable and unjust ; and that this measure has been framed to put an end to nepotism and favourit- ism for the future. To learn how far the old system has been iniquitous we must refer to the speech of the hon. gentleman who introduced the measure, and it furnishes us with evidence of a very important character upon the subject. For thirty years Mr. Service has been closely connected with the commercial interests of Victoria, and an observer of what was going on in the public service. Now he comes forward and tells the Assembly that the condi- tion of things in it has become

such as cannot be described otherwise

than by the word "deplorable." In portraying the manner in which it has arisen, the hon. gentleman does not seem to have taken sufficient account of

the state of education and circumstances

of the colony. The demoralisation

which has arisen he attributes to the introduction and retention of men in all branches of the Civil Service without

their passing through the lower grades ; and to political patronage lifting men "over the garden wall" into the pleasant shades of the public preserve. It was because the upper classes in the United Kingdom were crowding the public service with younger sons, and making it costly and ineffective, that the system of competitive examinations was

introduced there. Besides, there was no : excuse for the conservative arrangement, because there were always plenty of competent servants available. Twenty years ago that was not the case in Vic toria, any more than it is in Queensland

now. We have had neither time nor

opportunity to create or cultivate a large supply of well-qualified civil servants, especially for the higher branches of the service. Hence the administrators and heads of departments have been glad to get good men, though they did not come up

the ladder of successive promotion. In Victoria things have now altered with the lapse of time and increase of edu- cational facilities. Candidates for em- ployment are numerous and competent, and, having a choice, it is clearly the duty of the Government to make provision for the best men being chosen. Our educational system is producing intelli- gent well-informed citizens, our popula- tion is increasing rapidly, and the time will come presently, when there will no longer be an excuse for patronage in this

colony.

The civil service reforms it is proposed to carry out in Victoria will commend the measure making provisions for them to all intelligent colonists. A sudden revolution is not to be effected. Men at present in the public service are not to

bo cont afintif on thfir tmeinçec, nc sa

many were on the famous " black Wednesday." A classification is to be made of all the work done in the various departments of the public service, and thc employees are to be graded and paid accordingly. If it is found, for instance, that a person is drawing a salary associated with a certain rank in the service, he must do the work of that grade : if he is found to be incompetent, then he must be content to occupy a lower position, or leave the service. In this way inefficient place-holders, who have been stuck into places for which they are not fit, will be set aside to make way for worthy officers. At the same time, so long as the former are receiving as much as they are worth they will have no cause of complaint. Besides, promotion will still be open to them. In any event they will obtain the usual annual leave of absence, and the stated superannua- tion allowance when they are entitled to it. Such arrangements are fair alike to the service and the servants.

With regard to the future, all first appointments are to be dependent on merit alone, and independent of all political influence. All candidates for office will only be admitted on the com- petitive system. They will be called upon to pass the civil service examina- tion, conducted by a board appointed for the purpose. Those who stand highest in these trials will receive the first appointments, so that though a. candidate may be the son of the Premier, that will not affect his position in the least. The best men will win, and it will be open for the son of the humblest colonist to gain the highest position in the service. There are to be two examinations-one for positions in the fifth and fourth classes, and one for the three hißher. The effect of this arrangement will be that men who have had a good deal of com- mercial experience and training, who are well educated, and otherwise com- petent, may be able to enter and pass for appointments in the third class, without having to undergo the drudgery, accept the small pay, and do the manual work incumbent upon those in the lower classes. A great many of those who piss for appointments in the latter, which must always be the more numerous, do not look forward to the higher appoint- ments, being conscious of their inability to pass the higher examinations. Still an officer will be permitted to pass from the fifth to fourth class without further ex- amination ; but he must pass the third class examination to fret higher. Then seniority alone is not io bc regarded in connection with promotions, but m-iit is

to he taken into account. A candidat» who liasses with hitrh honours, and shows a special apitude for the work committed to him, will not be prevented from rising in the service bv the inter- vention of some old duffers, whose onlv special claim may bc that they were in it

before him.

We can conceive that (hose who have

been entrusted with the management of the Government departments of the

public service in Victoria, will look forward with a sense of coming relief to the operation of the measure introducing these reforms. It will protect ministers and heads of depart- ments from a great many unjust reflections. The recent appointment of Collector of Customs for this colony will occur to many of our readers, as a case in point. In it the Government appointed a smart, clever, comparatively youthful official, and their conduct in not regarding the claims of senior members of the service was severely condemned. In Victoria in future such complaints will be dangerous, as they may lead to

revelations not to the credit of the dis- appointed officers. We regard " The Public Service Bill " of Victoria as an excellent measure, and trust we may be- fore long have one like it in this colony.

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE.

TESTIMONIALS.

TO THE EDITOlt OF THIS MORNING BULLETIN.

Sin,-Tn your report of Hie meeting of the North Rockhampton Municipal Council ou Mouday evening, it is stated that references were forwarded as to the character and capa-

bilities of Messrs. Part and Brown. No

mention is made of references of other appli-

cants, nnd nu the question being asked by

Alderman Nobbs and answered in thc affirma-

tive by thc Mayor that all such were read, it would lead readers of your journal to believe the other applicants did not, or perhaps could not produce any. I, as one of thc latter, forwarded references from some of the most respectable aud well-known citizens of Rock- hampton. By inserting the above you will greatly oblige,

Yours, &o"

J. F. DELAHEY.

Rockhampton, November G, 1833.

articleText:
COHRKSPON DENCE.

SUNDAY DIVERSIONS.

TO THE r.MTOU OP THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIR,-Will you kindly allow mc a space in your valuable columns to speak of thc manner in which the law is held in defiance at sonic of tho hotels in this camp as regarda Sunday trading, dancing and drinking during pro- hibited hours of trade. I give one instance which took place only a short time ago. An hotel was kept open for the purpoBe of dancing and drinking until four o'clock on thc Sunday morning. The question naturally ariiei

«here are our policemen when such things take place. , ? ?

I am, ic.,

VüI/CAH.

Pine Hi», December 2, 188».

articleText:
KOCK HAMPTON.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1883.

THE Convention of Delegates from the various Australasian colonies, todeliberate and determine on the proposed annexa tion of the New Guinea and the South Pacific Islands, has concluded ¡ts sittings in Sydney. A precis report of the proceedings, transmitted by telegram, has put us in possession of the resolu- tions to whichthey have come, but have left us very much in ignorance of the reasons by which the delegates were guided in condescending on them. For this ignorance we are indebted to the representatives of Queensland among others, and whether it is blissful or not is a question on which there has been a good deal of discussion. One of the first matters the Convention was called on to consider was, whether the press should be admitted to report the proceedings. By a large majority it was determined to exclude newspaper reporters, but to supply a fina's of the business for publication. To this arrange- ment we do not think much exception can be taken. The great advantage of

the publication of the reports of such , meetings is that they educate the mass of the people on the subjects discussed. The electors, who are the Anal court of appeal in all matters of public interest,

arc thus enabled to judge of the conduct ! of their representatives, and of the grounds by* which it has been actuated. It would, no doubt, have been useful and interesting to have been furnished with such information respecting thc recent convention, but in this instance there is a foreign element to be con- sidered. The question of annexation could not be discussed without pointed references being made to the possible intentions, aspirations, and interests of foreign powers. These would be read by the representatives of these powers, and transmitted to their respective Governments. They would, in any event, be liable to misinterpretation and misrepresentation, and might be the means of creating distrust and suspicion unnecessarily. Besides, prudence sug- gests that, where the expression of opinion is apt to be ham- pered among the delegates on the one hand, and to excite hostility on the other, among foreign powers ; and where no material harm can ensue from silence, it is the safer course to adopt the latter. It is not in accordance with the policy of Radical politicians, who would have all that is done by their representatives brought to the lieht : but we will not obiect to our

delegates having in this matter adopted

a Conservative course.

With the results of the Convention we think the public have every reason to be satisfied. The facts which led us to start this question of annexation were, first, the suggestion, circulated in the German Press, that Germany should colonise New Guinea ; and, second, the proposal, emanating from the French Government, that the Pacific Islands should be converted into penal stations for the reception of criminals. What we dreaded was the domination of a first

rate European power, and the establish- ment in our neighbourhood of nurseries of lawlessness, and crime. Upon these points the Convention has uttered no uncertain sound, and yet it has done so in a manner that should not give offence to the most susceptible of the powers of Europe. The first resolution agreed upon set forth that the intrusion of any European Power in the South Pacific would be regarded as detrimental to the interests of Aus- tralasia, and of those of the British Empire. An amendment declaring that the acquisition of dominion by any foreign power would be regarded as injurious to the interests of Australasia and making no reference to the British Empire was afterwards adopted. So far as we can make out the amendment was an improvement on the original resolu- tion, because it does not involve us in the maintenance of the foreign policy of the British Government. There was no

occasion for the colonies constituting themselves the champions of the British Empire in the Pacific. When they guard the interests of Australia they protect the Empire, and there was no need for

the exhibition of " Rule Britanniaism " which appeared in the first resolution. There seemed to be no doubt entertained as to the propriety of annexing the por- tion of New Guinea, not already under the protection of the Dutch. Indeed, after indicating the reasons for it, the Convention declared it to be its emphatic opinion that annexation was desirable. The resolution puts the arguments for it very succinctly, and its declaration leaves no doubt upon it. All this unity and determination, displayed at present, is in marked contrast to the indifference which prevailed before Sir Thomas Mcilwraith sent the Police Magistrate at Thursday Island to unfurl the British Ensign on the shores of New Guinea. That pro- ceeding was described by our Premier as a fiasco, but it drew atention to the sub- ject in a practical fashion, which could not have been done by any other means. It was a decided step in the right direction, and though the method was questioned the object was approved of. The unusual character of the step taken drew attention to the object to be gained by it, and that was the main pur- pose of the proceeding. In this case the end has justified the means.

On tlie question of the annexation of the Pacific Islands the Convention did not express so decided an opinion. There was some difference of views

on the subject among the delegates, but ultimately they declared that it would be well to hare any agreement, about them entered into by the Euro- pean Powers, placed on record ; and that they would be pleased to see them associated with the Australasian colonies under the British Crown. They declared their willingness to assist in paying the cost of government. The Convention, in most emphatic terms, protested against the proposal of France to transport large numbers of criminals to the Pacific. Upon reviewing the resolutions it will be seen that the prac- tical work done by the Convention has consisted of little more than a formal, concise, and united expression of opinions, that were entertained in all the colonies. The Press long since showed what were the sentiments of the colonists on the questions raised, and the Convention has embodied them. The delegates have done a good work, and have done it fairly well.

They luve also taken an initiative step towards federation, the consumma- tion of which has been the hope of many of the best public men in tlie colonies. Lord Derby, in his correspondence on the annexation question, suggested federation as an important factor in its accomplish- ment, and the Convention have not over- looked his Lordship's hint. They have agreed to resolutions in favour of a Federal Council ; and have set them- selves to draft a Bill for its constitution. This measure will be presented to tlie Parliaments of the Australasian colonies, and should it meet with their approval then the Federal Council will become in deed an Australian Parliament. Our information regarding thc constitution of the proposed Council, and the class of subjects to be dealt with by it is too limited to admit of our discussing them at present, but they are of the first im- portance, and ai oportunity offers should

receive the careful consideration of all colonists.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. FRIDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1883.
snippet: THE Convention of Delegates from the various Australasian colonies, todeliberate and determine on the proposed annexartion of the New Guinea and the

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

,.' FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1683.

THE Sydney Convention cannot claim, and has not claimed, any legislative authority. - For all practical purposes ' it has simply been a meeting of the leading men, who for the time being are respon- sible for the executive authority of the Australasian Colonies.' The' sixteen gentlemen who thus met to talk over the various matters they had in hand were perfectly entitled to attach a quasi con- fidential character to their proceedings. It would, perhaps, have been as well ii they had taken the public into their con fidence by allowing the reporters to attend, because the chief object of the meeting was discussion, and the presence of reporters would have immensely widened the area of discussion, and rfould have educated people more effec- tually into an understanding of'the position pf thc questions -discussed. ?Still, in a sort of surreptitious way a good deal of what has been said has transpired, and the, conclusions arrived at have been published. in an autho- rised form. The resolutions agreed to on the annexation question are no doubt most important, and will un- questionably lead the way .to further action, on the part of the Government which we call Imperial-that is, the Government of the Queen in so far as it relates to the British Empire. Yet it is quite certain, nevertheless, that the Queen's Ministers will act .entirely on their' own judgment br responsibility in carrying out the recommendations made. They are recommendations^ and nothing more. ' : ' ' '

But, in dealing'with the other matters so fully discussed, and io drafting a Bill to provide a Federal Council for Aus- tralia, these sixteen representative gen- tlemen tóok a step a long way in advance of any thing yet attempted at any Con- ference, and they have no doubt laid thc foundation'for future federal action if

it is ever possible to attain it., What, then, has been done ? It is essential we should clearly understand this. The six gentlemen who at present are at the 'heads of their respective administration in the Colonies of Australasja have

nlerlnfid thfimselvés to submit this ques- tion of federal action to their several legislatures, in the form of an enabling bill, which, after consultation, they have agreed to. This, then, involves the relegation of this question to the different legislatures for discussion in a definite shape, to which they are bound tb say either yes or no. The question, then, of federal action will no lunger be allowed to1 float about in an ethereal strata of the political atmosphere a long way above the heads of our ordinary legislators. They are to be invited to signify their assent or their dissent to this bill, and if their assent to signify this, by an address to Her Majesty's Government, to be followed up by Parliamentary action, includ- ing the assent of the lords, spiritual and temporal. - Here, then it is manifest that, by some means or other this gaseous body labelled federation, which has been floating about in mid air, the property of

two or three adventurous aeronauts has at last been dragged to earth and de- prived of its expansive stuffing. A

ballon thus reduced to its substantial essence is a sorry spectacle, with but scant furnishing of such body and bones as we expect in a vehicle fitted for loco- motion on the surface of the earth. Nevertheless, the balloon is caught-we can now analyse its structure, and if it so pleases "the Divinities who shape our ends rough hew them as we may " it is just possible that the shapeless wreck, as it now looks, may yet be en- dowed with a life which may send it spinning on through the stormy universe.

Who can tell?

In the meantime the Federal Council Bill, as agreed to by the Convention, is a singularly embrionic creation, to all out- ward appearance utterly unsuitable for any great purpose of national union or usefulness. Yet, having regard to the infinite insignificance, and even to the repulsiveness of nature in the ruder forms of creative energy, it becomes us well to remember that first effects, like these in the direction of national acquirements, have often been mere abortions which have lo be rectified by time and experience. When, therefore, we come to think what might have been thirty years ago, when the Aus- tralian constitutions were being passed through the hands of our legislative artificers, this Federal Council Bill looks like a farce. It had then been contem-

plated, and indeed was so designed by Her Majesty's faithful Commons in Parliament assembled that Her Majesty should provide for the meeting of an Australian Parliament. Yet our " lords spiritual and temporal" being not improb- ably the repositories at that time of that power which shapes our ends rough hew them as we may, determined that this should not lie, and, dissent- ing from the Commons, they decreed that Her Majesty should not have any such reserved rights as those prefigured in the Bill. The conséquence was that the Australian Colonies were started in life each with their constitution so very much unlimited that lhere was no room

left for atty Superior authority, -except that of the-Queen'6 herself. Each is a

.liul^State itt itself with legislative powers,

which, by osage, fcavf ,become almost unlimited, or limited'' only" by the ajjegiauce which they bear to the sove-

reign. Look at Victoria. As a Slate Victoria is excessively 4oyal, sentimen- tally joya, tor almost a painful ¡degroeyr and yet Victoria, by her Parliament, claims absolute and unlimited indepen- dence within the mystic circumference of the British Empire. ? '

Where then is the margin for federal action? The Federal Council Bill is the answer we have to this most per- tinent question-and what does it pro- pose to do? It proposes to do as little as it ' possibly can in the first instance - and why ? . ? Because if it did it would arouse the enmity and'the' opposition of the existing legislatures. : The Federal Council Bill proposes then to create a most

singular1 body for legislative purposes ; it proposes thaf they shpuld meet at rare intervals, and that they shall have as little as possible to do. À Federal Council inferior in any respect to the legislatures from which it will derive its existence, is an anomaly in constitu- tional history, and yet such is the present position of the Australian Colonies, and suth are the privileges of the respective legislatures that there peem's to be no place left for functional development except by sprue such process as that which has been devised. A legislative unjon between two or more colonies is, a possibility involving absolute incorpora-' tion, but.,no Australian Colonies con- template this at present. They have fallen back, therefore, upon this federal compact as a possibility, and they fancy that they are about to find a bond of union in a foreign policy. The Island question is .this foreign policy, and having :found something, tangible on which tq poise the lever, it is .possible that they may evojve a mode of action.

Sut it if evident that before this is accomplished1 the subject has to be well discussed in every legislature which will be affected by it.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1883.

articleText:
EMU PAJK RAILWAY.

TO TUE EDITOH OP TH6 MORNING ?BULLETIN.

SIR,-If you can allow me to ooonpy a little of your valuable spice, I should like to make

a few remarks on "Observer's " observations

re petitioners' proposed route for Emu Park Railway

Obeerier says, " this line after passing Half- way House .goes through a barren unretnunera tive and almost uninhabited country.'* That the first statement is nonsenso, any person travelling along the road could see at a glanoe from the condition of the cattle, notwith- standing the rersot drought, and from the two patches of cultivation to be seen from any passing \ehicle. 'As 'to the second I guess

Air. Costello kfncfcs something more than tucker out of a part of it. But the third

statement showi that "Observer" lacks either the abilcy or the opportunity to observe. There are almost as many per- sons permanently resident on my selection, besides the popio at Mr. Costello's station, and tie numorous families on the Cawarral homestead area as there are permanent!; resident in "the centre of population," Cawarral township. Now, sir, if ' with > indi Bplandld < land, and mining resources and machinery to boot the township peoplchave onby managed to let the machinery go toits present state of ruin, and their traffiotodwindlétóitapresentibnhitfesimal proportions, war should the Government be~ asked to spend the money required for two (long) miles of railway to take (he traffic from

where it is to waere it is not.

As regards construction, though there may be no difficult« in either case, any person may know that it wpnld be cheaper to construct a line along tbe bwer road, which is almost level for more than half the distance in question, while the road via the township is one con- tinuous up-ant-down with at any ral», one nasty curve init.

Yours, ka..

D. WHITELEY.

Cawarral, December 26, 1883, '

articleText:
I 00ERESPONDEKOÍI. j

( TO THE EDITOR OF THE MOEHtHO VmSXlis. ]

Stn,-Ie the' Argot tumble to' fight its own tattles that it gets a " Dingo to bark for it. I imagine that "Dingo," .by his lingo, is related to "Snarley Yow." It appears he complains of scurrility in a certain correspon- dent of yours ; but I suppose "Dingo" will

allow that those who live in glass houses should never throw stones. Well, I dis- covered that the Argot, who threw stones very freely, lived in a house of glass, and I plead guilty to doing a pretty considerable amount of smashing, amongst that vitreous and transparent property ot your contem- porary. But I disclaim all scurrility. If I prove a person is willfully deviating from the paths of truth, and I call that deviation by its proper name-is that scurrility T If I believe a certain person is deceiving nu, and trying to take me in, and by which conduct I and many others will suffer-is it scurrility to expose

that conduct Î If a member of the Press inculcates fiendish statements-is it scurrility to compare that person with Milton's hero of "Paradise Lostî" Perhaps yoi will tell me. Sir, that, according to the strict definition of the word, all the foregoing is scirrility ; if so,

then I can only reply that yon cannot touch pitch, and go undefiled.

The, Opposition, after the Zulu fashion, collect their dead and wounded, and pitch them at us. "Dingo" advancte the "gooso and gander" arguments, and sayi "why, m the name of all that is lovely, should the corn farmer not be allowed two or three Coolies, as well as the sugar planter." Well, I do not know if he can have two or three, but if he pays the expense of bringing tlem here, and sending them back to their own country, he can have the minimum number that the regu- lations allow, if all the conditions are com- plied with. The Coolies were not to be restricted to sugar plantations, but to tropical agriculture-such as cotton, rioe, indigo, cotton, &o. If the corn-farmer or maize grower cannot see his way to employ them, "in the name of all that is lovely" why should the sugar planter, when he can, be Drevented from having them. Why should " Dingo " and others take it for granted that coolies wonld not return to their own country, when their term of service was expired, if they agreed to do so t They go back from other countries-then why not from this? By statistics it is shown that during the last twenty years ten thousand have returned to

Calcutta.

I shall now quote an extract from the Nor tlicrn JUincr, of Charters Towers, which claims to be another champion of the working man ; and after-reading it, I think everyone will Bee the hollowness of Liberal championship. The editor is commenting upon the Premier's speech at Rockhampton, and replies to the argument that the Kuropean labourer will not work cheap enough, "Now," he says "in answer to this argument we may say that labour sufficiently cheap, abundant, and reliable can be obtained from Great Britain and Europe, if a proper system of emigration be adopted. If, for instance, emigration com- panies, operating in England, wore empowered to engage men for certain terms and wages for plantation work, there is little doubt the difficulty would be met. The Chinese adopted this plan in introducing labourers into Cali- fornia, and though in their case it was véritable slavery, the principle at the bottom was that of associated labour working in defined terms; The assertion that Europeans declined the work, and it was not fit for them is easily answered. With tho limited number of Europeans introduced it was not to bo expected that the men coming here would choose the worst remunerated kind of labour."

Now, the working men will observe that tho argumont is that it was on account of thc limitednnmberintroduoedintothecountry ; and that were'emigrants from Europebroughtoutin unlimited numbers wages would fall all round ; consequently they would then as soon work on the sugar plantations as at any other kinds of labour, when the wages were the same. Now, can the working men of Rockhampton doubt, after this exposure, that there is a conspiracy between the Liberal press and Mr. Griffith to materially cut down their wages. They may remember that it is the very same scheme the Argot broached some time ago.

I think it must be allowed that I am quito justified iu denouncing the Liberal press and the writers in it as superlative humbugs.

Toura, &c.,

ANTI'HUMDUO. Rockhampton, January 8,1883.
heading: CORRESPONDENCE. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

KOCKII AMI'TON.

TUESDAY. MARCH 27, 1883.

AN adjourned meeting nf gentlemen favour- able tn thc reception of Mr. (tedmund, M.F. «rae held in the Hibernian Hall last night. There was a large attendance and a committee was appointed to carry out arrangements in oonnection with Mr. Redmond's recoptlon hero. Owing to pressure on our space thc report of tho meeting is witheld.

A TELEGRAM from Gympie to Mr. James Mackenzie, F.C.8. of the Rockhampton district, stated the sittings of the Annual Moveable Committee in oonnection with the Oddfellows' Order closed yesterday. Bro. John Sterne, of Warwick, was elected O.M.; Bro. J. Wakefield, of Rockhampton, D.G.M.; and Bro, W. Macandie, of Brisbane, C.S.

AT the Police Court OD Saturday one drunkard was cautioned and discharged.

WE draw attention to the annual vestry meeting of the parishioners of St. Paul's Church, to be held to-night at eight

o'clock.

IT will be seen by an advertisement in another column that Mr. J. Ferguson will address the electors of Rockhampton in the School of Arts on Thursday night.
