articleText:
[OVlÙHflillUctM,

KOCK ll A MI-TON.

SATURDAY, MASCH 31, 1883.

THE general awakening of interest in the subject of immigration throughout Australia is a very noticeable and ought to be an encouraging sign of the times. In all the colonies the cry for "more hands" is heard. We know what we ourselves are doing. In New South Wales, a steady importation of immi- grants is going on, and provision for largely increasing the supply has just been made. South Australia, which has of late years reverted in a timid and tentative manner to ¡ts old policy of importing population, shows a disposi- tion to launch out again into a regular system of State immigration. In Victoria, where complete and selfish isolation is regarded as the " settled policy of the country," the resumption of assisted immigration is being discussed as a possible contingency. Even in Tas- mania, where, from various causes, there! is really little opening for new-comers, the desirability of encouraging immigra- tion has cropped up as a public question.

Some deduction must be made for

temporary and accidental causes in esti- mating the value of this apparently unanimous impulse towards the re- sumption of an Australian policy of immigration. It has been harvest time, and general prosperity having sent people flocking ioto the towns, there has been a great dearth of hands in the fields, throughout the two I great agricultural colonies of Victoria

and South Australia Something over twenty million bushels of wheat have to be reaped, bagged, and transported, and the strain on the country labour market is severe. It is noticeable that about harvest time there is always some reference made to the need of more population in the two colonies mentioned. But the erv this

year is very much stronger than it ever was before. Wages are exceedingly high, and as all the colonies are freely carrying on public works, both through their general and municipal govern ! ments, and propose to increase rather

j than diminish the rate of public ex-

penditure, it is evident that relief must be afforded to the labour market or evil will result. It is bad for a colony when labour is underpaid, it is equally bad for it when labour is so highly renumerated that the cost of production leaves no margin of profit to the producer. The enormous rate of wages paid in Victoria during the gold excitement, and in other parts of Australia during similar periods, are not cases in point, because the profits were then abnormal and the renumeration for work, though actually very high, was not disproportionate to the value of its pro- duce. But the present prosperity of Australia is due to the extension of industries-chiefly pastoral and agricul- tural - which though decidedly re numcrative are not yielding excessively high average profits, and can be easily stifled by being over loaded with costs. It must be remembered that capital is entirely beyond our control ; we can no more keep it in our colonies than wc can grasp and hold a wreath of smoke. We may import it by millions in the shape of public loans, but if it does not find profitable employaient h.Te, the money

will slip »way elsewhere to seek for it. ' Tbe only capitalist we can compel to carry on 1f0tjc *t a loss is the Govern- ment; and to" depend on this power to make up for the loss of private invest- ment would be just as wise a thing to

do as for a workman to expect to j -console himself/or the loss of employ- j raent and h\s weekly wage, by taking ! shillings out of his coat and putting

them into his trousers.

All these arearguments with which we are familiar, and which need not be urged on our own public. Queensland has never, in hex darkest hour, lost faith io assisted inmigration, even though she has been put to sore straits at times to keep it up. BIL we reproduce them for the benefit of our neighbours in the south, feeling justified in doing so by seeing the fa'triliar illustration of the money value à an immigration reap- pearing as a iovelty in the leading columns of sich a journal as the

Melbourne Argu. We desire to impress on them the necessity of acting while in their present fume of mind, and taking really practical steps for providing an influx of po|ulation equal to the growing need of the Continent. There are "lenty of politicians in the south who hug themselves in the belief mat they will always get a sufficiency of people from the sup- ply imported by the colonies which assist immigration. This is especially the case in Victoria-¡hat colony so exceedingly Australian and patriotic in speech, and so intensely selfish and provincial in action. But it must be dealt with in a broader and bolder spirit now that the colonies have established such close intercom-

munication, pnless Australian progress is to be alternately checked, first, by the want of poptlation to apply money ready for investnent, and then by the want of capital frightened out of the country by exorbitant rates of wages. Mo 'Fran« Stuart who read a timid and contradictory paper on the subject at a conference between the Mel- bourne Chambers of Commerce and Manufactures a few weeks since, said he did. not think it could be satisfactorily arranged until the advent of federation. For our. part *we' are inclined to think that federationwili never be satisfactorily

arranged until the colonies are able to , understand th« necessity for joint action in a matter ol such obviously common

interest, and tike the necessary steps to I carry it out. ill that would be required

is for ea ch cololy to provident) proportion j to itspopulatioi and revenue, for a regular

annual import if immigrants. Each could |

dei as we art: doing now in regard to I the internal tistribution of the new- comers, and 'each could select by preference thejclass of people it con

kept up a fair aimerica! proportion. If this were done there would be no need

for any special irecaution against immi- grants leaving Sne colony for another. If one roan landed in Queensland thought he woild prefer Victoria as a permanent home, there would be another who would findjhis way from that colony

and the result) beneficial to all. Let Victoria abanrjan her attitude of selfish isolation and teasing to reckon on pro fitting by the immigration expenditure of her neighlours, lay out her fair proportion of tie cost of peopling Aus- tralia, and let New South Wales and South Australia increase their annual ex- penditure to a lum more in accordance with the aecesf ties of the case, and the thing is done.5 And when we see the Southern colqiies in this simple and natural manne; give a practical proof that the Australian communities really recognise the ¿ct that they bare mutual duties and a rational aim in view, we

shall be disposed to believe that at last

a solid substratim of reality is forming | itself beneath'the heaps of oratorical froth which nov surround the question of federation. <

RUMOUR has it that the ill-advised snit Miles v. M'llvraith has eost Mr. Milos £4,000, whioh s quite likely to be within the mark. It firther says that the footing up of this sad aoene bas led to a certain degree of oooliess between client and oounsel, which wald be natural enough, but which is after all here rumour.-Tribune.

IT will be remeabered that some time back a man named Jihn Zonoa received severe injuries while hi was engaged at work on the wharf, rom the effeots of whioh he never reooverd. We are pleased to note that efforts are bring made to provide for the comfort of his widow and family, and a musical entertainment is to be given on Monday eveningin the Lake's Creek School- room, when we bope there will be a large

attendance.

Ms, JAMBS CARMODY, lately first assistant at the North Rockhampton State School, has been promoted to the position of first assistant in the Central School. On the occasion of his leaving the north Side school ho was preseuted with a beautiful writing-desk by Mr. J. Spiers,

provided that all would be natural,

«no, on uelMIÏ of the teacher» anil pupila, in a few word«, withed him success in bis new position, Mr. Carmody feelingly responded, and thanked them all for their kindly «pres-

sions for his welfare.

BEFORE the Police Magistrate yesterday, Peter . Warren, better known aa "French Peter," was cautioned for his disorderly con- duct «nd discharged. Patrick Joseph Tierney, . saddler, was charged by John Rutherford with being absent from his hired service. Mr. Melbourne appeared for the complainant and Mr. Brumm for the defendant. The evidence

of both parties was heard, and it appeared that defendant had absented himself at certain times while under the influence of liquor. The i matter was arranged by defendant being

ordered to pay £2 2s. professional catt« and I 3s. Cd. costa of Court on bis consenting to

return to work.

j THE Bunyip s.s., with the southern advices I from the Q.R.M.S. Chyebassa, returned to

the Company's wharf early yesterday after- noon. On her downward trip she took a quantity ol provisions for the barque Mary Evans, at anchor under the lee of Cape Capricorn. Shortly after leaving the mail steamer the eugioeer reported to Captain Dunlop that the boiler was injured. Under these circumstances the captain deemed it prudent not to proceed to sea, and accordingly .teamed np thc river, after leaving the provi- sions at the lightship, at a moderate speed. The Bunyip was kept in front of the Egmont, s.s., in case «bc became disabled, and she reached tova without any further mishap. Pending repairs to the boiler the local agent of the Company, Mr. A. T, Wood, secured the service» of the Government steamer Fitzroy,

wj&a w¡U leave to-monrow afternoon at twp

with the maila and passengers .tor the «out

tnaOboat.^. ,fk

A very deserving young officer in the police force here has received promotion, which has been earned by a careful attention to his duties. We refer to mounted constable O'Rourke, who leaves on Sunday for Cook- town, where he will be stationed as senior constable. O'Rourke has been six years in Brisbane, Clermont, and Rockhampton, and during that time has proved an efficient officer.

SEBGEANT CAREY arrived from Blackall yesterday with the girls Fanny and Florence Parker, who were committed for trial on a ohsrge of child murder at Windorah, and Agnes Connolly, committed for trial for the murder of her husband at Blackall. Tile prisoners will be tried at the next sittings of the Supreme Court, to be held at Rockhamp- ton on the 17th April.

j HEBB D. BANDMANN writes us from Calcutta on 5th February that he leaves for the colonies Bhortly, by way oí Queensland ports. The "eminent tragedian" is accom- panied by Miss Louise Beaudet, and a strong company. He purposes visiting Rockhampton en route to Brisbane and the southern capitals ; and, if suffioieut inducement offers, will appear here in either "Hamlet," the "Merchant of Venice," or "East Lynne." We have lively recollections of Herr Bsud mann's performances in ¡Sydney and can safely say Rockhampton playgoers will have a treat if even for one night. We Bhould much prefer to see his rendition of Hamlet, as other artistes have done their best to morder tho character they have attempted to pourtrsy. What the "sufficient inducement" consists in we leave the future to disclose.

IT will be seen by an advertisement in another column that the time of arrival and departure of trains running between Emerald and Capella will bo altered on and after Monday, 2nd April.

THE usual monthly meeting of tho Farmers' and Selectors' Association will be held this morning at the School of Arts, when a paper will be read by Mr. P. Egan.

Tue following is the state of the Hospital for the week ending Friday, March 30 :-Ad- mitted during the week, 3 males ; discharged, 6 males, 3 females ; died, one female patient (Jane PariBh, aged 30 years) ; remaining in hospital, 27 males, 6 females; total 33. Seven patients in the special ward.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1883.
snippet: THE general awakening of interest in the subject of immigration throughout Australia is a very noticeable and ought to be an encouraging sign of the times.

articleText:
TRADE IN EMERA AD,

TO TUB EDITOR OF TUE MORNING BULLETIN. I

Sid.-I notice ia your valuable paper of the 9th, a letter from your Emerald correspon- dent He writes for the purpose of inducing some person or persons of principle in the butchering, basing, and general etorckeeping business to come »nd settle down here. He states the price of meat at ii. and 6d., and only a limited supply of bread from Bogantungan at 7d., and concludes by stating there is a splendid opening here for a few spiritual business people.

In my opinion your correspondent should have gone a step further, and have stated the largo number of wealthy people who, have made this rising town their permanent home, also that a fair proportion of them being con- nected with the railway, have tho privilege of obtaining goods from Rockhampton freo of railage.

The coming storekeepers should also bo reminded that they will have to compete with the almost omnipresent Chinaman, who by praiseworthy economy in architecture, food, and clothing, together with his ability to trade by day and night, as well as on Sundays and public holidays, places himself in such a posi- tion that he caa sell a few of the commou necessaries at lt or 2 por cent lower thau his white brother.

Let the coming storekeepers also bear in mind that they will be expected to keep every article in the trade from a needle to an anchor ; must sell at a price as low or lower than the Chinese ; and give three, six, or twelve months credit, if required, be- cause the Chinese " no aavje " when credit is required. It those business people who are thinking of starting here can fulfil these con- ditions they will do well. Otherwise they can hardly expect to prosper ; inasmuch as the Chinese have now a character for honesty and straightforwardness, and thereby obtain the liberal support of those who can pay ready

cash.

Further, for the encouragement of those who may bc induced to try a new field, I may state that a new butcher and baker havo made a start. Meat and bread have come down to old prices, and there is no appearance what- ever of any attempt to raise -tho price of goods.

The black clouds that for a time hovered over this inland town have now quite cleared away, and those requiring goods of any description, whether they live in town or country, may come forth with the prospect of getting value for their money, ns they could ubinin in thc far-famed town of Rockhampton, with the exception of a trine added for

railsce.

IYouri, otc,

OBSERVER.

Emerald, April ll, 1683, I

articleText:
MONDAY, APHIl-, 23, 1883.

DEVOTION to principles is generally lo be regarded as a virtue, and a consistent man will obtain a certain amount of

respect from others, even though he may be at variance with the principles they themselves uphold. There are many principles which very eminent men have endorsed, that have since their time, and even during their lives, been brought into question, and their soundness tested, the effect of which has been to modify, and in some instances entirely reverse them. In young countries, one great .problem before statesmen is how to develop dormant resources; and the first difficulty that is met with on the threshold is the competition to be con- tended against, by all industries in new countries, with articles which are imported from old States, in which such industries are thoroughly established, and economi- cally carried on. The difficulty of obtain- ing labour, owing to the scarcity of population in a youthful nation, is also at all times a chief obstacle in the way of progress.

As to how the difficulties pointed out are to be met, there will of course always be a difference of opinion, but upon the existence of the difficulties, and the desirability of overcoming them, there is unity. Unfortunately when attempting to deal with this important and intricate subject, those who discuss it generally enter upon its consideration with some pet theory of their own to maintain. They start wilh some principle of their own, which they deem immacu- late, and anything that violates such principle must in their opinion neces- sarily be wrong. Argument with them is perfectly useless ; the partizan stands by his favourite principle grimly deter- mined, and says : " Adam Smith laid down a certain principle as essential to the wealth of nations ; what is being proposed violates that principle ; I am with Mr. Smith, and will never surrender his principle." Of course when you get a noble patriot on his mighty " rock " in this manner, the only thing to do is to leave him there, in the hope that the intelligent electors will in due j season remove such a clog to the wheels

of progress. If this peculiar class of legislator heard a man insisting that I steamers, such as the " Orient " liners,

were a mistake, because Noah built on a different pattern, and Noah knew all

about ship-building, he would be amazed i at such monstrous absurdity. Yet him- self sticks to Adam Smith in precisely

the same manner as the oilier would to Noah : one is not more obstinate than the other.

Among other industries that of sugar-V growing is undoubtedly one of primary importance to the prosperity of Queens- land. This all admit ; but as soon as it is attempted to ascertain the best method of fostering that industry, nearly every one digs up some principle of political economy, laid down generally by a long-defunct genius, who had no practical expérience of Queensland, and, therefore, could not lay clown principles essential lo her progress and prosperity, and having exhumed this inviolable principle gets on it, and wont be knocked off. In considering the best method of fostering sugar-growing the most practical procedure is to determine how sug.ir is produced elsewhere, and what competition will our own produce be likely to meet with from foreign imports. There are two courses that now suggest themselves : one is to impose a pro- hibitory import duty on sugar, the other to grow it as cheaply here as elsewhere.

If the former course were followed the

price of stig ir to the consumer would be tremendous-say retail Sd. to is. per lb., because to make sugar-growing suffi- ciently remunerative to pay white men to weed the cane, cut it, and do other work of the kind on plantations, it would

be necessary to gel a high price for the article. None would pay Sd. for home- grown sugar, however, if the imported article could be obtained cheaper, and thus a heavy import duty would have to be imposed. Here the never-say-die ad- vocate of Free-trade would certainly get on his " rock," and cry out about violating some principle ; the duty would not be permitted, and the industry would be retarded while such person piously obstructed. Undoubtedly the protective policy would be inexpedient, since it would tend to increase the price of a very necessary article of diet.

Turning to the other proposition that is, to the endeavour to grow the article as cheaply here as elsewhere-the question arises-how can we grow sugar here, so as to compete with the imported article, without increasing the price of it to consumers? On studying sugar growing countries, we find that in all such very cheap labour is employed, and if we are ever to compete with them we must have the same. If there is a man, who can and will do the work for ^24 a-year and a few bags of rice, thal is the man we must have, if we want to grow our own sugar, and retail it cheap. When this is proposed the advocate of the working-man gels on his "rock," talks about lowering wages, and driving thc poor British workman out of the country. Now, we do not believe that any race of men under the sun could ever drive a genuine liritish mechanic off the continent. He can do his work, and follow his handicraft without fearing any man in the world, and the only man who is afraid of competition is the man who knows he is no good. Cheap labour for sugar plantations will not lower the wages of bootmakers, boilermakers, tailors, &c; on the contrary it will in- crease the demand for machinery of all kinds, and give an impetus to the iron trades ; it will increase the demand for meat and bread, and drive butchers and bakers ahead. The only man in the country who would feel the injury at the introduction of cheap labour on planta- tions would he the idle loafer, who wanted to get big wages for doing low class plantation work. Even New South Wales turns to the contemplation of the sugar industry by observing that in other countries coloured labour can produce the article cheaper than the home cultivator, and begins to realise that to compete in the industry cheap lahour is essential. As might be expected, as soon as this question comes up each enlightend debater rolls out his " rock," gets on it, and screams aghast "Slavery! Reduction! Ruination to to the poor-working man!" and hopes by this eternal yelling to hoodwink the elec- tors, and evenutually drift off his "rock" on to the Treasury benches, for which his soul yearns. Patriots of this class are on the war-path now, and dance on their little " rocks " in frantic anticipa- tion of " loaves and fishes " in the immediate future. May the scene to them not be, perhaps, delusive; and may not these pure patriots be eventually found silent, crushed underneath their own mighty " rocks I" This will soon

be decided, and the question of. " advancement or stagnation " for a time

settled.

TUE Customs collections at this port for tho week ending April 21, amounted to £2469

17s. Gd.

AT tho Police Court on Saturday one drunkard was cautioned and discharged. The case of W. Pattison v. J. O'Shanesy was further adjourned for a week, as was also tho case against John D'Arcy nlias Richard Shortie for the laroeuy of two cheques.

THE Government -Otadle of the 14th instant notiBes that the Rev. W. H. Williams has been authorised to celebrate mar- riages in tho Rockhampton district. Certificate oF discharge in insolveucy has been granted to Robert James Salisbury, of Spottiswoode, near Taroom. Tho following is tho Committee for thc Stato school at Cometville : - Messrs. Michael Uradshaw, John Crawford, James Donovan,, Edward W. N. Godber, and Peter Mannion.

As an instance of thc wonderful development of au industry, it is stated that during last year Messrs. James Epps and Co. despatched

from their establishment nearly 15,000,000 , packets of cocoa. They have erected mag- nificent premises in thc Italian style of architecture near the Victoria Embankment, and thc growth of thc business is evidenced hy the fact that, whereas in 1830 tho con- sumption of cocoa throughout the whole of the United Eingdom was estimated at only about 425,000 lbs., the quantity now produced by one firm alone amounts to millions.

THE writer of " City Notes " in a Loudon evening journal says :-" Some striking faets relative to tho increased consumption of Indian tea in this country arc given in Messrs, Gow und Wilson's report for thc past season. They state, for example, that duriue thc year 1S7S, out of every 1001b. of all descriptions of tea consumed in this country, 23, or one in about foiir-aiid-a third, was Indian tea. Last year tho proportion was 31 per cent., or nearly one in three. Thc deliveries ot China tea have receded from 125,000.00011). in IHl'J to 113,000,0001h. in 1SS2, while thu home con- sumption of Indian tea has increased from 35,000,000 lb. to 51,000,000 lb. iu'.the corres-

ponding years." «v/ ^THE Kev. W. A. Diggcns preached a vciy impressive sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Church, oil the duty of th&ukfulucss. Ile referred to thc waut of a superintendent and teachers in thc Suuday School, and re- marked that it was a channel into which thu efforts of a grateful heart might be turned. Ile also referred to tho canvass for thc ocw church falling through, and «aid tiley were at once confronted with thc stern fact that they had insufficient gratitude if they could not ßparc either the energy or means to complete these works for thc glory of God. The Conclusion of his sermon was of general interest, ile said -

Or again we have been startled »nd horrilicd during the put week by a réédition of the most utter depravity, the total ignorance of right and wrong, and the awful spiritual destitution that exista in districts surrounding this town.- Arc we to enjoy all the blessings of the light of thc ','ospel, and at the same time make no effort to dispel tho thick darkness, the positive heathenism that reigns around us. Aro wc to look upon our fellow countrymen, boys and girls Bink to an eqtial depth ot lawlessness ami sin with the degraded aborigines of the colony, and not stretch out a hand to help them. Ood forbid. It is torus herc in lîockliainpton tn commence the work which others will carry out. It is fur un to dispense the blessings which we have received. lt ia for us to teach thc Gospel where it is yet unknown, to plant thc cross »here it has not yet found its way, to form Christ's work, and extend Christ's Kingdom, There is thc natural outlet for our thankful

DCES. Let not our Saviour look dova upon ,

this congregation Crom heaven and say, I

" Were there oat ten cleansed, but where are 1 the nine ; there are not found that returned to give glory to God, save this stranger."

A MAN named Robert Thomson was arrested on Saturday, on a charge of having stolen a piece of bacon from tho store of Mr. M. Kelly, of Deuham-street.

"ON DIT" says the Maryborough Chronicle, that the Harbours and [¡ivers Department has received instructions from the Ministry to securo the removal of the dredge Saurian from Maryborough, to Rockhampton without delay.

THE Commissioner of Police has received a telegram from Normanton reporting that Mr. Murray, of Morstone, had found the body of Mr. Crawford, late manager of Rocklands, who had been killed by the blacks. The con- stable at Tambo reports that a man named Madigan attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat. He is now in the hospital in charge of the police.

BEFORE it is too late we would call the attention of the Committees of our leading Cricket Clubs to the preposterously small extent of useful ground in the area granted by the Gogango Divisional Hoard aa a cricket reserve. The land is such a peculiar Bhape, too, that a large portion of it will bc perfectly useless for thc purpose for which it was in- tended. Tho lino of fencing will run right through the ground ou which the matches aro usually played, of course making it perfectly useless. We understand the Board grantod the extent of land that was applied for, and would no doubt extend tho area if proper representations were made by those con-

cerned.

TUE action of the Licensing Bench (says tho tJarijhorowjh Chronicle) in absolutely refusing to renew licenses for those public-houses agaiust which convictions for selling liquor to kanakas have been recorded, during the past twulvc mon'hs, is a salutary punishment which ought to have full effect in putting a stop to thu undesirable traffic. Three licenses have thus been refused, and though thc conse- quences to tho applicants will probably bo serious, we have nothing but commendation far thc Bench in taking the drastic course they have. No doubt there arc other publicans equally guilty, but they have so far eluded detection, and the warning now given them will perhaps bc obeyed.

UNDER date Tambo, 7th tinstant,tbe Courier correspondont writes:-"The following are thc stock movements since I last wrote ; 9500 fat wethers, the property of John Govett, Portlind, for Rockhampton ; W. H. Govett in charge. 13,000 owes and 300 rams, the property of T. L. Richardson, Canonbar, New South Wales, bound for the Gulf i A. W. Watts in charge. 10,000 ewes of C. B. Fisher's, from Nuoda, going to the Diaman- tina ; W. H. Wyatt in charge. As yet no min has fallen, though we hear of plenty all round the district. If we do not soon get somo Tambo will ho in a bad state ; the cattle arc already heginniug to look the worse for tho long drought. It is reported our member, Mr. Jahn Govett, is to be here in a few days to render an account of his stewardship, and that the Hon. B. D. Morehead is also expected."

DURING tho progress of a cricket match at North Rockhampton, on Saturday afternoon, between tho Zingari and Albert Clubs, Mr. \V. H. Bell, a member of the former team, was struck very severely by tho cricket ball. Mr. Bell was stationed at point, much too close in, and a ball driven smartly to long field off by Mr. Grecnelsh struck him on thc forehead just above the Tight eyebrow. Tho ball knocked Mr. Bell down, making a dreadful gash on his brow, and leaving him partially insensible. After the wound had been plentifully bathed, tho injured gentleman sufficiently recovered to be taken to his residence. A very similar mis- hap occurred, in thc same match, to Mr. F. Hunt, who had ,i nasty cut ou the forehead from a bumpy ball whilst acting as wicket- keeper. Theso accidcuts should induce our crickcteiB to do all in their power to secure s proper wicket to play on, for nuder tho present system it ÍB positively dangerous to life and limb to play on suoh hard, rough ground.

THK Volunteers commenced class-6ring at tho rifle bntts, on the north side, on Saturday afternoon, at half-past two o'clock. Thirty six members mustered at the Drill Shed in uniform, but In consequence of that building having been lent to Mr. Cribb, for the usc of the newly arrived immi grants, the men wore marched tc Captain Melbourne's office, where the ammuni- tion was served out under the supervision ol that officer. Ou arriving at the targets twenty rounds were fired at 200 and 300 yards. Both targets were used, and firing was kept up without intermission until sundown, Lieutenant Robinson bciug thc officer in charge. Some really creditable scores were made by a few of thc young members, and should these recruits practice assiduously they will no doubt develop into expert marksmcu, The shooting having concluded the men marched back to town in good order, apparently well pleased with their afternoon's outing.

THU remainder of thc immigrants by the Ravcnscrag, excepting thoso placed in quaran- tine, arrived in town on Saturday. Tho large number of married couples has rendered it necessary for the siugle men to sleep iu thc Drill Shed, while the young women's quarter: arc occupied by some of the married couples. Thc usc of thc Drill Shed was granted by Captaiu Melbourne, the officer coiniuauding tho Volunteers, on tho application of the Immigration Agent. Captain Melbourne caused the room to be lighted with gas on Saturday night, and under the direction of than officer and other gentlemen, un impromptu entertainment was got up among the immi grauts, some of whom proved themselves experts at dancing, while others delighted thc bearers in thc they sang several excellent songs. Tho evening was made all tho merrier by tho distribution nf small motley prizes to the successful competitors in certain classée nf amusement. Altogether a very enjoyable cvuuing was spent. Tho young men appear lo bc a very fine lut of fellows. About forty met with engagements on Satur- day at from 20s. to 25s. a week, with rations. A lariçc number of thc Bingle women have also yfouiul employment, some in town and somo in

the cnuutry. Six have becu engaged for one inland town, at 15s. a week each, and those in t'lwu will receive from 10s. to 12s. a week. None of tho married couples have yet met with engagements.

A sad accident was reported to Senior- Sergeant Graham on Saturday morning at two o'clock, by a Pole named Marcus Tarnetski, who is a bailiff on Mr. Patrick Galvin' selec- tion, at the fifteen-mile cattle station, Port Curtis Road. It appears that at about seven o'clock on Friday evening a man named Victor Mischka, about twenty-three years of age, was endeavouring to split a log of timber with dynamite, which he placed on the top of the log, and built in with clay. He then set fire to it with a match, but it exploded, striking him in the eyes, face, and chest. The unfortunate fellow ran about thirty yards, shouting the while, and then fell to the ground. His mate went to his assistance, and with some water bathed his face. Mischka at the time was bleeding from the eyes, mouth, and chest. Tarnetski thought it best to bring him to the hospital here. He placed the sufferer in his cart, and, in company with his wife, started, but when about four miles from town Mischka expired. The body was taken to the dead-house at the Hospital where it was examined by Dr. Callahan and Dr. Thurston, the first-named giving a certificate to the effect that death was caused by a shock to the system induced by the firing of some explosive substance near the body. The Police Magistrate gave an order

for burial.

AK eclipsa of the moon was visible bera last night to the naked eye. Being Soe and clear the sight was observed by a good many people. The first oontaot with tho shadow toole place at 915 p.m., tho middle of the eclipse at 9 51 p.m., and the last contact with the shadow at 10 26 p.m.

A CABMAN named James Saunders* was arrested on Saturday night shortly after nine o'clock on a charge of drunkenness and furious driving. It appoars ho indulged in tho last named practice much to the danger of .the crowds who thronged the streets on Saturday night. He succeeded in running over an un- fortunate Chinaman, who, however, escaped with but slight injury. Several other pedes- trians narrowly escaped a similar accident.

AT St. Paul's Church yesterday afternoon, the Rev. W. A. Higgens presented Mr. A. J. Richardson, late superintendent of the Sunday School, with a guld chain in recognition of his

services io that capacity during a long period. 1 The rev. gentleman paid a fitting compliment to tho recipient by referring to the energy with which ho had entered into all work con ?

nccted with tho school. The gift was acknow- ledged by Mr, Richardson, who thanked the donors and also Mr. Diggens for the way in which ho had referred to his services in con- nection with the school. During last week a vory handsome Bible was presented to Mrs. R, Skuthorpe, who has also left the Sunday School, as a mark of the esteem in which she was held by the teachers and scholars.

A fire broke out on Friday morning in a house at Radford, near Nottingham, and two women and three children wcro burned to

death.

John Goode, formerly a captain in tho 10th Hussars, who was conviuccd of an assault cu tho Queen in 1837, but who being found to be insane bas since then been confined in a lunatic asylum, died a few days ago.

"General" Booth, of thc Salvation Army, had an interview ou Monday with Earl Granville on thc subject of tho expulsion of Miss RootU and Miss Charlesworth from

Geneva.

The steamer Buenos Ayrean, from Havre for Glasgow, on Tuesday ran into and Bank tho steamer Strathdee, off the island of Arran. The captain and ton of tho crew of the Strath dec were drowned, ono man only being saved.

A young mau named James Smith was con- victed at Edinburgh on Monday of killing a gamekeeper ou Lord Stair's estate, near Girvan. The prisoner was sentenced to

(loath.

James Anderson was hanged on Monday in Lincoln Gaol, having been convicted of thc murder of his wife at Eastferry, near Gains- borough.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1883.

articleText:
ADVANCE BOOKHAMPTON.

TO TUB EDITOR OP THE MORNING BULLETIN. 1

SIR,-It gave me much pleasure ta read Mr. Tcnison-Wood's letter io your paper (of thia morning, because it affords another proof of what I have before pointed out, that Bock, hampton as the outlet of the Central Districts, has a position unequalled by any other town in the colony, and given capital to develop her immense resources, sheraust inevitably become the premier town ; for the anomalous situation of Brisbane, being as it were in a comer and remote from all other parts of the colony, condemns her to an early fall from the proud eminence she now enjoys, But let me enume- rate the great Bourccs of wealth and com- merce which surrounds Rockhampton, and which, sooner or later, will force her into the position of the wealthiest and most populous city in Queensland -.

1st. IVe have a harbour of refuge, which can be entered in any weather by the largest ships or steamers afloat sailing from any direction ships can come from. 2nd. We have a river which can be made navigable for the largest vessels. 3rd. We have a great pastoral back country producing wool and beef in abundance. 4th. We have a complete circle of auriferous reefs that are proved to be highly payable. 6th. Extensive alluvial auriferous deposits which are also proved to be payable. 6th. We have many thousands of acres of rich Buger land. AU these known sources of wealth remain, comparatively speaking, un- tapped.

Last, though not least, we have, if Mr. Tenison-Wood is correct in interpreting the testimony of the rock, vast and rich coal deposits of the best description. Mr. Wood expresses his opinion that " the advantage of a sufficient local supply are BO manifest that it must stimulate enterprise sufficiently to reveal some of the many rich seams which the district undoubtedly possesses." In conclusion he says that " when thia is accomplished the cheap working of the line will be accompanied by a great stride in the commercial prosperity of the oentral districts of Queensland. Well, sir, as to the stimulating effeota of Mr. Tenison-Wood's letter I hare my doubts, as the people of Rockhampton take a deal of stimulating before they are capable of action. Their apathy is something marvellous, and they seem to he totally incapable of turning their grand position toacoount.

But the cause of this insensibility to their own interests is not far to seek. Rock- hampton for many years has been in the garotting grip of the so-called Liberal party, which has paralysed alt her energies, and she has been handed over by that bigottcd party a helpless vietim to the selfishness of Queen street politicians.

Under the M'llwraith Ministry «110 bas shown symptoms of reviving lifo. Such stimulants as the three million loan, and the mail contract have had a wonderful effect, and hare enabled her to struggle to release herself from this terrible grip. The election of Mr. Ferguson two years ago was the first sign of returning life, and the defeat of Mr. Paterson in the late eleotion still further loosened the grip upon her throat.

But to return to Mr. Wood's letter. He proposes the diamond drill, and indicates where it should he used to prove the accuracy of his scientific knowledge. Now, the dia- mond drill was made a great point of in the addresses during the election by both our members, and it ie to bs hoped that Mr. Wood's letter will stimulate them to procure from the Government this necessary machine to quickly bring to light the great sou roe of wealth and prosperity that lie hidden beneath the stratified rocks.

But why wait for the slow process of Government, and why should not the mer- chants aud capitalists of Rockhampton put their own shoulders to the wheel, and form a Diamond Drill Company, and proceed at once to action. Surely, under the Mineral Lands Act, they could secure to themselves any discoveries they might bring to light. Yet, perhaps, they arc afflicted with the com- munist mania-that the Government should have everything, be everything, and do every- thing, to the total extinction of all private enterprise. Carry ont the assigned reasons for this supposed proper function of Govern- ment to their logical issue (that is-if it pays companies to construct railways, &c, why should not the Government do it instead and

reap the profitB) we shall soon have the Government oar sole bankers, butchers, bakers, and barbers, fcc., which state of things I think most people would denounce as preposterously absurd.

I am, &c,

ANTI.HCHBUO.

Rockhampton, September 3, 1883.
heading: ADVANCE ROCKHAMPTON. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1883.

THE destruction by fire of the Fitzroy Meat Preserving Works, Lake's Creek, the property of the Central Queensland Meat Export Company, at an early hour yesterday morning, is a calamity of which it is impossible for us to estimate the magnitude. It is a catastrophe of national interest und importance, and

the influence of which will be felt not

only in this colony, but in commercial circles in the United Kingdom and continent of Europe. The Lake's Creek Works had come to be regarded as the most complete of thc kind in Australia, il not, indeed, in the world. At the expenditure of a large amount of capital, and by the application of technical knowledge, gained by long experience and observation, they had been placed in

a state of increased efficiency, not only j for the purpose of carrying on the meat preserving business, but for entering on

the Frozen Meat Trade. Shortly after ] midnight on Thursday morning the cry of fire was raised at the works, and at daybreak the long range of worskshops was a mass of smoking ruins. In accordance with the practice he had fol- lowed on former occasions the watch- man of the works had gone at an early hour on Thursday morning, and kindled the fire under a vat or boiler ia which fat had to be melted. Having done so he went about his other duties, anticipating that the vat would be attended to

by the workman whose business it was lo look after it. By some accident the fat became overheated, overflowed the vessels in which il was contained, caught fire, and flowed in a stream of

flame along the concrete floor of the building. The flames quickly caught the timber weatherboards composing the sides ol the building, and these being extremely dry and more or less smeared with grease, fell a ready prey to the devouring element. One who was present, and witnessed thc progress of the conflagration, s.iys the fire licked up the houses as if they had been a sheet of paper. Vile long range of shops whicli stood parallel to the river became a mass of fire. A small portion of their contents were saved, but only amid danger and risk.

Upon a rough calculation the Direc-

tors have estimated the value of the j propetty destroyed at about thirty thou

sand pounds. One half of that will be covered by insurance, but the remaining half will fall upon the company. Largt as is this loss it constitutes but one element in the misfortune, the magnitude of which arises from the effect the stop- page of the works will have on the rising meat trade of the colony; on the pastoral interests of this district ; on the leading local industry of this locality ; and on the trade of the town.

With regard to the first the occurrence is particularly unfortunate. After many years of anxious endeavour to gain that place for our preserved meals in the markets of Europe to which they are entitled, they were beginning to command a more ready and extensive sale. A great impetus has been given to the trade by the receipt of a large

order from the French Government. It

had been satisfactorily executed, the last cases being those on board the Ranelagh when she sank in the river last week. Possibly a new contract might have been entered into had the Company been able to fulfil it. In the meantime they will not be in a position to accept any large orders for at least six months to come. Then, again, the trade with Batavia, to which other than the directors of this company have been looking forward with many hopeful ex- pectations, will be nipped in the bud. The Fiado, had been chartered by the E. and A. Fresh Meat Company of Melbourne, to take 2400 quarters of frozen beef from the works to Singapore ; about three fourths of the quantity was ready for her ; but she was nearly a fort- night behind time, and only arrived here yesterday morning-too late to receive the cargo prepared for her. Orders for preserved meals for home consumption, and supplies for agents in London and elsewhere will necessarily be interrupted :

and for a time the meat trade of the colony will be practically suspended.

This circumstance will not fail to tell on

it in future, and considerable efforts may be required to raise itto the same degree of prosperity.

On the cattle trade of the district the cessation of the steady certain demand for fat stock will also have a consider-

able influence. A gentleman intimately and practically connected with the trade calculates that the Lake's Creek works have heen the means, while in active operation, of raising the price of cattle in this district to tire extent of ten shil a head on the average. As illustrative of the transactions in which the Com- pany engaged, we may mention that Mr. William Pattison was under con- tract to supply them with upwards of 2500 head. Nearly the whole of these had been delivered. The turn-

over of capital in the course of a season, we have it on good authority, amounts to two hundred thousand pounds. For- tunately the loss in this connection will not be great, as the supply of fat cattle in the district has been well nigh ex- hausted, and the state of the country will prevent those at a distance from travelling. Before stock are again in the market there is a prospect, we are glad to learn, that the Works will be in full working order.

In this town the greatest sympathy will be felt for the operatives and others employed at the works. By their suspension upwards of two hundred

bread-winners will be thrown out of employment. Many of them have been long engaged in the establishment, and while acquiring skill and facility in the performance of special duties required

of them have become unfitted lo some

extent for other pursuits. They cannot, therefore, turn their hands readily to such other work as may be available for them. Then there was a large staff of tinsmiths, including a contingent who recently arrived from Scotland under special agreement. Their occupation is in the meantime gone. The wages-bill of the works ranged from j£soa t0 £%5°

a week.

As the greater portion of the sum we have just mentioned was spent in Rock- hampton it is evident the effect of the suspension of the industry on the retail

trade of this town will be consider- able. For a time at least the absence of Lake's Creek customers will effect the weekly drawings of most of our shop- keepers.

With very great satisfaction the public

will learn that the directors of the

Company have not been completely overwhelmed by the disaster. They take a hopeful view of the situation, and have resolved on a course of action creditable alike to their intelligence and public spirit. At a meeting held yester- day afternoon they resolved to call up all the funds they can, to issue new stock,

and lo make an effort to have the works

going again in six-months. It is to be hoped that all who have the means at their command will aid them in carrying out this resolution, so that the town and district will soon recover from the effects of this sudden public disaster.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1883.
snippet: THE destruction by fire of the Fitzroy Meat Preserving Works, Lake's Creek, the property of the Central Queensland Meat Export Company, at an early hour

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1883.

THE'last quarterly statement that will be issued by Mr. Archer, as the Treasurer of the present Ministry, vf as published in the Gazette last week. It affords a striking contrast, indeed, to their first quarterly statement, which showed a fast accumulating expenditure and a failing revenue, and which was issued at a time when the colony was in the depths of a depression. We are not among those blind supporters of the present Govern- ment who think that they restored the condition of the public finances as by a magician's wand. We admit that the stagnant period of 1.874-9 was in a great

measure due to other causes than in- efficient administration. But we do con- tend that the difficulties of the situation were aggravated by the incapacity of the then Government. In 1874 the session was marked by a perfectly needless and entirely mischievous alteration of the tariff, and by an attempt to resume an area of land altogether in excess of the demand for bona fide settlement. In 1875 the timidity of the Government in the matter of borrowing induced them to pass the Western Railway Act, under

which it was intended to carry out the south-western line from Dalby to Roma, and, as the Central line could not possibly be continued on the same prin- ciple, to provide an excuse for discon- tinuing its extension altogether. In 1S76 the Macalister Ministry broke up througli internal dissension, and the country was precipitated to the depth of humiliation by the appointment of the Thorn Ministry, while confidence was seriously shaken by the Settled Districts Leases Act, the Railway Reserves Act, and the six-in-a-block scheme of railways. In 1877 the spectacle of a colony governed by a " nominal Premier " was continued, and universal distrust resulted from the dread of further heroic legislation by a Ministry whose sole hope of retaining power by in their ability to dazzle the popular imagination and to set class against class. In 1S78 the country was governed by the Opposition, who emas- culated the great measure of the session -the Redistribution of Electorates Bill -compelled the Ministry to pass the Local Government Lill, and showed their power by voting ,£44,000 for roads and bridges in the teeth of the Government, whose duty it was to pro- tect thc Treasury. And that Govern- ment consented to retain office for six months after they had been shown their utter powerlessness to guide thc Legisla- ture. All these events undoubtedly con- tributed to the destruction of public confidence, and discouraged capitalists from engaging in new industrial enter- prises.

It wa=; in this state of r.ffjirs that the M'llwraiih Ministry took office, and courageously f.iced the public odium attendant upon ,i policy of retrenchment. They made some mistakes in enforcing this policy, one of these being the sum- mary dismissal of over 100 men fruin the Ipswich workshops. This and

many other stern lessons in economy I produced great discomfurt at first, but the session of 1S79 did much to

re-eslablish public confidence. It proved that thc colony was no longer ruled by a ministry of expediency, but liv men who had well-defined opinions, the courage of their convictions, and the determination to legislate and administer for the benefit of the colony rather than lo appease public clamour. They entered upon their second year with slightly more encouraging prospects, and by its close they had the satisfaction of

demonstrating that distrust had been, displaced by confidence, and adversity by prosperity. Since then progress has continued to an unprecedented extent,

until in the transactions of the two years; which closed on 30th June last the combined surpluses had amounted to ¿¿558.00o. As in the two preceding years the deficits had amounted - to two thirds of that sum the change that had occurred was almost unparalleled ; and,, we repeat, although not entirely due to good Government was largely assisted by that very substantial boon.

But the Ministry has outlived its use- fulness-at least that is the verdict just given by the constituencies-and the time has come when they must, for a period at least, give*place to other men. The Liberal Patty led by Mr. Griffith has been purged of its contempt by a five years' residence in the cold shade ; and the general hope is that they will have so far profitted by the discipline they have undergone as to be worthy of again sitting on the Treasury Benches. For ourselves, however, we cannot con- fess to much confidence in the Coming Men. They have done so badly in Opposition that we can scarcely expect to find them do well in power. Mr. Griffith

excepted, there is not a competent debater in the party. Pollysyllabti Mr. Dickson has not the ear of the House ; ranting Mr. Rutledge has the ear but not the understanding or sympathy ; venomous Mr. Miles' oratory is inarticu- late and largely composed of wise shakings of (he head ; gurrilous Mr. Groom so habitually draws the long

bow as to be the victim of incredulous audiences ; while such geniuses of disorder as Brookes, Isambert, and Kellet, can be no help to any political party. The country, we are sure, has no faith in these men, and were not Mr. Griffith an unquestioned lawyer of mark, his party would be utterly devoid of governing qualifications. We must, however await events, only trusting that the feebleness and menaacity of the last Liberal administration will not be re- peated in the Ministry about to be

constituted.

But to our muttons. The gross revenue for the quarter has been over ,£700,000 or at the rate of .£2,800,000 per annum. The expenditure has been ,£407,000, or at the rate of over ,£1,600,000 per annum. Including thc loan and special disbursements the outlay for the quarter was ,£875,000,

or over three and a half millions

sterling a year. This for a popula- tion not exceeding 270,000 souls is certainly astounding. The revenue balance to credit in the Treasury on 30th September was .£013,500, or, charaicß it.Äith ^7rfíq-,uuc/"- thc amount of one quarter's interest which has ac- crued on the public debt-a net balance of ¿4S3i500- With such a surplus the Ministry ought to be able to relin- quish office with satisfaction and pride.

The prosperity of the colony is plainly evidenced by the elasticity of taxation revenue ; by the large augmentation in pastoral rents ; by the very considerable increase of postal and telegraphic receipts ; and by the rapidly accumula- ting earnings of the various railways. On

the Northern line the increase on the corresponding quarter of 1882 was over ,£16,000, and on the Central line, despite the bad season, nearly ,£4000. The Maryborough line shows an increase of nearly 50 per cent, while the Northern line receipts have nearly doubled. Having achieved so much in their five years' term, Ministers may well retire to rest and be thankful for a while.
heading: The Morning bulletin ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1883.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1883.

TBE WEER.,

Tuonan Parliament will not meet again till the 10th January, and Ministers are not ex eluded from sitting in the Cabinet by reason of want of seats, the Government have given their opponents little time to hnng forward candidates to contest the seats with Ministers As it IB, nearly all the Ministers have been elected The Hon Mr Griffith was nomi nated on the 17th, and elected on the 20th, his opponent, Mr Raven, receiving very little support The members for Darling Downs Kennedy, and Moreton have been returned without opposition They are all men of political experience, and were returned as Liberals ft is quite different with Hon Mr Dutton, who has not yet been nominated

articleText:
KOCKUAMl'TON.

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1883.

AMONG the greatest obstacles to progress of lliis colony have been the want of labour, and the utilisation of facilities for its distribution. In the early days of the colony, when the convict system was still in operation, free emigrants were im- ported, and landed at Brisbane; but their ultimate disposal being controlled by the Government at Brisbane many of them were conveyed to the southern parts ot the colony. The practice then inaugurated, of subtracting Queensland emigrants, has continued, and within the last few weeks has again attracted pro- minent attention. How far the reports which have been raised are true, and the agitation which has been based on them is warranted, we arc not in the position accurately to determine. Of this, how- ever, we have plain evidence on the surface, that the former have been exag- gerated, and thc latter fostered for political purposes. There has always been a considerable amount of intercourse between this colony and New South Wales. It must be difficult to determine the number of persons who leave for good, and of those who come here to take up their residence. From the Statistics of the Colony, we learn that the number of persons who arrived at the various ports in the colony in 1882 was 27,000, or 17,043 mote than left the ports. The number who left was 9957, and 7307 persons went to New'Souih Wales. But there arrived, within thc same period, from the older colony 9552. It thus appears that from the adjacent country as many people came to Queensland as left it for all countries. The balance of intercourse is thus seen to have been greatly in favour of this colony. Recently the cry has been raised that there was a great exodus of newly-arrived immigrants going on ; that they were crowding

over the border of New South

Wales, near Stanthorpe ; and swell- ing the passenger traffic on board the coasting steamers. Notwithstanding the amount of writing that has taken place on the subject, there is nothing to show that the departures have been greater than usual, or that they are out of proportion to the number of persons, who have recently arrived in the colony. It always has been the case that people came here under our free emigration system, with the object ol levanting at the first opportunity to ¡oin their friends in New South Wales. The fact has been well known, and has formed the subject of comment in Parliament. When tliî last Immigration Bill was under discussion clauses were inserted, imposing severe penalties 0/1 persons, who, having come out assisted under our Immigration system, should, within a certain period, attempt lo leave the colony. These clauses were modified by the Iben Leader of the Opposition,

but it was thought they were still suffi- ciently stringent to restrain those who came here only lo leave for

the adjacent colonies. It is a signifi- j cant fid that no attempt has | been made by the Government to enforce thc penal provisions of the statute. When thc outcry was raised about the departuies of immigrants, an official in (he Immigration Department in- stituted an action against a man named Macartney for violating the law, but the ca*e was withdrawn, as it had not been sanctioned by the Colonial Secretary. No prosecutions have been ordered, and the public have been left somewhat at a loss how lo interpret the state of affairs. Klher the penal clauses of the Immi- gration Act are of no avail in checking the departure of our new chums, or the number is not nearly so great as has been

reported, or the number of persons corning from Sydney is equal to that of those departing.

What is greatly to be deplored in connection with the recent agitation in Brisbane was its party character. The actual agents in it were the unwitting tools of political wire pullers. Imme- diately upon the accession of the present Government to office, and when the public were on the gui rive as to the revelations that might be expected in fulfilment of promises made, the press organ of the Queen-street party came out with a shrieking paragraph about the way in which money was being squan- dered on immigration. There happened to be a glut of men at the Immigration Depot at the time. Some of these men, and idlers, who are always ready to raise their voices when the question of wages is concerned, took up the cry o too much labour. It is always agreeable to the latter, when they can earn. as much money in a few days as will enable

them to loaf about the rest of the week.

They are of the same mind as the wharf lumpers at Sydney, wbo would like to see immigration stopped, though the whole of the inland districts should be starving for labour. Among these dis- contented people the flame lit by the Liberal organ burnt freely, and was cleverly fanned. A députa

lion to the Governor was orga-, nised, but he referred those who wished to wait upon him to the Immigration Board, by whom they were softened with promises of work from the Government. With this they seemed to be quite satisfied, and no more com- plaints were heard. That the latter

were such as are common to new

chums on their arrival in this colony has become obvious. Single men and girls have been rapidly absorbed in the population. Orders for men to go out west have since been sent to Brisbane, which it is found impossible to fulfil. Men with large families will not go out into the country, nor will mechanics.

Whether these people or the Immigration i Agents are most to blame is an open question. In the meantime the rapid

relief the labour market has received, ' since the agitation arose, shows that it was to a large extent artificial. This effort to secure political capital by pandering to a class, docs not reflect credit on the Liberal Press, which has been rather too keen in this instance.
heading: The Morning Bulletin. ROCKHAMPTON. WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1883.

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE.

SABBATH OBSEBVANCE.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIR-From tho frequency, with which the 8abbath ie desecrated, by persona amusing themselves by shooting in the vicinity of Rockhampton on 8undays, one would imagine there was no law on the subject, or that the police are very remiss in not bringing the offenders to justice. Thu, practice is not only unseemly on the Sabbath day, but positively dangerous to those who wish to take a quiet -walk and enjoy a breath of fresh air. In that much frequented place of resort North Rock- hampton shots may be often heard, and branches cut off by them, so near as to make it anything but comfortable to the passer by and yet those who are paid for preventing breaches of the law, seem to be both deaf and blind to the matter. Other localities are

nearly as bad, but this is more dangerous because of the greater traffic.

For the sake of our townspeople who like to enjoy a quiet walk thero, I will make an extract from an Aot passed in New South Wales before separation, and still in force in Queensland and I trust the police will act on it, and put a stop to the practice. It is the 6th Victoria No. Ö, intituled " an Act to pre- vent shooting for pleasure, sport, or profit on Sundays." Following the preamble it says : " After the passing and publication of this Act, any person who shall be found engaged in shooting at any pigeon match, or for pleasure, sport, or profit of any kind what- soever, on Sunday, or who shall be found carrying firearms on that day, except os hereinafter provided, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor ; and, on conviction, before any justice of the peace, shall forfeit and pay a penalty or sum of not more than five pounds, nor less than forty shillings; and it shall be lawful for any constable without any warrant or other authority than this Act to arrest any person whoaball be found shooting or carrying firearms, contrary to the provisions hereof, and such person to be carried with all convenient despatch before a justice of the peace, to be dealt with according tc law."

ClauBe 2 exempts those who carry firearms for the protection of life and property, and constables and others who carry them for

lawful purposes. ,

By inserting the above you will oblige,

CITIZEN.
heading: CORRESPONDENCE. SABBATH OBSEBVANCE. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

articleText:
ROCK I IA MITON.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1883.

FROM a remark made by Mr. Ferguson the other day, at a meeting of the Cham- ber of Commerce, we are very glad to find he is of opinion the time cannot be far distant when the management of our harbour affairs must be placed in the hands of local trustees. This opinion, we know, is held by the Chairman of the Divisional Board, and it will, we doubt not, be adopted by all who recog- nise the advantages of local government. Sir Thomas Mcilwraith, when discussing the Port Ainu Railway Question, stated plainly that it would require to be con- structed by private parties, because it would be vain to ask Parliament to do so, and at same time carry on the river works : and if we urgently demanded the former wc must abandon (he latter. Indeed, he hinted that the latter must be suspended, because there were not funds io cirry them on promptly. The works on the Fitzroy River have been regarded as unremuneralive, and hence the difficulty about completing them. At that time it does not seem lo have occurred to the Premier that an organisa- tion might be created which should be able, with a lillie assistance, to Telieve tho central authority of all trouble and responsibility with regard to our har- bour. Al present thc Harbours Dop.nl nient of liie Government is not popular. It seems to be over-burdened with work, and hampered by officialism. The Fitzroy River, for more than a year, has been completely neglected. The old dredger was employed, and s steady clïort mule to cut a ship channel through the Upper Flats. Just when the latter work had been completed, and

there was a prospect ol the channel being greatly improved by a little cutting at the crossings, the dredger was with- drawn, and the shallow sandy bars ate allowed to remain, to the obstruction of all navigation. The growing increase of traffic on the river, proves the necessity for the improvement of the navigation, yet our merchants and shippers, who are immediately and deeply interested can do nothing to mend matters.

Then again, our swelling trade has led to a demand being made for enlarged wharfage accommodation. It has been proposed that a floating wharf should be constructed, so as to be available at all states of the tide, and by sea-going vessels. An extension of the existing wharves has also been suggested, with the object of giving accommodation to shipping, and protecting the river bank. The Chamber of Commerce including our leading commercial men, see the necessity for these improvements, but all they can do in the matter is to go to the Town Council, hat in hand, and respectfully solicit the Corporation to undertake the new works. If our Muni- cipal authorities treat the subject as they have done the Baths Question, it may be a very long time before the wishes of the parties interested are attended to. The Council must calculate whether the works will pay-whether they will yield a revenue, not only sufficient to meet the interest on the outlay for the works, but give a profit to the corporation. We have thus the curious spectacle of the merchants and ship-owners, who are directly interested in the maintenance of the river navigation, and ample wharfage accommodation, impeded, on the one hand by the laxity and carelessness of thc Government and their officials, and on the other by the dilatoriness and money-making spirit of the Town Council. The crutches on which com- merce depends are both unreliable.

In these circumstances the desirability of forming a Harbour Trust, to take charge of all matters connected with the shipping interests, seems obvious. There cannot be the least doubt, we think, that if the maintenance of the River Works had been dependent on the will of the commercial men, shipowners, and steamship agents they would not have been neglected as they have been during the last few years. If we want a guarantee that the present system of neglect shall not prevail in future, we must have a local harbour trust. Brisbane River is under the eye of the Government, lt may be regarded as under their personal supervision, and malters there have gone on smoothly. The mail steamers can now be taken up to the town. If ever deep-sea steamers are to come up to our wharves, our merchants and shipowners must have the power of controlling harbour affairs. It wilt not do to have the river works neglected, or attended to just as may suit the interests of poli- ticians. The well-being of this com- munity, and, indeed, of the whole Central Division, depends upon our having ample and convenient shipping facilities, and these ought not to be made or marred to suit party purposes. So long as the present system of harbour management - or mismanagement - remains, we have no protection that this will not be the case. From the past, we have no reason to form any pleasant anticipations of the future.

A Harbour Trust, composed as it should be of persons representative of the interests involved, would, be eminently practical and useful. It should include members representative of the shipping and commercial in- terests ; of the Town Council, as curators of the Municpal property, of the Divisional Board, as protectors of the northern bank of the river ; and one or two representatives of the Govern- ment, in the event of the Treasury con- tributing to the funds of the Trust. By such a board the interests of all parties would be carefully and immediately attended to. If wharfage accom- modation were required the neces- sity for it would be most apparent to the members, and they would allow no trifling obstacles or considerations to interfere with the providing of it. As they would be rated according to the amount of outlay at any time they would be very careful not to incur needless expenditure in any quarter. They would be less liable to squander funds than Government officials.

?It will be argued that the rates de- rived from the river and wharves would would not be sufficient to carry out the necessary works ; and that to complete Mr. Nesbit's scheme of river improve- ment would require all the funds that could be raised by a Hir bour Trust. There is no doubt the completion of these works would require a large expenditure, but it is not neces- sary that it should be made all at once. The Harbour Trust would have a large and steady revenue from tonnage and wharfage rates. For a lime thc Govern- ment could -supplement the local rates, as il does those of municipalities and divi- sional boards. There is at present an unexpended vote of about twenty-six thousand pounds for the Fitzroy River works ; and thc S.iui ian, which is now at work in thc Mary River, has been built for thc Fitzroy. Were the Government to hand over these to a Harbour Trust, and endow it with reasonable powers of assessment, a corporation might be created that would be of the greatest public service. It would relieve the Government of works, with which, wc think, it is apparent they cannot deal very satisfactorily. Their past manage- ment, at least, has been far from success- ful. A Harbour Trust, moreover, composed of local men : holding its deliberations in this town ; exposed to the criticism and comments of the com- munity ; and responsible to the consti- tuency for its actions would be a living, active organisation ; and not a dull inert mass,-unapproachable, difficult to move, like that under which our harbour affairs are placed at present.

IT will be remeirjlieruil that a few issues since wo notified that certain " foreigners " [ who had been paying thiB oity a professional

visit, circulated some valueless cheques before leaving, and warrants bad been taken ont for their arrest. Sinoe euch warrants have been signed, nothing baa been apparently done to bring the oulprits to justice. We have been informed that on tho warrants being aent to the port at which the men landed who bad attempted to defraud oar tradesmen, the money, for the payment of which the cheques bod been drawn, waa paid, and thus execution al the warrants stopped. This may

bo perfectly correct, but it is tho first instance that has come under our notice of such a method of proceeding. When the cheques were drawn to which we allude, the mau who signed them cither knew that at the time they were so drawn, they were or were not good, and valid orders for the payment of money, and upon this issue bo should have been tried. Tho fact of his willingness to pay the money when aoutronted with a warrant, does not dis- prove his intent to defraud at the time he drew ont the orders, and if be know that such orders would bo dishonoured, or if there was reason- able evidence to show that he must bave known they were valueless, the law assumes inteut. It seems to us he was guilty of a crime, and should have been brought before his country. - If anyone cm throw light upon the subject we shall esteem it a favour, for when when we remember in the case of a lad tried at last sessions for forgery-or rather altering an order for .the payment of money

with inteut tn defraud-the accused tendered repayment nf the amount he bad come by dishonestly, and was yet tried, committed, then pleaded guilty and was sentenced. We are at a loss as to whether or not in theoase

of the illustrious foreigners, a felony has been compounded.

DÜRING tbe debate before the Royal Colonial Institute on the paper read by Sir

Francis Dillon Bell on the Indebtedness of tho Colonies, there appeared on the part of a large majority of thc speakers a desire, not so much to arrive at a fair unbiassed decision on the matter, as to represent the colonies being justified in continuing borrowing. The sole object of the speakers seemed to be to prove this, not to test the subject, and when most of the speakers aro remembered to be men who are largely iutcrosted in maintaining the credit of the colonies, while others are immediately iuterested in the profits accruing from the suc- cessful floating of the loans at present under proposal, it will be understood that all their glowing panegyrics os to Australia's boundless wealth, and almost incalculable assets, must be taken for what they are worth. It was also a noticeable feature of the debato that the only speakers who questioned thc correctness of Sir Francis' calculations, were greeted with interruptions, and not acoorded a fair and impartial hearing. One of, perhaps, tho most remarkable suggestions fell from the lips of Mr. Strangways, who pointed out that when tho colonies had no debts they had no friends. This wss hinting at the advisability of getting into debt to gain the interest and friendship of the creditors. If the dove were to flutter in tho vicinity of an eagle, tho said eagle would doubtless take an interest in it. If that is the sort of interest England takos in tho colonies, it means that her capitalists Want ta strangle our prosperity, and retard our progress, by having us in the handy position of being able to put the screw on at any time. Look at the idea from an individual standpoint, and let us suppose that a progressive young man in Queensland, wishing to obtain a uumber of friends, got over bead and cars ia debt : would there be many people found lOBt in admiration at bis far-seeing and noble policy Î Yet this pernicious principle is actually advocated in International policy. Mr. Strangways, how- ever, struck a very tuneful chord, when he said it was significant that the consideration of tho wealth of the colonies had been brought before the Institute at a time when large loans were being put in the English money market. It was significant, but surely the members of the Institute did it unwittingly-surely they bad no interest in proclaiming Australia's wealth. We know this is an age of diem terostcd patriotism, and so uiuBt consider that the remarkable coincidence to which Mr. Strangways drew attention was quite acci-

dental.

TUE weather during yesterday was quite « change to what has boen experienced lately, the sky was cloudy and soveral heavy showers fell. Early yesterday morning, before day- light, a trcmcudous shower fell, one of the hoaviest that has been experienced for some time past. The rain appears to have beon pretty general throughout tho district.

TO-DAY is the last day for receiving tbe voting papers of the electors of No. 1 Sub- division of the Gogango Divisional Board, and all must bo in the hands of tho Returning Officer (Mr. Pattison) by four o'clock in the afternoon. The candidates are Mr. T. Dempsey, of Gracemere, and Mr. T. H. Hobler, of Westwood.

Tua twentieth monthly meeting of No. 9 Building Society was held in the Secretary's (Mr. R. L. Ditjdin) office last night. Messrs. J. Wakefield and D. Wiley presided as direc- tors. The subscriptions and interest received amounted to £146 3s. Od. Four advance

shares were sold at an advance of ten per

cent.

A CONSIGNMENT of ginger ale was sont to Bnsbáno yesterday in the Derwent, to tho order of a woll-known hotolkeepor, who is desirous of ascertaining whether the cordial which has found favour in Rockhampton will suit the [esthetic taste of the Brisbanites. The consignors and manufacturers are Messrs. Johnson and Whitehouse, who* aro to be con- gratulated that their renowned ginger ale is so much Bought after both at home and

abroad.

Of all the dreadful cases of chronic drunkounesB, the one that caine under notice in Blackall, Thursday, February 1, is ooo of the most deplorable. It would seem that a man named Wodge had been staying for a lengthened period at a public house called thc Douglas L'ouds Hotel, kept by auutlicr man named IVinliini. This hotel had originally been owned by Wedge, who.had sold it to Tom kins, part of tho payinuut being made by bills nf £50 each, which matured from time to time. During ten weeli s £129 4s. Gd. worth of grog was supplied by Tomkius to Wedge, and Wcdgo tmvitlg no cash, tho amount was debited to bim, apparently with thc intention of deducting it from the amounts of the various promissory tintes as they fell due. The follow ing is a list of thc value ol liquor supplied daily to Wedge:-On November 19 to grog, &c, amounting to £1 5s.; 20th. £1 15s.; 2lst, £1 5s.; 22nd, £1 3s.; 23rd. £1 fls.; 24th, ISs.; 25th, £1 ; 2fitb, £1 ls.; 27th, Cl ls.; 28th, £3 17s. 01.; 29th, £1 lils.; 30th, £2 11s.; December I, £1 19s.; 2nd. 12s: .Sr.!, 14s.; 4th, £1 3s.; 5th, 13s ; Cth, ISs.; 7th, Cl 9s.
