After having imbibed this quantity of spirits &c, it is not surprising that tho man died, mir is the nio.ltc.il evidence extraordinary that affirms the cause of death was -" excessive use of anlent spirits." The publican never called in medical aid, though Um wretched nun wai in a frightfully emaciated condition, and taking no fnoil, nut the sichtest effort was made, as the evidence showed, to prevent his poisoning himself with drink or to en*

deavour to persuade him to take some aoudahmeot It may be a hint of Value to lome publicaría to tell them that when a man cannot keep food on hie stomach through excessive driuking, it is just os well to oatt ip medical aid.' To go on supplying drink to such persons, is to run the risk of a trial for

manslaughter,

THE Illustrated London News, received by the Inst mail, contains a portrait of Sir Thomas M'Ilwraitb, K.C.M.G., Premier of Queensland, and a Bhort biographical sketch

of his life.

HOME papers just received mention that Mr. Kennedy, his daughters Majory, Maggie, and Helen, and his son Robert, were jost completing a professional tour ia Scotland prior to leaving for Australia and New Zea- land. Mr. Kennedy is regarded as the best Íirofessional exponent of Scottish songs now

iving. Many in thia town have a lively recollection of his laBt visit, and will bo glad to see him back again.

TUE usual monthly sitting of the Licensing Court, convened for yesterday, fell through, as the only members of the Board who appeared were the Police Magistrate and Mr, W. Pattison, J. P. Probably if Mr. Kilner, a member of the Board, had been sent for the requisite number of members-three-to form a quorum, would have attended, and the business could have been proceeded with. AB it is the applicants for licenses are put to the inconvenience of waiting another month. We understand Mr. J. Brown, a member of the Board, waa unable to attend through pres- sure of business, and that;the present Mayor, an cx-oficio member, is dobarred from sitting, aa bo has an interest in the letting of a hotel to a tennant. The applicants' interests and Íiersonal convenience should surely receive a

ittle more consideration.

MR. GOEHEL and some of the ratepayers, whose lotter was submitted to the last meeting of Gogango Divisional Board, oalled upon us last Saturday to state that in their communi- cation they had no intention of dictating to, or interfering with, the freedom of the Board. At the same time they seemed anxious the

public should know that the road-gang bad been removed from a highway, and put to work on a side-road adjoining property belong- ing to Messrs. Pattison, Lucas, Atherton, and Macdonald, members of the Board, Upon inquiry vre Hod that the road party was sent to do some little work upon the road to Yeppoon, where tho gentlemen named havo allotments of land aud housos. The work occupied tho gang a short tithe, and tho men hive since been moved to erect a bridge at Limestone Creek, which was agreed upon six months ago; The work being done is on the road on which the gang were formerly engaged, and ia more urgent than any near the complainers1 selections, where the latter want them to be employed. The action of the Board, therefore, affords no room for reflection, and will meet with the appobation of the ratepayers generally.

Tn KKK is a Municipal Bye-law in this town compelling vohiules to carry side-lights at night, but this regulation is honoured in the broach rather thau in tho observance, for several nights past we have notioed spring-oarts without lights ; and on Sunday evening two foot-passengors came pretty near being run over by one at the corner of East and Fitz roy-streets, it having no light whatever. Other vehicles carry only one light, which is at times mystifying to drivers ooming in an opposite direction, sinee they are left in doubt as to which side to pass. While we were unearthing the bye-law relating to the lighting of vehicles we stumbled on the following:-"6. No per- son shall ia any street or publio place, blow any horn, ring any bell, or use any musical or other noisy instrument, for the purpose of calling people together, or of announcing any

show or entertainment to which admission is

obtained by ticket or payment, or for the pur- pose of hawking, selling, or distributing, or collecting any artiole whatsoever, or of obtain- ing inouey for nlins, or announcing any sale or auction, or public meeting, or any olhor pur- pose." Of course it will be apparent to the most oasual observor that this is almost daily violated by the bellman. If there is , one thing that tbe Town Council is peculiar

for, it is the neglect of its regulations.

THE usual monthly meeting of No. 8 Build- ing Society will be hold in the Secretary's (Mr. II. L. Dibdin) office to-night.

AITKNTION is drawn to tho salo by Mr. G. 8. Curtis of the cabin fittings ot tho immi- grant ship Melpomene.- The sate takes place at the wharf at eleven o'clock this morning.

ADMtNtSTEKINO DHUGS TO DotM AND PlOS. -The following ia the safest method of giving medicine to dogs in liquid form. Tic the mouth and have bim held firmly. Then draw out the cheek, which acts a funnel, and poor down thc fluid. If he clenches his teeth so as toexclude thc liquid, puta bit of wood between them. In giving a bolus or ball, one person should hold the dog between his knees, the hinder part resting on tho floor. Another per- son thou forces open the mouth by pressing thc forefinger and thumb of thc left hand upon the lips of the uppor jaw, aud with tho right thrust the ball far enough back toward the animal's gullet to ensuro its ready pas- sage to the stomach. To prevent disgust aud sickness, nauseous medicines should be enveloped in thin paper or on a thin flour wafer. Whenever possible the necessary medicine should be introduced into the food of the pig. If this is impossible, small pigs may bc drenched by seizing them by both ears, placing them between tho legs, aud lifting them a few inches from the ground. The medicine, previously mixed, is gradually poured into the mouth from an iron spoon by another person, the elevation of the head causing the mixture to pass backwards, and thus be swallowed. For large pigs, the opera- tor can hold the head firmly between bis kuces. whilst au assistant secures tho hinder portions. The first, lifting the hoad a little, turns it somewhat to the right, separates thc lips un tho right sido, when ho oin pour tho contents of thc boru or boltlo into thc alible of thc mouth. Or again, thc animal may be Secured by a tunning noose toa post, and then he drenched by a single person.- American A<jriritHnri»t.

A NEW CLASS OF HMIINES.-In beam uugincs, such as are no tv used as steam motors, anil for diving pumps and binning machines, tho activu or passive substance generally moves in closed cylinders with pistons moving to and fro. Professor Wellner, of Urunu, bas latoly shown that various boam cngincs may without dilliculty bc made, in willeri the fluid nets in open vessels by its weight or upward trust, and, in some cases, tli -y may be advantageous. A first group described consist* of direct-acting beam elimines with water power. An oscillating benn bas atone cud a scoop to bold water, at thc other a weight balancing half that of thc water. The scoop, raisod to its highest point, receives water thtiiugh a pip.', entering a sunk part in its bottom fnuu au upper reservoir, a valve being automatically opened when this (low is required. Thc excess of water sentis that cud ol the beam down, ami the scoop ctnpt es itself below (the valve having closed meanwhile) ; then it is brought back by the weight to bc filled again, and so on.* Tho oscillatory motion may be converted into rotatory in thc usual way. This' beam-engine may bc made double. Again, direct-acting lie.nn-cngitics for raising water aro describod. Hero oscillatory motion is imparted from a driving abaft to a beam weighted at one end and having at the other a vessel with valve which alternately dips into and (ills with water at the lowest point of its courso, and delivers thc water at its highest point into a trough. Another group consists of direct acLiug beam blowing engines. In one of these a couple of one-armed levers are worked up and down on terminal pivots, ona on either sido of a wind-chest in water. By this motion, a vessel like an inverted scoop, to which they are both attached, ia alternately

raised and depressed in water, from which it partly emerges at the top, and exchanges its water (or air. A valve at the top of the scoop closes on commencement of the descent, and the imprisoned air is carried down , and

forced into the wind-chest. Other varieties of these machines are indicated.

"SPAVIN CURE."-A spavin (says the American Agriculturist) is a growth of bone upon thc hock joint of a horse. After the growth bas become solid, an'd is a true spavin, it can not be cured, but only relievod. Spavins are often very sensitive, and oause great pain. They cause tho horse to tread upon thc toe of thc foot for relief; this changes the growth of the foot, and of the máselos and tendons of the leg more or less. Thu hoof grows high at the heel, and contracts. Now this condition of things can not be cured in the ordinary sense of the word, and any seller

of a liniment or other article who claims to enre spavin is a humbug. Nevertheless, the liniment may be valuable as affording relief to the horse, either by benumbing the muselés, or by allaying the inflammation or irritability of the parts, so that the animal may cease to go lame for a time, if not permanently.

AN APPEAL TO THE FAIR SEX.-It will be remembered that the Marquis of Lorne recently held out high hopes to unattached young women who may be disposed to emi- grate to the Canadian North-west. He said that a young woman would have twenty offers in a week, and that the further West she went the more offers she would get. A pamphlet just published, entitled " Fat Land for Lean Tillers," states that a good-looking woman oan choose among fifty adorers, while a plain one can select from five ; and the writer interprets his estimate literally by adding that, ia his opinion, no good-tempered woman is plain. The author quotes from a Canadian paper the following paragraph on the subject :-"The cry is: Still they don't come. Giris of Ontario, come West I come West ! We have in our town many eligibles. The first comer can choose between a thin lawyer, a stout doctor, a retired but not retiring mer- chant, and one still in business. All are war- ranted docile, and tired of a life of eiuglo unblessedness."

TUE HAIR, TRADE.-The dignity of human hair (says the Pall Mall Gazette)-tho pride of women, as the advertisements tell us-seems to have received a rude blow at Birmingham. A German named Lotzo was sentenced there to six months' imprisonment for etcaliug 871b. of Swedish human hair from his employer, valued at £400. or about £4 a pound. It appeared that Lotzo sold this precious artiole at the same price as ordinary horsehair, and disposed of £200 worth of the choicest specimens for thc ignominious sum of £15 " on credit." Several hairdressers wore incrimin- ated by tho revelations of tho delinquent Lotze. It is to be hoped, however, that they will not in turn denounce the ladies who aro now wearing this £200 worth of the choicest specimens, - or .tho consequences may be disastrous in the extreme to those ladies. It is well known that no one can retaiu stolen goodB even though he or she may have paid for them, and if a certain number of Birming- ham ladieB arc proved to be wearing these borrowed, or rather stolen, plumes they will probably havo to immediately divest them-

selves of them.

DRINK AND LABOUR.-Mr. William Hoyle, tho statist, in a lotter to the Times on tho subject of " Drink and tho Labouring Classes," says :-" Let it be borne in mind that during the past ten years the population of the United Kingdom have spent nearly £1,364,000,000 upon drink, or nearly twice the amount of the National Debt ; and whoo it is remembered that this expenditure represents about an equal sum of indireot loss in the burdens and misohief whioh result from drinking, or a total of direct or indirect cost and loss of over £2,700,000,000, it will show the terrible charactor of tbe burden which hos been weigh- ing down the nation's industries during the last ton years. No wonder, therefore, that there should be poverty, degradation, and misery. How could it be otherwise ? There are other reforms which the country needs ; but I vouture to say that without a reform in the habits of our population, including both rich aud poor, the uplifting of tho masses is au impossibility ; but with this reform eecuce, poverty, degradation, and misery would soon be a thing of history, and along with it there would be froedom from the orime, vioe, and moral pollution which are everywhere asso- ciated with intemperance."

TUE MONGOOSE.-A few years ago the island of Jamaioa was trouWod with a plague

of rats. So vast were the numbers of these destructive rodentB that the growth of many valuable crops was seriously interfered with. Fox-terriers, ferrets, aud other animals destructive to rats, were introduced, but failed to irrest the plague, but iu 1872 Mr. B. Espent imported some nine mongooses direct from India. In a few months they bred freely, and being distributed over the island, in the short space of two years had extirpated the

rats. The beneficial effect of their introduc- tion has been estimated at from £100,000 to £150,000 a year. The mongooses not only destroyed rats, but vast numbors of snakes, toads, and laud crabs. They have been since introduced with advantage into Cuba, Barba does, and Porto Rt'oo. Mr. W. Bancroft Espent read a paper on the history of the acclimatisation and utilisation of the mongoose in Jamaica at a recent meeting of the Zoolo- gical Society of London, and threw out the suggestion that a trial of its sorvicos m Aus- tralia as a destroyer of tho rabbit might bc found to be advantageous.

PROPOSED IRISH EMIGRATION TO MEXICO. A Dublin correspondent telegraphs to the St. James Gazette that an Irishman has arrived in Dublin from Mexioo, with a letter from the Government of that country, empowering him to communicate with the Mexican Minister in Paris with reference to

the emigration of Irish families to Mexico. He states that the Mexican Government aro desirous that a thousand families from Ireland should emigrate to Durango, and that 1,800,000 dollars have been voted for tho purpose of starting the emigrants and pro-

viding for them on their arrival. He also adds that thc soldiers of Irish nationality in Mexico pressed him to forward the scheme to thc utmost of his power, being anxious to hive as many of their countrymen over as possible. When in New York, on his way to Irclan 1, tho agent was waitoil upon by O'Donovan Rossn, who tried to dissuada him from his olijeut, (tating that he would only ba promoting the desire of the hated Kn^lish Government. Rather than cucnurago Irish Irish emigration it was thc object of the Irish iMatioualists to put as puny obstacles iu the way as possible, aud, in fact, when tho oppor- tunity occurred, they sent emigrants back to Ireland. Tho agent, however, holds opposite views to O'Donovan Rossi's, nuil iu conse- quence, while in New York, he was boycotted ivy tho Nationalists Uc expresses his inten- tion of communicating with Mr. Tukc and others. He anticipttcs opposition to the Mexieau scheme of emigration from thc Nationalist party in Ireland.

SWEET POTATO VINES -It is well known among farmers and gardeners, says an ex- change, that peas, beans, tomatoes, and some othor plants noed some support to climb up-m to keep thom off the ground, or else the result of the crop will not prove satisfactory. In the caBc of theie plants thc reason is obvious enough. Not only do thc plants need all the air and sunlight they eau get, but thc fruit itself must be kept off tho ground, or it will decay and become prey to vermin. But few ever tlwught of providing similar supports for sweet potato vines to climb upon, or ever thought that it would be any benefit at all to keep thom off the ground during thc growing period. Yet au accidental discovery, made thc (lasts ummer, almost convinces us that it would bc much better to provide in some cheap way a support to keep tho potato vines off the ground aud thus havo both them and the earth about thc roots more accessible to light, heat, and air. AU know how hard it is to prevent sweet potato vines from taking root, especially during a rainy season. If, then, thc vines could he minie to climb upon some such support as brush, stuck along the ridge from end to end, this would be prevented, the vines and the whole plant

would set more air, and tbe ground could bc worked and kept 6ne and mellow a« long as tho growing season last«. The consequence would be larger and bettor flavoured potatoes

and more of them.

ROCKHAMPTON.

THURSDAY. MARCH 29, 1883.

UPON the Eirl of Derby becoming Colonial Secretary for the British Empire, in room of Earl Kimberley, the Agents General of the British Colonies waited upon him, and collectively congratulated him upon his accession to office. What was said and done on the occasion has

formed the subject of friendly comment in the British and Colonial press; Much more seems to have been understood than was expressed on the occasion. Sir Alex. Galt, who then enjoyed the title of High Commissioner for Canada, was spokesman on behalf of the Colonies, and the pith of Ms remarks were that the reception of the deputation was regarded as evincing an appreciation of the growing impor-

tance of the constitutional colonies. " Our respective Governments " he said " will be promoted by a more formal recognition ' than has hither- to been found advisable of the deep interest, which is felt by the colonies in all that concerns the nation, of which they regard themselves as an integral part." Lord Derby replied in courteous phrases, and while confessing how im- possible it was to forecast the future, said "the British Government recognised and duly valued, the attachment of their colonial kinsmen to the constitution under which they lived, to the mother country from which they have sprung, and to the empire of which, though divided by distance, they continue to form an integral part." These are mere formal phrases, apparently, but they are held to possess a significance which

lies below the surface. It has been a

matter of some jealousy and ill feeling that, while the envoy of any petty European state or duchy claimed, and was accorded, certain honours and privileges at the British Court, the representatives of colonies as large as the whole of Europe-of people attached to Britain by ties, kindred,

policy, commerce, and aspirations, and in number far surpassing the population of Continental provinces, were denied suc'i favours. They have been kept in the background, and treated very much as commercial officers rather than

political representatives. This latest proceeding on the part of the Agents General is made matter for congratula- tion, because by it they are supposed to have improved their political status. The Times says:-"Since they have become the mouthpieces of their Govern- ments Tor political as well as commercial purposes, the Agents-General feel that the statusaf accredited representatives should be accorded them. They are the only channel through which the Imperial

Government can obtain authentic know- ledge of the aims and ' wishes of the colonies, and that being so The Times considers that every facility should be given them for discharging their func- tions." Other English journals coincide in this opinion, and colonial ones in general express satisfaction at the in- creased dignity acquired by our repre- sentatives. If the proceeding possess all the significance which some people desire should be attached to it, then we must ourselves pay more attention to our Agents-General. Their duties hitherto have, to a very large extent, been of a commercial character. Their duties

have consisted mainly, it has been understood, in purchasing materials

for carrying on public works in the colonies, and in promoting and regulating emigration (rom the home countries to those represented. If, however, they are to possess political privileges and I functions in future, some effort will

require to be made to define these. No argument is needed to show that it will not do to endow them with unlimited

political powers. If they are left to do as they please, they may commit the colonies to a course of action, which the bulk of the electors might repudiate. An illustration of the danger to which a colony might be exposed by the unwar- ranted action of an Agent-General was furnished by the conduct of Mr. E. Jenkins, when appointed representative of Canada. Being of advanced Radical opinions, and of an assuming disposition, he almost brought the home and colonial authorities into collision. His peremp- tory dismissal from office alone prevented

much mischief. It must be remembered that the connection of the colonies with the mother country is of a most in- definite description. The British Parlia- ment is supreme over the whole British empire, and the acts of our colonial Parliaments are liable to be annulled by it ; but the Imperial government would scarcely dare to impose an obnoxious statute on any colony, or decline to authorise a measure, in adopting which our representatives had the support of their constituents. The Crown is the

fountain of justice in the colonies, and retains the power of declaring peace and war, but these are bonds which it would not be difficult to sever. In this

state of our relationships, it will be apparent, that an imprudent officious Agent-General, acting in perfect good faith, and doing what he belived to be for the best, may never- theless prejudice the political liberties ind privileges of the colonists. We have a most tender and loving regard for the mother-country, and the political rights we possess ia common with all British subjects, and have no wish these should be imperilled by the conduct of any indi- vidual. That will be best prevented by withholding the power of doing so. It must also occur to maayjol our readers that if Agents-General are to havean improved political status they should be changeable like the administrations they represent. A political representative, void of political bias or proclivities, would not

be worth much, because a person öfthat character could not have paid much attention to the affairs of the colony. Every man of intelligence forms his own opinions, and seeks to give effect to them. A Radical Agent-General, therefore, without trespassing beyond the recognised bounds of his province, might nevertheless be a serious trouble

and inconvenience to a Conservative Administration. To make the head of our London office in accord with our Government it would be necessary he should be of the same party. These" points are of so much general interest they are sure to attract attention in the other colonies, and it is to be hoped our electors will not remain indifferent as to their settlement.

After a few fitful showers on Tuesday and yesterday a thunder plump occurred yester- day afternoon, and the downfall continued with little intermission, until the time of our going to press. Weather reports show that most of the northern coast towns have had light showers, and in the western districts there were indications of rain. Tho prevailing wind on the coast was south-east, and vessels going south would likely meet with adverse

weather.

THE session of the Protestant Alliance Friendly Society of Australasia waa oontinued yesterday in the Protestant Hall, when all tho delegates present on the previous day were tn attendance. Tho sitting lasted from eleven o'clock in the morning till ten o'olock at night, and the business transacted was the revision

of the rules. One of those passed yester- day was that the nearest relative of a member should receive £15 at his death. The statement of the incidental fund for the last year ending January shows the receipts to have been £617 10s. ld. and the expenditure £558 5». lOd. leaving a credit

bali ince .of £259 4t. 3d. The fonds invested show a credit to the lodge relief fund of £104 3s. 2d.; fanerai fend, £490 la. lOd ; in- cidental fund, £259 4s, 3d.-whioh is invested aa follows :-£119 Ila. 7d. io the Government Savings Bank, and £439 17s. 8d. to the credit of the Grand Coanoil in the Queensland National Bank. The sittings will be resumed this moroiug.

MESSRS. C. BUODEK and T. Oxnam with a

party of gentlemen interested in the devolope mont of the mining resources of the district paid a visit to the Crooodile goldfield yester- day. They left town at 10 a.m. and had fine weather, ani a good road on the outward journey. They arrived on tho field shortly before 1 p.m, and commenced the work of inspection. The first claim visited was that of the Crocodile Creek Alluvial Gold Mining Company where it was seen that Captain Osborne was making good progress in sinking, a depth of about eighteen feet having been reaohed. Until timbering up is done no farther sinking osn be accomplished. Several men were engaged cutting the neces- sary timber for that purpose. Pits had been dug for the engine bed, and the work per- formed showed that Captain Osborne had began preparations in a style euch aa would be expected from an experienced miner. Some

of the drift on top of the wash dirt looked good, but was uot tried. Altogether there was evidenoe of very satisfactory work, so far, having been performed. The machinery lately arrived from Sydney will be trans- mitted to the field so soon as the road is prao ticable for travelling such weighty material. Messrs. Muir and Company are working No 1 claim on the Uurdett-Ooutts line of reef, and from the character of the stone being raised a good crushing is anticipated. In the Block and Pillar claim, one and a half mile from Crocodile Creek, the proprietors, Messrs. Hicks Brothers, stopped at the water level owing to an influx of water. They are doing top work, and have a quantity of splendid Btone at grass. They seemed quite satisfied with their prospects, judgiog from the quality of the stone shown. Some of the party did a little Alpine climbing on the hill to inspect the ground held by tho proposed Crocodile Mountain Cold Mining Company. They returned fully satisfied as to thc show of tho locality. Probably their visit will stimulate them to urge on the formation of tho Company, aud facilitate the commence- ment of operations in a favourable season. The country all along the road and at the Crocodile is said to be looking splendid, thc gross having a verdant appearance and water being plentiful. Thc return journey was effected under circumstances far from pleasant. When about a mile and a-half from thc creek a blinding rain ant in, and further on it was found how heavy had been the downpour.

Sheets ot water covered the road and low

lying country in all diieo'.ious, At Meura

' . i..- '? , -

Platos the creek «na fuÚ» four feet high. Fortunately the travellers ïrere eaeooncedín a oovered-in sociable, and ejàeped a drenching. ' We have to thank Hr. O.«ogden-for th« lore going particular« of the trip.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning, before the Police Magistrate, a disorderly oharaoter was fined five shillings, which he paid. ,

THE latest arrivals of stock at Lake's Creek have been 99 fats on the 22nd instant, 90 on Friday, and 68 on Monday. They came from Messrs. Thomson «od Bowan'« Malvern Downs Station, Leichhardt District, and were tracked from Emerald.. -They croiled the Fitzroy Bridge in charge of Mt. B, Pioton.

' THC Q R.M.S. Chyebassa with the mails for London via the usual ports, left the Brisbane bar yesterday at 1-30 p.m. and is expected in Port Alma to-night. Attention is directed to the notice tn another column respecting the closing of the English mails. Letters for or via the United Kingdom bearing the customary late fee may be posted on board the Bunyip at the A.S.N. Company's wharf ap to eleven to-night.

Maur of the eleotors of this distriot will no doubt be glad to hear that our junior member, Mr. J. Ferguson, will deliver an address at a pnblic meeting in the School of Arts this evening at eight o'clock. He will explain his action in the Assembly during the late session, and also expound Vis views on the leading topics of the day. We trust there will be a large attendance not only of his sup- porters, but of the electors genorally. The chair wlU be occupied by Alderman R. Sharples, ex-Mayor.'

One, telegraphic advioes state that the Marine Board of New. South Wales have deoided to prosecute the parties concerned in sending the steamer Pacific to Bea without a properly certificated engineer. She was bound from Sydney to Brisbane Water, but was {ticked up by the steamer Tuggerah ia a help ess condition, and apparently not properly found. The southern preis wrote strongly on

the matter, and it was naturally considered the Marine Board had oegleotod their duties in this as well as in other instances. We are glad to'see that aotion is about to be taken in

the matter.

AT the meeting of the Council this afternoon matters of more than ususl importance are to be dealt with. The Mayor will move the

adoption of the report of the Special Com- mittee on Wharfage Extention, It will be re- membered that at. the last meeting of the

Council Alderman Sharples sought to mire a

motion to the effect that one of the contractors

ander the Corporation be disqualified from tendering tor any municipal works in the future. He notified his intention, however, of giving notice of motion, and to-day .he will move " That Mr. William Davis lie disquali- fied from holding any further contracts with the Council for the tyrm of fies years."

IT is reported on good authority (says the Courier) that the Government have, pending a reply from the Imperial authorities, completed their arrangements for taking possession, in the name of Her Majesty, of that part of New Guinea whioh is not affeoted hy Dutch claims. The recommendation of the Government bas now been a month in the hands of the Secre- tary of State for the Colonies, and is probably pigeon-holed until what is deemed much more urgent business has been disposed of. But what may be deemed comparatively unimpor- tant in respect of British interests, is of very great moment indeed to ns, far our colonists have already considerable interest involved in trade with New Guinea, whUe the prospective interest of the colony in the occupation of this great island ia beyond calculation. At first eight the step contemplated by our Govern- ment seeras*a bold one, but it does not com- promise the Imperial authorities, being taken without their knowledge and consent, and if our oocupation should tureatcD to create inter-

national difficulties, the worst that can happen,

through what may be stigmatised as colonial precipitancy, is that we should be required to

withdraw troia the island. Such a contin-

gency, bowover, does not seen at all probable if, as we believe, the action of our Government is heartily supported by the Legislature.

" G." writes the Courier as follows on the subject of finding water by means of the divining rod :-" A gentlenan from the

western districts related to ne, a few days j ago, a circumstance which, if true, would go to show that supermundane gifts, to which some people pretend, might, after. all, be turned to good practical aooouat. A boy, son of a carrier, was taken to a place aomewhere on the oonfines of the Mitchell and Gregory ? districts, where it was snpposbd underground water was likely to be lonni. Arriving at the place fae started on foot with a twig about three feet long, and which breached out into a fork at one end. Each end cf the fork was pressed lightly against the poiutof the thumb, whilst with the points of his forefingers he supported the twig in a horizontal position, or rather, at a dip of 45°. .He had not walked

many miles before the twig suddenly dipped j until the end touched the ¿Jroánd. The spot was marked by a peg, and, isaya my infor- mant, at that spot there is now a well giving a never foiling supply of water 1 It etrikes me there is a muon more useful field for the operation of Brisbane spirit than its attempt! ng to collect news from other worlds by -table rapping."

Ws were yesterday permitted to inspect the plana for the new Sohool of Arts, which were conditionally aooepted by the Committee on Tuesday night. The front of the building

ig ta be of Stanwell atone. The entrance

from William-street is by a vestibule, 12 feet I wide, which opens into a lobby 40 feet long, in I the centre of which, on tho right hand aide, j is a door leading to the library, 40 feet j long and 20 feet wide. At the right hand

ooruer of the library is the librarian's room, j

12 feet long and 12 feet wide. On the other ; side of the lobby is the olasi-room, the same j size as the library, at the far end of which is ; a committee-room 12 feet square. At the end j of the lobby is the ball, 70 feet long and : 36 feet wide. At the end of this room is the stage, 16 feet long and .12 feet wide, on either side of whioh are dressing rooms 12 feet square. In the centre of the lobby is the etairoase. On the top story

facing the street is a balcony, and on j

I either side there are baloonies 9 feet wide. On the loft hand side at the top of the landing I ÍB the reading room, which is 40 feet lons and

20-feet wide. On the other side of the build- j ing is the mnseum, of the same size. On both

sides of the building are verandahs, 9 feet 1 wide. The upper part of the hall will, of course, be available for nse when required.

A MEETING of the Committee of the Fittroy Pastoral, Agricultural, and Horticultural Sooiety was held in the offices of Messrs.

Brown aud Risien yesterday afternoon, when i

there were present:-Messrs. J. Thomson (in |

the chair), J. Macpherson, H. Cooper, O. M. Leigh, J. Brown, D. Martin, and H. W. Risien (secretary). On the motion of Messrs. - Brown and Jooes, the following gentlemen were appointed judges at the

forthcoming show : - Blood horses :-Messrs. - W. K. Peberdy, E. Wilson, E. (I. Wood, ¡ and .1. C. Collins ; draught horses-Messrs. D. Martin. S. Bilitho, J. Costello, J. O. Porteus, J. Murray, C. Dallon, G. Fox, W. Nott, and - Triffitt ;' cattle-Messrs. V. Dowling, J. Boss, M. Christian, J. Button, J. Badgery, aud H. Badgery; fat cattle - Mc»»ra. W, Jajer, I) Martin, J. J. Macder- mott, J. Jackson, J. Hyland, and IV Picton ; stuop and wool - Messrs. W. Thun.son, -f. Alberton, and J. Thoms III j do^a and poultry -Messrs. J. V. Browne. S. H. Mills, and tí. li. May; sections 8 to-ll-Messrs. Vf. Cairns,

J. O'Shaneay, T. Kelly, J. Pattison, T. Irwin,. and G. M. lyeigb ; agricultural implements a'id machinery-Messrs F. Linthwaite, ti. Byan, G, Alley, B, M'Kay, and - Fraier ;

aeotlon 13-«amt «a {or agricultural imple-, pent« and jnaohtnefy. Accounts amounting '

toJB7 6«. W&mjei for payment,

tne^tag tormlj^ajejfl, ^4 '? ^jaj. ?^HUMMOCKY ISLAND wat aold fast weèk«t' the Giadstone Land offices to Mr. H. Misting,' who purchased the ten years' lease at £8 12s,

per square mile.

/ li will be kean by our advertising oolumns, j

that Masara. W. F. Walton and Co. have decided to elose their piara ot business at six o'clock every Saturday on and after the 7th April.

MANY Rickhampton acquaintances of Mr. Henry Friend senior, one ot the oldest iden- tities, will be glad to leam, that acoordtng to the Gladstone Obmrver, ha has arrived safely at Townsville after a five months' cruise among the South Sea Islands as labonr agent. It is (tated he waa unwell, but Dot seriously in- disposed.

A NEW ZEALAND paper states that a waterproof cardboard, which promises to be a formidable rival to corrugated iron, is about to be introduced into that colony. It ia adapted for numerous purposes on the farm and station, such as reefs, eheds, hut», rick covers, cattle troughs, &o. For roofing it is olaimed that there ia a great saving in labour and time, as it is only necessary to fix the cardboard on an open framework, no close boarding being necessary underneath to sup- port it, as in the case of felt. We commend this to the notice of residents in .this district, who can obtain further particulars on applica- tion to Messrs. Johnston and Co., of Welling- ton, N.Z.

A CRICK-iT match wat played yesterday afternoon, at North Rockhampton, between a team of niue from the Early Closing Associa- tion and a similar number of All-comers. The former team won by 21 runs, For the All- comers, Whitman (17) and Johnston (12) played well for their scores. On the Associa- tion side Barber (29) played a lucky innings, giving several ohances, whilst Thwaites played well for ll. Whitmau and Johnston bowled with most effect for. the losing team, and Thwaites for the victors. Messrs. Whitman and Thwaites were the respeotive captains.

ls our report of the proceedings at the Polioe Court yesterday "Bridget Kelly waa summoned by Honorah Kelly for assault, should ravi "Bridget Kelly summoned Honorah Kelly."-For. Sydney Bulletin in the paragraph yesterday referring to Mr. Easton, please read " Melbourne Bulletin."

MURDER BY BLACKS.—The depositions taken at the inquiry into the death of Mr. Marcus Beresford, of the native police force, who was murdered by the blacks on the night of the 21th January, about twenty-four miles from Farley head station, in the Mackinlay Ranges, have just reached Brisbane, and from them we extract the following account of the sad occurrence :—On the 17th January, Mr. Beresford, in charge of five troopers, left Devoncourt Station for Chatsworth. Nothing further was seen of him by white men until the report of his murder was brought in by three of the troopers, all of whom had been badly wounded. The other two reached Farley head station, but were too badly hurt to proceed further. It was stated that Mr. Beresford had been killed by the blacks while asleep, and his body was found as the troopers had described, rolled up in blankets and lightly covered over with sand. The skull and forehead were smashed in, and there was also a spear wound in the right thigh. All round where the body lay were tracks of the blacks, and a great quantity of their implements of war were

strewn about, many of the latter being stained

with blood. All the witnesses agree in the belief that there is no reason to suspect the troopers of fowl play. Indeed, the two troopers who reached Farley head station had quite a number of spear points in them, and the other three, as before stated, were severely wounded. A grave was dug on the spot, and on the order of Mr. A. A. Hart, J. P., the body was in- terred. A rough head and foot stone were put in the ground to mark the place of his burial, and the grave was paved round with rough stones so as to keep the heavy rains from washing the earth away.—Courier.

A EOWINO OïLKBRrrr.-Those who take an interest tn aquatics (and we believe there are a good many in this town) will doubtless be pleased to know that a celebrated rower has arrived in Maryborough, and intends settling down in the neighbourhood. We refer to Mr. T. G. White, whose name about 25 years or 40 ago was as well known in the rowing world as Hanlon'* and Tricketts are now. Mr. White during his halcyon days rowed seventy-five races, of which fae won no less than sixty-seven. Amongst others, he defeated George Drewitt, J. Finnis, and the oelebrated Harry Clasper. The mee with the latter was rowed on the Champion Course, from Putney to Mortlake, on the Thames, and time in which it was performed has never been equalled. In Franoe, io the year '57, at Paris and Rouen, he won four rases in oue day, being in each race pitted against a fresh man. For this feat he was decorated by the late Emperor Napoleon personally, receiving at his hands two splendid gold medals, and was highly compli- mented by his Imperial Majesty on the prowess he displayed on the occasion. He has-also been decorated with a massive gold medal by the Sing-of the Belgians for rowing per« manees in Belgium. He twice challenged Harry Kelly, the ex-ehampion of England, for a stake of £200, but Kelly would not piok up the gauntlet. He was, however, after one of the most successful careers on record, at last defeated by that wonder of his age. Harry Chambers, in a race for the ohampionBbip of the United Kingdom. Out of the numerous trophies he has won in his time, he bas brought to Maryborough the Dogett coat aod badge (one of the greatest curiosities probably ever ecen in this colony), the medal presented to him by Napoleon III,, some valuable rings, and a number of other oostly presents received at various times from distinguished parsonages, the Prince of Wales included. These were courteously submitted to our admiring gaze yesterday at the Post Office Hotel, where, for the present, Mr. White is staying.- Mary- borough Chronicle.

A CLEVBR ABUEST.-On the night of 2Stb nttimo, Mr. Hugh M'Donnell, of Elisabeth street, Melbourne, was robbed of a valuable gold watch and chain, in a mysterious manner whilst be waa returning throng!) the city to his home. Being somewhat under the in- fluence of liquor he could not remember the locality in whioh the robbery was committed. The case was placed in the bands of Detective O'Donoell, who for som-) time had suspected a : Chinaman, residing iu Brogan's-Iane, of being

implicated in various robberies, and he there I fore determined to exercise bia vigilance in

that direction. At about ten o'clock on Wed- nesday night, O'Donnell, who had been watching tho Chinaman's house for about an hour, determined to enter, and induced a youngman, named M'Donald, who was pass- ing the place at the time, to knock at the door. As the door was opened M'Donald

Walked straight inside, but immediately he

bad done aa, O'Donnell, «rho frai following him, waa observed by the Chinaman, who rushed for the door and managed to cloie and 4nak it before the detective ooeJd get.inside,' In'¡the meantime, young M'Donald was'eon

fjneu in house thoandcoufrontedbyamannaOMd James Stewart, alias Allen, and the China- man, Before, however, the inmates of the house had time to attack him, O'Donnell, from the outside, smashed the door to pieces and got inside the place. The Chinaman immediately seized a hatohet, which be threw to the man Stewart, O'Donnell then

rushed at Stewart, and a desperate struggle ensued between them for the possession of the hatchet, which ended in O'Ponnell secur- ing it. The Chinaman had by thia time made bis escape through the back portion of the premises. After O'Donnell had sncoeeded in getting the hatohet from Stewart.-the latter ran ¡to a tea chest in ¿ne ot the rooms, snatched tbo missing watoh from under the chest, and threw it out of the window. It was picked up by the detective, and Stewart was arrested and. taken to the watchhouse. O'Donnell subsequently returned to the house, and apprehended the Chinaman. Both pri- soners were brought before the City Bench charged with the larceny of the watch and chain, which were valued at £80, and on the application of Detective O'Donnell they were remanded for a week. The Chinaman gave the name of Sye Kenim.-Melbourne Age.

articleText:
THE LAND QUESTION.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIE,-Seeing that the ideu enunciated by Mr. Ferguson at the Sohool of Arte upon land tenure are gaining ground, I ask your per.; miaaion to give my opinion on that subject.: In the first place, I agree that the State ia entitled to claim what is usually called the unearned inurement ; but I do not agree that the proposed mode of getting it will either effect that object, or any other good one.

When we consider how a custom becomes a

law ; a auffrauoe becomes a right j when we, consider the difficulty of distinguishing the; unearned increment from the well-earned fruits of ths industry and foresight of the tenant ; and when we remember how success- fully a large body of tenants can resist an' increase of rent, then J., think we must con- clude that the proposals of Mr. Ferguson would not effeot his object, bat would be more likely ta practically alienate the land, without any adequate return to the State, for it would be certainly impossible to Ret high rents.

A lend tax is of the nature of a rent charge in favour of the State, and may be made as Srest or as little as the Legislature may

oem just and, wise ; - and this, is, in my. opinion, the best means of ohumiug, the unearned ¿norement. Bat In order to learn the advantages, or disadvantages, of saoh a' tax, it would be necessary to consider at length the prinoiple Of taxation. The highest estate whioh a subject osn have in land ia the fee simple, and this is no mors than a qualified fee ; and the owner holds as a tenant ander

the Crown, so that really an estate in fee , eirople is merely a tenanoy, But any less estate is hampered with legal restrictions, whioh mom or less prevent the lend from being used to the greatest rmhlichsnefliV and the State, which regulates the MfeBup of: real property by demise, may also)^^^^nry, Í enact laws to regulate the uses |^ewmi lt shall be applied, . ,

loan see no good objection to the creation of large estates or to the system of landlord and tenant provided the landlords be not absentees and provided the landlords be other ! than the State. ? On the contrary I think this is the best means of giving the direct manage- ment of the land to practical men. A tenant from year to year, or for a term of years, gets in fact the ase of capital (equal in amount to the value'of the fee simple) at the lowest current rate of interest, for interest upon mortgage is nearly always greater than a fajr rent obarge,-«nd frequently men who are rich enough to own a farm, and have'snfflcient capital to stock it. are too fond of their own estate to ase the land to the greatest public

benefit.

. If any of your readers learned in land laws would give a short account of the oases whioh gradually converted the old tendal tenares of. villeinage and knight servios, into the copy bold abd fee tenares of the present day, it would be interesting and instructive to those who agree with Mr. Ferguson's ideas.

Yonn, &c.,

H. BEAK.
heading: THE LAND QUESTION. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.
snippet: SIR,—Seeing that the ideas [?]ciated by Mr. Ferguson at the School of Arts upon land ten[?]re are gaining ground, I ask your permission to give my opinion on that subject.

articleText:
KOCIUIAMTTON.

THUnSDAY, MAY 3, 1683.

THE period at which Parliament will meet is a fair subject for public dis- cussion. Among the constitutional duties of an intelligent body of electors, and of the press as thc exponent of their feelings and opinions, is to watch how the business of the country is being con- ducted, and bring such influence as they may possess to bear on the Ministry, in the event of errors being made, or want of activity displayed. That there should be no unnecessary delay in the manage- ment of colonial affairs will be admitted, and, in criticising thc date of the meeting of Parliament, the press is per- forming an important function. It is a pity, however, such intelligent journals as the lirisbone Telegraph and Too- woomba Chronicle cannot discharge it without indulging in offensive, vilipen I dil g. and abuse of the Premier/ and

attributing to him interested motives in delaying thc assembling of our legislators. In a Government Gazette Extraordinary Parliament has been prorogued till the 5th June, and it is assumed that, between that date and the 151I1 November, when the present Parliament will cease to exist by effluxion of time, the period is too short lo permit ol useful legislation being accomplished. The Premier is twitted by the journals we have named, with not having redeemed a promise made to Mr. Griffith last Session, that Parliament would be called together sooner this year. But no definite promise was made. When interrogated upon the subject by the leader of the Opposition, ?lbe Premier said. " hejhpu¿iLJiiiuself_¡t woiíidue a~imicTrbëller arrangement to bring Parliament together earlier next year than was thc case either in the present or last year." From the state of the public business thc Premier does not now seem to be of opinion that there is any necessity for the session opening earlier much than in the last two years. The Opposition journals have attempted to show cause why Parliament should meet sooner, but in this matter they have not made out a good case. Tile C/imu'ck, after devoting a column and three quarters to prove that Parliament should have been called together earlier this year, completely dis- integrates its own arguments by re- marking-" The Parliament is now in the last stages of its existence. It may certainly be called a moribund Parlia- ment, and to allow such a Parliament lo initiate any measures of Government legislation, will be entirely opposed to all constitutional practice." It seems a fair deduction, from Ibis state or matters, that there is no necessity for Parliament meeting early. It is not in a condition to produce useful measures, and, there- fore, it is most desirable, it should not spend time in making the attempt : as our contemporary remarks that would be opposed to all constitutional practice.

The Telegraph says " the delay in putting into practice the personal views of the Premier, as to the time of meet- ing, may be due to the incompleteness of the negotiations on the land-grant railway schemes, and coloured labour for sugar plantations." Upon pondering over these matters, our readers may find some difficulty in discovering where the incompleteness exists. Practically, thc

present Parliament has shown its dis- ' approbation of the Warrego Railway scheme. It will not likely be brought forward again for consideration before the Dissolution. The Transcontinental Railway scheme is the question of the day ; and with regard to it, the Premier's

views have been matured. To some extent - in fact, as far as he could manage it, we may suppose-they have been embodied in thc Agreement, entered into by thc Ministry, with the Australian Transcontinental Railway Syndicate. We cannot see why there should be delay because of any incompleteness of negotiations on these mailers. In connection with thc coloured labour question, our contemporary suggests that lbe delay may be due lo time being required to developc a scheme for obtaining natives from New Guinea. That is, in the highest degree, im- probable. All accounts £0 to sliow that thc natives of Papua would not be suitable for plantation labourers. Pie sides, should any attempt bc made lo im- port them, thc utilitarian, selfish character, thus impaited to thc annexation scheme, would certainly detract from thc honour and wisdom of thc proceeding. Far other and more creditable motives, we have no hesitation in saying, inspired llie Miniilry in their endeavour to attach New Guinea to the Jirkish Empire, lt shows a remarkable want of imagination, or political perspection on the part of the Queen-street philosophers, when

they cannot propagate more reasonable and realistic grounds for thc postpone- ment of ihe meeting of Parliament.

Among the journals which have con- demned the policy of the Government, in delaying the convening of Parliament, is the Brisbane Courier ; and its utter- ances, though in general scorned by the Opposition press as unworthy of con- sideration, have been paraded in the columns of the latter, and commented on as an embodiment of wisdom on this matter. The Courier proceeds on the assumption that as Parliament has been prorogued till June it will not meet till July ; and considers that in such an event there will not be.time for such legislation as it deems probable. Now, we have good reason to believe that our contemporary is wrong in his supposi- tion ; that Parliament will meet in June; and that the real business of the session wilt be proceeded with in July and August-as the Courier argued it should. It is our contemporary, there- fore, and not Sir Thomas M'llwraith, who has made a mistake. But even in the event of Parliament not meeting till July, there will be ample time after that for the despatch of all the business that is likely to come before it. As our Toowoomba contemporary remarks, il would not be altogether constitutional for a moribund Parliament to attempt serious legislation. The Treasurer will probably be prepared to make his Annual Statement early in July, and the discus-

sion of the Estimates will be the most

important business of the Assembly. Of course, the Transcontinental Rail-

way Agreement will come up for discus- sion, but wc do not anticipate it will occupy much of the time of the House. It seems probable the Ministry will dis- cover, «vhen Parliament meets, they will not be able to pass it ; and they will not prolong contention unnecessarily. We think it improbable they will take any steps in regard to the introduction of coloured labour. AH they could do would be to submit regu- lations for the introduction of Indian Coolies, provided they have

come to terms with the Government of

India regarding them. The only measure that may require a fair amount of con- sideration is a Redistribution of Seats

Bill. It may well be discussed in July, and disposed of carly in August. By the end ol that month the business of the Session should be over, and members then be free to court the constituences.

It is more than probable, indeed, they will begin to do so before the Dissolu- tion ; and we cannot help thinking that one reason why the assembling of Parliament is delayed is because Ministers mean to keep members at their legitimate work, and not talking through the columns of Hansard to their con- stituents. With a general election only a few months off lhere will be a great temptation to indulge in speech-making, and the Government have done well in denying hon. members the opportunity of wasting the time of their colleagues, and taking up the attention of Parlia- ment, by engaging in electioneering haiaseuss,... The Government having allowed them ho time to talk théyTflüst reserve their orations till they meet the

electors.

THE pcoplo of Rockhampton aro a long suffering people, They have, indeed, the credit, with the inhabitants of some other towns in tbc colony, of looking well and sharply after their own interests. This is a popular delusion. They are content to endure inconvenience, and even hardship and danger of the most unreasonable kind, just because it pleases some people to inflict them. The habit of Bilent, unmurmuring submission, which waB learned in the days whon the trade of thc port was a monopoly, has become a second nature; and things that vere, and are, are accepted aa the things that shall he for ever more. If anyone doubts this, lot him go down to tho wharves when tho steam tender, which conveys passengers to tho direct coast mail Btcamcrs of the A S.N. Company, or to Hie Queensland U.M. steamers for or from England, is leaving for Keppel Bay. The un- rivalled accommodation furnished on board of the s.s. Bunyip is well known-by sad ex- perience-to all that " co down to thc sea in ships, aud do business in the mighty waters." The witty Frenchman who said that Admiral Byng was shot "-pour encourager hs autres.1' anticipated the principle on which tho A.¡S.N. Company treats tbe travelling public that go to and fro on thc Fitzroy. The object of tho company is evidently to encourago travelling in general, and travelling by their own steamers in particular. The spacious promenade pre- sented on thc deck of thc Bunyip, which may he said to be all poop, main-deck, and fore- castle rolled into one, especially when tho passengers havA to share it with scores of boxes, and hundreds of bags of sugar, or rico, or other merchandise, is associated, in tbe memory of thousands of travellers, with the liveliest recollections of thc room which it afforded for oxcrcisc, on cold and long winter nights. The snug comfort of thc protection afforded by the awning overhead, which, for greater snugness, is fixed at a height that ignores "chimney pots," has been felt and blessed in many a drenching downpour af raia. Aud then the saloon, with its inner sanctum, tho (adios' cabin-how often have tho limbs

of weary passengers found sweet and refresh- ing rest ou ita luxurious couchoB, with a valiso or carpet-bog for pillow 1 Wo say nothing of thc elegancies of the table, in which passengers have always found n solace far the minor annoyances that arise 'from tho delay of "tho mail boat." Tho /Bunyip is a groat institution of Uockhampton, * and tho Fitzroy a worthy successor of its great prototype thc Bronzewing. Nothing ! would form a better preparation for a voyage

to Brisbane or to Townsville in thc spluudid coast steamers, ur a better termination to such a voyage, than to spend six or ten hours on hoard of thc Bunyip. In thc former case tho passengers will bo duly prepared to lind in tho crowded saloon of thc Klamaug or thc Quai- l-ling, a palace nf fiplenduur ami luxury; in tbc latter, ho will bave learned by the lime he roaches thc wharf at Itnckhemplmi, to appreciate the conveniences which he has left behind bim, and over which porlinps, he had been savagely growling. The salutory cITect of this kind of experience on passenger*, and on thu reputation and profits of the cwnpany, have evidently leen appreciated by the latter ; fnr instead of providing a large and more comfortable steamer to replaco thc Bunyip when disabled, they have been content to hire from a local firm a steamer whose dimensions ahnest lit ber for being the l'.nnyip'a tender. For weeks past the passen- gers to ami from every steamer, that merely r.ills at Keppel li iv, have bad to travel in thc Mabel, a vessel which affords the very mini, mum of accommodation, and iu the event itf bad weather, or bing detention, the very nnxi inum of discomfort. It is due tu the owners of tho Mabel to say ber tiny avlona io ita fittings is nut inferior to that of the Bunyip, and to tho master and crew that they il o their utmost for their passengers. But any ono making a surrey of the Lilliputian s.s. caa

only too easily imagine how miserable wonld be the plight of a fall complement of passen- gers, were the voyage to or from the Bay to be made under steady rain, or to be diver- sified by a sudden thunderstorm. Sup- pose that to these were added the cold of a winter night, and perhaps ten or twelvo hours' detention in the Bay ; and the effects on the health of weakly men and delicate women and children would, in many cases, be fatal. It is a disgrace to the A.S.N. Company that so miserable provision has been made by them for passengers by their coast steamers to and from Rock- hampton, and it is no credit to our Chamber of Commerce that this abuse has been allowed to exist so long. The intimation just made by the agent of the A.S.N. Company here has not come a moment too soon ; and tho fnllil tnent of the promise will not be at all retarded by our calling attention .to tho hardships, which are being endured at the present time by every passenger, who is obliged to sail to or from the Bay in the tender now running. The magnitude of thc Rockhampton trade, and its rapid growth, ought long ago to have secured for the port a steam tender, in which passengers might enjoy a little of the comforts and decencies of civilised life. Companies, we are aware, have no conscience, butin their dividends, and it is simple folly to suppose that they will pay any attention to any interest but their own. Wo imagine however that in this matter the A.S.N. Com- pany has been somewhat short-sighted, The field would not have been so open for others to "cut in," and reap thc golden harvest, which this Company^ once had all to itself, and which it might have kept to itself perhaps to this day, had it looked less to im- mediate gainp, and more to tho conciliation of the goodwill and support of tho publie. We trust therefore a Company, whose same in spite of msny drawbacks, is still a household word in Queensland will use every effort to place their steam tender service on thc Fitzroy, on a footing in keeping, at once with their own name and tho requirements of tho port.

AT the Police Court yesterday, before the Police Magistrate, oue drunkard was cap- tioned and discharged. Ji uma Whitfield, who has been on remand for several days, charged with a similar offence, was also cautionod and discharged.

Mr. BURNS, of Messrs. Burns and Twigs, leaves in the launch Fairy to-night with atores, &c, f >r tho raen employed in the con- struction of thc Port Alma wharf. The bracing piles have been erected, and the work of fixing the permanent piles will shortly bo

commenced.

A SHORT time ago attention was drawn to the drinking fountain at the Post Office corner. It was damaged by a runaway cab horso, and the drinking cup broken off. Since then the Municipal Council have taken no steps to supply the missing link, and as a good many thirsty people use tho tap, the aldormen may be answerable for a number of sore lips.

WE mentiouod the fact of a dead bullock

having been left near Kalka C.eck to pollute the air, and have since learned the beast has not been removed. Wc arc assured thc polico are the proper persons to seo to thc removal of the animal, and they can afterwards claim tho cxpeuaos iucurred from the owner. Tho necessary information respecting thc owner- ship of tho dead boast can oasily be obtained.

Flto.M a southern paper wo notice that one of the musicians who carno to Australia with the Austrian Band has engaged ia a very novel enterprise for the public amusement. He is returning to Austria with forty live Kangaroos, and it is said ho has already caused a preliminary announcement to bo made in Vienna of a grand Kangaroo hunt to bo held under tho patronago nnd in the presence of the Empress of Austria, who is passionately fond of the chase.

Tw° bundrod and forty fats, from Moray and Elgin Downs, wera brought to Yaamba by Mr. P. M'Laughliu lately, and aro spelling there before leaving for Lake's Creek in charge of Mr. G. Cooper, for preserving pur- poses. Eighty-two fat bullocks, for preserving, from Zilzie, on account of Mr. W. Pattison ; fifty from Belmont, same owner; and 127 fats from Calliope Station, Mr. James Thomson

owner, Mr. Bobers in charge, arrived at Lake's Creek during the week.

A GENERAL meeting of shareholders of No. 7 Building Society was held in the offices of tho Secretary (Mr. B. L. Dibdin) on Tues- day afternoon, Mr, H. Schmidt, who occu pied the chair, explained the object of thc meeting was to elect a trustee in thc place of Mr. A. Feez, who had resiguod. Mr. Vcsper mann mored, and Mr. Bleicher soconded, that Mr. W. Allen be elected to the vacant posi- tion, which was agreed to, and tho meeting

then terminated.

TUE Gladstone pilot schooner Enid, in charge of Mr. Pilot Whitfield, arrived here the other day, having come round Cape Capri- corn to effect repairs. From constant usige her docks want repairing and caulking. Wo aro informed sbo will act in place of thc Fitzroy, which is disabled, and for some weeks to come Gladstone will bo without thc schooner. Thc pilot and crew have returned to Gladstone. The mon ara naturally dis- gusted at tho loss of their floating homo, as they incur the expenso of a shore residence.

THE usual fortnightly sittings of thc Small Debts Court wore held yesterday morning. There were only three undefended cases for hearing, viz.':-T. Jones v. W. M'Donald, value of a horse, £5 ; Ballass and Co. t>. P. Brown, work done. 18s. ; and Barns and Twigg v. Davis, work, £2 10s. In all the cases verdicts were given for the plaintiffs. In thc defended case of Tcagle «. W. Black, claim for work doni, £6 18?., a verdict was given for tho de- fendant with costs. The defended case of W. Jackson ». G. Ocstmann, for goods supplied, amounting to £2 5s., was adjourned until this morning, in order to enable tho defendant to produce evidence.

TOE usual monthly meeting of the Bcuovo Icnt Society was hîl.1 ia tho School of Arts yesterday afternoon, when there wore present : -Mesdames Ferguson (in the chair), Diggens, Fairbairn, Browne, Sutton, Buzacott, and Mills, and the Bev. W. A. Diggens, Bcv, B Hartley, and Mr. H. M ills. The minutes of tho previous mectint; wore read and confirmed Thc following district reports were road : No. 1 district, rclioved, adults 8, children 10, expenditure £4 13s. lld,; No. 2, relieved 3 adults, £1 Gs. 4il. ; No. 3, relieved, adults 4, children 10, £3 4j. 3.1. ; No. 4, rclioved, adults 2, children 3, 19s. 2.1. ; No. 5, relieved, adults, 0 ; children, 10, £0 12s. 51.; No. (j, relieve.!, adults, 5; children, 10, £2 8a. 7'l. The accounts iu connection willi tho Nursery were next road, and amounted to £5 Ss. 2J. Tho report of thc Benevolent Asylum for tho mouth of April was as follows :- Inmates during the mouth adults, 20 ; children, 8 ; admitted during tho month-adults, 3 ; children, 5 ; discharged adults, 4 ; children, 2 ; uumbcr of inmates adults, Ki; children, Ct. During thc niunth tliTO had been one birth and two death». Tho expenditure amounted to £3S '.ls. 2d.

The Committee acknowledged with thanks a parcel of clothiug from Mrs. Sydney Williams and another froiu a friend. The Kev. H. Hartloy moved and thc Hov. W. A. Degens seconded, that the reports as read be nd.iptcd. Some discussion tonk place with reference tn a caso in No. 4 district where a woman was receiving relief as lier husband was sick, refused lu work because she was «?"ly to get 4s. a day. Mr. Hanley in.ivc.I that nny woman who refused work when it was «iir.n: 1 ns in thc case iiii-nUoind should (jot nu further assistant from tho Society. Mrs. Fairbairn seconded the motion, which

was agreed to. The Treasurer's statement of j accounts wai read and deemed very catii

factory. Several accounts were pasBed for payment. It waa announced that the grocer for the ensuing quarter waa Mr. Kelly, and the chemist Mr. Ingham. Mesdames Sexton and Diggcns were appointod the Visiting Committee to the Asylum for tho month, and the meeting then terminated.

HERR BANDSIAJW and Company arrived in Rockhampton yesterday afternoon, and a bellman loudly proclaimed the "eminent tragedian " would appear in the Theatre. We belicvo " Hamlet " was performed, and that emotional drama was witnessed by a largo

audience.

YESTEMJAY afternoon clouds began to gathor in tho north-west, and about three o'clock a good thunderstorm, with rain, was expected. Bat in this wc were disappointed, for beyond a few drops of rain that fell between three and four o'clock there was no rain at all, and the clouds gradually dispersed.

WE understand the sadden extinguishing of the gas lights on Tuesday night was caused by one of the gasometers being allowed to run out before the full one was laid on. Ko public explanation has been afforded by the Gas Company, and most of their constituents arc quite in tho dark as to the absence of light in their premises on the night referred to.

BY the coast mail boat Inspector Isley, who is well known to many of our townspeople, arrived here yesterday, to assume command of the Police Force. He was accompanied by two black trackers, and as they are said to possess tracking powers of a remarkable character, they will prove a valuable acquisi-

tion to the district.

A MEETING of tho Fire Brigade Board was held yostcrday afternoon in Mr. Dibdin's office. Present :-Messrs. J. Ferguson (in tho chair), Sharples, Dibdin, and Hunter. Thc minutes of thc previous meeting were read and confirmed. The Chairman reported that the survey of the sito for the erection of a new

engine-house in Bolsover-strcet bad been made J by Mr. Bichardson, the District Surveyor,

and it would be forwarded to tho Government for their approval. Tho balance-sheet and roll-call of members were laid on thc table, and approved of. Mr. Wilson, architect, was in attendance, and handed in plans and esti- mates for the erection of a new engine-house, with a tower alongside, which was estimated to cost £500. It was decided to carry out the building in full accordance with thc plans submitted, and a eub-committoc, consisting of Messrs. Ferguson, Hunter, and Sharples, was appointed to superintend thc erection of tho building. It was also decided that a general inspection of the brigade should bo held on Monday, 14th May, at eight o'clock.

THE want of a Children's Hospital is fre- quently being illustrated, and especially in

connection with thc number of children who come herc with their parents as immigrants. Only tho other day we heard a man ask thc wardsmau if be could take bis child away if he was to find work. He was informed by thc wardsman that if the child was well

enough in the opiuion of the medical officer to bo removed, be could do so, but not unless this was so. Hero was a hard case-thc man, perhaps without a penny, and unable to take work in consequence ofhisnot being able to take his child away on account of its illness. It is not likely he would leave it in suck a place as the Dépôt, with no ono to tako care of it. What, then, had he to do but to wait till the child was lit to bo rcmovod, and then he might not bc able to procure work. Had

there been a Children's Hospital he could ;

have sent tho little one there, and left it there without any uneasiness until it was all right again. We have beard nothing with regard to the establishment of a Children's Hospital lately, but we mention these facts to show that the necessity for it continues to increase.

IT docs not say much for tho honesty and gratitude of thc new chums in tho Depot that they should have commenced to try tricks on tbe wardsman. Ho generally givcB out free passes every evening to those who Wi6h to go up thc lino the next morning in search of ! work. Those who have been in tho Dépôt a I certain length of lime cannot obtain thc

passes, and they get those who can to procuro them as if they wished to go up tho line. Tho next morning tho man who bas no right to the pass makes uso of it, and the ono whose name lt was out in is left behind. If tho pass is not used on the day on which it is issued it is no use, and tho immigrant knowing this comes to Mr. Beasley the evening that he should have gone in the morning, says he was unable to go,

and asks for another pass to go the next morn- i ing. It is probable this sort of thine bas been going on for some time, but tho wardsman has at length become quito as cute as thc " new chum," and bc will not give a second pass to

any one of them ou any pretence whatever, j In order that those who are innocent may not ' suffer by this strict action, wc advise them to inform Mr. Beasley as early as possible when they know they will be unable to proceed np tho linc on the morning they intended, and for which their pass was drswu out. m

WE understand tho Government has given instructions for the survey of a township on thc reserve between the Six and Sight Mile creeks, on tho Kockhampton-Gladstono Hoad. For some time past application was made both to the Gogango Divisional Board and the Minister for Lands for permission to erect stores and public-bouses on the Reserve, and although no opposition was offered to the erection of buildings, no permission could bo officially granted. A number of persons aro now residing in thc locality, nearly all thc land being selected. A large sawmill is in course of construction for Mr. 1*. Rgan, the contractors for which are Messrs. Burns and Twigg. When finished the mill will afford employment to a number of persons, as there is an almost inexhaustible supply of thc best hardwood near thc creek. The Kight-inile Creek, where thc mill is being erected, is navi- gable for miles, but tho land on the lower portion is nothing but mud flats. It was generally thought thc creek was a tributary of tho Fitzroy River, but persons who have been exploring it lately conclude thc creek as well as Mistake Creek, which enters Raglan Creek about four miles above Port Alma, is all ono. Our informant states thc want of horse accommodation is severely felt by travellers, as for a distance of eighty miles an tho road there is no calling place.

TIIK criminal sittings of the Maryborough Circuit Court were opoucd last Thursday before his Houor the Acting Chief Justice, and concluded ou Friday. Though there was a largo number of cases for hearing, they were got through mach more quickly than those beard at tlu late sittinqs of thc Court in Rockhampton. Mr. 1'. Heal acted as Crown Prosecutor. Of thc eleven prisoners tried only ouo was acquitted. Tho following sen- tences were inilicr.ed : --William St. dames, for stealing a horse, thc property of ,T. T. Amicar, two years' imprisonment with hard hiboar ; W. T. Hopkinson, fur stealing a marc, Ihe property of \V. ll.irnsnii, eighteen months' imprisonment willi hird labour; Harry Hirt, for larceny as a bailee of a sewing machine obtained on Hie tiuic-piyni jut system from W. Williams, twelve lu mlhs imprisonment with bani labnnr. Sarah Morrell, a youni! girl about Ki years »ld, fur tho larceny of £6

at Tiaro, six months' hard labour in thc

Toow.'oni'ia (raol ; \V. Anthony and Thomas Skilfius, for larceny of goo ls from Ranmy and C;».'s store at Mungan. Iwe-lve mouths' hard labour; Charles Mullo)-, for obtaining money limier faUc pretences, twelve numths' hard labour; .launs Stanley rf/m« Janies Wildon «fin Considine, f.ir f.irging and uttering, seven years' penal servitude ; llarrv Tcll.ie, for forbin ; nod uttering a etienne ntl Mr. Hooker, < ighlccli m.mills' hard labour ; Timothy Toomey, for forging and uttering a cheque at Gympie, two years' hard labour. Thomas Georgi! Summerly was charged willi embezzling the sums of £i 15s. and £1, the property of tho Singer Manu

factoring Company, but he was acquitted.

No bills were filed in the cases of William 1 Ahern, charged with wounding at Mount Perry ; Captain S. R. Thomas, charged with setting fire to the brig Janet Stewart at the Solomon Islands ; and \V*. L. Lynn, charged with shooting a mad kanaka on board a recruiting vcsBel. The civil sittings of the Court were concluded on Saturday, and thc Acting Chief Justice left Maryborough for Brisbane on Sunday morning last.

MR. E. MACARSE disposed of the right to erect a publican's booth at the forthcoming Gracemere Show on Tuesday to Mr. M. Mac- farlane for £17 10s., and the Tight to erect a fruit stall was sold to Mr. J. Dobbins for £2 5s.

IT will bo seen from our report of thc Divisional Board meeting held on Tuesday last, that on the motion of Mr. Macdonald a statement was laid on the table of the expen- diture in connection with thc roads at Yeppoon. As this document was not read at the meeting, and as tho Clerk declined to allow us to copy it without the authority of the Chairman, we were prevented from pub- lishing it in the report of the meeting, lt seams to have been obtained in some other way than through the proper authorities, and having appeared ia tho columns of our con- temporary, we have no hesitation in repro- ducing it. THE cricket match yesterday, between the Early Closing Club and a team of All comers, resulted rather disastrously for the former, who were beaten by an innings and G2 runs. Thwaites, for the victorious team, played a fine innings for 44, though ho was badly missed thc first ball. W. J. Bryan and Thwaites bowled with telling effect. CAPTAIN SVKES, Harbour Master, states i

reference to our paia'raph in yesterdays issue respecting the Kcilawarra s.s., that he received a message from Pilot Roberts at 9'30 on Tuesday night, through ono of the crew of the upper lightship, to tho effect " that tho Kcilawarra is ashore on the rocks abreast the black buoy below tho Upper Lightship ; her bow is on thc rocks and she is lying at right angles with the channel. The steam lauuch Ant ¡8 sunk in mid-channel off tho Keilawarra's position." Captain Sykes states bc proceeded at once to tho launch Mabel, which returned to the wharf when hailed. The message received from thc pilot was transmitted to the office of the steamboat agents. Captain Sykes emphatically denies that he said tho vessel was injured or making water, but he advised sending down punts to lighter tho vessel if she bad cargo on board. Captain Sykes and Captain Iîunter went to the Kcilawarra yester- day morning. The vessel floated off the bank at 0.30 a.m. without assistance, and Captain E. J. Boult telegraphed from Keppel Bay that tho vessel was in no way damaged. We understand the Kcilawarra, in proceeding down the river, overtook thc lausch Ant, which was towing thc schooner Fern outward. She cannoned off the end of a spit, and striking the Ant obliquely, tho latter sank, and tho Kcilawarra grounded on the north bank. The Ant lies in about seven feet of water at low tide, with about twenty inches over her highest part. Uer position is indicated by a dingy flying a red flag in thc daytime and at night time a white light is shown. The Ant will bo raised immediately tho necessary appliances can be obtained, lier crew Iud just time to clamber ou board the Fern which vessel was uninjured. Thc engineer eays that the last time he saw tho Ant he noticed the after cabin lockers were in thc aBhpit, so she must havo col- lapsed rather suddenly.

THE name of tho racehorse Mistletoe was inadvertently inserted among tho acceptances for tho Moreton Handicap yesterday.

IT will be noticed by an advertisement in another column that the water mains will be

closed on Friday for the purpose of making

new connections.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. THURSDAY, MAY 3, 1883.
