title: {'id': '77', 'value': 'Morning Bulletin (Rockhampton, Qld. : 1878 - 1954)'}

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27. 1883.

WITH more than ordinary interest our readers will peruse the Governor's Speech, delivered at the opening of Parliament on Tuesday last. Had it been a bona fide production of the putative author, we might have had a more concise and forcible document ; but as the expres- sion of the policy and contemplated administrative acts of the Ministry, lo be keenly criticised by the community, it

will bear full examination. On the two

great questions of colonial politics it utters no uncertain sound. Alter a few compli- mentary phrases about the late Governor, and the appointment of the coming one, and a little pardonable self-gratulation about the prosperity of the colony, the Speech adverts to the land grant railway questions. The agreement, which has been entered into, between the Governor and the Australian Transcontinental

Railway Syndicate, for the construction of a railway, in terms of the Railway Companies' Preliminary Act, from Charleville to Point Parker, will be sub- mitted for the approval and ratification of Parliament. So also will the Warrego Railway Bill. That these measures «viii

receive what the Governor solicits

"calm and dispassionate judgment"-is extremely improbable. The pub'lic mind has become unsettled in regard to ' them, and political feeling runs too high to permit of either being deliberately and dispassionately discussed. The fact that they are referred to in the opening paragraph of the.Speech favours the expectation that they will be sub- mitted to Parliament at an early date, and encourages the belief that Minis- ters attach the greatest importance to both measures. .' From the manner in which these railway schemes are referred bj) the inference is plain that their rejec- tion or acceptance will decided the fate qf the party now in power..

; The allusions to the annexation of New Guinea are not grandiose or ex- travagant, as they might have been in the circumstances. Charged with the responsible duty of not only main- taining the liberties and safety of the people of this colony, but of guarding the land of their adoption-an outlying portion of the British Empire-from the domination or danger of sudden invasion by a foreign foe, Ministers felt that they must keep a watchful eye on conterminous territory. New Guinea, it was apparent, might at any time become a source of annoyance and probable conflict ; and when rumours began to prevail, that it was coveted by France as a penal settlement, and by Germany as an eastern naval station, our rulers calmed their fears and anxieties by taking possession in the . Queen's name of the nearest land on

the island. Their conduct has

been variously regarded, but it ?has not been repudiated by the British Government, and in all probability will be confirmed. Their proceedings in this matter has caused Victoria to regard with similar appre- hensions the New Hebrides, and an united appeal has been made hy thc Colonial to the Imperial authorities to annex the Pacific Islands, which seem naturally to belong to Australia. Such acts display farseeing wisdom and prudence, which are worthy of the highest commendation in our statcmen.

On the Coloured Labour Question the Speech is pointed and clear in its remarks. The regulations, necessary under the old Act of 1SÓ2, and which must be concurred in by the Indian Government, and the Colonial Parlia- ment, before they can he acted upon, have now been agreed to. They also will bc submitted for consideration and approval. The policy of the Govern- ment on this question is simple and plain. They favour the introduction of Coolies, because by this means they will provide a safeguard against the injurious competition with white labour of the Chinese and Kanakas, besides removing the stigma which attaches to Queensland for cultivating the labour trade and perpetuating a species of slavery. Thc paragraph on this subject is most suggestive, and deserves the careful con- sideration of the wage-earning classes of the community. It indicates a decided policy, in striking contract with the nihilism of the Leader of the Opposition OD this subject,

'*'N^drnra|dîate action is to be taken on

the land question, but the Government

èçM t? §M%?t no ordinary significance tèvealeaTry the report of the Under- secretary for Lands. Selection is going on rapidly in this colony, but agriculture is making slow progress. The inference is plain that dummying and jobbing by selection is attaining noticeable magni- tude, which will presently call for a remedy.

Promises are made that public works, giving employment to the labouring classes, will be pushed forward, and our mail and emigration services via Torres Straits improved to meet the demands upon them. It is pointed out that though the finances of the colony are in a prosperous condition, and there will probably be a handsome surplus at the close of the year, more money must be borrowed to carry on public works and immigration, and make provision for the redemption of a million pounds sterling of debentures presently falling due.

A Re-distribution of Seats Bill is promised, but only if other business shall permit of its being thoroughly con- sidered, and its details arranged. Some time ago we pointed out that such a measure was now due, and that it was the privilege of the Conservative party, acting on former precendents, to pass it. The census returns and statistics of immigration have no doubt put the Government in possession of facts, which should have enabled them to prepare a fair and comprehensive measure. It is greatly to be desired they should launch it, and guide it through the stormy sei of debate, rather than lamper with the subject in an Additional Members Bill, which, how ever necessary and fair, will be open to misconstruction and opposition.

Many of the measures prenvsed in the concluding paragraph have already been approved by the Council or the Assembly, in and consequence they should not occupy much of the time or

attention of Parliament. None of them

is of such an impirtant character that its postponement till another session will seriously interfere with the interests of any large class of the community.

Comprehensive, sufficiently decided to indicate the policy of Ministers, the Governor's Speech will at once satisfy and stimulate expectation.

AMONG the important public papers issued in anticipation of the meeting of Parliament, is the Annual Report of the Commissioners for Railways for 1882.. It is not a concise condensed record, but consists of a series of re- ports on the different railways in the colony. The general statements are grouped in a conluding paragraph. The Report will not fail to attract unusual attention at present, as capitalists, who may have been considering the propriety of investing in Transcontinental Railway stock, will be anxious to learn how the present railways are paying. The year to which the Report refers was a prosperous one, and from the increase in business and traffic connected therewith

the railways should be paying well. On turning to the terminal paragraph of the report we find that with the exception of the Bundaberg Railway all our lines have been yielding interest on the money expended on them. The amount of capital expended on open lines is .£6,244,682, and the net earnings yielded last year interest at the rate of ,£3

ns. id. per cent, or 18s. i^d. more, than in 1881. The most remunerative ¡ railway is the Northern, which last year paid £4 14s. 6d. per cent interest, or 13s. less than in 1881. Next comes the Central Railway, which earned £4 Ss. sd. per cent, being an increase of ios. 4yíd. On the Southern and Wes- tern Railway the profits gave £3 6s. 8d. per cent, or an increase of £1 is. 8d. On the Maryborough Railway there was a falling off during the year from £5 i2s. o^d. to .£3 9s. 6d. The increase

is gratifying, but when we look at the amount of money expended, the rate at which the resources of the colony are being developed, it is not greater than might be expected. There is reason for solid satisfaction in the fact that

the earnings on our railways compare favourably with those made by lines in the other colonies. The percentage of profit from those in Queensland is 3-ss ; in South Australia, 2-57 ; in New Zea- land, 3"9i ; in Victoria, 4/04 ; in New South Wales, 5-31. In the United King domjthe average interest earned is 4-33 per cent., and that amount our railways shall yield next year, if the development of traffic continues to progress at the present rate.

The amount of money expended on our railways in 1882 was £566,08$ from loan, and ,¿¿242,131 from revenue. The expenditure from revenue for en- gineers, traffic, and locomotive depart-

ments on the several lines was-Southern

and Western, ,£151,229 ! Maryborough, ,£14,705 ; Hnndaberg, ,£6,672 ; Central, ,£52,824; Northern, ¿16,698. Thc

revenue from the principal lines has been as follows : - Southern

and Western, £130,231 ; Central Railway, ¿63,244; Northern Railway, £16,222. The expansion of the Rail- way Department, and the encrcased business done, the Commissioner for Railways points out, are indicated by "an increase of I2'i4 per cent(of*tS*!$ open for traffic ; an increase of 4ri 2 per cent (371,763 miles) in the train miles run; an increase of 4368 per cent (174,764 tons), in thegoods conveyed; an increase of 10477 per cent (259,080) in the number of passenger tickets issued ; an increase of 17'52 per cent (9420) in the number of bales of wool carried ; an increase of 33-15 pei cent, (£115,570) in the gross earnings ; an increase ol 23-99 per cent (£46,852) in the working ex- penditure; an increase of 10-94 per cent (7) in the locomotive stock ; an in- crease of 14-29 per cent (13) in passenger vehicles, and an increase of 16-47 Per cent (143) in goods and oilier vehicles."

From a comprehensive table included in the report we learn that the number of miles of railway open in the colony in 1SS2 was 898, 97 having been opened in the course of the year, and 340 being under construction. The cost per mile

opened was ¡£6954. The total earnings was ,£464,160, and the expenditure ,£242,131. The average earnings per' train mile run was 7s. 3#d.; on the Central Railway theearniugs was 8s. io J^d per mile. The average working expenses were 3s. 9 J^d.; on the Central Railway 4s. o j^d. The per centage of working expenses to earnings was smallest on thc Central Railway, where it amounted to 45*51; while the average for the colony was 52'17.

No serious accident occurred on any of our railways in 1882 ; but that is not a remark the Commissioner will be privileged to make next year. The Sandgate Railway accident will call for comment and ex- planation in next report. It is far from satisfactory to find the Com- missioner complaining about the want of rolling stock for the Bundaberg and Maryborough lines. The same com- plaint might be made about the supply of passenger carriages for the Central Railway. On holiday occasions, when a demand is made by Sabbath School children, or any large number of the public upon the railway, the deficiency of carriages at once becomes apparent, During last year only seven engines and thirteen carriages were added to the rolling stock of our railways, though nearly a hundred miles had been opened for traffic. List year the number of

locomotives was increased from fourteen

to sixteen ; but only one passenger carriage has been added since 1880. With the exception of cattle waggons, the number of which has been increased from six to twelve, there has been no material additions to the rolling stock of the Central Railway for the last three years. The recently made new waggons, &c, were urgently called for.

WE are informed by the Treasurer of the Hospital that the collections at St. Paul's Church on Sunday last amounted to £18

lCs. 9d.

MR. J. WILLIAMS' racehoraoB Satirist, Wheatmeat, and Fisherman arrived yesterday afternoon by tho s B. Derwent, in charge of thoir trainer, J. Hughes. The horses were got safely ashore, apparently none thc worse for their sea trip. Tiley are now quartered at Tully's Sportsman's Arius Hotel.

FOUR of the sailors of the Circe were arrested yesterday afternoon for disobedience of orders. Their names are Charles Olsen, W. J. Grey, Martin Fell, and Robert Muir. Some little trouble was experienced in arrest- ing them. Four policemen prooceded on board, and two of the sailors agreed to go along quietly, but the others, who resisted, were handcuffed. They were, however, brought safely to the lockup.

THIS afternoon there will be a cricket match

played at North Rockhampton, between teams under tho captaincy of Messrs, 6. H. Church and O. W. T. Moffat. Flay to commence at 2-30 Bharp. Moffat's Eleven: G. VV. T. Moffat, J. J. M'Dermott, T. Higson. W. Baird, H. Prior, F. Barton, Cohen, R. Morri- son, J. Higgins, Sullivan, D. M'Pberson. G. H. Church, 0. Steele, A. Palmer, W. Jackson, J. Bryan, J. Williams, li. M. ¿ber- deen, J. H. Church, M. Doolan, W. Whitman,

R. W. Holden.

WE noticed yesterday that the wail of the lookup keeper's house here has given way, and looks as if it would fall in at any time. An examination of the interior of tho bnilding shows that the wall is craoked in several places. It gave way suddenly 011 Sunday morning to such an extent that tho lockup keeper IB unable to open the front door. It is hoped that something will at once bo done to remedy thc present condition of the building, as it is unsafe for a person to sleep in such a

place.

,/ THE annual tea meeting ia connection with rthe~~B«pti8t Church took place lost night.

There was a large attendance at the tea, which ?was provided by the members of thc church,

and superintended by tfje ladies. The church

was nicely decorated with flowers and ever- greens, and over the pulpit was the word " Welcome." After full justice had been done to the excellent tea provided the church was cleared, and a puhlic meeting was held. The Rev. G. Slade occupied the chair, and there were on the platform, the Hevs. A. Hay, T. Jones, D. Mossop, R. Hartley, and W. H. Williams. Tho meeting was commenced by thc singing of a hymn, and prayer by the Hov. lt. Hartley. The Chair- man delivered a suitable address, thanking those present for their attendance. He called on the Secretary to read tho report and balance-sheet. Mr. A. Card read tho report, which showed that during tho year thc church had steadily aud unostentatiously proceeded with its work iu all branches, and was able to report that steady perseverance in good doing had been rewarded with encouraging success. The roll of membership had boen perceptibly increased, whilst thc cougrogation also had received marked accessions in point of numbers. The admis- sions to the church during the year by confession of faith had been five, and by transfer from sister churches in England and tlic colony thirteen. The Sabbath Schools both in Dcnison-strcet and North Rock- hampton had made satisfactory advances. Owing to migration the congregation at North Rockhampton which had been decreased in numbers had of late exhibited an encouraging increase in thc attendance. The Baptist periodical still met with a cordial reception from the members of the church and congre- gation. Tho Treasurer's statement would show the need of increased liberality on the part of those interested, ami it was hoped that when the next Treasurer's statement was presented it would ho of a more encouraging nature. Thc young men of the Church bad formed a union of a most important nature, and the ladies' sewing meetings had also been success- fully carried on. Much of the succoss was duo to the indefatigable labours of tho Rev. G. Slade. lu concision the report expressed a hope that the successes of the past year might urge members to increased zeal and devotion to thc Master's cause, and thus lead to greater aud moro glorious results in thc future, Tho balance-sheet showed that at thc end of thc last church year there was an over- draft of £S3 2s. Cd., and tho expenditure during tho last year was £324 2s. I0J. The receipts were £304 7«. 2d., thus showing a deficit for the year of £19 15s. 8d., anil an indebtedness of £102 6s. 2,1. Out of the donations, amounting to £72, £70 bad been given by one member of tho church, Thc report of the Young Men's Mission showed that about six months ago n few younjj men met toji tbcr nt thc Kev. (i. Slade's house, and tho idea of forming themselves into a hand was gladly received, rul«s were made, and a president, treasurer, and secretary chosen. At the start the re were nine members, but two of them left thc town shortly after, and now thc num- ber could be doubled. At that time ono cottage and n Sunday morning prayer meeting were held, which were well attended, and during thc Inst few months thirj wore eood discussions, reading*, and OHsays, together willi a concert and coffee supper, nil nf which were well att. ii lc I. Ai ti m S-.Í.H1 they willie! In rank first in Rock- hampton ; und tn do thc work that was necessary it was desirable to have a hall, a reading room, au amusement room, a cricket club, aud a codee room. AU that required money, whioh was ueoesaary if the mission was

to go ahead. If that wag provided it wat hoped that ia tbs next annual report they would be able to say the association woola pot only be a light to Rockhampton, but that its influence would have extended far and wide. Addresses were delivered by the reverend gentlemen au the platform, and anthems were sung in excellent style by the choir to the accompaniment of Miss Davis on the harmonium. During the evening a collection was made on behalf of the church.

THE latest arrivals of stock at Lake's Creek are-20S head of fats from Mr. E. G. Wood, Calliungal station, owner in charge. The cattle are for preserving, and reported to be a primo lut. A mob of 200 from MesBrs. Berkelman and Lambert, Fitzroy Vale, in charge of Mr. W. Coleman, are expected to arrive nt Lake's Creek to-day. They are for preserving purposes.

A SQUABBLE occurred between two sailors last night, but they were quietened before the police arrived. A constable interrogated one of the men* as to what bad happened. He WOB

informed the other man had insulted bim. Thc constable then told the man to go home and kicked him off the pavement into thc gutter. This is not the correct method of dealing with brawlers while a lock-up is near at hand, and the constable should be taught his duty.

THERE arrived by the Derwent, s.s., yester- day, a two-year- old* draught stallion named Rüther Glen by Sir Colin (imp.), a pure bred Clydesdale, out of Jean hy Pride of Scotland (imp). Thc dam is prize taker in New Zealand, and her stock hauy proved success- ful. Rüther Glen was bred by Mr. Thomas Porker, of Otago, New Zealand, and pur- chased in Sydney by Mr. H. ll. Bamnan, of Tryphnia Valo station, near Dingo, and from his appearance tho colt should prove a volu- tion addition to tho stock of the district.

EDWARD LAWN, cabdriver, met with an accident on Monday afternoon, by which ho had his left collar bone broken, WSB bruised on thc back part of the head and sustained a slight concussion of the brain. He was driving along Denisonstreet, when the horse shied at one dray and collided with another.

Lawn was thrown from the box seat and

received the injuries mentioned. A passenger on the cab stopped the horse after it bad gone a few yards. The only injury to the cab was the breakage of a lamp. Lawn was taken to his residence in Alma-lane, where he was attended to by Dr. Poland,

Two gentlemen were rowed off to a steam boat lying in mid-stream, and having com- pleted their business, were left in charge of the boat to come ashore. They were both well up in shipping matters, but were un- accustomed to thc uso of the oars. The result was that they pulled in a most erratic manner for about two hours, and BB there was a strong tide running it eventually landed them, not at tho Corporation Wharf, the point they started for, but near the Rocks. They got ashoro after footing it through tho mud. They intend joining a rowing club to acquire experience in the use of tho sculls.

A Mon of blacks camped at thc back of the Hospital a few nights sinco and made such a row that the patients were unable to get sufficient rest. Information was given to the police, who at once routed them, Our atten- tion has been direoted to the fact that there have been a number of blacks camped at the corner of Denham and Denison Streets, near the Victoria Stores, and though they do not create a disturbance, they are not very desirable neighbours. Of course they are camped where there are a number of Chinese who supply them with opium. Tho police ought to clear them outside the boundaries

of the town.

THE dredge Saurian (says thc Maryborough Chronk'e of Saturday) is eipeotcd to finish during the ensuing week thc cutting near tho mouth of tho river, to which lier operations were limited by thc Harbours and Rivers Department. Wo may therefore look for her early departure for Rockhampton. Putting on ono siilo for thc present any comment on the " sham " which has been perpetrated by the Government in connection with the six months' probationary work in the Mary river, wc may call attention to the fact that the work done by the Saurian is

practically worthless unleBs a little more

is undertaken. It is not too much to ask that the Saurian be detained for six weeks or so longer, to dredge a shingle bar so as to afford an ordinarily safe paBsage for thc steamers which now daily enter or leave this port. The spot is doubtless well-known by the harbour authorities, as it is too well known by the shipmasters trading hither, and we deem it simply our duty to throw out thc foregoing suggestion,

THE fresh plans for thc proposed lock-up and police quarters at North Rockhampton aro on view at the Clerk of Petty Sessions' office. In the first plan it was intended thc structure should bc of brick, but no one ten- dered, and thc presont specification contains details respecting a wooden building with a galvanized iron roof. Thcro will bc a sitting aud dining room, with two bodrootns for the senior-constable's quarters. The other por- tion of the building will consist of a con- stable's bedroom, and two cells for the accommodation of prisoners, A verandah will run the length of the bui'ding, and another will abut on thc back quarters. Tho plan shows no kitchen or bathroom, the latter a necessary convenience in tho tropics. There are fire-places in tho sitting and dining rooms, and the cooking may he done in either of those. A tank at thc rear of the building, estimated to contain 1000 gallons of water, will provide an ample supply for domestic pur- poses. On paper the building looks very complete, and will provo a handsome addition to the north Bide.

THERE was a very good attendance at the Theatre Royal last night, Donizetti's opera "Lucrczia Borgia" being the attraction. The grand music in this opera afforded an oppor- tunity of the ability of tho Montague-Turner troupe to render a heavy work'in an adequate style. Thc argument is not of nn entertaining character on account nf its tragio inci- dents, Lucrczia Borgia being oompollcd by her husband to poison her illegitimate son Gennaro. Miss Montague, in the title rule, appeared to great advantage, her acting in each scene being excellentand in keeping with tho character. Her vocalism was quite a treat, and in the.lighter arias, such OB in the slumbering scene with Gennaro, sho was much appreciated. In thc duct with thc Duke and thc lina! act where Gennaro dies, M ¡SB Montague wns rapturously applauded. Mr. Turner was somewhat hoarse in thc opening seine, but this wore off and he Bang thc remainder of tho music with much taste

and feeling, Mr. Browning made a very im posiug Duke and his rich baritone voice had full display in tho Vendetta song. Miss Saville dressed the part of Maffeo Orsini effectively anil was rewarded with plaudits for the drinking song "Il Segrctto " which she sung with good effect. Of thc minor characters Mr. Kncland ns Gubctta and Mr. Balfour as llustighello vero pro- minent and did good service. The choruses were excellently sang, nod tho dresses and stage accessories in keeping with thc perfor- mance of thu opera, which was a pronounced success. To-niidit Maritana will be repented, and as thc li^ht"music which runs through it is in favour a largo attendance is expected. Tho Comp my announce Saturday night for thc last pcrfurniaucu.

Wi: have received a memo from a corres-

pondent aniline us lo contradict n statement wu made iii reference to tin: petitiou for a municipality for North limkh.iiupton. Our correspondent says thc pclitinn is numerously signed. This we cati ^uite believe, hut wc fail to eeo that because thia is so our notice of it ii incorrect, As a matter of fact the

petition bas not been taken round (or signature

for the reason stated by us.

THE purchasers of tickets in the "Wizard's" eensultatiou on the Rockhampton Handicap, are requested tn call for sams without delay, aa the drawing will positively take place next week. A few remaining tickets for sale.

ADVT.

IT will be seen from onr advertising celumnB that Mr. Cr. S. Curtis will sell by auction, to-day, a large consignment of New Zealand timber of various scantlings. Builders and others must be prepared to offer fair prices, for it seems there is a danger of the growing timber trade with New Zealand being

starved out. We have been informed that shippers of thu timber are thinking of with- drawing from this market unless better prices can be obtained than have recently been ruling. We hope that such will not be the case, as the reBult would certainly be that prices would again advance, and prove an obstacle to those of small means erecting cottage residences. A cargo of kauri timber, shipped for this market per Devenport, has been diverted to Melbourne in consequence of the unfavourable reports of thc sales mado here. The brigantiue Sea Bird, upwards of two hundred tons burden, will be Bold at the wharf to day.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1883.
snippet: WITH more than ordinary interest our readers will peruse the Governor's Speech, delivered at the opening of Parliament on Tuesday last. Had it been a bona

articleText:
KOCK. HAMPTON.

TUIiSDAY, AUGUST 21, 1883.

THE electors of the Leichhardt district have had the views of the candidates

soliciting their suffrages fairly placed before them, and need have no difficulty in determining for whom they will vote. They are not left in any doubt as to the political faith of the gentlemen emulous of representing them. Mr. Scott does not conceal the fact that he is a Government man, and he does not shirk from declaring that he will give them his support in their projected I schemes for the promotion of the pros-

perity of the colony. Rather than that I the colony should be slowly sadled with- an enormous burden of debt, he will agree to the construction of railways on the land-grant principle. In coming to this conclusion, Mr. Scott is acting prudently and wisely. In recognising the principle he is admitting, what so many candidates fail to see, there is a power of good in the system. This [ was so generally recognised, when thc

Railway Companies Preliminary Bill was before Parliament, that it is difficult to understand the great antagonism that is shown to it now, in any other way than by concluding it has been fostered for selfish or party purposes. The idea of paying for railways with our waste lands commended such a system to everyone.

Mr. Griffith said the main point to be looked to was, thal the enhanced value of the land near the railway so made, was equal to the bonus given for its con- struction. Other prominent members of the Opposition spoke strongly in favour of the principle. Now, the objection has been raised, that the system would lead to the formation of large freehold estates ; but that is a mere speculation. The proprietors of the

alternate blocks would not retain them for their own use. They would dispose of them in such a way that the traffic on the railway would be promoted by their occupation, either as arable farms, sheep runs, or mineral lands. The line-owners, for their own interest, would see that . the country was put to the best uses possible. As we have already remarked, land-grant railways may be made on terms highly advantageous to the colony, and un- accompanied by the dangers which the opponents of the system imagine. Mr. Scott is liberal in his ideas on the coloured labour question, and, rather than our rising and most important agricultural industry should perish, he would permit the employment of Coolies. He points out how at any time, should difficulties arise, the importation of this class of workers could at once be put a slop to. The debt under which the colony lies to the present Administra- tion for their management of our finances, is a subject on which some of their firiends have had nothing to say on this occasion, and Mr. Scott does well in calling attention to the obligations of the electors in this matter. When we have the financial affairs of an older and richer colony in such a state, that the working men ol the capital admit there is no other way out of their troubles save by taxation, we

must give great credit to our Govern- ment for their management of the finances. Though Mr. Scott has not much interest in the Leichhardt now he is a local man. He is bound up in its affairs by many old associations, and his

claims on the electors are of such a

character, we feel confident they will not

be overlooked, and that he will be re- I

turned at the head of the poll. I

Mr. Dutton comes forward as an opponent of the land-grant principle, as applied to railway construction, and as

an exponent of the new gospel on the ¡ land question. This candidate takes an unfair advantage of his Ministerial opponent, by importing the terms of the Agreement on the Transcontinental Railway Scheme into thc discussion.

These are not before the electors. Par- liament condemned that scheme. It has been withdrawn ; and it is evidently unjust in Mr. Dutton lo dwell upon it in the way lie has been doing. His objec- tion that land-grant r.iilways would lead to the formation of large estates is more reasonable ; but it comes with strange awkwardness from a man who propanes the leasing ol land in blocks of 20,000 acres. Such a proceeding nt present would go a long way to the aggregation of these large estates, the formation of which he dreads. Mr. Dutton would

not alienate any portions ol the public estate. He would substitute a system of leasing. Henry George and Russell

Wallace have found in him an earnest -

disciple, and he is entitled to credit lor the disingenuous w.ty he advocates the system. It looks well in theory,

i but Mr. Dutton must see there is

this danger in his scheme, that when leaseholders have entered on th .se 20,000 acre blocks he speaks of, they will use their all-powerful interest to obtain pre-emptive rights to the land ; they will return representatives pledged i to maintain them ia their holdings ; and

in this way they will upset the leasing system. It has been stated in some quarters that this greater fixity of tenure, and increase of pastoral tents, are only advances towards the ultimate appropria- tion of our western lands. There are other dangers connected with the radical change in our lind system, proposed by Mr. Dutton, Tvhicli must make the electors very chary about giving it their support. Mr. Dutton speaks in qualified language as to the introduction of Coolies, and would confine them to sugar plantations if they are allowed to come at all. Having large interests in the district Mr. Dutton possesses claims on the electors, which are entitled to their favourable consideration.

Both Mr. Scott and Mr. Dutton are gentlemen of independent means, who will be able to give their time and attention to the political interests of the constituency, without fear or favour. They are their own masters. As much

cannot be said of Mr. raul. He would, no doubt, as far as he could serve the constituency : but it is for the electors to consider whether he would be entirely free of the influence of the company or syndicate, with which he is associated. Besides, circumstances might arise which would ' necessitate his departure for New South Wales again, and no one can say when a new election might be- come necessary. Mr. Paul's views on the political questions of the day are not such as should commend him to the electors of the Leichhardt. On the land-grant railway principle his senti- ments are analagous to those of Mr. Dutton ; and his strong opinions on the Coolie question will not be shared by electors, who have no need for coloured labour. It is idle for Mr. Paul to attri- bute our present prosperity entirely to a succession of good seasons, when he knows the colony has been able to benefit from them to a greater extent, in consequence of our Mail Service, and careful management of the finances and public works of the colony, than it would otherwise have done. Providence pro- vided the means of prosperity, and the Ministry-who are not by any means "angels from heaven"-have enabled all classes to take full advantage of them.

It is for the electors to consider what connection Mr. Paul has with the Leich- hardt district now;."and wTiether in returning him thïywill not be placing their representation at the command of a southern company of capitalists, anxious, by all means, to promote their own interests.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1883.
snippet: THE electors of the Leichhardt district have had the views of the candidates soliciting their suffrages fairly placed before them, and need have no difficulty

articleText:
«OCiyfÁMr'TON.

FBJÓAY. AUGUST 31, 1883.

PVsr Liberal contemporaries are be- ginning to " hallo before they are out of the wood": they are "counting their chickens before they are hatched." In other words, before one half of the elec- tions are over, they are beginning to j count the majority by which the Ministry ! will be defeated when Parliament re 1 assembles. Such a procceedirjg will mislead very few people, and if it pleases I our contemporaries to engage in it we have no objections. At the same time they anticipate that Mr. Griffith will be able to form a capable Ministry, and will inaugurate a public policy fraught with great good to the community. We wish we could share such anticipations, for there can be no doubt the colony desires a change of Government, and it is always possible for a new party in power, follow- ing the direction indicated by public opinion, to devise ne«' and commendable schemes. When we look to the leader of the Opposition himself, we cannot recognise that the colony has in him a master-mind, capable of devising administrative measures, such as the New Mail Service has proved to be, for the development of the material interests of the colony. The hon. gentleman has never shown that he possesses the inventive faculty, which, when the occasion demands, enables the person endowed with it to form plans, and carry them out to a suc- cessful fulfilment. Critical ability is the strong feature in Mr. Griffith's character, but we all know it is much easier to point out the weakness of a

scheme or a measure, than to construct

the one or draw the other. He will ¡ probably himself take the position of

Colonial Secretary, which will involve ¡ attention to the affairs of immigration, I i registration, police, prisons, boards of j

i health, lunacy, &c. From his know- j ' ledge and experience of public affairs,

the hon. gentleman should be able to '

administer the department effectively, j

but the demands on his time and atten- ' tion in connection with these matters will be made in addition to the pressure

arisim; from his position as head of thc j Government, and supposing he leaves j

his professional practice altogether

neglected. It is not to be expected, we : think, that the hon. gentlemen shall re- j ceive much assistance from his prospec- j tive colleagues. As to their earnestness j

and good intentions, we have not the smallestdoubt,andonlywish thcirabilities were equal to these. Mr. Dickson did not distinguish himself as Treasurer, for when he entered upon office in 1876 there was a surplus in the public accounts of .£67,714; in the following year it was reduced to £15,291 ; and the first year the present Administration were in office the Treasury had been so exhausted lhere was a deficit of ;£z 16,807, Either Mr. Garrick or Mr.

Rutledge will make a respectable Attorney-General, but we look in vain for gentlemen on the Opposition side capable of administering either the Department of Lands or Works. Mr. Mein will fill the office of Postmaster General with advantage to the com- munity, and credit to his party.

While we do not anticipate from the ptrsonel of the coming Ministry they will he capable of great things, we can find little for congratulation in the pro- gramme, which Mr. Griffith laid before the country at the beginning of the present election contest. It is con-

tended that he is not bound to show his hand till he is called upon to play, but he seems to have been of a different

opinion. What is the meaning of his message to the constituencies, as his election Address may be called, if it does not foreshadow very plainly the works policy he intends to pursue. It seems to be concluded by our opponents that the land-grant rail- way principle, and the coloured labour question, have been consigned in thc meantime to the limbo of condemned schemes ; but the country may depend upon it they will not be allowed to re- main dormant for long. The land-grant principle has not been abandoned. Sir Thomas M'Uwraith has declared it shall form a prominent plank of his platform in the future ; and, when the necessity for its application becomes more ap- parent, the electors will educate them- selves, and have a better understanding of how it may be applied with advantage to promote the affairs of this colony. The sugar interest, again, is too large and important to suffer obstruction by the intervention of legislative restrictions of the kind proposed. If planters cannot get Coolies they will import Chinese, and a steady stream of these will soon tell, not only on the sugar industry, but

on every other in the colony. Those who speak in an indefinite way of Mr. Griffith having great things in store for tis, roust have forgot that on the main topics of political interest he has already formulated his views, and indi- cated his policy. He tells us himself that two of the most urgent questions, which can engage the attention of the electors in a young and undeveloped country ol large extent like Queensland, are emigration, and the means of com- munication. With regard to the first of these, he proposes to introduce white labour al the rate of about forty thousand persons annually. As the vast majority of immi- grants come here without capital, and without the means of taking up land and "bccupying it, employment for them must be lound on public works. The colony will, therefore, have to Providern, immense sum of moneytoja^rf^oiir in this way, and ^tffTarger sums to furnish it with enjoyment, if it is to be retained jp viii colony. This outlay, it is calefied, will be met by the increased r£KSiue an dutiable goods-that is to

say on spirits chiefly. It must be perfectly plain, however, to any one, who looks beyond the immediate future, to see that such a policy is fraught with roany evils. It will tend to fill the country with people de- pendent on Government for their daily bread. They will look to the central authorities for employment, and will place and retain in power those who are most liberal in providing occupation for them. Evidences of the evils

attending this system exist here already, and their multiplication ought not to be encouraged. Of course, it may be con- tended that settlement will keep pace with the expenditure on immigration and public works, but that seems to be ex- ceedingly doubtful. Observation of what has taken place already does not go far to warrant such an expectation. It is not a thing that can be relied on with

! any degree of certainty as to its fulfil- ment. There is as much reason to apprehend danger as advantage from it.

j Such immigration, moreover, as Mr.

Griffith proposes, will not meet the demand for labour, which proceeds (rom our most promising industry. The im : portation, therefore, of what may be

regarded, to a considerable extent, as unproductive labour, may be attended with very serious consequences. Then, with regard to means of communica- tion-the other great question to which Mr. Griffith refers-his views will not commend them to the electors, for they are vague and indefinite. He

declares that the trunk lines must be carried further west, and at the same time confesses coast lines are urgently needed. The former he will carry orr by means of loans, if he can raise the money ; the latter by a guarantee system. He adopts the policy of his political opponents, and substitutes a guarantee for land-grants, in connection with the western extensions. Having let the electors into his confidence on these matters, Mr. Griffith cannot get away from them. He must embody his views in any scheme he may propound. They may be more attractive when explained and discussed at some length, but in the meantime, we look upon them with little hope, and less confidence.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. FRIDAY, AUGUST 31, 1883.
snippet: OUR Liberal contemporaries are beginning to " hallo before they are out of the wood": they are "counting their chickens before they are hatched." In

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1883.

THOSE of our citizens, who, on Sunday

last heard a rumour that several of the

recent arrivals by the mail steamer Duke of Westminster, and immigrant ship Nebo, had been taken to the Hospital, smitten with small-pox ; and who gave ready credence to the story, evidently had a correct and well-grounded apprehension of what might have been the case. They were evidently alive to the danger of the situation. It is greatly to be re- gretted, we think, that the authorities, on whom we depend to protect us from such a calamity, are not equally alive to the critical circumstances in which this community has been placed. We are quite prepared to hear at any moment that small-pox has broken out in our midst, or that it has been carried to some of our inland townships, and is commit- ting havoc among both black and white men, beyond the area of ordinary medical practice. The apathy of the central authorities, with regard to the danger to which we have been exposed, contrasts very unpleasantly with the activity and determination they have manifested in protecting themselves. The Duke of Westminster, with the sick surgeon on board, reached Brisbane early on Tuesday morning. Imme- diately upon its being discovered that Dr. Woodward was ill, and that there was a suspicion of small-pox, the utmost precautions were used. The ship was quarantined; the immigrants were trans- ferred to Peel Island ; and the medical officer and his attendants to Bird Island.

There they will be kept till all danger be past. In the meantime, however, a large consignment of immigrants had landed at Rockhampton. They were brought up on Sunday even- ing, and at once mingled freely with the immigrants from the ship Nebo, who were then in the Immigration Depot. It must have been perfectly well known to the Immigration and Health Officers in Brisbane that this was the case. Nevertheless, though it has been de-

clared that Dr. Woodward is suffering   from virulent small-pox, though every

care has been taken to guard against an  

outbreak in Brisbane, absolutely nothing

has been done to keep us clear of the   disease, or prevent its dissemination. Our Acting Health Officer has not

received a word of warning or advice.   Commenting on the case on Wednesday  

the Brisbane Courier said :

" The arrival of tho mail steamer Duke of Westminister with small-pox on board is a serious event. If we are correctly informed,

that no health officer visited the steamer in

Keppel Bay, there was culpable negligence on the part of the officer entrusted with the duty of inspection. It appears that Dr. Woodward, the doctor of the Duke of West minster, who is now unmistakably suffering from small-pox, was unwell when she arrived in Keppel Bay, and the passengers for Rock- hampton were being disembarked, but it was not till after they had been landed that the eruption declared itself. Had the health

officer visited the vessel, he would probably have seen cause to delay the landing, and thus avoided the danger which now exists, that contagion may have been conveyed to the community in Rockhampton. It is evi- dent now that Dr. Woodward was in the first stage of the disease when the steamer arrived in Keppel Bay - a stage at which it is at least possible that the invalid may infect others. At the same time the symptoms of the disease are not at that period sufficiently marked to make its diagnosis certain. The sufferer may have had a suspicion of the true nature of his complaint, but being unsupported by the presence of the officer, whose duty it was to guard against thc importation of infectious disease, he may have shrunk from incurring the grave responsibility of stopping the land- ing of the immigrants. The extent of the mischief done - if any - depends of course on the manner in which Dr. Woodward himself, caught the disease. If he, as is supposed, was infected at Batavia, the contagion may have been confined to his own person ; and the precaution-which we presume will be taken - of gathering and isolating the immi- grants at Rockhampton, will be sufficient to insure the colony against the spread of the disease. If, on the other hand, a number of passengers were exposed to the same chances of contagion, wc may hear of the disease making its appearance in the other coast towns, which received batches of immigrants by the Duke of Westminister."

On Friday the Courier modified "its statements regarding the supposed direliction of duty by the Health officer at Rockhampton. It then explained that the fault, which has exposed us to our present danger, lies not with the health officer at this port, but with the Department. The rule now is that a steamer arriving at a northern port is there inspected, and then passes down, as a coasting steamer, without further inspection. All this it will be seen, increases the gravity of the charge we make against the departmental authorities in Brisbane, that they have been culp- able of gross neglect of our health and safety. They seem to have been so selfish and scared they could think only of their own safety. The moment it was known that Dr. Woodward was ill of small pox, intimation of the fact should have been sent to all the ports at which emigrants by the Duke of Westminster have been landed, and the health officers advised as to what steps they should take, in the event of sickness appearing among the new chums. While putting our autho- rities on the alert a few useful hints might have been given. We are sorry to say we cannot congratulate our readers upon all danger being past. It is only about a week since Dr. Woodward's case was pronounced to be one of small-pox, hut he was ill long before he

reached Brisbane. When at Cooktown he was complaining, and a rush came out upon him at that time. There can be no doubt he had the disease about him, when sending off the emigrants to the different ports. He is very much to blame for not having summoned medical assistance, which he could easily have done hy telegraph. Our

health officer could then have visited  

him at Keppel Bay. It will occur to many to ask where did Dr. Woodward catch contagion ? The Courier suggests that he may have done so at Batavia. In that event he must have carried it about with him for ten days - the time taken by the steamer on the voyage between that port and the Queensland coast, If he, a medical officer, on board a large ship, with all manner of comforts, could thus be an involuntary vehicle of disease, have we not great reason to fear that the immigrants, with whom he was coming in daily contact, may be the means of spreading it far and wide. We are not out of danger, and while we urge upon our authorities and medical officers the duty of being careful and watchful, we would insist upon personal

cleanliness on the part of members of   the community, and the free use of   disinfectants.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1883.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1883.

By the latest files fron: England we have information regarding the introduction into the United Kingdom of the Parcels Post. This is merely the extension of a principle, which has long been carried out in practice in the home countries. Small parcels such as watches, jewellery, and samples have always been trans missable, at rates slightly in excess of those charged for letters of equal weight. Under the new system the charges will be for a parcel not exceeding i lb., 3d.: above 1 lb. and not exceeding 3 lb., 6d.; above 3 lb. and not exceeding 5 lb., od.; above 5 lb. and not exceeding 7 lb., rs. The result of the change will be watched with much interest, because already it has become apparent to persons familiar with the attempts that are made by citizens, who would assume a very indig- nant air if their loyalty and public-spirit were questioned, to cheat the Govern- ment, that it will be liable to abuse. The sample post had to be abandoned, because dealers instead of confining their remittances to samples, sent goods which had been ordered, perhaps by post cards, and sold on credit. Thus, it will be seen the revenue was defrauded in several ways. Attempts were also to send lelters open af the ends, under the guise of circulars, at the cheap rate, and so numerous have these been that it has paid the authorities to maintain a special stalT of assistants to detect them, and charge the penalties incurred. The income earned by the detectives has more than paid their salaries. In connection with the new parcels post system, it is pointed out that a person may send through the post ten parcels of seven pounds each-in all seventy pounds of merchandise-at a cost of ten shillings. In this way the service may become encumbered, and the cost of carrying it on will exceed the income. This is a matter on which experience will furnish the required information. Another objection to the system is that parcels may be despatched containg letters, and the present revenue of the Postal Service will thereby be reduced. Here again the results must be learned from experience. It may be difficult to ascertain to what extent the parcels are laden with letters, but if the letter-postage revenue is greatly affected, and a reduction is apparent, the con- clusion that letters are being sent in parcels will be obvious.

Among the reasons which may have induced the Post Office authorities in the United Kingdom to inaugurate this parcels post system, the great convenience

it will be to the nublic was doubtless

thc most prominent. Railways have run staRe-coaches and carriers' wains olT the highways and byways of the old country. In many outlying localities the rural postman-trudging on foot, or perhaps doing his journey in a spring cart,-is the only means of communica- tion with the t;reat centres of commerce and trade. Orders for articles may be sent by post from any patt of the country, but the difficulties of fulfilling such orders for want of carriage accom

modation are in many cases insuperable. No public conveyances run to small villages and country houses. To enable the postman to carry parcels the Postal authorities will require to furnish them with vehicles. When they do this they will secure nearly all the carrying trade for light articles, and pro- vide a system that will be of immense advantage to residents outside of towns and beyond the reach of railways. Its benefits will be most felt in those parts of the country to which the iron horse has not penetrated.

A consideration of this fact must raise the enquiry-whether a useful and remu- nerative parcels post system could not be established in this colony? The difficulties attending the transmission of small parcels from one part of the colony to another are at present very numerous. Indeed, the danger of total loss is so great that trade

in this way is seriously hampered. It».: the United Kingdom Parcel Delivery Companies undertake the carriage of Parcels from London to almost any part of the civilised world. These companies have been making the trade which the Government have resolved to prosecute. We have no Parcel Delivery Companies in this colony, and there is the greater reason, therefore, why the Government should undertake this service in the

public interest. We are not prepared to say it could be efficiently carried oûTtô"" all parts of the colony, because the number and aggregate weight of parcels, newspapers, and letters would increase on many routes, beyond the carrying capabilities of a single horse ; and on many lines of travel the roads would be impassable for vehicles. Wherever Cobb's coaches travel, and wherever the mails are conveyed by coach the

Parcels Post could be introduced. Little need be said to show how

greatly trade might be stimulated by it. Our daily journals contain long lists of articles of interest and utility, of novel- ties and specialities, lo which merchants invite the attention of. customers. But'

these are beyond the reach of persons' residing on inland stations. They can only be procured at considerable risk, trouble, and expense. Suppose, how- ever, in connection with the Postal De- partment there were this parcels .delivery system, anyone could write to Rockhampton or Brisbane for some speciality or novelty ; the

merchant there could meet the demand

by transmitting the article by post, con- fident there would be little risk, and the least possible delay. It appears to us the system would be specially useful in facilitating the sale of medicines, books, jewellery, drapery, &c. In cases -of sickness an order for medicines, sent,

perhaps, by telegraph, would be fulfilled without loss of time, and thus suffering would be avoided and lives spared. As roads were opened np, and the coach routes extended, the advantages of the system could be carried to all parts of the colony. A list of the places to which the Department was prepared to undertake the delivery of parcels could be displayed at every post-office in the colony, and thus the public could learn how far the parcels delivery system could be available. Our Post Office service is not remunerative at present, but it seems to us the probabilities of a parcels post increasing the income of the Department are greater in this colony than in the United Kingdom. For these reasons it is to be hoped the establishment of a parcels delivery system in connection with our postal service may receive the attention of the public, and those on whom rests the duty of providing means for the develop- ment of trade, and the multiplication of the comforts of the community.

A LTnoTjGH the old opinion llmt leprosy I'B contagious ia now generally discredited, w« aro very glad to lenin, upon Dr. Thurston's authority, that the diseased Chinaman at Bogantungan is not suffering from it. lt may be hereditary and non-infectious, but we have heen informed on good authority that sin oe tho Chinese bogan to mix with the South Sea Islanders it has appeared and become common among the latter. We must remember, more- over, that in tba Middle Ages it prevailed in Europe, and there were at one time 19,000 lazar houses for the reception of persons afflicted by it. It still exists on the west coast of Norway ; the Baltic provinces of Russia ; in certain parts ot Spain and Por- tugal ; all over the East ; in the West Indies, mid Central America. The cause of it is un- known, but it is said to prevail most among persons who largely uso fish diofc, and inter- marry closely. Neither of these circumstances aro likely to lead to ils propagation in Queens- land, hut as it is an incurable and loathsome malady, and may spread where it appears, wo think those afflicted with it should be prevented from mixing unguardedly in com- munities. Total isolation would bo hard upon tho snfjeror from leprosy, hut tboBe who have a horror of the disease should bo pro- tected from inadvertent contact with him. Thc old custom of making the leper wear a distinctive dress is one that should be revived if no restraint is to be pot upon the afflicted.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1883.
