articleText:
RqCrtHAMl'l'ON.

MONDAY, JANUARY 29, 1883.

THE question of the validity of the pro- ceedings in connection with the late Municipal elections is still open, not- withstanding the severe logic that has been brought into exercise to show their legality. Il is comeiiueii mai, uccauac Alderman Sharples had not been nominated as a candidate till after he had issued the notice for the election, that he was quite entitled to act as Returning Officer till the day of nomina-

tion. When the clause in the Local

Government Act is looked at, even j cursorily, it will be seen that this isa mistake. It distinctly states that no person shall act as Returning Officer at any election who shall foi»;«« a candidate at such election. The exact words of the clause are :-" no person, who acts as Returning Officer at any election, shall be ot become a candidate for any office at such election." Now the

question is did the Mayor (Mr. Sharples) act as Returning Officer at the late election? Unmistakably lie did up till within a few hours of the nomination. The advertisement notifying the election bore his name as Returning Officer. Then did he become a candidate at that election? Unquestionably he did. Again, if the Mayor intending to become a candidate at the election, did, as Returning Officer, notify the election, was such notification legal ? If it were legal Mr. Wakefield's return was legal, and Mr. Sharples' return illegal. If such notice were not legal, then neither Mr. Wakefield nor Mr. Sharples are legally elected. The wording of the clause Of the Act is plain, in that it markedly points out that no person shall become a candidate at an election for

which he has acted as Returning Officer ; clearly pointing out that no man having

received the nominations of other can- didates, shall himself become a candidate. Now, Did Mr. Sharples do this, or did he not? The advertisement in reference to the election says that--" Nominations close at 4 p.m. on the 24th instant, and the Returning Officer will be in atten- dance from 3 to 4 p.m. of that day to receive them. They may, however, be handed lo him at any time previously with a deposit of ,£$ in nomination of aldermen." Here it is prominently shown that Mr. Sharples could have had the handling of the nominations of other candidates, in direct contravention of the Act, since his name appeared as the Returning Officer at the foot of the advertisement notifying when nominations must bc in his hands ; while he himself became a candidate afterwards. It has been said we must look to the spirit, and not to the letter of

the statute. We are quite willing to do ' so, and hold that in spirit the act con- templated the prevention of the very questionable proceeding of which Alder- man Sharples has been guilty-that is, for a person to go on acting as Returning Officer till the last moment, perhaps dealing with the nominations of others, and then himself becoming a candidate. What is the meaning of thc phrase s.hr// heroine, if it be not prohibitory of such a proceeding. The Act provides that the Chairman of a municipality shall bc the returning officer al an election, unless he is "incapable of acting." Now, at the time he signed the official notification of the election. Alderman Sharples was not incapable, but having assumed

the position of returning officer he was prevented from becoming a candidate. By bis own act he disquali- fied himself, and the actual Returning Officer in receiving his nomination, made a mistake. Taking this view of Ihe matter, the proceedings were in order and legal as far as Mr. Sharples' nomina- tion, but they were stultified by what took place afterwards.

The Town Clerk has power to appoint a returning officer,^^d, when the alder- man appointed by^HEouncil "became incapable or refusea^o act," he was justified in appointing Alderman Williamson. But the latter gentleman issued no notice of the election, and that issued by Alderman Sharples was mullitied by his subsequent action.

With reference to the cancelling of Mr. Wakefield's contract-very possibly Mr. Wakefield can cancel his contract and take the legal responsibility-but the question is not, can Mr. Wakefield do this and incur an action at law, but it is, can he thus constitute his own legality as a candidate for election. The Mayor and Mr. Wakefield may have decided to transfer the contract, and thus relieve Mr. Wakefield of his contract under the Council, but to our mind a duly convened meeting of the Aldermen should decide such ancellation, and not the Mayor

j and contractor. How can the Council

confirm the Mayor's action, seeing that j Mr. Wakefield will then be sitting, and voting on the acceptation of his resigna- tion as a contractor with the municipality. I Besides, if Mr. Wakefield by his own

I action could rid himself of his contract,

there was no need for him to consult the Mayor at all ; nor is it necessary to get the consent of the Council to the action of the latter. We are quite aware that by section 38, a defective election shall not invalidate proceedings of the Coun- cil ; but that does not relieve the person elected of responsibility of sitting and voting without being competently elected. He may be called upon to show cause under clause 46 " why he should not be ousted of the office." As we contend there was no legal in- timation given of the late election, all the gentlemen returned may be called upon, under a rule of the Supreme Court, to defend their seats. Then again under clause 116 if the Chairman if a Municipality, or Returning Officer, having undertaken so to act, shall be guilty of any negligent act of commission or omission contrary to any of the pro- visions of the part of the Act referring to elections, he shall he liable to a penally not exceeding fifty pounds. Now it is a moot poinl whether both Alderman Sharples and Williamson have not been guilty of negligence-the former in acting for a time as Returning Officer, and then becoming a candidate ; and the latter in receiving Alderman Sharples' nomination,-or, indeed, any of the nominations, without having issued notice of the election.

Upon considering the numerous ques- tions raised, we think our readers will share our opinion that there has been culpable carelessness in connection with >U~ I-fT »Wlinn Of co»« it may SUÍt the book of interested persons to say "What is the use of raising a row; whether the councillors be properly elected or not will not invalidate the pro- ceedings of the Council." That is quite true, and we have no objections to the gentlemen supposed to be elected ; but in matters of this kind, we hold it to be of the utmost importance the law should be strictly adhered to. No gentleman, who, so far as he is personally concerned, has acted fairly and honestly, in order to secure the honour of a seat io the Council, should be exposed to an action of " Ouster of Office," through the carelessness of any official. Besides, it will be open to an elector al any time to raise such an action, and cause councillors consider- able trouble and expense. People may scout the idea of such a thing, but gentlemen who give their time and services freely to the performance of public duties, should be protected from the possibility of annoyance. We have no guarantee that this will be the case, if the Local Government Act, is not under- stood and acted on. It is not in any spirit of fault finding, but to secure purity of election, that we have referred to the irregularities noticed.

TUE Brisbane Hospital bas lately attracted oonsiderable attention, and tho Committee of Management have decided to put the institu- tion on a proper footing. Being mostly men, seemingly, with exalted ideas of their own wisdom, the metropolitan faculty have hit upon the idea that if the visiting staff of surgeons be placed in authority over the resident surgeon, matters will go along smoothly. Thia system was tried in the Mel- bourne Hospital, and increased the death-rate there beyond the expectations of even thc most sanguine undertaker. Now the Brisbane hospital is about two miles out of the town, and wc will suppose that a serious case nf accident arrives. Thc resident surgeons either soothe thc patient down, scrape a little of thc mud off him if he has been run over, or else let him lie, and messengers are sent off to rally tho honorary medical stall. While these gentle- men, who, it may bc, are attending their private practice, arc being collected from all points of the compase, the patient suffers untold agony, or possibly gives (lp the ghost altogether. If, say, a typhoid case comes in-well, it is necessary that the physi- cian should see the patient at least three times during the first twenty-four hours. This being the case, it is pleasant to think ol an honorary physician driving two miles out ami back from his private residenoe, during a day. Our local hospital is in such a first class and satibfactnry condition, that we eau quite alford to grow funny over the Brisbane one, and offer a little fatherly advice. From a selfish point of view, the lVeas might be prompted to advocate Hie system of placing resident hospital surgeons under tho control of the honorary physicians, because there would be BO much squabbling in the hospitals, and so innny fatal tormina, ti'im ti accident cases. This, it will be seen, would furnish many sensational paragraphs, but it is our pride to rise above pcrsuunl considerations. Thus even thc pros pects of thu eurgoonfl nuarrulliug with each

utlwr daily, and frightfully inlurustiii;; deaths occurring frequently, do not CIUIHO US Iq advocate placing tho resilient medical staff under the visiting surgeons. The Brisbane hospital committee advise a trial of tho prac- tice, and so doubt before hag interesting remits may come under notice,

ExraAORDiKaRv. though (he statement ?eenie to soma, it-«ornes to na {rom the Superintendent Of the Immigration Dépôt, and therefore should be thoroughly reliable. It is this : That the rate of «ragea offered to Immigrants has risen considerably since the introduction of Kanaka labour. There is hardly any necessity to remark much upon this, the {act is unmistakeable, and should silence those ? thickatidthin opponents of coloured labour. Looking at the question cf employing Coolies on the sugar plantations, it «rill be seen that so long as these men are employed in only such work as white men won't undertake, they must have tho effect of increasing the demand for white labour, lt must bc remembered that, say for picking coffee, white men are unavailable ; the work could not possibily be sufficiently remunera- tive to pay them, and yet leave the planter a fair profit. The same with sugar-it simply would not pay ta employ whito men among tho canes, and we have too much respect for the Bristish workman to ever hope that he would work far thc paltry wages, which can alone be offered for this class of employment. But let us suppose that cheap black labour is em- ployed where white is unavailable, suppose that thuB sugar and coffee plantations prosper,

this must necessarily increase the demand for. machinery and appliances, in the construction of which white mechanics are employed. It is au unmistakeable fact that with tho growth of the sugar industry the iron trades have im-

proved, and undoubtedly the building trade j

would also increase. When Kanakas were first introduced there waa the usual cry out against black labour, but the effect of it has boen to raise white men's wages. When Mr. Brookes defied any one to point him to a pros- perous country where black labour was employed, he forgot lodia, and possibly forgot this country where Kanakas are in service.

THE Customs collections at this port from the 22ad to the 27th iastsut iaolusive, amounted to f1026 Us. ii.

SOBS nice specimens of the rose-apple were brought to our office on Saturday by Ur. Goebel, ' Silverhill, Mount Hedlow ' Road. They had the odour of roses, and a pleasant taste. The tree, which ÍB now producing a full crop, has been planted five years.

OH Saturday afternoon, at North Rockhamp- ton, a hundred yards' foot-race took plaoe between two amateurs, Messrs. A. Boldeman and W. Belfield. Boldeman assumed the lead at the start, was nveer passed, and won oleverly by over a yard. Time, ll secs.

Toe early Closing Association has arranged with the Mastodon Minstrel Company for their band to play selections in the Cremorne Gardens, on Wednesday afternoon next. A programme of amusements will be published to-morrow, and the Committee is endeavouring

to provide rational enjoyment on the half holiday for thc emancipated employees.

A Government Gazette Extraordinary was issued on Wednesday notifying that " Her Majesty the Queen has been graciously pleased to appoint the Honourable Thomas M'IL wraith to be an ordinary member of the second-class, or a Knight Commander, o! the most distinguished Order of St. Michael and St. George.

NOTWITHSTANDING all that has been said and written about the danger of allowing goats and cattle to wander about tho roads ia the municipality, no remedy for it has yet been put in force. The Inspector of Nuisances seems to be comparatively powerless to prevent it. A case has occurred that we hope will be the meanB of stirring np. our muni- cipal authorities to a sense of their responsi- bility in this matter. At an early hour yesterday morning, a gentleman residing on tho Range was unexpectedly called upon to go for a doctor and a norse. In returning with the latter, and driving smartly of course, the horse and buggy come upon a oow slumbering on tbe road.' There was a sharp collision, the result of. which was the occupants of the vehicle were thrown out, and one of them severely injured. In this case we hope an action will be raised against the members of the Council, as there can be no doubt they, by their negligence, contributed to the accident.

SEVERAL antidotes have been proposed for the conversion of our young men from a too fond attachment to fire-water. Matrimony has been suggested but the sinners have replied-" there is none here to marry." This difficulty appears to be the other way round in the northern districts, for the following plaintive appeal is from one of our exchanges: -"Matrimony.-A young lady, age20, wishes to correspond with a gentlemen able to keop a wife comfortably, not over 30. Please enclose photos. Address-"A.B." Post Office, Towns- ville." This is of course a gratuitous advertise- ment, but there being a lady in the caso-well, even newspapermen nave somefeeling. There is something vague about the advertisement, however, for though the lady's age is stated at twenty, it is questionable whether she does not require a young man able to keep a wife over thirty. Mow, there is a difference of having to keep a wife of twenty years and one of thirty. Up to about twenty-five "love in a cottage " sort of existence will suit the lady ; but at about thirty some solid comforts are demanded, and the appetite loses its sylph-lik* and poetical smallness.

WHEN Mr. Brookes referred to the treat- ment immigrants receive in Rockhampton, there was no doubt much good ground for his complaint. It appears, however, that ns far as providing suitable food for theBe persons there is some difficulty to be overcome by the Superintendent of the depot. He is not made aware of the precise time when the new- comers may be expected, whian, of course, inconveniences bim greatly. This matter should be attended to, if there is to be any comfort ensured on arrival at Rookhampton. Undoubtedly it is very necessary that during the first evening after landing tho greatest care should be taken to protect the immi- grants from the danger of falling into the hands of unscrupulous persona. Hence the rule of looking the Immigration .Depot, and preventing the egress of the arrivals, or ingress of an indiscriminate mob, is very proper. When this is done, of course no opportunity is afforded such immigrants as have money of purchasing such luxuries as fruit and vege- tables, which they would relish after a long sea voyage. There being nothing to prevent vendors of these articles from selling them through the Depot gate, it may be expected that some enterprising fruiterers will, on occasion, attend. If they do so, the new- comers will appreciate the attention, and the tradesman, no doubt, be well paid.

THE limited attendance in the front eeats of the Theatre Royal on Saturday evening last most have convinced the manager of the Mastodon Star Minstrels that tho character of the entertainment on Friday evening did not quite suit the taste of Rockhampton audiences. AB there will be a variety of performances in future, and the errors of the opening night may be avoided, we have no doubt the com- pany «ill draw good houses. The negro minstrel entertainments have lost the attrac- tion which their novelty gave them for a time, but they are still relished as an alterative in amusements. Seldom is it the case, as in the Mastodon troupe, that veri- table negroes are among tho performers, and this fact will interest many. On Saturday evening thc performance was very fair, 'ihr: einging, both comic and senti- mental, wa« full of humour and sentiment, as the pieces rcijuiri;,!. 'Mirri; was »Icnty of go in tho choruses of the former ; ami a nice har- mony aili! Mewling ol voices in those of thc lattur. Thc colloquies were amusing, and |io»s<'iMi"t the 6»ul of wit-brevity. In the socoud part of thc cntcrtaHiniout tue fun was rough st tittles, but it wai uever out of place, and seemed to afford much amusement to a large notion of the audienoe. The Minstrel!

aré defer, and Rockhampton people aré not alow toi recognise talent, «o that good homes, ve anticipate, will reward their efforts this

week, ?

Wi understand that the newly elected

Aldermen intend taking their seats at the next ' meeting of the Council, being of opinion that their election is perfectly legal. It has also been considered by some of them that the question of : the validity of their return is a very small matter.

? A MEMORANDUM front the Telegraph Office last night stated all the southern lines were down, and wo are, therefore, without our late telegraphic intelligence. The interruption to communication with the south by wire bas been caused by thunderstorms.

Tue supplement to the Queensland Govern- ment Oazetie, issued on Wednesday, the following eales of laud are announced :--On Cth March, at Rockhampton, C town lots in the county of Livingstone, 1 country lot in the parish of Yeppoon, 4 town lots in the county of Plantagenet, 2 suburban lots in the county of Pakington, and 9 suburban lots in the parish of Banana,

OH Saturday the weather waa rather hot throughout the early part of the day but in the afternoon a heavy thunderstorm came up and some very desirable rain fell. The lightning was very vivid at times and the thunder loud. Yesterday was slightly warm and iii the evening the sky became overcast considerably, lightning playing around. At night a light shower fell.

AT a meeting of the sslection committee, held on Wednesday night (says the Courier) ¡the following team were chosen to play against the English cricketers in Brisbane : - Messrs, Baines, Gowan, R, Dixon, Egan, Gregory, W. Hobbs, Neeson, Nettle, Nesbitt, John Petrie junr., Pratten, P. Roberts, D. Scott, Silvester, Smith, StricV land, Votler, and Wearne.- Emergencies MesBrs. White and Gibson. Umpire-Mr. R. C. Miller. Soorers-Messrs. A. Down and C. Thorne. The uniform of the local team wilt consist of white flannel ehirt and trousers,

and white hat with a band of pink and blue ribbon (intertwined). The Government intend to declare Friday, the 2nd February (the day on whioh the match begins), a nubba holiday, and it is hoped that all tho business houses

will be closed on that day. \J -JJTHE children of the Orphanage returned irorh their holiday trip to Mackenzie Island by the steamer Fitzroy last Saturday: They were taken by 'buses in attendance from the wharf to their home, and appeared on the way perfectly happy anil Contented. The trip up tho river was a remarkably pleasant one, and all the good things that had been kindly provided for the excursionists were thoroughly appreciated. Too much can hardly be said of the kindness of Oaptain Hunter in the matter; who has shown a great amount of interest in the little unfortunates, several times visiting them during their stay on the island, and exerting himself to Ret donations of eatables for their pleasure. The children looked very hearty, and a little burned with the sun on their return, and no doubt will, for many a long day, re. member their pleasant trip. Mr. Raingér, the Superintendent of the Quarantine Station, waa particularly kind in providing fish during the stay of the little ones, and also kindly allowed them the ase of a boat, which was in oontinuai request, as well as the other one pro- vided by Oaptain Hunter.

MESSRS. W. HOWARD SMITH AND SON'S new steamer Moreton berthed at Hie Corpora- tion wharf yesterday afternoon. She left Sydney on Sunday morning, the 21st instant, and arrived at Wewoastle at 5 p.m. Here a oargo of coal was shipped for the Railway Department. She continued her - voyage at 3 a. ui. on 23rd, and anchored in the Fitzroy

River on Saturday to await tho tide. She' arrived here at 2 p.m. A southerly wind with high sea prevailed to tho Seal Rocks ; thence to Cape Moreton fresh head winds ; and from the Cape to Keppel Bay thick blinding rain with heavy thunder squalls were encountered. In this rough - weather the ship behaved admirably, and displayed good sea-going qualities. The Moreton ia built somewhat after the style of th» Keilawarra, but, there is more space on deck' aft. She was visited by a large number of persons yesterday who inspeoted her from stem to stern with much interest. We append a description of the steamer whioh is a noteworthy addition to the steam fleet of this port, anil should prove very

serviceable and suitable for the trade between N. 8, Wales and the Queensland ports. The Moreton was launched in the beginning.ol August last from the yard of Messrs. W, Walker and Co., of Deptford, and is a' very smart-looking vessel. The best steel is used in the construction of the hull, the dimensions of which are as follow :-181 feet long, 27 feet broad, depth of hold 10 feet 10 inches. This gives a register of 355 tons, with a carrying capacity of over 700 tons. Her engines were made by Bolton and Watts, of Deptford, and are on the compound principle, with all modern improvements. They are of 70 horse- power nominal, and aro expected to drive the ship along at a rate of over 10 knots. During tho voyage from Glasgow the Moreton came along under easy steam, so that no actual test of her steaming powers has yet been hod, though the record of one day's work showed that she had covered 230 miles. She is pro- vided with four steam winches for the out-put and taking in of cargo, and steam is alBo utilised in steering the vessel and for supply- ing the means of ventilation to the saloon and second cabin. Tho latter improvement is a novelty, indeed-the Moreton is the first vessel that has been supplied with the patent apparatus driven by steam for ensuring the thorough ventilation of the berths. Con- sidering the size of the Moreton ber saloon is roomy. It measures 40 feet by 24 feet, and is very chastely fitted up, and painted, light green and gold nicely relieving a white ground, and walnut panels highly polished setting off the whole. Ample provision is made for ventilation, as, in addition to the apparatus referred to the face of the berths is made of jalousies, and there are openings over the tops of the doors to allow of the ingress and egress of air. There is accommodation in the saloon for twenty-four passengers, who will find themselves very comfortably provided for, many of the details in the ship being an improvement on the accommodation usually provided in intercolonial vessels. The second cabin is also a comfortable apartment, and bas room for twenty-four passengers. The officers' and engineers' quarters are amidships, and

the crew are accommodated forward. The Moreton has a splendid deck for promenading upon, and, covered with awnings, it will bo anattractivospot for passengers on awarm day. She is commanded by Captain George Andrews, late mate of the Keilawarra, who has received woll-carned promotion in the service. Mr.

Murray is chief officer and Mr. A. Jnnner second orScer. Chief Engineer, Mr. J. A. Freiakc ; second engineer, Mr. George Maurice ; third engineer, Mr. G. Garde ; chief steward, Mr. Brown.

THERE were no cases foi hearing in the Police Court on Saturday.

ALBRECHT FEEZ has just landed, direct from home, 60 cases superior Still and Sparkling Hocks and Moselle (in quarts and pints), equal in quality to the best brands of champagne, and at most moderate prices; also, 100 cases of Morhit's Patent Stopper Lager Beer (in pints). Inspection invited.

Oíhf^vninjif iilletiit,

KOCKll.ÚU'TON.

FRIDAY. MARCH 2, 1883.

SOME of our readers may have been deterred by its length from reading the reports:which we gave of the annual meeting of the Central Queensland Meat Export Company ; and of the visit paid to the Fitzroy Works at Lake's Creek by the directors, shareholders, and others. We hope, however, they will be carefully perused by every one in- terested in the prosperity of the Central District. It only requires a little thought and consideration to see clearly how closely the meat trade, as the directors propose to develop it, is asso- ciated with the progress of this portion of the colony. The fact is eyer staring us in the face that the pastoral industry is now, and for many years to come will continue to be, the mainstay for tile, employment of capital and labour in our midst. To the west of Rockhampton is a wide .area of country, which has within the last few years been opened up by the Central Railway. As it is being pushed out westwards it is tapping still wider areas. At present we have not fully realised the stock-bearing capabili- ties of this country. Even in the Settled Districts our experience of the results of fencing and water conservation has been been limited, and has not been of such a character as to furnish accurate data for calculations as to the future. Ac- cording to our latest returns the number of cattle in the Central District was 1,037,236, and of sheep, 3,245,292. Within the last year the effect of the operations of the Company has been to raise the average price of cattle twenty shillingsa head. Thatuponthctotalwould mean an increase of capital-an acces- sion of purchasing power to the squatters, of a million of pounds sterling. They would have that much more serurity to offer for cash needed in increasing their herds and improving their stations. Owing to thc restricted range of the company's operations it has not done this ; but a little reflection on these facts and figures will enable our readers to realise the mighty influence it may come to exert on our pastoral industry. In Rockhampton district alone there were in i88r, 193,778 caltle. Now an in- crease of one pound sterling a head on one fourth of that number is equal to nearly ,£50,000 or the entire capital of the Company. Very lillie foresight is needed, we think, to see that, if the Company is to be instrumental in main

taining this increase io value, not only must the capital solicited by the Direc- tors be subscribed, at once, but provision must be made for the expansion of operations. The Directors have booked already as many callie as will keep the works fully employed till November next. The number is 13,000 head, and it must be apparent that quantity can represent only a small portion of the the surplus stock of the district. These figures refer to cattle alone, but as our Central Railway penetrates the sheep country, the squatters will look to this port to provide them with facilities for exporting mutton as well as beef. Indeed, Mr. William Pattison, in the course of his remarks at the works on Wednesday afternoon', hinted at the desirability of this being done. In their immediate interests it seems clear the squatters should not restrain the energy of the Meat Export Company by withholding the capital required for it. When it is remembered that the price of cattle in future - will be ruled by the capabilities of the company, every man who owns a hundred head should take shares in the undertaking.

Our mercantile and manufacturing j interests are so closely associated with in fact, are so dependent on the pastoral, that anything which effects the latter tells on the former. A severe drought spread' dulness in the town as well as in the country. It may be true, as Mr. Liver- more says, that the Company is a squatting concern, but it is something more. , It is an important factor, in the promotion of the general interests of the colony, and as such should receive the support of all classes of the community.

.With considerable satisfaction it will be observed, that, in laying down the lines of future action, the Directors of the Company are more intent upon prosecuting the freezing than the meat preserving department of their business. This shows prudence on their part,

and a comprehension of the proba-' bilities of the future which . should commend their wisdom and judgment tb the shareholders. The success of the Fitzroy works has been due to the cheap price at which beef could be obtained, and the admirable manner in which it has been preserved. Competitors are starting up, however, and among recently prospected companies is " The Austra- lian Fresh Meat Company" with a capital of ¿£200,000. - The promoters; of this, or some other company, proposed to expend their funds in Melbourne, as,it was remarked, theclimateof Queens- land increased the difficulties of meat preserving. Because at Lake's Creek these difficulties have been overcome by Mr. Bertram, it does not follow that the absence of them would not facilitate and cheapen the cost of meat preserving in Melbourne. Then, again, labour there is much cheaper than in Queensland. At present the Company can tempt tin- smiths hither from the Victorian capital.

Our cheap beef is a set off against dear' labour ; in Melbourne labour is cheap

but beef dear. If an intercolonial frozen meat trade spring up, and the Melbourne makers can purchase Queensland car- casses at a slight advance on the price paid in this colony, then, with their cheap labour, they may be able to undersell Fitzroy Works pre- served meat in the markets of Europe. That is an easily comprehensible con- tingency. It is also within the range of possibility that an Australian preserved meat business may be created in the old country. We can imagine a time when the importation of frozen meat from South America and Australasia will so reduce prices in the home market that meat preserving shall become aprofitable industry. Unless Queensland had then a large supply of cheap labour, meat preser- ving would become unprofitable. Some may , think the chances of such a state of matters Arising are too remote to deserve considerations. But, the transitions in the meat export trade have been so sudden, and startling, there is reason to dread any eventuality, within the bounds of reasonable comprehension. There is not the same grounds, how- ever, to dread the interruption of ihe frozen meat trade. To it there seems to bc no limit, save the refrigerating capacity of the Tha'chihery and chambers at the works. At present 10,060 carcases a year could be chilled for exportation, and without much expenditure of capital, or addition of labourv the "output" could be increased. As time goes on the cost of freezing and carrying meat will be reduced. If the .invention of Mr. Joseph James Coleman, of Bell-Coleman fame, succeeds, the facilities for trans- porting dead meat from our western pastures to Keppel Bay will be greatly increased, and it is impossible to com- prehend the magnitude to which it may expand. So long as we can produce beef and mutton cheaper than any other country, so long will our frozen meat trade be a large and flourishing industry-and that shall be a very long lime indeed.

IN anticipation of tho cricket match with Brisbane, thc Committee appointed to select thc Rockhampton toain havo arranged tu have a match played between most of thc loading cricketers of the town, preparatory to any selection being made as to who shall bc in bludcd in thc Eleven to oppose the metropoli- tans. The match takes place at North Rock- hampton on Saturday next, and the teams

will he one of Eleven and the other of Fifteen

players. Tile teams have bcon chosen thus : -Tho Klcvcu : Messrs. J. W. Rutter, H. BoWcman, F. Boldeman, A. Boldeman, F. Comley, J. Bartlom, W. \V. Willis, P. Mil- ford, U. E. Wilson, C. E. Bowman, and A. Crow; emergency. A. J. Haswell. The Fif- teen : Messrs. A. J. Haswell, P. S. Russell, F. Cheshire, G. RoMemau, F.. Rosa, A. Brooke, M. B. Poll. A. denham, D. C. Macpherson, H. Skinucr, W. John, T. V. Nobbs, G. B. Jones, W. Braxton, M. Kaine, A. S. Tonipson ; emergencies, A. ß. Catt, A.

M'Millan, and ll. Burns.

TUE steamer Bunyip, left thc A.S.N. Com- pany's wharf shortly after seven o'clock last night with the Knplisli mails and passengers for the Q.R.M.S. Dorunda, Among the latter were Major Feez, M.L.A. for Leichhardt, Inspector nnd Mrs. John Stuart, Mr. C. E. Wodehouse, Land Commissioner, and an old resilient here Mrs. Ottley. Inspector Stuart and Mr. WndehonBe have received twelve months leave of absence, the former on half pay and tho latter on full pay. A largo number of friends assembled on the wharf to

wish them ¿on toyage. Thc Bunyip had cast

. ,-\ ?. :

off from the wharf 'before Captain BUis and non-commissioned orneen of the looal Volun- teer dorps arrived on the scene. However,

the stearaer^bad to .put back for Mrs, Ottley,, who 'nearly lost her- passage, and toe oppor- tunity was availed of by the "red coats to shalne hands with their gallant Major. AB tho stcarnor cleared off three hearty cheers were given for thc Major, who responded with '.'.Cod bless you all," \Ve trust tho voyagers Will ieturu. to Rockhampton; with ren'oWM health after their trip to the mother country.

TUE northern districts were visited by a giueral rain yesterday, as will be seen from oijr weather reports. In town there was a rather heavy shower during Ihe afternoon, and. at night there was every appearance of more. Previous to the shower it was oppressively close in town, affecting a considerable number of people, who complained of feeling unwell.

., ¡THE three: children named respectively

Elias 'Beat/ «even years, Benny licet, four years, and Fanny Best, nine years, were brought before the Police Magistrate yesterday, charged with being neglected children. The evidenoe of Constable Williamsand Mr.-King Veen, showed that the children were in the habit pf wandering about North .Rockhampton in a- destitute condition, and begging food from residents in the locality. They aleo herded with the aboriginals. Their mother was confined in the look-up forexaminationas to her - state of miud, their father refused' to support

them, and suent bis earnings in drink. Tjaking theBe circumstances into consideration the Police Magistrate ordered the girl to be sent to the Toowoomba Industrial School for seven years, and direotod the admission pf the boys to' the Rockhampton Orphanage. Mr. Cribb also directed the police to institute pro- ceedings against Best to opmpel him to con- tribute to the support of his ohildren. Outside, the Court bouse several uncompli- mentary and forcible remarks were made concerning the unpiroutal conduot of the mao.

MB. A. E. ALEXANDRE, who has been for many years in business in Rockhampton ais ab auctioneer and' Commission agent and Government valuator at the Customs, has determined to relinquish business here and try his fortune .in Sydney. He has; there- fore, sold out to Messrs. it. Foulkes and J. T. Richardson. The new firm will trade under the style of R. Foulkes and Co., and com

munee operations on the 1st April next. Ao | announcement by circular to that effect has . been made, , Ip is intended to oombine the busi- ness with that of stock, station, Custom.House ahd shipping agency. The former will have. ' the attention oFMr. Foulkes, and the Custom House and shipping will be in the hands of Mr. Richardson., The former gentleman has had a lengthened experience in stock matters,' and Mr.-'Richardson' after eleven years'

service with MeBsrs. John Headrick and Co.

has acquired a thorough knowledge of the work of which he will have the management.' Tho now firm will carry on business in the premises at present occupied by Messrs. Alexander and Sous.

PARTIES requiring a horse and buggy should not overlook, tJiQ sale to be conducted to-day by Mr. Ó.' B. Shaw, at his Chambers, in Quay-street. Sociables, buggies, a cab, and a selection of horses are all to be brought under

the hammer. ? ?

TO-DAY MI. Curtis holds an important,sale of merchandise, consisting of the remainder of the stock-in-trade of the late firm of Messrs. J. Headrick and Co. Afterwards he will expose, to public competition the fine, blook of land adjacent to tba Commercial1 Hotel, in Quay-street, and two blocks of land on Athelstane Radge. The stores will be sold first, and the land probably about ono o'clock. It is to be noted that the sale is' to take place in Messrs. Headrick'a stores, in William .street. .'?'???

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

MONDAY, APRIL 9, 1883.

IN all the Australian colonies it is a fact, which bitter experience seems to have placed beyond the reach of controversy, that agriculture will never attain to the dimensions required of it, unless man greatly aids Nature in producing

circumstances under which it is at all possible. We do not refer to the clear- ing of the land from dense scrub-the growth of ages-or the breaking up and

reclamation of the soil. These are con- ditions essential to successful husbandry in any climate. In temperate regions

circumstances are suitable to the

growth of cereal crops. In general the rainfall is ample ; the soil when cleared is suitable ; and the heat and sunshine are sufficient to bring the plants to maturity. If the farmer only performs the work that experience has shown to be necessary, in the ordinary course of years he can obtain a fair return for his labour. Farming in Australia, except in a few favourable localities, sad experience has demon- strated, cannot be carried on with so much certainty as to results. The chief reason of this is our dry climate,-our uncertain rainfall. Where it has been attempted to prosecute agricultural pursuits under purely natural circum- stances, failure has taken place. It is not so much the want of rain, but the absence of moisture for the crops at a critical stage of their development, which has led to disappointment and loss. Thus it has been made plain that our farmers must come to the aid of Nature, in a manner, and to an extent, which are quite unnecessary in tem- perate regions. Water conservation, and distribution, or irrigation, must form, in theory and practice, among the greatest concerns of Australian husbandmen. They have learned that, in regard to these malters1 they must do a great deal of work, if arable agri- culture is to become, as it is desirable it should, a large and important industry. This ts generally admitted, andnumerous questions now present themselves for discussion and settlement, in connection with this large and important subject. Some of these it is most desirable our farmers and selectors should carefully consider. The Government have promised, if permitted, to pass a Water Conservation Bill, and among many topics, which the electors at the present time should turn over in their minds, this ought not to be lost sight of. A most important point for consideration is-how far the collecting and distributing of water is to be left theprivateenterprise. It will appear quiet evident, upon a little reflection, that if every large landholder is permitted to carry on works in his own interest solely, disputes and contentions will be certain to arise.

Cases, similar to these of which wejpme times read in the home papers -pierop up, and in proportion as the interests

associated with them here will be much

greater, so will be the obstacles to their satisfactory settlement. The-diversion of a water course, whereby a mill may- be stopped, or a source of water supply for cattle removed, gives' risè to costly law suits in England. Now, if we look to the flat character of the greater part of this colony, to the scarcity of

permanent streams of water, and lo the j value of moisture in agriculture it will be seen that individual meddling with what is public property must be rigidly supervised. In the streams of Europe, where surface water is not so valuable as in this colony, the proprietor of the lands on either side could not erect a weir or dam dyke, to the pre- judice of his neighbours farther down the stream. Should it be thought desir- able lo form dykes across some of our flowing streams, for the purpose of disseminating water over a wide area of level land, then great injury may be done to those whose lands farther down

depend on the river for moisture. There seems a likelihood, if private irrigation works and the damming and tapping of our running streams are to be allowed, that the smaller landholders may be placed at a disadvantage. We can conceive of the wealthy holder of a large estate, situated on the tipper channel of one of our rivers, constructing works which would catch the rainfall, divert the water to his own uses, and deprive landowners

lower down the stream of their natural and accustomed supply of water. Here there would be a clear interference with

the rights or property. Deprived of its natural supply of moisture the land of the lower proprietor would be greatly depreciated in value. One caa conceive, again, of a capitalist forming a large dam, and cutting off water from his neighbours, and tendering dam-making on their part altogether useless. It is

the more desirable that attention should

be paid to this subject 'now, because there are large areas of land in the hands of the Government, and the natural water-supplies of these may be seriously injured for all time coming by the works of far-seeing, skilled, and unscrupulous

conterminous land-owners. In this con- nection we may be permitted to point out that, not only the collection and dis- tribution of surface water, but the dis- charge of the surplus must be attended to. Proprietors, for their own sakes, will

see to it that the water which is not

appropriated by the soil on their estates is not allowed to accumulate, and form improductive swamps or sour the land. But will they be perfectly careful in these matters with respect to their neighbours' lands. In legislating on the subject, we are afraid it will be well to provide for

the waste waters from one estate not

being allowed to run off and accumu- late on another. Indeed, the more the Water Question is looked at, in the light of the points to which we have called attention, the more urgent does it appear to us that the Government should give it their earnest consideration. An opinion has been expressed in some quarters that the Government should make a hydrographie survey of the whole colony, with the view to the formation of a general plan

of water collection and distribution. However desirable that would be, we are afraid the scheme would be of too

great magnitude and cost to be under- taken at present. But we see no reason why such an object should not be aimed at by 'the present and succeeding Ad-

ministrations. It would be a national

work of first rate importance and uni- versal interest. Though it might not be commenced at present, it should certainly be kept in view, and whatever is being

done in the meantime should be effected so as to harmonise with it in future.

OUR télégraphia news is meagre to-day iii oonseqnonee of tho transfer of bnBineBs to the telegraph office having to some extent impeded communication with the south.

J .THE criminal sittings of the Central District

Court will commence this morning before Jadge Miller. There are only two cases for trial, viz., John Doigan (on bail), for embezzle- ment; and - Fitzpatrick, for unlawfully wounding at Springsure.

TUE exhibition of piotures at Mr. G. S. Curtis' rooms was visited by a largo number of people on Saturday night. They will be on

I exhibition again to-day, and will be sold by

auotion on Tuesday morning, at eleven o'clook.

THE immigrants by the Duke of Devon- shire are slowly meeting with engagements, only four or five single men having found work, at from 20s. to 25s. a week. The only single girl available for hire, has found a

place at 10s. a week. The number for this post was 26, including 3 married couples, 3 single women, 3 children, and 14 single

men.

As our readers are aware the three New

[ Caledonian escapees, who landed at Toorilla

a short time since, were brought to town on Friday night. The steamer Heka, with Con- stable Siebert on board, left here on Wednes- day, the 21st March, and experienced very rough weather all the way to Stannage Bay, where she arrived about five o'clock on the afternoon of the 29th ultimo. The escapees were all at Mr. Rogers' station when Con- stable Siebert got there, and at the request of Mr. Rogers the constable did not put them in handcuffs or close confinement, as that gentle- man promised to be responsible for them. They remained there roaming about at liberty till they saw the steamer ap- proaching the bay, when two of them Charles Guerin and Alphonse Camus took to tho bush. This was on the 1st April. A fpursuit was started and after a ride of about forty miles they were found walking in the direction of Rockhampton. They were then brought back to Stannage Bay and arrested. , Next day they were taken on board the

steamer, and arrived in Rockhampton, after a

very rough voyage, on Friday night about nine o'clock. During a gale met with on the home trip the steamer had to put in to a small bay about twenty-seven miles from the mouth of the river. Here those in charge went ashore and got wood and some food, both of which they had run short of owing to the length of tho voyage. At one time the steamer only made about three or four miles in three hours. The escapees' conduct, we are informed, was extraordinarily good, and they behaved themselves like men who had nothing at all to fear. The length of the boat in which they came from New Caledonia is 16 ft 9 in., the depth 3ft. 41/2 in., and the breadth 5 ft. 71/2 in. It is in a very bad con- dition, the bottom being nearly all smashed out by being cast on the rocks. In it there

is room for fifteen persons. No name can be.

traced on it. The men state that they had

672 francs and 60 centimes before the boat was wrecked, and every day while they remained at Mr. Rogers they were diving for the money

as soon as the tide was low enough, but ~ though they could see it, they were unable to' get it owing to the roughness of the weather. ' They have, however, picked up on the rocks the following articles they had before they were wrecked - two towels, one shirt, one pair of trousers, the rudder, and pieces of anchor chain. As is stated elsewhere, they were brought before the Polioe Magistrate on Satur, day morning, on a charge of having no lawful

visible means of support, and remanded until , ten o'clock this morning.

THE Customs collections at this port for thu j week ended . April 7 amounted to £2609

19s. lld.

MR. EEDHÛSD wa«, wo are informed, driven round the town on Saturday by several members of the Reception Committee. It will ba observed by an advertisement in another column that he will deliver a lecture in the Hibernian Hall to-night at eight

o'clock.

FAREWELL sermons were preached by the Rev. J. Williams yesterday morning and evening, in thc Primitive Methodist Charon. At both diets of worship there were large

attendances. Tho Hev. W. H. Williams

preached his introductory sermons in the Wesleyan Churoh. At the morning and evening services there were Urge congrega-

tions.

At the Police Court on Saturday morning before the Police Magistrate one drunkard was cautioned and discharged. Charles Quirin, a carpenter, native of France, aged 27 ; Alphonse Camus, cook, native of France, aged 36 ; and Louis Kirisac alias Jean Marie Beignet, mason, native of France, aged 61, were charged with having no lawful visible means of support; and were remanded til this morning.

Ta-LgasAMS received on Tuesday -(says the Courier J by the Commissioner of Police, state that a boy named John Edwin Wright was Booidentally killed at Upper Caboolture while returning home from churoh on Sunday after- noon. He was riding in company with his brother, when the horse ridden by deoeased stumbled and felt, rolling over the boy and killing him instantly. The horses were can- tering at the time of the accident. One Wm. Grell was found drowned yesterday in a waterhole one mile from Bogantungan.

SOMETIME ago' We drew attention to the objectionable behaviour of certain "dwellers intents" in the Moore's Creek aorub. The Trastees of the Queen's Park took the hint, and caused the persons to remove elsewhere. We are informed they have locatod themselves on the Rockhampton pasturage reserve which is now termed Canvas Town by the north aiders. As the ground is under the control of the Gogango Divisional Board, we trust they will take immediate steps for an abatement of

the nuisance. '

L/ THE new Telegraph Offioe has been oonP Kpleted, with the exception of a few finishing

toaohes to the interior. Yesterday waa occupied by the officials in ohanging the con- nections from the old to the new offioe, and Mr. Hanna, Telegraph Master, and Mr. H. Starke, Instrument fitter, wore busily em- ployed so as to prevent any delay in telegraphic communication. From a cursory glance we may safely assert the accommoda- tion for the public ia replete with every convenience, and will be a great improvement on that furnished in the old offioe.

AFTER a lengthened tour in the northern towna Miss Clara Stephenson has returned to Rockhampton, and announces she will appear in conjunction With Mr. G. H. Barford and a small but select company in the Theatre to- morrow night. A musical comedy with Miss Stephenson in tbs title rôle of "Josephine, the Daughter of the Regiment," will bo tho opening piece. A musioal interlude will follow and the performance ie to close with a soene from the Hunclilaek, and the "Mountain Guide." Only two nights' entertainments are

announced and as tho oompany possesses fair ? dramatio abilities they are likely to draw good '

houses.

ONE hundred and one fat bullocks from Malvern*Downs were trucked from Capella and on arrival at the Railway Terminas four were found dead. The cause is stated to

have been the overloading of truoka, but with whom the blame lies we are not aware. The remainder, ninety seven, were taken charge of at the station by Mr. R. Picton and arrived at Lake's Creek on Tuesday night. A mob of 112 bullocks for boiling down arrived at Lake's Creek Works on Saturday, from Mr. Button's Canal Creek station, Mr. Donald Cameron in charge. He reports plenty of rain and the country in a very bogey state, in fact so much so, that rations could not be sent up. Thirty fat bullocks from Kroombit Station, in charge of Mr. R. D. Davey, camped at Graoemere on Friday. They are intended for sale in this market.

ON tho 10th of October last samples of the water and mad of tho Fitzroy River was sent home to Mr. W. J. Dibdin, the analytical chemist to the Corporation of London, for tho purpose of comparison with the water of the Thames to come before a Royal Commis- sion sitting with regard to the alleged Eollution of tue Thames waters. The samples

ave been submitted to chemical and microscopical examination, and to the courtesy of Mr. R. L, Dibdin we

are indebted for the following particulars : - " The total quantity of dry solid matter ob- tained from the suspended matter was 35-14 grains. As the label on the bottle was in some parts unreadable in consequence of the spirit having leaked, I am unable to convert this into grains of suspended matter per gallon of water. Microscopical examination of both samples showed that there was entire absence of matters of a sewage charaoter, bnt that particles of a vegetable origin were present. The quantity of nitrogenous organic matter, ascertained by chemical analysis, corroborates the microscopical evidence, andieaboutthesame

as that present in samples of mud oolleoted j from tho "saltings" (banks in coarse of denuda- tion) of the Thames. Tho results of the examinations are given in the aooompanying table, with some analysis of Thames mud for

comparison. These samples aro of im- i portance, as they show that the mad of a

pare river contains nitrogenous organic I matters nearly equal in quantity to that in mud deposited in the Thames. It is there- fore beyond doubt that the banks which form from time to time in the Thames are not

caused by deposition of the London sewage, or they would contain a far higher percentage of organic matter and nitrogen. This will be seen by referring to the accompanying

Georgs Bandall, oar emigration lecturer. . in England, bas been addressing largo andiencos at Grainthorpe, Grimsby, North Kyme, Billinghay, Walcott, Timberland, and

A TELEOUAM received by Mr, W. J. Whitman, from his firm at Windorah, atates that Cooper's Creek was a banker, and the water was up to the doors of the store. Since September there was a scarcity of water and feed, and water had to be brought a distance ot aiic milos, Now the residents in that far distant township are rejoicing in tho. all sufficient supply that has come when so much

needod.

We have received the prospectus of The Queensland Leader, a new weekly paper, which Mr. W. P. Mellefont is about to bring out in Brisbane. The prospeotus says : "While attaohed to no party, or subsidised by none, the proprietor intends by articles vigorous, incisive, and logical, unflinchingly and' unsparingly, to expose and denonnoe all shams or bypocricies, class legislation of any kind ; and to advocate tho passing of such laws as are just to all members of the common- wealth, and which tend to make us a great, prosperous, and happy people." It wilt be a cheap eight page paper.

MB. E. JEUNE, the genial chief officer of tho steamer Leichhardt, was lately the recipent of a testimonial in Maryborough. A local paper states that at the invitation of a large number of commercial and other tra- vellers, Mr. Jeune attended in the Royal Hotel to receive the gift which had been got up as a token of the esteem in which be is undoubtedly, held by the travelling public. There was a goodly assemblage of subscribers, on behalf of whom Mr. IS. J. Banbury presented Mr. Jeune with an address and well-tUled purse of sovereigns. The reoipent " wiped away a tear " and responded in a neat and modest speech, and the proceedings then assumed a becoming convivial character.

THE vacant allotment opposite the Cosmo- politan Hotel in Archer-street was the soeno of a pugilistic encounter on Saturday night. Two youths quarrelled in town, and deoided to settle their slight difference by an appeal to arms and fists. Accompanied by a number of lads of varions ages, they made their way to tho battle ground. For twenty minutes they pounded away at each other in the most approved style. Ono of the combatants, who was of slight stature, hurt his thumb, and " threw up the sponge," expressing his willing-

ness to "have it out" another time, the other boy, who was of stout build, stood the punching very well about the ribs, but his "claret was drawn," and his eyes had a slightly darkened appearance. The proceed- ings were oonduofced with more than extra quietude, otherwise tho policeman on the Fitzroy-street block might have settled matters

in another fashion.

EMIGRATION TO AMERICA.-The Pall Mall Oaiette says.--" It ie calculated that 731,000 persona entered the United States last year as immigrants. This is the largest total of any one year in the history of the Republic-larger by 14,000 eren than the total for 1681, not- withstanding the fact that the closing month of last year exhibited a diminution in the stream. Nearly five millions have in thia way been added to the population of the States since 1870, including of course that year. In the very worst year of stagnation after 1873 tho immigration never fell below 160,000. A country so powerfully sustained by now blood cannot but progress, however much it may be loaded by foolish fetters."

A CATERING CAT.-A wonderfully efficient rabbit destroyer has come under the notico of the Narracoorte Herald in tho Bbnpe of a cat belonging to a family residing about two miles fromNarraooorto, "Charlie " (for that is the feline's name) has gone out every morning on a bunting expedition, and, averaging the spoil, he has brought back at least one rabbit or hare every day. His victims are generaily bares, and frequently they are as largo BB himsolf. Formerly this cat was a good tnöusor, but since "bo hsB taken to a higher game ho looks upon mice with lofty in- difference, as being too insignificant for thc exercise of his prowess. This suggests thc advisability of letting loose a number of cats, which would soon multiply and make them- selves a severe check to the increase of the rodents. If this idea is adopted not much expense will be incurred, as cats are oheap and plentiful.

SEEIOITS ACCIDENT FROM A SPLINTER-,

Tho wife of Mr. Angus M'Kinnon of Chinchilla, whilst engaged in household duties bad the misfortune, some ten days ago, to get a large aplintor of hard-wood (iron bark) into the sole of her left foot ; no notice was taken of it as it appeared only a trifle, and was forgotten; on last Sunday (28th) irregular action of the musoles of the face and neok occurred, with difficulty of breathing ; but as Mrs. M'Kinnon had some time before suffered from chest disease, her husband attributed tho attacks to that. The case getting urgent, he telegraphed to Dalby for medical aid. Dr. W. Howlin saw Mrs. M'Kinnon, extracted the irritant, and seeing she was suffering from traumatic Maim*, which required constant attention, had her conveyed to tho Dalby Hospital for treatment. She now lies In a very precarious condition.-Dalby Herald.

OUTRAOE AND ROBBERT.-On tho morning of December 27 a BeriouB outrage oocurred on the Newcastle branch of the North-Eastern Railway between Shields and Jarrow. It appears that Mrs. Atkinson, fruiterer, Agnes street, South Shields, left by tho 6.54 p.m. train for Newcastle, having in her possession moneys amounting to between £40 and £50, with which she intonded to discharge certain bills or purchase new stock. On the train arrivingat Jarrow station, the gusrd'sottention was direoted to tho compartment into which Mrs. Atkinson had entered at Shields. It was then discovered that she was lying at the bottom of the compartment, apparently in a fit. She was found to be unconscious, and was conveyed to her home, when it was found that her pocket containing the money had been wronohed from ber dress and was gone. She was still unconscious at noon. A few

pieces of silver were found on the carriage floor, and there were marks of a straggle, while her arms and body showed several bruises, The guard pointed out that, as the compart- ment was close to his van, had tho woman screamed he would have heard her cries. The police were investigating the matter at the time the mail left England.

PAINFUL MATTEM.-Thora is sometbiq very odd «nd uncomfortable (remarks th Graphic) ia the recent appearance and disap pearancea of very young girls. Tho imagina tion shrinks from attempting to reconstruc tho history of the poor child whose body wai lately found in s starch box. That she wai murdered seems certain, that 6he wa: murdered with oircomstances of great cruelty seems probable. Worse than all, as no one has missed the girl, as no search was made for her, aa no one has reoognised her, it is a natural inference that she was destroyed by the people who knew ber best, and ought moat to have cherished her. A story not much less unpleasant is told by a correspon- dent of the Daily Netos. This gentleman, writing from Bromley in Kent, Says that in September or October last a young girl was found, apparently at tho point of death, on one of the commons in thc neighbourhood of Bromley. " lier condition was terrible, end defies all description." At the Bromley work- house she was carefully and kindly nursed and restored to life. She is apparently about fiftoeu years of age, has given different names, and absolutely refuses to say who her parents are, whence abo came, or bow she wandered to a suburban common and nearly starved to death there. She is pretty, well educated, and was not badly dressed. Two hypotheses suggest themselves-thc first that the girl bas been cruelly treated at borne ; thc second that she has beeft drawn away from homo or per- haps kidnapped, and is ashamed to return.

The correspondent who tells this story iii the I

*r l ri

[BpitiNeus believes that thçsSiri "Ml

«ander off again to avoid identity, meaning to avojfl being identified. Altogether it Béeras ¿bat mysteries as difficult to unravel as tho

story of the "Woman in White" are not aliao lutolynnknown in real life. Other "mysterious disappearances " from that oitraordinary place West Ham admit of easier explanation.

BouiiHEV AT A CONVENT.-At Adelaide, on Tuesday night the Dominician convent in Franklyn-street was broken into by burglars, who after soaliag the high wall obtained an 'entrance into the main building through a window. They appeared to have set to work to systematically ransack tho whole establish- ment, which they managed without attracting the slightest attention from the inmates. The altar was pnllod down, and the chalice and Silver candlesticks stolen. From the intri- cacies of the building and the rooms through which the robbers had to move, they must hare obtained some prior knowledge of tho place. Thc police have arrested three men on suspicion of being concerned in the robbery. The tops of two candlesticks have been found buried ia thc ground in tho vicinity of tho convent. Tho value of tho booty stolen is

£40.

TUE FISHERIES EXHIBITION.-It ha« been announced that her Majesty will open the International Fisheries Exhibition in person on May 1. The buildings are in a forward atato of preparation. It has been found necessary to provide nearly 250,009 square feet of covered Bpace, at a cost of £20,000. Tbero will bo 20 eea-water tanks, requiring 100,000 gallons of salt water, and as many of fresh water, in whioh the live fish will be exhibited. A novel feature will be a daily demonstration by the cooks of the National Training School of Cookery of the faot that the cheaper and ooaraer kinds of fish, whioh are never seen in the London Marketa, may be more profitably used for food than for manure. A number of large wooden galleries, varying in length from 200ft to 400ft have been

allotted to England, Canada, and the United j States, New South Wales, India, China, ko. ¡

A TERRIBLE FALL.-At Brownhills, near i Birmingham, lately, as a cage containing three ! men were being let down the No. 3 pit belong- ing to tho Cannock Chase Colliery Company, the rope, a comparatively new one, about 3 in.

in diameter, suddenly snapped, and lot the ' cage and its hapless freight to the bottom of the shaft, a distance of about 150 yards, An

exploring party as speedily as possible was ' organised, and the pit bottom having boen reached by means of another shaft, lt was found that thc iron -cage had gone clean through 9in. planks, covering the "sump,"

In which it was mixed with the bodies of the unfortunate men. Under these circumstances the work of recovery was a tedious one, and was not completed till about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, when the corpses were found to be in a terribly mutilated condition. The names of tho unfortunate men are Thomas Collis (50), fireman, married, with six children ; Hebert Grimley (25), pit blacksmith, married ; and Francis Horton (19), unmarried-all of Chase town. The rope had boen properly tested before the men were let down, and nothing was noticed as indipating that it was at all faulty.

THE INFLUJISCE OP FOOD OH GOWS,-Pro- :

fessor Sheldon Bays that the proportion of | butter in milk was much more easily influenced by changes of food than was the proportion of casein ; so that it followed that the nitrogenous

Was more oonstant than the non-nitrogenous , matter. Thus the improvement of milk was more in the direction of an increase of fatty matter, and less in that of an increase of cheesy matter ; therefore the high feeding of cattle was moro advantageous when the milk was used for butter than when it was used for cheese. On tho Derbyshire hills it was a common saying that " the poorest land made tho beat cheese," Paradoxical as this might bo, it was absolutely true, although it assumed that the poor land was sound, in that it required no artificial drainage. CheeBO produced npon such land os this, if properly made, would be better than that produced apon richer soil, The quantity per acre was less, but the quality was superior. Tho reason of th¡B was supposed to bo that the f;rass grown on rich land contained a much arger proportion of the elements which went to form fat, while that grown on poor land contained a larger proportion of the clomcnts which went to form flesh, from the latter of which cheese was made. Another considera- tion was that it was a much simpler and easier thing to make good eheese on sound poor land than apon rich land.

DISTRESSING SHIPWRECK.-The following acoount of a distressing shipwreck, and the severe Bufferings endured by the survivors, is given by the Boulogne correspondent of Thc Tima, telegraphing on February 7:-"The Kenmare Castle, commanded by Captain Barrett, of the Castle line of steamers, left London on January 23 for Hongkong. Sevoral mishaps befell her prior to ber leaving the Channel, and she encountered a strong south-westerly gale in the Bay of Biscay, the bigh Beas completely destroying her steering goar. On Thursday at sunset tho saloon was crushed, and in the course of the night carried bodily away, tho water entoring freely. Thc passengers wera with difficulty conveyed to tbs engine-room, the ladies m their night attire. Finding that the steamer was filling and the Water in the stokehole, a boat was

launched by order of tho captain, who placed all the passengers, a lady from Bedford and her three daughters, Mr. and Mrs. Harrock, of Swatow, China; and Mr. Alexander D. Henry, of Dundee, late of Ceylon, in her. Mr. Holness, second officer, thc third officer, and a crew of seven Chinamen also got in. Scarcely had the beat left, when the VOBBOI sank soddenly, with between thirty and forty men on board. The high ssa threatened at any moment to swamp the boat. Mr. Holness, knowing that he was 160 miles from land, endeavoured to steer in the track of outward

and homeward bound ships, Oa the second day the third officer, from wont of food, be- came mad, and jumped overboard, bot was caved after an hour had elapsed by throwing an oar to him. On tho third day the ladies wore sinking fast. The privation waa intense, no food of any description having been placed in thc boat. Thc lady passengers were tossing for three days in the open sea in their night- dresses ; the only further clothing obtainable boing the men's coats and a shawl. The occu- pants of the boat warn at laat roduoed to chewing Mr. Harrook's flannel vest as their only ration till they were picked up. Several vessels were sighted, and one especially, although quite near, took no notice. On tho evening of the third day tho Montataire bore down and took them all on board. Every kindness was shown to them by the captain and crew of this vessel."

TffE JAMAICA JJANANA TRADE.-A large

and increasing export trade of bananas is j being carried on between Jamaica and tho j United States, chiefly from thc ports of Kings- ton and Fort Antonio, fro n which regular lines of steamers ply monthly, or bi-monthly to New York, Philadcphia, Baltimore, -iud New Orloans, each of thom carrying from 5000 to 10,000 bunches. The banana is an annual, the fruit coming to maturity about a year after thc ehoot is planted, tho trunk of the tree subsequently attaining a height of 8ft. to

10ft., and a girth of 3Cin. From this trunk, ' which is of a fibrous nature, are thrown out long palm-like branches, at thc junction of which appears the fruit, each group of bunches numbering from four to twelve, being called a "hand," and each hand having eight or ten bananas upon it. A bunch of eight bands is the ordinary standard size of ship- ping fruit. From thc root of the tree several shoots or suckers sprout, oach of which, in turn, becomes a fresh tree. Thc life of thc banaua tree, however, is not usually long, for it is foiled after tho fruit is gathered, and sometimes, indeed, during tho operation Jamaica contains a good many banana plan- tations, varying in size from 25,000 to 200,000 trees, for the most part cultivated by tho Bmall settlers in tho different parishes. These holdings generally consist af three or four acres of land, on which tho owners live in a temporary mud hut, being afraid to leave their property to thc tender mercies of their nci/jh ¡ hours, who rob each other's gronnd with thc

I strictest impartiality whenever thoy cm get a

Ifonp«. \^e^ràdÈUia very primitive. The

load l>oing iflMÄTry a big iron hoe, a bole is »dag and the sacker is planted in it, in moat cases natnre doing all that is necessary ; bat in larger plantations the trees are planted with some degree of system in the form of squares, and trenches are dug for irrigation, the banana .thriving best in-darhp, «tiff soil. '. SChe vallie-of the industry is shown by the fact that in 1877 there was Bliipped from Kingston 422,101 worth, whereas in 1882 it was $56,538 ; the amount cloarcd out at Port A ntonio for the

same years being$15,871 and ?I53,l36respec- ' tively. Resides all thia, considerable qaiuitities were shipped from the "ports of Lucca, Montego Bay, St. Ann's Bay, and Port Mara, on the north side of the island. The. average shipping prioo is 50 cents per bunch all tho year round.-Times.

articleText:
KOCICUAMI'TON.

SATURDAY. APRIL 28, 1883.

THE disciples of dynamite appear to be increasing and multiplying exceedingly. The scare created in London and the other large towns in England, by the explosions and rumours of explosions, seems to be almost equal to the terror which they have inspired in Russia. Since the announcement came to hand, that the coronation of the Czar was

positively fixed for an early date, antici- pations of plots and disasters have led people to wonder whether, indeed, the ceremonial would take place, or whether another postponement was inevitable. It is understood that the 27 th of next month is the day named for the cere- mony, and we may be sure that every possible precaution will be taken, to pre- vent the intrusion of any unlriendly and unwelcome guests, at the stately cere- mony, which is then fixed to take place. In spite of this, however, there can hardly fail to be many gloomy fore- bodings among thc loyal subjects of thc Czar Alexander. The air of Russia, as well as the air of the whole European continent, is full of the germs of Socialism, Anarchy, and Nihilism, and the ranks of secret societies include men of all positions, from those of the lowest order of life, to men moving in the highest court circles. Many of the Nihilist conspirators and assassins have already met, on the scaffold ; a death which few will say was not deserved; but at the same time, there does not appear to be the slightest decrease in thal fierce and bitter political discontent, which existed when the present Em- peror came to his throne under circum- stances of peculiar horror and atrocity. Indeed, if the latest news is to be con- sidered reliable, the Nihilists appear to be getting more and more exasperated, at the refusal of the Emperor to grant the demands on which they insist, and they now go so far as to threaten the son with the fate of the father, in consequence of his obstinacy. The boasted civilisa- tion of the nineteenth century may now surely be regarded as myth, for if thc advance of knowledge has made known the existence of dynamite, that very knowledge has also taught, men this tremendous power as a new force in the hands of conspirators. Buildings are to be shattered, lives are to be lost, in order to compel England to let Ireland go ; and in Russia, one Czar is murdered, and his successor threatened with a similar fate, unless the socialistic demands of the secret societies are complied with.' What will he the outcome of the struggle it is impossible to predict. In England, indeed, all the explosions that are threatened and talked of, even if they look place, would be little likely to accomplish the end desired by their perpetration. Damage to property, and loss of life might be caused, but the cul- prits would in due time bc brought to justice, and matters would otherwise go on as before. In Prussia the state of affairs is entirely different, and it is interesting now to recall certain words spoken by M. Gambella about Russia and her political condition. In Russia, M. Gambetta said, lhere are, to all intents and purposes, three Governments,-the official Government of the CZJX, the semi-official Government of llic l'anslavists, and thc Revolutionary

Government of the Nihilists. " Thc official Government of the Czar is at St. Petersburg, the Government of the l'anslavists may be presumed to bc at Moscow, bul the Revolutionary Govern- ment of the Nihilists is everywhere - among the officials of the Empire, the bourgeoisie, and thc common people. Many of ils leaders have been executed ; many more are in prison : but still it cannot be doubled that some are com- fortably quartered in palaces and Slate buildings." In this lies the danger. Nihilism is so widely spread among all classes, that it might bc as well, if the Czar determined to deal with what may almost be termed a national movement by other means than by repression, imprisonment, and the

scaffold ; but, under present conditions, it seems almost certain that another catastrophe is sooner or later inevitable The gradual spread of the principles of Communism and Nihilism is one of the most alarming features of European Society at the present time, for although the secret societies possess more power in Russia than in other countries, it is because of the wide spread political disaffection, and the intolerable burden that the people feel, in living under autocratic institutions. In France and Germany similar powers are at work, but though, in the former country, the Republican form of Government appears at present to act as a species of safety valve, whereby the expression of popular, discontent is afforded full vent ; in the latter country, the lorces of Socialism are only at pre- sent kept in check by military despotism, and the iron rule of the Chancellor Bismarck. In the smaller and adjoining countries, similar forces are at work, and though, at the present time, England appears to be suffering under a tem- porary infliction of the same description, she is indeed the only country in which discontent and conspiracy is con I fined to a very small portion of

Her Majesty's dominions. The disease I is, indeed, localised ; and on this

account cannot be considered incurable. 13ut in Europe such is not the case, and it would be a foolish attempt, on the part of any political prophet, to predict the fate of those dynasties, which are now seated on the various thrones of Continental Europe. The future, indeed, of the old world is dark and uncertain, and though Australia is far removed from the scenes of conspiracies, and their con- sequent deeds of violence, yet it is impossible that a great many must regard with the deepest anxiety, the various dangers and difficulties to which our mojlicr country, as well as the other European communities, are now exposed.
