THE Sydney Heraldo! the 21st instant, in

an articln on tho annexation of new Guinea

says :-It must bo remembered, however,

that, little as Queensland may want New j Guinea, she could ill afford to eec that island pass into other hands ; and what is true of Queensland is true of all the Australian colouies. In some respects also thc future of New Guinea is of more consequence to Great Britain than that of Fiji. If wc do not take New G niñea, Borne other Power will ; ami in thc hands of Germany or France or Italy thc island would involve more expense and more trouble than are likely tu bc thc result of its passiug iuto those of Queensland. Tho Imperial Government will do well to look at both sides of the question. No doubt the step which has been taken is an unusual one. We may add that it is a matter for regret that a policy which so materially affects the whole of thc colouies catiuot in some way or other tic discussed by the colouies as a whole. On thc other hand, however, it must bc remembered that, great as may bc the

interest of New South Wales or Victoria in the future of New Guinea, thc interest of Queensland is much greater. Further, if the political objections to thc present method of annexation are considerable, thc Imancial injections are small. If the Home Govern- ment were to anucx New Guinea, it would have to set up au establishment there, but as part of the colony of Queensland, New Guinea will require no separate Governor and no separate *y8tem of government. As to tho mutter of protection, wu have already in- timated that it is not at all likely that in tho keeping of tho cidonius New Guiuea will givo th« Homo Government nor« trouble tiiaa

would result from ¡ts being annexed by strangers. Upon the wholo, we see no cause for the annoyance which the action of Mr. Chester has occasioned in the House of Commons.

WK have to remind those desirous of heariug intellectual lectures on subjects of interest that the first of thc scries on the world's life

history, «rill be delivered by Mr. William Denton on Monday night. Tho subject for that evening is "Tho Fiory beginning of our Planet." Mr, Denton is oxpectod to arrive from Maryborough, where he has successfully

lectured, in tho Queensland e. to-morrow.

A VERV serious casualty (says the IK. B. Nam) was nearly happening during thc passage of the Geelong steamer from Brisbane to Maryborough. Some time during the middle of thc night the chandelier in the saloon fell down on tho table with a crosh, and thc oil in thc lamp caught fire, the flames spreadiug with a terrible blaze, and threaten- ing the whole ship. Of course thc utmost con- sternation was caused amongst the passengers, but fortunately Mr. C. P. Chistoe, who was on board, brought a blanket from his b-rth, and managed to choke the Hames. One shudders to think what might have happened had it nat been for Mr. Chistoc's presence of

mind.

Ouït (Courier) New South Wales correspon- dent writes :-Tho coup de main of thc Quccnslaud Governni'eut in annexing New Guiuea has excited a good deal of talk in political circles here. It will doubtless bo gratifying to Queensland to know that it bas thc sympathy of ita oolonial neighbours il) taking tliis important step. Thc Premier stated in the Assembly, ou Thursday, in reply to an impromptu question by Sir Henry Parkes, that thc Government had wired to the Agent-General expressing approval of tile annexation. As Victoria has done likewise, thc Queensland Govcrmneut may consider its

hands considerably strengthened in tho 1 business. What with enterprises of such

pith and moment as the Transcontinental | Railway scheme aud the New Guinea seizure, Sir Thomas M'llwraith bids fair to be regarded as the Disraeli of Australia.

TUE splendid establishment known as Millaquin Refinery (says the Maryborough Chronicle), called into existence by the spirited enterprise of Mr. R. Oran and bis sons, was submitted to a formal christening ccromony on Friday night, when a large con- course of guests from all parts of the colony assembled at the invitation of Mrs. Cran to participate in the pleasures of a ball in tho Refinery. The occasion was something more than an act of private hospitality, and the compliment BO gracefully paid to the numerous residents in the district who figured as gueBts was highly appreciated. The services of thc Maryborough Town Band were called into requisition, and the spacious doors of Milla- quin afforded room for tasteful decorations and appointments such as seldom greet thc festive eye in those latitudes. Tho joyous proceedings lasted till a late hour, and thc numerous contingent of Maryborough guests left the ball room for the steamer Queens- land on Saturday morning, tired but happy,

ÏHE11K was quito a stir in crickctiug circles here this week whon it was announced that a redoubtable wielder of the willow, named Bannerman, had arrived in Rockhampton. Each leading club was dcsirouB of inter- viewing him, if only to enrol bim as an honorary member, to try conclusions with au opposing eleven. Some said it was thc re- doubtable Charley Bannerman, tho whilom champion batter, whose praises everyone saug until he began to Bhow a falling-oil in cricket. Others were positive in their assurances it was " Gentle " Alick, tho yuuug brother, who has so lately distinguished himself. The new arrha), Ike Bauucruian, was "trotted" out to ibo practice ground, and handled the bat. An authority on cricket mattera thought ho Bbaped fairly. Just faucy a cricket celebrity like Bannerman shaping fairly. The idea seems preposterous in Rockhampton,

when oue remembers how thc brothers

played for thoir side on the greca sward.

But still more so when it became known that I Uie Bannerman was an ex-detective officer from Brisbane. How our local cricketors could have got up so much excitement without iuquiry appears somewhat strange, Still they live aud will learn.

TUE concert given by Mrs. Bridson's pupils last night, as was anticipated, was a success in cvory way, the hall of the School of Arts being crowded. The concert was opened by thc singing of the chorus "Credo," by eleven young ladies, in a very pleasing manner. This was followed by tho solo "The Red Robin," which Miss Mackean saug with great Bwectucss and clearness. She was assisted in thc chorus by ten other ladies. A duct on two pianos was the next item oo the list, aud was well executed, tho players keep- ing excellent time. Miss L. Lloyd rendered tho solo "Geraldine " very effectively, behm applauded at the finish. MIBB Lona Hill's playing of the instrumental solo, "Carnival de Venise," was excellent ; as was also tho singing of " After " by Miss Jennie Davis. Misses M. Murphy and S. Lloyd next gave the vocal duct "QuiB Est Homo" in such a style as to " bring down tho house," thc way tho first-named young lady went up the high parts being excellent. A duet on two pianos was followed by the solo " For You," which Miss Mackean again rendered very sweetly. A chorus, " When life is brightest," followed, Thc first part concludod with " 'Tis the Harp in the Air," by Miss L. Lloyd. The second part commenced with thc solo " Thc Rest of the Story," givou by Miss Jennie Davis very pleasantly, which was followed by a piano solo by Miss Youug. As soon as Miss Maggie Murphy appeared on thc stage Bbc was greeted with applause, as by ber singing in the duct in the lirst part those present expected a treat, and they were not disappointed, as she sang the ballad " Waiting " with groat feeling and swectucss. Miss Sarah Lloyd rendered thc solo .* Alas those Chimes" very well. Another quartette herc came in, and Miss Murphy gave "Oh, how Delightful " in such a manner as to elicit au cucore. A chorus was next givcu by eleven ladies, followed by thc ballad, "Oh, Erin My Country," which Miss Sarah Lloyd saug excellently. The con- cert was concluded by nu instrumental quartette, and the comic chorus "The Attractive Girl," the Inst verso of which bad to bu repeated in response to an encore. The way tho selections on tho piano were given reflects great credit on their instructress, Mrs. Bridson. The singing of thc Misses Murphy, Mackean, and Lloyd were the features of the evening, and wo arc sure all who visited tho School of Arts last night cujoyed a treat.

TiiKRK were no cases for hearing at the Police Court yesterday.

A sTcTTD-Looiusi; recruit halted before a blacksmith's shop, thc proprietor of which was forging a shoe, aud oj'cd thc performance with much interest. 1'he brawny smith dissatislied with thc man's curiosity, held thc red-hot iron suddenly under Iiis nose, hoping to make him beat a hasty retreat. " If you'll give me a haifa crown 1 will lick it," said thc soldier. " I II stop thc braggart's jaw," thought the smith as he took from lin pocket a half-crown and held it out. The cunning sou of Mais quickly grabbed thc coin, licked it, and walked away whistling " The girl I left behind me,"

articleText:
J CORRESPONDENCE.

FßEE SELECTION.

TO TOE EDITOR OF TUE MORNING BULLETIN.

SIB,-Ferhapi you could inform ma what the words free selection mean in this country? I bare been at a loss, sad have puzzled my brain many a time to try and find out. The reason I ask ÍB I know a few parties living near the Bawson Bridge : some of them have spent a great deal to earn a living. They tried, on different oocasions, to select land or purchase it, and the answer on all occasions was simply no. Now, let any one look at the gardens along the Central Railway, and see if they can say it is impossible to make a home for families. Some have lived near the railway for a great many years, and have never con- tributed anything to the Treasury for the maintenance of nie railway ; and those that have done both, and have made a temporary home, are now in any moment at the mercy of fate, and any Improvement which I know they have made avail them nothing; whereas, if the land had been their own they could olaim a right to their labours. Now, Mr. Editor, is it consistent with the land laws in this country, that all along the Central Railway, from Gogango to the head of the line, there is not one foot of land to be either selected or purchased, or obtained even for the grace of God. That ie the meaning of settle- ment in Queensland. They talk about Ireland ; but, bad as it is, you can get land for money there. But in this country side where I write about, I have known parties that were willing to pay, and could not get a square inch. That is according to my experience the prac- tice of free selection and settlement in QueenB Blsnd. Now, air, if the Government would take it into their head, and throw the land open along the Central Bailway, and let any one that thinks fit secure a spot to live on, I think it would confer a great benefit on the country. Hoping I have not taken up too much of your valuable space.

1 am, bir, {co.,

A LOOKER-ON.
heading: CORRESPONDENCE. FREE SELECTION. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

articleText:
KOCK ll A M l'TO N.

SATUHDAY. AUGUST IS, 1SS3.

Tun news that Sir Stafford Northcote's motion repudiating M. de Lesseps claim to a monopoly of Canal construction across the Isthmus of Suez, has been re- jected by a lar^e majority in thc English House of Commons seems to intimate that Mr. Gladstone will be left almost unfettered as to the course he deems

advisable to pursue in the matter. The preliminary agreement whic

entered into between the English ' Government and M. de Lesseps pro- vided that the Suez Canal Company were to make another Canal alongside their present one, on condition that the English Government give securities fur the land required, and provide ^8,000,000 for the execution of the works, the Company in return consent- ing to allow an Englishman to occupy

the office of vice-President of the

Directorate, English pilots to navigate vessels through the channels and to re- duce to some extent the rate of charges. Naturally enough these conditions are regarded as quite inadequate' by the English shipowners, and as they own about four-fifths of the vessels that pass through the Canal, it seems only reason- able that they should expect to exert a preponderating influence on its manage- ment. The high rate of dues and the frequent stoppages and delays in the present canal, have already acted very

prejudicially toward British interests, and | the Chambers of Commerce have only represented the opinion of theshipowners and the public in protesting against the repetition of such a state of things in the second Canal. In consequence of such an expressed opposition, itseemsthat the English Government despatched Sir Charles Rivers Wilson to negotiate with M. de Lesseps as to the financial details of the new scheme, but nothing appears to have been definitely arranged, for M. de Lesseps has announced his deter

mination of proceeding with the construction of the second Canal, and promised to reduce the tariff charges in proportion to the increased profits realised. That the duplication of j the Canal will be a profitable investment I there appears no room to doubt. In

1882 the gross receipts exceeded those of 1881 by upwards of .£370,000, I or nearly 3^ per cent on ten millions of

! capita! ; and it is calculated that the 1

double Canal, with the increased traffic, , would pay a good dividend at half the

I rates which are at present exacted.

This being the case, and it being the fact that this large amount of revenue is i furnished almost entirely by British I shipping, and that the Canal is now the

recognised highway between England and India, as well as her Australian Colonies, it seems a manifest injustice that English shipowners should have such a small share in the management. Mr. Gladstone has, however, admitted j that the concessions granted to M. de ! Lesseps, secured to the present company

the exclusive right to traffic by means of I a Canal to the Isthmus of Suez, and

therefore it appears that it will be neces- sary for the present to acquiesce in the construction of the second Canal by the I original Company. There can be no I doubt also, that the predominant position

held by England in Egypt is a source of jealousyand concern to French politicians. The successful termination to which the insurrection of Arabi Pasha was brought by the English troops, was a bitter pill for a nation like the French to swallow. By abstaining from co-operation with

the English and refusing their assistance to maintain order in Egypt, they thought to embarass the British Government, bul now find that they took the one step that was necessary to secure the pre- dominance of England. The only triumph that can console them in their dejection is that the Suez Canal was a French not an English enterprise, that even the idea was treated by English- men as chimerical, and then when its construction was satisfactorily accom- plished that it is Englishmen, more than any other nation, who are forced to make use of it. Under the circumstances, it is natural enough that the Suez Canal is a pet hobby and pride of most Frenchmen and that it is regarded as a species of triumph ovar pervidious Albion. It may therefore be supposed that Mr. Gladstone's Government consider that it would be both unwise and impolitic to adopt any course that would offend the easily roused susceptibilities of the French in this matter. The second Canal cannot be constructed without money, which must he supplied to a great extent by English capitalists and the power of the purse will therefore necessarily remain in English hands. Our present position in Egypt also, makes il probable that in time of war, it would be incumbent on the British

troops Jboth to maintain order in the country and to secure the perfect safety and neutrality of the Canals, acourse which might thus from a variety of reasons, cause some decided change to be made in the new management as now conducted hy the French Company. It seems, how- ever, probable at the present time that increased consideration will have to lie

shown toBritishinterests,orthatotherwise | English capiul will not be given, and in ' the event of M. de Lesseps being unable j to carry out his expressed intention of constructing a duplicate Canal on account of his disregard of those interests, it would be certain that the force of opinion in England would be in favour of the enterprise being carried out by means'of an English Company. There is as yet no reason to doubt that matters will he put on a satisfactory footing to all concerned, and that though nuny complicated details will necessarily have to be discussed before any understanding can be arrived at, yet M. de Lesseps and the French Company can hardly be so blind to their own interests as to risk thc construction of any rival Canal to compete with their own. Thc facility of the passage ot vessels through the Cana! is one of the questions which touches these colonies most closely, for a quick and easy com- munication with the mother country is in these days a matter of the utmost importance to the merchants and busi- ness men in Australia, and it can there- fore be a matter of little surprise that the interest taken in the négociations which are now pending have been watched here with considerable anxiety. The protests which have been lur-var.lj.l from these colonies, as well as the remonstrances of the British ship-owners, have doubtless had considerable effect in inducing Mr. Gladstone to press M. de Lesseps for further concessions, and

it appeats highly probable that a fair and amicable agreement will shortly be con-

cluded.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. SATURDAY, AUGUST 18, 1883.

articleText:
1

KOCK II A Ml' I ON.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1883.

WE are not surprised to learn that the settlers in the vicinity of Mackay are beginning to complain of the wanton and complete extermination ot birds in that district by the Kanakas employed on the sugar plantations. These coloured gentry have come within the pale of Christianity, so far as Sabbath observance is concerned, inasmuch as they enjoy a holiday once a week, which they spend in roaming about with fowl- ing pieces, and more primitive engines of destruction, with which they wage a ruthless war upon the leathered tribes. The consequence is the latter are rapidly disappearing. We dare say thc settlers are not much moved to complain of this on aesthetic grounds, but we have no doubt many of them are touched hy the absence of the vocalists of the groves and scrubs. Though the songs of the latter do not flood the car with melody like the lark at heaven's gale singing ; like the throstle cock, with yellow bill, fluting in the dawn ; like the mellow m ivis that " hails the nightfall ;" or like plaintive Philomel, mourning in the dewy night, their " «¡ld woodnotes," possess a strange chirm, and diffuse sweet aiis of sound amid the pre- vailing silence of the lovely bush. Hut apart from the murder of nature's choristers, and the enforced silence of thc scrubs, the settlers must objjcl to war upon winged things, on the ground thal their interests are thereby likely to suffer. Even though they have no' read

of the results of avicidc in other coun- tries, limited consideration and observa- tion will convince them that il «ill be detrimental lo their interes's. The law of life, like all others of nature's institu- tion, cannot be rudely and wantonly violated, without ihose who commit the outrage being penalised in consequence. Life though bestowed with prolusion by Nature, u nevertheless in some degree, as il were, held sacred ; and its wanton destruction is generally followed by im- plosant results. When the balance of power is destroyed a period <»f disorder and ceiier.il sufTei'm^ follows. Il is probable the selectors on thc Endeavour River dread the material consequences, which are likely to succeed the destruc

lion of their bird companions ; and it is well they are alive lo ihe danger. Birds are a power in the economy of the universe. Like oilier creatures they have a beneficent work to do in main- taining the order of things ; and, if they are interfered willi to any great extent, their work is not done, and physical disorder follows. This has been repeatedly taken notice of by naturalists and students of life in its varied forms. In many countries it has

been observed that when birds were destroyed insect pests began to multiply, and did so at such a rapid rate that their feathered enemies had to he induced to reappear again upon the scene, or mau

had to take such measures as were within his reach to restore the balance

of power. In the United Kingdom gamekeepers are employed to kill such wild quadrupeds and birds as prey upon game-birds and their young. Weasels, cats, polecats, martens have been abolished from the list of native fem natura: ; and hawks, owls, jays, magpies, crows are being greatly reduced in numbers. The entire disappearance ol the latter is only a question of lime, if the destructive system is persisted in. The result is that small birds of the finch tribe have been contantly on the increase, and were it not for the opera- tions of bird catchers, would be a serious nuisance. As il is, tiley are pests to the farmers and seed growers of the southern counties. The stork-dove or wood

pigeon has also increased to such an extent that farmers in some counties have felt compelled to form societies for its destruction. Prices are paid for pigeon's heads and eggs, just as they ave in this colony for marsupial scalps. In France again wild animals and birds of all kinds are killed for the pot, and

the land seems desolate without them. The result of this interference with nature's arrangements is that insects have become plagues. This has been more remarkably the case in tropical countries. Insect life in them is more abundant, and varied in its forms. Reports from South Australia inform us the farmers there have been suffering from a plague of grasshoppers. The birds seem to have been driven out by drought, and unchecked in their increase the locusts are ravaging the fields. Something of this kind is doubtless what the farmers near Mackay dread, and with good reason. While birds are death to grasshoppers, we must not forget they also live upon forms of insect life not so noticeable by man. Insect-feeding birds do not confine themselves to one article of diet, and many of the less noticeable species; of insects are not the least injurious to vegetation. Many kinds of blight arise from minute insects living on the sap of the plants on which they appear. These animalada: are the food of larger living forms, and these again are calen by others, till birds appear as the destroyers of the more robust. There is a living chain, and if any of the links be broken the consequences become apparent. If the wanton and ruthless destruction of birds is continued around Mackay, there is every reason to suppose that the canefields may suffer. Of this, we may be certain, thal fruit pests will become numerous. In their crawling and flying slates, insects will multiply, unrestricted by the presence of their natural enemies. But while il is highly desirable that regard should be paid to the wishes of the agriculturists at Mackay, and that the Kanakas should be restrained in their destructive pro- clivities, some method should he observed in the matter. Deslruclion in one sphere, and preservation in another, are equally liable to be altended with disagreeable results. If any regulations are to be made on the subject they should be the result of careful and con- tinued experience. Mere haphazard rules are likely to do as much harm as good. They must be carefully con- sidered, and some care must be exercised in enforcing them. By this means legitimate sport may be preserved, ihe laws of life observed, and interference with the rural industry prevented.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER IO, 1883.

THE WEER.

SIR ANTHONY M usn HAVE, Govornor of Quoouslanrl, reached Brisbane on Tuesday last, and Parliament having put off its meet- ing for a day, ile was received with all the pomp and dignity becoming bis High position ; he was nccomp{uicd by Lady Musgravo. On Tuesday he vPis sworn into office as Ad- ministrator of tho Colony, and on Thursday was present at the opening nf Parliament. His speech was a manifesto of the policy of thc Ministry, lt is penned as if tho projects in it were to bo carried out, but there is uot thc least likelihood nt that being done fur come time to come at least. One ol'jeet of the Ministry in meeting Parliament has evi- dently been to get on opportunity of laying before the country, in an explicit anil formal manner, a list nf tho matters they deem of most pressing interest, and which should command thc attention of tho legislature. This also appears from the proceedings in Parliament ou Thursday evening. Ministers brought forward a motion fer printing the proposed expenditure of estimates in ) 883-4. The Hou. S. Vf. Griffith moved they bu nut printed, SD that thc paper might not hecotnr; a record of thc House. Tho House rejected the proposal, .ind others of a similar character, submitted with a similar object. Tho Premier then spoke, and embodied thc contentB of tbc papers in bis Bpeoch. After sonic discussion the House adjourned till Tuesday next,

BEFORE the echoes of thc distant contest in the Cook electorate have died away, thora come from Brisbane tho reverberations, which tell of the concluding battlo iu tho great electoral struggle. At the polls thc Ministry were de- feated, and it only remained for their antago- nists to put forth their power and drive them from office. The Opposition havo lost no time in makiug manifest their intention. On Wednesday, when the House met and was con- stituted by Commission, thc first business to be disposed of was the election of a speaker. The Government, not having Mr. King within reach to recal to his old position, proposed the Senior Member for the Leichhardt, Mr. John Scott. The Opposition proposed Air W. H. Groom, one of thc members for Toowoomba. AgainBt his appointment tbe Premier offered a most vigorous protest. He expressed astonishment at Mr. Griffith having the audacity to propose as President of the House a man to whom the judges of the land could

not accord the full liberties of a free citizen.

Other members were equally plain spoken in their pretests, but on a division the appoint- ment of Mr. Groom was carried by twenty nine votes to seventeen. To emphasise their objections the Ministry proposed a member of the Opposition, Mr. Fraser, but the solid phalanx on the other Bide remained unbroken, Mr. Scott's vote alone swelling tho minority. In order that strangers to tho colony may undcrstaud the objection to Mr. Groom, wo may explain that he was transported for life from the United Kingdom ; is a ticket of leave man ; and, report says, has boen twico convicted of crioio in tlic colonies. At the general election in 187S he was returned as a supporter of tho Conservative party, aud when tho Douglas administration was ousted, he put forward claims to office. These were not entertained whereupon he joined thc Opposition, and be- came one of thc most influential men in its ranks. His position as proprietor ot' the Toowoomba Chronicle baa given him consider ! able political influence. [Ie has alan been

Mayor of thc Municipality, ami in that I capacity was brought iu contact with the late

I Governor, Kir Arthur Kennedy, wlio liai a [ country residence near Toowoomba. Mr.

Groom improved his opportunities, embraced every occasion that offered to flatter tbc vanity of Sir Arthur Kennedy and his daughter, and had his name associated with theirs. On this ground it is possible Mr. Griffith may arguo that society haB condoned Mr. Groom's offences, but an astute lawyer should seo that the Mayor of Toowoomba is au official thc Governor could not cBoapo recog- nising, but that an unforgiven convict is quite a different person. In connection with tho election of Mr. Groom to the Speakership of tho Assembly, we would recall to thc minds of our readers the words used by the Leader of the Opposition at tho Ipswich banquet, "They (tho Ministry) had exhibited theiu eelves to tho other Australian Colonies, and to tho whole world, as sotting at de6ance, and trampling under foot every rule that was in other countries laid down and recognised, be- cause there were iu politics, as in private life, certain unwritten mles of honour which men were supposed to observe." We leave it to our readers to judge, whether tho gentleman who ottered thcBC words, and those who supported him, in thc appointment of a convict to the Speakership of thc Legis- lative Assembly, have not only set at defiance and trampled uuder foot, rules of honour recognised in other countries, but have offered an insult to every honest man in this colony. When thc Speaker went on Thursday to be sworn in to office be was not accompanied by any of the members of the Ministerial party. People are saying-What will they think of us in the other colonies? But wo may ask What will they think of us in America and Europe 1 What will they think of ns in Eog : laud 1 Indeed-what will they think of us in

China 1

A REFERENCE to tho division liât shows that thc vote ia tho Assembly on Mr. Groom's appointment was a purely party ono. Mem- bers like Mr. Dutton and Mr. Hurley, who were not supposed to have committed them- selves as members of tho Liberal Party, have formed part of the solid phalanx. This shows the decided determination of tho Iscador of tlio Opposition that Mr. Groom should bo appointed. It also shows thc influence

the latter has obtained in thc counsels of the Liberal Party. There can be no doubt he enforced his claim to ofGcc, if not by what be did now, hy his conduct when he waa refused office before. Had he boen discarded now he might not have had tho courage to go back to his old friends, but by his secession he would have made a serious breach in the Liberal ranks. The inference from the whole proceed- ing plainly seoms to be that tho Leader of the Opposition is prcparod to violate thoBe unwritten rules of honour, to which he so recently called our attention, rather than put in peril the unanimity of his party.

articleText:
CO Hit ESPONÜUKCIS.

THE GAS.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORN INO BULLETIN.

SIR,-Your commenta on the affaira of tho GnsCompany, would, I believe, have been very different had you cared to inquire into all the circumstances of thc connection of the new mains in East-street yesterday. Since tho departure of our pseudo engineer great incon- venience has been experienced by the public from thc condition of the broken footpaths. So soou, however, as the Directors realized that they must help themselves, instructions were giveu to finish the mains and services. Thc work commenced at daylight yesterday (Monday), and was continued without inter- mission until 10 p.m., whenthctask was com- pleted. The men employed worked for eighteen hours ; a great part of the time with the heat at 100 in thc shade. This work had to be done in the full blaze ot the sun and in a stooping posture. It is a matter of admira- tion that thc physical strength and endurance of these Englishmen and their pluck and courage did not give way under such a severe

and prolonged strain. Also it is a matter of 1 thankfulness that tho storm indicated by the i barometer did not reach us. From your tele

graniB tins morning wc leam that our neigh- bours at Toowoomba have been less fortunate. This calamity of the destruction of the Gas WorkB at Toowoomba, killing the manager, who leaves a widow and ten children, will I am sure, awaken the) sympathy and help of very many in Queensland, lt will

give mc much pleasure to receive subscrip-l tiona for Mr. Webber's family, and I know! well that our Rockhampton public will respond j and enable mc to send such a subscription as J will show that gas people who try to do theij^

duty are not quite so bad os you would majfe

people believe wc arc. I

Yours truly.

HENRY MILLS,

Secretary Gas Company.

November 13, 1883.

[Instead of beginning at daylight tbe Com- pany's men should have commenced at mid- night on Sunday so as to have the earthworks cleared away from the pipes at daylight, and the cuttiug aud connecting done during thc day. By getting through their work in tho cool morning thc men would not bave had their physical powers taxed in the manner Mr. Mille refers to.-ED. M.J3.]

articleText:
TRANSCONTINENTAL RAILWAY.

TO THE EDITOR OP TUE MORNINfi BULLETIN.

Sin,-I should think all true patriots would hail with satisfaction tho successful negotia- tion by thc Premier with Mr. Houry Kimber, the agent of the English Syndicate, of an agreement to construct the Transcontinental Railway on thc land-grant system. There can be little doubt among the unprejudiced but what the completion of this écheme of tho Premier's would place Queensland in thc front rank of the Australian colonies, and that we should soon have a large agricultural and pastoral population located in the interior, which, by means of the great arteries of com- merce, the railway lines wonld cause an immense trade to spring up between it and the principal coastal towns, bringing wealth and prosperity to all.

Of oourse, that partisan journal, the Daily Northern Argus, gnashes its teeth with rage, now that it sees the Premier will, at the next

meeting of Parliament, be able to place before it an agreement for ratification, which is cal- culated to confer such great benefits

people will view it without prejudice, they must acknowledge this grand scheme of the Premier's, will advance the interests of the whole people, and confirm them in tho admitted prosperity which they uow enjoy. The completion of the Transcontinental line, with the ramification of the branch lines, will be the crown of that building, the foundations of which the Premier has already laid, and will raise Queensland into a powerful, rich, and populous state in a very few years.

But this policy of progress, foresight, and commou sense, has set your contemporary and thc rest of the so-called Liberal Press, on the rampage again, and they arc venting their splenetic rage in efforts of vituperation and disparagement. Your contemporary would have us believe that an imbecile yielding to the implacable howlers, and clamour of a clique, is constitutional conduct-and that the firm standing by the constitution ÍB tyranny, sud despotism. But I in no way identify the matter contained in the leaders of the Argus with the opinions of the people. It is simply the organ of a clique, whose object is to pre- vent the advance of Rockhampton, and they muBt hook on that old drag, the Anjm, to thc wheels of our progress,

when the Brisbane firm of Griffith and

Co. consider our pace is getting too fast. They mean not only to check tho speed, but to place obstructions in the way to overturn thc Rockhampton coach. When I bring to mind tlic windings and thc turnings of the A rguK upon those vital questions that concern our prosperity, which one day is for one thing and anuthcr day opposed to it ; I am induced to exclaim-ls it possible, the utterances of that maudlin paper can have any weight with the people of Rockhampton, when the pros- perity of this town is concerned ? Have they not marked the conduct of this weakling in our camp ? It may be that they are blind to thc insiduous assaults of the Argiis at their best interests, and require thc dust to bc wiped from their eyes, before they can see clearly.

Then let us examine the conduct of the Argus upon some of those questions that affect our welfare. First, we will take the Port Alma railway. On this question the Argita is plainly trying to thwart the project,

because it knows it would benefit Rock I hampton, end therefore it gives the cnn , il nf

a " Bushaia" to cause disaster, lt takes its

[ euc from Brisbane politicians ; the honourable

George Thorn for instance, who bas said

upon tho colony, and

the

that tbs whistlo of the first locomotive at Port Algia will Bound the death, knell of Rockhampton, when, if be really thought so, he wgnld be, the'first to recommend the prosecution of the railway. But the . knell

that it would sound would bè the demise of the Brisbane trade with tho north, and that of Brisbane as the capital of the colony. That we have good grounds for the suspicion that tho Argus is playing the traitor, the following will show :-When the river training wall was proposed thc Argua had leader after leader in disparagement of it, and denounced the work aa a folly, and argued in favour of a railway ; but now when we have the opportunity of both deepening our river and getting a railway it argues against a railway and proposes an absurdity which it knows will never be attempted, and sets forth the advantages of improving our river. The evident object ÍB to cause vacillation in onr opinions, and to baulk both projects, and retard the improvements to thc approaches of our town.

Again, when capital from Victoria was being introduced into our western country the Argus denounced that. Yet no one will now deny thatourpresent prosperity ispartly caused by the introduction and distribution of that capital among our merchants and wage-earners. Again when our Trunk line of Railway was proposed to bo carried out due west, the Argun, mindful of the interest of the Brisbane clique, fought hard to divert us from our pur- pose, and advocated a detour through Peak Downs towards Aramac. Again, how stren- uously it has worked, and is working to prevent the establishment of the sugar industry in Rockhampton.

In fact when one comes to think over these things it is plain the injury Rockhampton has sustained through the evil councils of the Argus is incalculable-But the nature of the disease being once known the proper remedies can bo applied. Doubtless the Libearal journals will go into hysterics of joy over the doings of the masses-how easily can it be made " them asses "-at the Towers, who, after being thoroughly humbugged-if the telegrams are correct-harnessed themselves to the carriage of their idols, Messrs. Griffith and Dickson, apparently without the slightest con sciousneBs'.that they had been humbugged and tho degraded and ridiculous position they were placing themselves in. No wonder after that exhibition of servility by the working mon of Charters Towers thc Argus, while commenting upon the Cingalese, imply that £20 per year with rations was quite good enough for Euro- pean labourers, yet most of them who dragged the car of Mr, Griffith receive from £3 to £4 per week. And tho Argus is doubtless pluming itself upon its discernment that " them asses " are not capable of distinguish- ing between a demagogue and a statesman, and know not that in politics the demagogue standB in thc (same relation to a statesman that a quack doctor does to a physician, which is the position Mr. Griffith and Sir Thomas M'll wraitb. respectively occupy in politics.

Yours, &c.,

ANTI-HUMBUG, Rockhampton, Jannary 2, 1883.

articleText:
--rr---?---:

ROCKHAMPTON.

FRIDAY. JANUARY 26, 1883.

T#í tendency of all the" colonies to : undertake large 'monetary responsibilities to Erigtisfi capitalists,has lately attracted the attention »f both the . English and -'Colonial Press, and it certainly seems to be the. general opinion that the colonies1 bave, one and' all, been ^contracting

National Debts on mach too extensive i'a scale. In countries, where indirect taxákion is ari institution, and direct taxation;'totally abolished, the majority of people do not realise at first how heavily the liability presses on them which takes ? their revenue to pay interest merely while the great National responsi-

bility goes ion increasing. Of course, in - 'young countries where a large revenue is

?obtained. from the sale.oï Crown lands, and wjjerp '. taxation is comparatively light, the payment of interest on loans does not press inconveniently, but it

must be botne in mind that the colonies

are every year parting with the public

estate. This means that the assets of

every colony ' are becoming lessened, while their liabilities are steadily in- creasing. In answer to such objection it is only fair to say that those who favour

this state that if the Crown lands be

passing but, of the hands of,the Govern- ment, that public works of a remunera- tive order are being constructed, and that the assets are therefore not melting away. It is further argued that a great portion of the money realised (rom the sale of Crown lands is expended in rail- way'construction^ and that every mile of railway increases the value of land in its vicinity almost double. This last argu- ment may be readily disposed of by slating that before the government land has a. chance to rise in value on the

/approach-of a railway line, it is bought up at cheap rates, so that when the rail- way enhances its value it does so for the benefit of some private person, not for the government of the country. Also, land is allowed by the government gene- rally to' be ' so Surveyed that the cream of it is picked out,: and the unpurchased lots left in unsale- able shapes or positions, thus securing them to a certain purchaser at his own price. From this it may fairly be said that the Government do not reap much benefit from railway construction, so far as it enhances the value of land. As to the other statement, it must be remembered that all thc public works obtained in exchange for the lands require a considerable outlay to .keep them in working order, that many of

them are not remunerative-such as

costly public buildings, and the improve- ments of parks, gardens, and public luns-and that some of them actually entail a loss upon the country yearly, to keep serviceable-roads and bridges are of this class. There can be no question whatever; that the policy now pursued by several of the Colonies simply amounts to lessening the assets, and increasing the liabilities ; and any busi- ness man knows bow that ends, sooner or later, in private affairs. National insolvency, is of course, almost impos- sible, for if the country that has taken up loans to another nation cannot pet its interest, it seizes the revenue, even by force of arms, and increases taxation until the liability is met. Such pro cedings generally result in bloodshed, revolution, and wide spread misery.

About a fortnight ago Sir William Jervois, the Ute Governor of South Australia, took occasion in bring- ing to a close his successful term of service as regal representative in that

Colony,, to bpftu out the danger of South j(ustrau^" continuing to increase nts monetary responsibilities. He pointed out that the lofDs raised and authorised by that Colony atfJtHint to ¿£14,000,000 sterling, and ¡that Vie Colony only has 290,000 inhabitants who are the conjoint debtors for that amount.

This really means that, «very resident ip < South Australia is a debtor to the extentJ of over ¿£48, As one half, .the, popula-

tion are not worth anything like this sum ? it practically amounts to a liability of ¿£96 on 195,000 i people; 1 : In fact beyond question a, debt of ¿£14,000,000 nj a country of 290,000 inhabitants, is a

very tidy sum no matter how you look 1 at it. Referring to this . conditionof 3 affairs Sir William says : - If it si? 1

happened that there 'should come.j together a shortness of money here, bad seasons, and perhaps financial tightness in London-events whithl venture, tflf say may be regarded as: pqssjbjlittes-r the crisis here would be ^seriously aggravated, and all would suffer. The working nun, the propertied class alike would feel it, and all are interested in putting the finances of the colony in the proper position to resist any such strain." His Excellency then went on to show that the proper way «. ease the strain- of

the debt was to add to the population. J ,"I know" .he, sáid, ' "ther£"',ï?,.';an | idea, prevailing very often on the part of the working men, - that ' immigra- tion will do . them. harm, , and that high wages mean, .great, .employ- ment ;. but that is, not the catie, geode men, as you all know.: You -may have more wages and inoré employment with a large population, and less wages and. less employment with a small popula-' 'lion. I do not propose immigration with a view" of reducing' wagés/bùl I propose it in the interest of all. Immi- gration would help to pay the interest, on your debt, and what is more, looking at it from a working man's' standpoint,

it would Vender necessary rppre jhöuses,.

and give more employment for builders, clothiers, shoemakers, and more employ- ment all round ; and, of ' course; would improve the market for farmers' produce,, and promote settlement." These first class . utterances simply mean this: Stop borrowing and increase the num-. tier of settlers in the country. Then, if we cease borrowing how can we construct great railways-why they would have to .remain, unbuilt for ages at this rate. There is one way out of the dilemma-construct railways on the land-grant principle, and thus cease" increasing the national liability, and lessen the burden of that already in- curred by increasing the number of

colonists. ?

This subject can hardly be left with- out noting, the great disinclination in some quarters to bear the naked truth. We put it plainly and. unmistakably that

the borrowing powers : of the colonies,, have been overstrained. When this is said, it does not mean that financial ruin is staring us in the face; it does ,not. mean that We shall never again be able .to borrow money in the English market; but it does mean that it is our duty to carefully watch our liabilities, and see that they do not increase inordinately, while our assets are diminishing. . The liability of this Colony amounts at present to about ¿£ 13,245,150, âtid the popula- tion is put down at 227,000! Thus we have a liability amounting td ^58 per

bead, on each resident; . Since: the returns ort which this is based were made up, immigration has increased the population, and so reduced the debt per head to slightly less ;, but this is quite too much liability. It may not be too muchif we go on addingtoourpopulatiori, and . not ¡ adding to our, .debt. The people in the country must have food and clothes, and revenue can' be obtained from them indirectly by taxing these, so that when the population has> increased so as to ensure a revenue

proper, . sufficient to pay ? interest oh 1 borrowed capital, and Carry on the government, of the country, we may again borrow capital if necessary. The interest at 4 per cent on :the

¿£13,245,150 borrowed amounts to t '¿£529,806,.^ annum, and the revenue ' being ¿£2,023,668 for 1881-2 there is left for the carrying on of the govern- ment of the country, the maintenance of non-remunerative worjes, charitable institutions, penal establishments, &c, ¿£1,493,862. When it is taken into considerâtion that one-fourth of the reveriue-¿£2,023,668- is derived from land sales, and we deduct thjs irom it, we get the revenue proper at £1,517,742. and; taking from this the interest to be yearly paid, the case looks worse, for we only have ¿£987,936 to carry on with yearly. Then it must be borne in mind that bad seasons would materially affect our revenue should thpy happen, that is there would be a less consumption of dutiable articles if money became scarce. So that it simply amounts'to this : we would have barely enough revenue for the requirements of the colony if we laid out our, land revenue in permanent works-as we should even supposing seasons of prosperity succeeded each other regularly. Let one season of a disastrous nature overtake us and we should imme-

diately feel the weight of our self im- posed burden of national debt. This would necessitate increased taxation. Plainly, therefore, our policy should be increase the population, and let borrowing alone, until we have secured a revenue proper, that will pay interest on the national debt, and defray thc cost of government, making allowance for all possible contingencies. This is a safe course, and will be found in the long run among the surest roads to lasiing prosperity.

A SUSSE of duty to tho ratepayers of the Municipality induces us to call attcntiôu to what we regard ns culpublo carelessness in tho conducting of tho recent municipal election. Clause 7b* of the Local Government Act pro- vides-"No person who acts os returning officer at any election, shall be or become a candidate for arjy offico at such election." The public notices of the election were issued on the 12th instant signed by Mr. Sharples as Returning Officer ; and they continued to

austin .this JfortMie ptffV HU tbs 2*4 faltan» IMO nflfcje oft« elecjjfcn Wu tjfaedny jyJerBttn WifclnsÄ who «Med as jjffurrfgg

yloottçn, Ala*man^hn,rpläfiouldVot issue ^njuíiptioe as retarniog o'fficer ; ño other pdcipe was ÎBBued than his informal one ; and, it is a question, therefore, whether the rate- payers having received no proper notice, the

instant, attention was called to the,fact that

Mr. Sharples. , he}ni.'fl candida^

aot aa ' rettlrnlng officer, 'and Alderman . Sumner was appointed. Then again, with \ Regard to the return of Mr. Wakefield, matters were not as they ought to have been. TJp till a late hour on Wednesday afternoon this gentleman was a contractor under the Council, and as such, under olaune 85 of .the Local Go- vernment Act was debarred: froto being or continuing to be a Oonnoillor. 1 .for the pur 'pose of removing his disability tu this respect lie transferred his contract, and the Mayor, Without consulting tbe; Cqunoilfagraedi to the transference. Of course bis Worship had no .right to arrogate the -power of the whole

j Council in this fashion, and even though the

latter homologate bis-action,' vre"question if 'that will mena matters much. Being ia ooh'-" tractor, when be was elected, Mr. Wakefield, we are afraid, cannot legally hold-his seat. For Mr. Wakefield we have great sympathy, as he did the best he could, when he became aware of bis disqualification, to rid himself of

it, but fae was evidently too late. :>Heinuet,.' before acting in the Council, ascertain whether, being incapacitated, he shall not be liable, "for every such offence to a penalty of fifty pounds,, ano^ such. penalty -may be re- covered by ahy1 persori-with free costs of suit." It seems to UB our municipal authorities have been somewhat remiss in their duty on this occasion.

Ur to a late "hour last night telegraphic*

/communication with thesouth was interrupted by thunderstorms,;land /therefore lour late telegrams are not to hand.

BEFORE the ; Police' Magistrate, 'yesterday ' morning, one drunkard' Was discharged and another fined five shillings. Peter Johnston was fined five shillings, for being drunk and disorderly.

THE-weather yesterday was exbeodihtJTy hot1 during the forenoon, but towards evening a cool breeze sprang up. ' At about' half-past

ten at night a heavy shower of. rain fejl, . which wiU'bo'generally'appreciated. ' ' ' '

OWING to the steamer Governor Blackall not leaving Bundaberg till ten yesterday morning,

the Mastodon Minstrel tr jupo were unable to . reach Rockhampton in time to give the'per-

formance in the, Theatre-Boyal as advertised* ' | They will, however, open to-night, nod previous to the performance the Company's brass band will parade the streets.

A CRICKET match of more than usual

interest will take plibeai North Rockhampton

'to-morrow, (Saturday)..afternoon, oominenoiag; |

at half-past two, between a team of All- comers, and the Eleven who so easily defeated thé Bogantungan representativos on Saturday last. The following team ha«; boon chosen for the AU-cotners :-Messrs, J. W. Rutter, F. Milford, J. Bartlem, P. S. Russell, E. Ross, A. Oxenham, G. Boldeman, G. B. Jones, F. Cheshire, A. J. W. Braxton.

A GENTLEMAN informs us of what he calls

something new under the sun, a$ least .in.this,, district.' Much to the, gçftfafioàùon^ ?f m¿ny Of the passengers' ' by the down train on

Wednesday, grapes ,were, offered I fbHissleHiá' i shilling; bags, ' at one ?at the' tank ' stations. - .Wine in nature's'bottle ir'vei^.^atefuT'on'j ; such bot days es we have had lately.- It is ' surprising that something of this'tobrt bas not ! been done before. : Grapes róllgroW'álmost ¿ny

Where in this 'climate, and 'they 'might 'be-'' offered for aale with -profit td' the prodboèr, and .pleasure to the obusu'raer, at'»lost of! the stopping places on Ure line;

WE understand that aTl'.the immigrants that

were tor hire at the depot, and who reoently ? arrived per the Almora, have been engaged at satisfactory rates. We believe that the

rute of Wager at whiöb'tne 1äst'Töt'of_s'ingle~~ men hired at, was from twenty to twenty-five shillings per week. It would seem that much of the inconvenience resulting on thc landing of these people, is owing to the Superinten- dent of the depot not ( knowing .when the" immigrants will actually arrive. Much' . trouble is also caused by tho way iu which tho

luggage is brought to town,- it being necessary on the last occasion to send several different times to the wharf for this, .... >

MR. JAMES DELANEY, Gold Warden's clerk, bas just returned from an official visit paid to the Canoona goldfields and its neighbourhood. His mission was to collect the revenue in the

/Shape of £i, the annual license 'of a store- keeper at Canoona, And tb obtain' a iteturb of miners. He informs ns there are five miners fossicking at Canoona, Where there is a puddling machine, four on; Bonnie Doon Creek, three miles from Canoona ; and eight are Btill working at -Princhester , Creek. Nothing definite ÍB known aa to the success or otherwise of the miner's efforts in developing the resources of the places named. Mr. W. E. Wassman, the storekëéper"at Canoona, however, said he was "doing pretty, wçlh" This may be regarded as an indication that those on the field are at least earning tucker.

, IN our shipping column we have -previously referred to the very smart trips made by Btoairiers and sailirig crafts trading to Queens- land ports, and are always glad to notice the promptitude with which, at times, under favourable auspices, a particularly rapid voyage is made. It is cheering to find the You Yangs, s.s., one of the oldest colonial sea boats afloat, out-rivalling previous "fastest trips on record." According to the Telegraph .Shipping Board, the You Yangs, from Sydney and Brisbane, arrived at Maryborough yester- day. On tho Board, it «va» also notified BIIO arrived oir Flat-top Island at 9'30 on Wednes- day night. So, tl,at actually before the vessel had arrived at Maryborough she was at Flat- top Island, about six miles from Mackay. This latter intelligence was telegraphed from Mackay, aud must have been sent yesterday morning, as tho Flat-top Island line to Mackay has been discontinued. Thc fact of the matter is that much inconvenience is

experienced in ascertaining the movements of ? vessels paBsiug Flat-top. Tho news does not arrive hore as a general rule until about twelvo hours after a vessel lias passed tile Island.

THE Aramac Mail says :-" Every now and then an indignant epistle comes from a sub- scriber who has not received his. paper. We are very careful in the matter of posting the Mail to our subscribers, and from inquiries we have made we are lcd to believe that in many iustancuB the loas of thc missing papers may be traced to the fact that there aro persons in the district who will not afford tho trifling annual sum required for the subscription, but wlio appreciate.our paper sufficiently to pur- loin other people's copies. We are also in- formed, nu good authority, that the road mails are not carried as they ought to bo, the papers being carried loose, so that anyone might take one if they felt so inclined. That -people do take thom is certain, as our road subscribers araconstnnlly complaining that their papers do not como to bawl. A bag should bc provided for tho loose road mail, and tbiH should never bc lost sight of hy the coachman. If this were' donc.i cause for cumplaint would not arise." We aro sorry to have to corroborate our contemporary's remarks as to thc manner in which papers are pilferred in transmission westwards. We ave continually receiving complaints from subscribers that our journal does uot reach tlicm ; and can only account for their disappointment by the papers being , stolen,

it ia considered likely his Excellency Sir Arthur Kennedy, onr present Governor, will retire on_a pension at the end of-his term of ,office here.ns. A"jpa-regal representative. It Wnrfd iáeéV that fitf Arthur has held office as a Colonial Oovernor-eince 1652-;-therefore his pension will have theen Well-earned,1

il«" another column it is stated the Yaralla,

Bj. left Alsatia (t) for the south yesterday.

We are glad to hear this, as we were in doubt

nat to the movements of the vessel, nothing having been-^npjwu/ here since she arrived tat Mackay on/ Monday last. f or the In- formation of these not acquainted with the position of Ahatjay we bave.tq state ii is the.new narpo of Walkerston, an inland town,, situated nine miles from Mackay. .There is .a telegraph station there, and the gentleman in charge has shown he is energetically inclined to transmit shipping news in thus notifying the Yaralla'a departure. We are glad of this, lind much appreciate'it.1 This ïs thé Yaralla'a first visit to Alsatia, so far as we,know, and

the event will probably be a notable incident . in the history ot that place. . ? .

OUR Gracemere agricultural correspondent ' . writes :-The weather for the laBt week has.

been unusually dry and'hot, and where the , grasa la enort.it ia .showing the effects of the powerful rays of old Sol .The farmers are busy preparing the lands intended for the early crop of potatoes. I supposé you ,are aware they Ret two crops of the mealy taber aanaally. One crop sown in February and

_ March conies in about May. ; ; Tb« second-crop ' * sovfn in August ripens in October and Novem 4>e|r. In some;, places eight to ten tons of good

potatoes have, .been : produced to the acre this year. The .oaten hay is [all cut and stacked, and the quality, and, quantity proved satis- factory, tlucerhe hay is always in season 'Jriblding its crops in rapid succession every five or six weeks, and in home places the crops are looking remarkably healthy gast now, rMaise and othercrops ondry slopes are looking dry and would be all the better for1 tome riin. Orange and other fruit trees are looking jwell, sud are in' healthy bearing, where the ground's has been kept loose and mulched ; while' in other Claces, .wljere.gpod .cultivation, has, not .been

opt up the trees are showing symptoms of distress, ano) fhe, fruitis looking stunted. .1; hope in m'y next I will have tb chronicle the visitation of a : copious, supply . pf. the cooling element., ' ,'| n

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.    

THURSDAY. FEBRUARY 8, 1883.

WITH their rapidly growing wealth the Australian Colonies are also increasing their responsibilities, and it is somewhat remarkable how very few among the colonists realise that the increase of wealth necessitates the institution of measures for its protection. The man who becomes possessed of property in a community readily grasps the idea that, a police force, and strong locks and bolts are unmistakeable requisites, but when the same principle is involved in international policy he fails to appreciate

it to the full extent. The total revenue of the Australian Colonies and New Zealand for the year 1881 was ¿£21,608,000, and when it is known that such a vast sum can annually be collected in taxes a very fair idea may be formed of the enormous wealth that has been accumulated on our shores. The contemplation of this treasure should be enougli to attract the attention of per- sons of marauding tendencies, and should occasion arise such would un- doubtedly tum their attention to our condition. The only cause for the colonists to fear that might bring about a visit from an armed force, would be the fact of England becoming involved in a European struggle-a con- tingency not by any means so remote as the majority of Australians seem to think. The Eastern Question has not yet been settled. The difficulties con- nected with it still remain unsolved, and it is not improbable that the highway of the world-Suez-will at no very distant date be the battle ground on which Ute Mussul- man and the Christian will fight out their deadly jealousy and national hatred. To .those who are unacquainted with the nations under Mahometan rule, it is difficult to convey even a faint idea of the intense detestation in which the mad fanatical worshippers of Allah hold the usurping infidel. This feeling is unquestionably fostered secretly by nations whose interest in the East render English supremacy in that quarter cause for envy, and doubtless the intrigues will yet be unmasked, and the bayonet drawn in a decisive struggle oh the shores of the Levant. Whether this will occur in our time or not, none can foretell ; but that, according to the law of the survival of the fittest, one of the two races must eventually obliterate the other, or so crush it that the remnant shall be absorbed, and thus its indi- viduality lost, is rendered certain by the experience of Universal history. If this be so, it has yet to be decided who shall hold Western and Central Asia, and though it is always hazardous to prophesy, we may indulge in it vaguely

decide who shall hold Suez, and who own India. When that time comes, Australia may find herself first honoured by a visit from an armed force.

In the consideration of this contin- gency two questions present themselves : firstly, when will the occasion be likely to arise, and secondly, what would be the nature of the force likely to be dis- patched against us. These two questions must be satisfactorily settled before any system of defence can be attempted. With regard to the first it is simply a matter of conjecture, but it may be re- marked that the safe side is to be ready for it, no matter how soon the dire necessity may arise. As to what force would operate against us ; there can be hardly any doubt we would be visited by fast steam vessels, carrying heavy guns,, and containing a force sufficiently large to overcome süch troops as might reason- ably be expected to meet them iii our largest centres of population.: Where these centres are, like Brisbane, Sydney, and other coast towns-the invading force could approach within a distance from which they could shell the cities. In other cases, where there would be a distance inland to traverse, troops would have to be landed.

In endeavouring to protect ourselves from such dangers as would threaten it must be clear that the one grand object to be attained is united action between the colonies to pre- vent the landing of an invading force,1 and, secondly, individual action in the various coastal cities to prevent them being bombarded. Taking the latter necessity first it may be remarked that the bombardment of Alexandria has clearly shown that land fortifications cannot resist the naval engines of war which can be brought against them. Alexandria was a remarkably strongly lortified position. There is no city on the Atlantic coast of America fortified as effectively as Alexandria was, and our American cousins have not been a little surprised at the ease with which Admiral Seymour battered down tremendous works, sheltering guns heavy enough, it was supposed, to prove destructive to almost anything afloat. Realising this, the next question is whether torpedoes could be used to protect harbours against a naval enemy. Torpedo warfare, how- ever, has not yet been scientifically worked out-or rather the science of it has not been. practically demonstrated. There is one peculiarity at present in the science that these frightful engines of war are as dangerous to those who use them as to the enemy against whom they are employed-that is unless they are fixed in position before being exploded. Now if a system of fixed submarine torpedoes were instituted it would be necessary for the approaching vessels to pass directly over them, and except in the case of their having lo navigate a narrow channel thc awful possibility of their missing them is too serious to con- template, Again, where a narrow channel is found the enemy can explode

îhe .torpedoes ^themselves before ¡their : vessels apffoxb. The! commanders, ¡ knowing tty fhfcrts that 4 barrow channel I h^o.be ^s«,>ould^lear jt of jíxed torpedoes for a start. In the meantime ttis at least advisable to realise that one good turret ship-a first-class steam ram mounting say one eighty-one ton gun

ftfquWL be «ore: effective tHào anything' ; else in preventing, such vessels as could safely -make the voyage to Australia from approaching within shelling distance of a

coastal city. "

With regard-to the establishment of a land force our real safety lies in railway construction. If the largest cities of Australia were all connected by

railway, troops could be massed at any ? point of the coast in sufficient ; numbers ; to defy any army that could ever land. : Local forces could keep the enemy in check and harass their landing, while the forces were being centred in. the town which it was the object, of the enemy to attack. Thus the secret of security lies in railway construction, but a secondary point is the necessity of training the colonists to the use of arms,,

and in a scattered population ? this is no 1 simple task. Our volunteer system, no doubt, in time, will be come effective, as a' nucleus of trained ' men around, which the inhabitants would assemble, but these inhabitants themselves must be, to< a certain degree, trained to be effective. This difficulty would, perhaps, be most easily overcome by training all the boys in the country while at school to the use of arms. If every public school had its cadet corps, the boys in after years would, at all events, remember sufficient in manhood to be useful as an

auxiliary in time of war. Lessons

I ¿aa; ttèyw childhood, especially lessons

oàjt j^ects of interest, are not easily forgotten, and boys learn drill and the use of aims, as Teadily as ' they do cricket and marbles. The safety of Australia in the future will depend not a little upon the training of the boys of to-day, and this is a part of education at present totally neglected in Queens- land'and South Australia. Victoria and New South Wales are not so in- different on the subject. In con- clusion it may be observed that it is gratifying to notice in Rockhampton that there is a spirit shown by the young mea in favour of volunteer duty, of which we have occasion to be proud,

and the fact is noticed in both Brisbane and northern towns, judging from the articles appearing in our exchanges. We hope that this patriotic spirit will continue to operate, and that all the residents will do their utmost to encourage it, fpr we know not how soon it may save both our lives and property.

THE naws by cable thia week convoys the pleasing intelligence that it is extremely pro- bable the dastardly ruffians who murdered Lord Frederick Cavendish ¡and'Mr. Burke in the Phoenix Park, Dublin, have at last been unearthed. At first the chargo against the accusoi was ridiculed by their counsel, but SB the case proceeded revelations were made which brought the guilt pretty well home to the prisoners. The mystery that has surrounded this diabolical outrage since its perpetration has been almost an incentivo to

Slender 'cTÍrnraáitíy" °tMP*JgA&J8$? &

criminals. Again, tho apparent utter in- ability of the English and Irish Detective Folios Forces to.obtoiu the slightest clue to the whereabouts of these bloodthirsty eaoundrcls proved the alarming and humiliating fact that there were actually residents in Ireland, who would shelter the most criminal offenders conceivable, It is also gratifying to learn that the murderous assassin who attempted tho life of the juryman Field, in the streets of Dublin, on the 27th of last November, has been identified, It will be remembered that Mr. Field was returning to his home after having performed his duties as a juryman on tbe date mentioned, when three men drove up alongside him in a car. One of these sprang out, stabbed Mr. Field several times with a sword, sprang again into the car, and waa driven away. - {Cavanagh the driver of the car has been .identified. We can only hope that tbe detection of crime may be evidence that there ia not so much feeling in Ireland antagonistic to law and order as waa painfnlly oyident.some time since. When Ireland ceases to conceal blood-thirsty assassins she may hope for justice and prosperity-but not till then. .. ^ ?

Till! frequent arrival on our chores of criminals who have made their escape from tMe french penal establishment,' cu the island of New Caledonia, baa led. us to consider which is the best method to adopt in the treatment of thees escapees. It will be at once apparent that the introduction of the criminal element of France, icto this country is not ' only objectionable but extremely dangerous, sod therefore we have a right to {irotect ourselves from the unpleasantness of

laving this class of foreiguer at large in our dominion. But it is impossible for any one not to feel some sympathy with such daring adventurers as these men are, who risk their lives in order to gaiu their freedom. In many instances unfortunate men have been banished to New Caledonia, for merely political offences -they been made criminals becauso they were unsuccessful reformers. No doubt in the interests of civilization, their punishment may be an absolute necessity. Still none the less, the picture of their struggling for days lo open boats, without compass or chart, without proper ? food, and no wator, while every. moment they have to bale for bare life-the contemplation of all this endured bravely and cheerfully, only to be rewarded with imprisonment on reaching our Australian coast, causes a shock to all those feelings which prompt human nature to succour the distressed. The police authorities in tin's colony proceed under the Vagrant Act against these refugees, clearly not becauso they are 6011a fide vagrants, but merely as an excuse for remanding them fromtimcto time until they oan be handed over to the French authorities. However expedient such a course may be, it is hardly redolent of that fair play English-

men boast so much about,

THE Keilawarra, i.s., which arrived hereon Tuesday evening, brought a fiue black colt, ft yearling, from Sydnoy. This animal, «hieb stands about fourteen and a-half hands high, «aa bought st Mr. Town's sale, Sydney, for 110 guineas, Mr. Wood, of Calliungal, being thc purchaser,

THEKE aro at present in the Hospital four immigrants off the Melpomene, and in the Benevolent Asylum thora are also throe of them. It transpires that on board ship these people were not any too healthy, and it is just possible that the medical examinations of pro- posed emigrants in England are only matters of form. The three immigrants in the Benevolent Asylum are bellly treated in the lymu 'ii ward, and o& the institution is r'titaliiislied for tho relief of local casca which destitution renders charity necessary to alleviate, it is just open to question whether some other arrangements ought not to ba made,

;? W« ondenrtond that there ia a movement/ jonipot amoîuth» wharf lumpers to raise¡sj«b-\ ¡ecrlptíous fpr the çurpost of raying: tb« pífete

imposed onÄe^üm Keogh, _. >? £. j

WE are informed that "Messrs, Brown and'

Risien, in eonjunction with Mesara, J. Macfar-^ lane and Co., sold at the Show Grounds I yesterday ICI adult cattle on account of ] Aléxan^r^hó^son^ Esq., of Tilpal selection, at prices ranging about 26s. 6d. per head. Many of the cows had calves at foot.

IT was intimated to a meeting of delegates ! from the Friendly Societies in Rockhampton, held in the Palace Hotel last night, by Dr. Poland, the recently appointed medical officer,

that he would undertake the duties of atten- |

ding members and families without the ; assistance of another medical gentleman. The ' proposition was agreed to.

THE patients in the special ward at the' Hospital were removed front the "Barcoo" to their new quarters yesterday. The Com. mittoc it will be remembered, decided at a

recent meeting, to utilise the detached j

building constructed as a fever ward, for the treatment of the special eases and the old building, once the Rockhampton hospital, removed from the river bank to its present ; position will be demolished. The newly con.

structed ward is a remarkably pleasant' and ' cheerful building, which the resident surgeon

(Dr. ; Thurston), has had prepared for the reception of the patients. The drainage has been very carefully attended to, and the bath . room and lavatory specially filled up.

BEFORE the Police Magistrate yesterday,

Walter M'Nicol and Myles Dempsey were  

charged, on remand, with the larceny of a tent and fly, the property of Francis Heffer-

nan. The evidence of James Florence, a  

bushman, residing at the 198 Railway Camp, was to the effect that he first saw prisoners at Emerald. He wanted to buy a tent and fly, and in course of conversation McNicol said he contd sell one cheap. Dempsey was standing near, aud could have heard the conversation. M'Nicol showed the tent, and witness agreed to buy it for 14s. The tent and fly produced are those purchased from prisoners. He subse- quently handed the property to the police at Emerald. This was the case for the prosecu- tion, and prisoners were fined £1 each, with the alternative of one month's imprisonment. They were removed to the lock-up, and after- wards paid the fine;

OUR Gracemere agricultural correspondent writing yesterday, says :-Some fine showers fell here lately, and the grass is now looking green and healthy. ' The fins crops of potatoes grown last sowing has induoed the farmers to cultivate more freely than usual, and lome are now determined on sowing acres instead of what:used to. be perches some years back. Late sowings of : maize and sweet potatoes are still being made, and when the weather proves favourable they often nive good returns. The plough is busily kept going on fallow lands preparing for early sowings of bay crops.. On a few selections dam making is going on, and

from all l ean hear some fears are entertained . that the taxation under the Divisional Boards Act will come too heavy to admit of dam making on a large scale. A very good ques- tion has been put to me here lately-" Will

dams be valued by the oubio yard of water, and will the owners of natural reservoirs have

. to pay acoording to quantity ?" I should

think if Mr. Archer's lake be measured his tax will come to a round sum.

IT will be remembered by some of our readers, that a man waa brought up before the Police Court a, few, days since, and very leniently dealt with on pleading guilty to a charge of disorderly behaviour in the Immi- gration Dépôt. Some particulars of this man's conduot have come under our notice

and wo certainly think that, taken in con- junction with the disinclination shown by some- pf those now lin ' the depot to accept rcasonablo offers of engagement, this man's behaviour .deserves to be expoBéd.

" -rr"; «??-». n- Ulm lieirm offered.

by a gentleman in search of a labourer,,a very fair rate of wages, the independent immigrant became violently indignant, .shook his clenched fist io the gentleman's face, took off his coat, and generally indulged in that pantomime so peculiarly Irish »hat subsides very rapidly under one good blow. . There was a police officer on the spot, but for some inexplicable

reason this officer deolined to arrest the

offender. Besides this CQBO, several employers have complained of the incivility of certain of the immigrants, and we are of opinion that a good effect would be produced by weeding out a few of thoBe still hanging on at the depdt.

TUE ordinary sitting, of the Small Debt* Court was held before the Police Magistrate and Mr. W. Broome J.P. yesterday morning, Judgment was given for the plaintiffs in the following undefended cases:-James Stewart, and Co., ». Gd. for goods sold. Alsum of £9 was paid in, and aa no evidence Was forthcoming to substantiate plaintiffs claim for the amount sued for,' Mr. Milford with- drew the case. Costs amounting to £2 8s, were allowed defendant. C. Wilde sued J.. Sellors for £20, amount of damages cassed by a dog biting hie wife on the thigh.1 The parties livo at North Rockhampton, and Mrs. Wilds wished to pass by the defendant's house and was attacked by the dog. Evi- dence for the defendant showed the'dog was

tied up, and when Mrs, .Wilds beat it the , animal broke loose and bit her. Judgment was given in favour of defendant, with £2 18s. costs. Mr. F. Milford appeared for the plaintiff, and Mr. Melbourne for the

defendant.

Tm two four-oared string-test racing gigs says the Chronicle constructed by Mr. Fuller, of Melbourne, to the order of the Maryborough Rowing Club arrived by the steamer Keil , awarra.; / The .boats »ra each .41 feet lang, 2

feet 7 inches beam, and fitted with elides 18 inches long. They are evidently two fine specimens of the racing craft. The Bowing Club now possess no (ewer than twelve service- able riding abd pleasure boats, 'not including a number of fiat-bottomed skiffs owned privately by members of the einb and located in the club boat-house. ?

ANOTHER batch of prisoners was landed from the Bunyip ' yesterday morning, and escorted to the gaol. Among the number are five Cingalese sentehcei by the Mackay Bench' to two months' imprisonment for breach of agreement. The other prisoner is an aboriginal named Toby, who waa «Mered by the Glad- stone Bench to find sureties-himself in £10 and two sureties of £5 each for threatening a chjld named Amy Kelly,. As the darkie .could, not ' find two respectable householders to

become bondsmen for his good behaviour, he I will have to complete a sentence pf twelve, months' imprisonment.
