articleText:
KOCKIIAMI'TON.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1883.

AMONG the rural industries, which in time will give pleasant and profitable employment to a large number of our colonists, none can be looked forward to more hopefully than fruit culture. Gar- dening was one of man's first pursuits, and he seems to incline to it from here- ditary disposition. City life never possesses the freshness and charm of work among springing plants and blos- soming trees. Enjoyment sweetens toil to the husbandman, who expectant waits the green blades coming through the brown earth, watches their progress to maturity, and with rejoicing, in the ingathering, reaps the reward of his labours, and realises his hopes. The majority of men, unless constrained by circumstances, would adopt agriculture, or her more engaging sister, horticulture, as a profession. In Queensland, besides its natural attractions, the occupation is held to possess the more powerful one of profit. Only a little energy and capital, it is concluded, are required to make it a means of affording remunera- tive employment to a large number of colonists. The manner in which this may be done, in the first instance at least, is not by the establishment of fruit farms, but by the erection and operation of fruit preserving' works. It is evident, however, that the formation of the latter must succeed the former at least to some extent. Without ample supplies of fruits the works would be useless : employment for them there would be none. On the other hand, until works are erected, and the growers can secure a ready and permanent outlet for their produce, they cannot be ex- pected to expend labour and land on

fruit culture.

From the columns of a South Austra- lian contemporary we glean some interesting information upon the condi- tion of the fruit industry in that colony, the consideration of which cannot fail to bc interesting and profitable to many of our readers. In Adelaide and its vicinity preserving works have been established, which are now doing a large trade-circulating great sums of money, and giving occupation to numerous hands. Many years ago a woman named Mrs. Chance began the manufacture of tomato sauce, and fancied she was doing well when she turned out three dozen bottles in one season. The sauce making proved so remunerative that jam-making was added. With the assis- tance of her son a factory was estab- lished. The building at first was eighty feet long by fifteen feet broad. As the trade prospered capitalists bought into the concern, and now it has attained large dimensions. The boiling-room alone is eighty by twenty feet, and there are store-rooms and work-rooms, nume- rous and capacious. Last year, we learn, the firm manufactured and sold two hundred and fifty tons of jam, equal to five hundred thousand pound tins. In a good year the firm turn out thirty-six thousand pints of tomato sauce. Besides jams and sauces tinned fruits and pickles are manufactured in large quantities. The preservation of candied peel employs

the bulk of the hands at the season when fruits are scarce. In jams and tinned fruits alone three hundred and fifty tons will be turned out this season, worth, at £50 a ton, .¿,17,500. Add to the

revenue from these the income from

tomato sauce, candied peel, &" and it will be seen that a most profitable and flourishing industry has been established. In another fruit factory the use of drying machinery has been introduced. Fruits suitable for the operation are placed on wire trays, and exposed to currents of hot air. In this way they are completely desiccated in a few flours. Sliced apples and potatoes are greatly re- duced in bulk. Carefully packed they can be forwarded long distances by sea and land, without losing their peculiar nourishing properties. Steam driven ma- chinery plays a most important part in these factories, and greatly facilitates operations. The large tinned cop- pers in which thc jams arc pre- pared are jacketed, and heated by steam. Pans, tanks, driers, lifts, are worked by steam, and an ingenious Yankee piece of mechanism has been introduced, which, working by steam, solders in thc ends of the fruit cans. Of course several hands are needed to attend to the machinery, and in several departments of the industry manual labour cannot be dispensed with. In Chance and Company's establishment eighty hands are employed. One half of that number arc girls, who are employed labelling, packing, and box-making. The wood is cut to size, and a smart girl can make eighty boxes a day, and, getting a penny for each, realises f;ood wages. The tins arc made outside the establish- ments, and employ a numerous contin- gent of tinsmiths.

There are three fruit faetones at Adelaide, and each finds a ready market for all it can manufacture. Among the fruits dealt with are grapes, apples, pears, peaches, nectaries, plums, rasp- berries, black-berries, mulberries, figs,

rhubarb, apricots, .and quinces. Among preserved vegetables are peas, potatoes, tomatoes, French beans, etc. The greatest difficulty in the way of the expansion of these fruit factories, is the wanto! supplies. Tbeycannotgetasmuch fruit as they requiie. In order to meet the demands made on them the.'ownets have to import large quantities of fruit from Victoria and Tasmania. About one third of the tolal quantity preserved is imported. This is due in part to the failure of the crops from drought or other causes. It does not do to depend altogether for certain kinds of fruit on the local supply. In the mean- time, however, fruit culturists have no difficulty in getting rid of all they can grow, at steady remunerative prices.

From what we have said, we think, it must be apparent that in the efforts made by Mr. A. Kohler, Pink Lily we have the beginnings of what may prove an important industry in this district. It rests with the farmers and selectors of the vicinity to demon- strate whether this shall be the case. Mrs. Chance, in Adelaide, began with three dozen bottles of tomato sauce in one season ; and now the firm employs

nearly a hundred hands, and has a turn-1 over of upwards of tweüty thousand I pounds of capital annually. There is this stimulus to growers in this dis

trict, the advantages of which they j never seem lo have . realised, that ' a large trade in tropical fruits awaits development at their hands. It would be useless to compete with S. Australia and Tasmania in the manu- facture of jams, but in the exportation of tinned fruits such as pineapples, mangoes, guavas, loquats, mulberries, and fruits like the whampee, of which we have not learned the true value, a large amount of busines might be done. It seems funny from its absurdity, that while we can grow sugar, oranges, and limes in abundance, we should send money out of the colony for marmalade and limejuice. Fruit culture and manu- facture in Queensland demand attention, and we hope they will not be neglected by the farmers and selectors of this

district.

Avrnovan we are oat at all inclined ta sympathise with strikes, there are occa- sions when even this method of demanding justice is allowable. .The strike among the femalo operatives employed in the Melboure clothing trade is quite a new development of thc system in the colonies, and it will gene- rally bo admitted that, when women Btrike ther must be something very unbearably wrong. Women have aot the same amount of resistance in their nature a« men. They will submit to injustice longer, and dread thc con- sequences of anything like a conflict, so that when they turn out on strike, we may be very certain they have been reduced to desperation. From personal knowledge we may state that thousands of girls io Melbourne work from eight to six per day, and only earn seven and eight shillings per week. _ In the dress- making trade twelve shillings is a good wage per week for a machinist to get io Melbourne, and these girls have to work at all hours if orders are not completed. It may be fairly Ba id that tailoresses, dress- makers' assistants, machinists, and sem stressea in the Southern capital are ground down to the very lowest rate of pay, that they aro worked outrageously long hours, and dismissed without a moment's warning if work runB out. It is well known that a

vast majority of girls now-a-day prefer factory i work to domestic service, as they are more

their own mistresses, and generally have their evenings to themselves. This bas caused a I glut in the labour market, and wages hare, as

a natural consequence, become lower and loner. It will be seen by our Adelaide tele- grams that in that city the operatives in the clothing trade have held a meeting to sympa- thise with the Melbourne girls, and offer them substantial support.

Last week probate was granted out of the Supremo Court in the will of Thornton Augustus Kennedy Morris, Rockhampton, to .Mary Ellen Morris, widow, personality,

£2000.

ADVANTAGE will be taken of the half-holiday to-morrow (Wednesday) to play a cricket match between teams representing the estab- lishments of Messrs. J. W.Face and Co. and   Joseph Pattison and Co. Wickets to be pitched at North Rockhampton at half-past two o'clock sharp. The following are the teams selected :—J. W. Face and Co. : G. H. Church (captain), R. M. Aberdeen, J. Williams, A. McCullock, W. Graham, C. H. Burgess, H. Ware, W. Baird, J. H. Church, C. Steele, and W. Jackson. J. Pattison and Co.: G. W. T. Moffatt, J. Morrison, H. Cross, J. Dempsey, G. Wickham, J. Bryan, A. Palmer, H. Prior, J. Clancy, R. T. Mitchell, and John Power.

BEFOKE the Police Magistrate, yesterday morning, the hearing of the case against John Ueigan for embezzlement waa resumed. The case for the prosecution wu« closed, and for tho defeoce Mr. Milford called Augustus Henry Campbell, who deposed he was book- keeper in the Municipal Council ; aa the 30th January last there were some rates due on thc Singer Company's property, and prisoner, on behalf of thc Company, paid the ratos, which amounted to £9 5s. 3d. In reply to Mr. Jones, prisoner eaid the rates were partly

for wharfage dues and partly for the premises; j

the water rates were due from I860 to 1SS2 on

thc premises, and not owing by tho company ;

prisoner paid thc amount in. notes and not by i cheque ; tho ratcB on tb,e shop were £5 lCs. 3d., water rates £1 Ss., and wharfage £2 4s. This concluded the case, and prisoner was committed for trial at the Central District sittings on 9th April next, thc previous bail being renewed, A drunkard was cautioned and discharged. A South Sea Islander named "Jimmy," charged with assaulting a police I officer, pleaded guilty, but was remanda) for

[ inquiry into his statements os to the retention

of money iu the lock-up,

Odi coast correspondent writes :-On Mon- day tho 5tli instant, a thunderstorm broke over thc coast frontage, since when the weather has been showery aud comparatively cool. Yeppoon and Emu Park still command numerous visitors, hut the want of accommo- dation at the former place prevents a greet many from going there who otherwise would. We have had a visit from Mr. M'Uonald, late of " St. Helena," who was as much suri>riscd as pleased at thc land he saw along the coast, and expressed great surpriseat eccingsiich land only used for grazing purposes. Sugar growing in this neighbourhood will yet bc a great industry, and that before long. I hope Mr. M'Donald considered he saw sufficient good land for several plantations during tho oucday lie spont on tho const. l>r. O'Connor and Mr. J. ltoas had a very narrow squeak on Friday week, when driving to Mulambin A short distance from tho half-way bouse their horses took a start, at.d one of the reins giving way immediately after, thc fore wheels struck a Btmnp nuil throw both ptntlemen out with great f.ircc. Thi y wi-ro both severely cut and bniisi'd, hat are progressing very favourably. The buggy struck s stump after passing the half-way house, and waa also considerably doubled up. Grui »ad water we, of course,

abundant, and corn crops ara looking jemark-. ably well Th» Uti; few dayl have been oool with dewy nights. , ..¡

THE last Gazelle notifies that sales of runs will be held in Rockhampton and Gladstone on 2nd April, and that a reserve of thirty-four peronea for a Fire Brigade Station has been

A" '«EETÍNQ ot ''ratepayers of No. 1 sub-

division, Gogango, will be held in the Normanby Hotel, on Saturday next, at 2 p.m., to transact business arising out of the late

election.

MR. DEMPSEY has issued instructions for a writ to be served on the Returning Officer at I thc late »lectipn for No. 1 subdivision of thc

Gogango Divisional Board for illegally re- fusing to receive certain votes in connection with the contest.

PONTIFICA!, high mass was celebrated on Thursday morning ia St. Stephen's Cathedral, Brisbane, for the repose of tho soul of the late Right Hov. Dr. O'Connor, Uishop of Ballarat. The Right Rev. Dr. Cani, Bishop of Rock- hampton, was the celebrant,.

THE last issue'of the Queensland ignaro which is just to hand is an improvement on past numbers. The advertising columns are being well availed of, and the journal appears to bo getting on a firmer footing. It has no love for tho "Telegraph," and does not disguise the fact. The illustrations are

fairly executed, thc one of the steam scoop at work at Roma being very good aqd interesting.

MESSRS. TRAVERS AND GIBSON, of Aramac

Station, in the Mitchell district, have im- ¡ ported from Sydney by the Keilawarra, s.s., ! a coaching stallion named Palmerston. He is a bay horse, with black points, not a speck of white to be seen, and his sea voyage does not appear to have interfered with bis condition. Palmerston's pedigree is not to hand, but we presume from his appearance he possesses good breeding, and will form a valuable adjunct to

the Aramac Station stud,

tURlKo the lost few days several applies-/

B been lodged in tho Gold ' Warden's office in oonnection with the goldfields in the dis- trict. Messrs. Hartley and party have applied for exemption from working for six months' their "Last Chance" claim, at New Zealand Gully, through excess of water. A similar application has been lodged, by Messrs. F. Morgan and party for the "Lady Mary" claim at Mount Wheeler. Messrs. IV. J. White and ? T. Oxnam have applied for 1800 by 400 feet of ground as a quartz reef claim at the Croco- dile Mountain, and for 800 feet of ground as a tunnelling claim on Crocodile Creek. Mr. William M'Kinley has applied for 200 by 400 feet at the Three-mile, west of Mr, Morgan's olaim as a quartz reef claim.

A MEETTNO of the friends and well-wishers of Major Feez, M.L. A., was held in the Town Hall last night, for the purpose of considering the propriety of testifying the respect and esteem in which he ,is held by this com- munity, on the eve of his departure on a visit to Europe. The Mayor (John Ferguson, Esq., M.L.A.) presided, and briefly stated that he occupied the chair with great pleasure. He had known Major Feez for upwards of twenty years as a worthy citizen of Rockhampton. In every movement for the advancement of the town or benefit ot the

community he had been every ready, to take a foremost part. He had not given tho form in which they should express their esteem for Major Feez, any consideration, and he invited gentlemen present to state their views on the matter. Some conversation followed,,and. a conversazione and ball were spoken of. Ulti- mately M. C. Thomson seconded by Mr.

Sheridan, moved that a testimonial be sub- scribed for and presented to Major Feez. This was unanimously agreed to. On the motion of the Hon. C. S. D. Melbourne, seconded by Mr. C. Harden, the following gentlemen were appointed a Committee to collect subscrip-

tions, and report on the form of testimonial to the subscribers:-The Mayor, Messrs. Sheridan, S. G. HHL G. Boldeman, and Büschel. A subscription list was opened in the room, and upwards of twenty guineas

subscribed at once. The collectors will lose no time in calling on our townsmen, and everyone will be pleased to have an oppor- tunity of subscribing to Major Feez's testi- monial.

WE have received, pef favour of Messrs. Saber Bros.. the annual report of the New South Wales Institution for the Deaf, Dumb, and Bliud. The report is very interesting, ns showing the progress made by some of the pupils, and some of the specimen essays by thc sadly afflicted little pupils, show that thoy are poBScsscd of, in many instances, con- siderable ability. At the same time there is evidence that marvellous ingenuity is exeroised in training the children undor such peculiarly adverse circumstances. Tho total amount of subscriptions for the year is shown by the balance-sheet to have been From annual Bubscriptions, paid by Sydney residents, £1,822 2s. ld.; country subscrip- tions, New South Wales. £618 3s. Gd.; Queensland subscriptions, £247 Hs. Gd. It muet bo remembered that the deaf, dumb, and blind children of Queensland arc admitted into thc Sydney Institu- tion, and that since 1870 as many as 27 deaf and dumb and 12 blind children from this colony wero received into the asylum. It is gratifying to notice that Rockhampton contri buted last year the very respectable sum of £42 to the subscriptions, and as it was all collected by Messrs, Saber Bros. they deserve hearty thanks for the interest and energy they displayed in tho charitable work. We also notice from tho report that one child was received into the institution from Rockhamp- ton in July of last year. We hope that sub- scriptions will bc as liberally given this year as lost, and that the collectors will be able to forward a sum to tin's deserving Asylum that will do credit to our wealthy community.

THE Westum Champion of the Gth instant says :-No rain baa visited Blackall during thc week, although there have been daily threatenings. Heavy rain must have fallen over Tambo way last week, for tho river came down a banker on Saturday, and the waters have not subsided yet. On Friday afternoon a heavy windstorm swept over tho township, doing a little damage to roofs and verandahs. R. St. George Caulfield, Government Auc- tioneer, stock and Station Agent, Blackall, reports under date February 15.-Stores :

1500 arc aoruit to start from Enniskillen. 150 head from Evesham for Lansdowne, Mr. Ross in charge, pasBcd 15tli instant. 12,000 ewes and 220 rams purchased in New South Wales by Messrs. Mair and Co. for their Corona Station, Catherine Creek, Mr. Gardiner in charge, passed on thc 30th ultimo. 0000 ewes and 220 rams from Terrawinda Station,

purchased by Messrs. Mair and Co. at a hiidi

figure fruin Messrs. Swift and Hann for Corona, Mr. 1). Halloran in charge, passed on the 30th ultimo ; these are a superior lot, being from the well-known Ercildoune flocks. 10,000 four-year-old ewes with 450 rams from Manfred, Now South Wales, pur- chased by Messrs. Williaineou & Co. for their East Darr Station. Mr. W. T. Liscombe in Charge, passed on thc 4th instant ; these aro iu splcudidconditiou. 15,000 ewes, purchased from Deniliquin and Mougadal Stations for Corona Station. 500 rams purchased from Bualmlla and LandalcB Stations for Terrick,

Mr. T. Higgins in charge, passod on thc Gili instant ; these are a grand lot, and being under thc care ot such an experienced drover, are sure to arrive nt their destination to thc satis- faction of their ow ners. 12,000 ewes and 450 rams from Coree and Bundure Stations, for Wellshot, Mr. P. Douglas iu charge, passed on thc 9th instant ; these are a grand lot, 13.000 ewes from Paika Lake for Messrs. A. Crombie and Cs.'a Strathdarr Station, Mr. Clancy m charge, passed on the 14th instant ; these are large-framed ewes iu very good order. 9000 wethers from Rookery Station, the pro

perty of John Hurley, Esq., Mr. W. Hurley in charge, pasBed on the 13th instant, bound for Aramac Station, Mr. Hurley harjng rented some country to fatten «ame.-Heavy raina on Lorne; creeks a banker.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, JUNE 28, 1883.

AT noon to-day the ActingGovernor will adivêfTïïs opening Speech io Hie members of Parliament who will (hen

assemble in the Legislative Council. There will be a brilliant gathering, no doubt, of fair women as well as clever men, and the powerful voice of Sir Arthur Palmer will make every word distinctly audible in the remotest corner or the Lords' chamber. The topics referred to will possibly be various. The country will most certainly be congratu- lated upon the capture of New Guihea. The Legislative Assembly will be cheered by the announcement that the revenue is buoyant-that the year, not- withstanding the ever-increasing demands

of the public service, will probably close j with a surplus of a quarter of a million, | making the accumulated surpluses of the i last two years just half a million-and that the country has never been at any previous time in its history so generally prosperous, or its industries in so sound a condition. There will, indeed, be a gratifying record of which Ministers and their friends may be justifiably proud.

Nor will their satisfaciion be much lessened when the Opposition declare that the success is due to luck and not

to capacity or prudence. For history tells us that the Liberals, so-called, have never held power without inaugurating- disaster, while the past four years of prosperity, though a usual accompaniment of Conservative dominancy, surpasses the prosperity of any previous Conservative era. These facts, therefore, must tell ; and, if the constituencies are wise, will influence many voters in casting their ballot-papers at the impending elections.

But much more debateable topics will be dealt with in the speech. Sir Arthur's deliverance upon the subject of the Transcontinental Railway will be anticipated with breathless interest. Upon it the struggle of the week will mainly be conducted, for upon it the fate of the Ministry will hang. The general opinion is that the agreement will be thrown out by a small majority if it should ever come under discussion ; hut let us hope it will not, except as a paragraph of the speech. It would be utterly hopeless to bring in the validating bill in the present Assembly, for if there was but a Government majority of two on the Warrego Bill, it seems impossible thal hy any accident a working majority should vote for the Transcontinental

Bill, lt is true thai lhere will be many absentees from the Assembly Chamber on both sides, but with the Ministerial cross-bench members on their side the

Opposition will make a very respectable show in respect of numbers. It has been already pointed out in a southern contemporary that the more constitutional and convenient course would be for the Opposition to move a want of confidence amendment on thc address, or at least to obtain a direct expression of opinion hostile lo ihe Transcontinental project. Thal being carried, the Government must resign or dissolve. The former they can do without the Acting-Governor's consent. The latter will be subject la

his sanction. If he thinks the voice of the country is against the agreement, and that the Opposition will be able to form a. Ministry commanding a working majority, he may refuse a dissolution at the outset. At any rate, he is not bound to grant a dissolution until satisfied that the present Assembly does not represent the country. It is just possible, then, that in the present state of the public business, his Excellency may think the

better course would be for Mr. Griffith to try his hand at passing the Estimates and other urgent measures, and then dissolve during the usual recess. But this does not seem probable, because the present Assembly was elected under the auspices of Mr. Griffith's party, and

therefore the dissolution is constitu- tionally the privilege of Sir Thomas M'llwraith's Ministry. Of course they may forego that privilege, ot Mr. Griffith, once in power, may be able to convince the Acting-Governorthat thenew Ministry are entitled to carry through the session if they can. If this should be attempted, the then Opposition would either have to submit or engage in obstruction either admitted or tacit. Forit mustremembered that a general election, when the Assembly expires by effluxion of time, is not an appeal ; and hence if the Griffith party are so powerful in the House and the country as their friends assume, they may be able to convince Sir Arthur Palmer that they could cany through the session, and then be the Ministry, who, by accident, were in power when the general election took place. Under such circumstances, however, a moribund Assembly would take upon itself to throw out the land-grant projects without affording the country an opportunity of pronouncing upon them. This would he a proceeding not quite constitutional, and it is not really very likely to be ventured upon.

Yet it is not at all unlikely that if beaten in what they deemed an unfair manner, or so as to place them at a tem- porary disadvantage with the consti- tuencies, Ministers will not advise a dissolution, but let Mr. Griffith try his hand at Cabinet making in the expecta- tion that he would not succeed and then that the Ministry would be recalled. In such case the session might either go on and the general election taite place in the recess, or an immediate dissolution might take place. The latter would certainly be the most proper course, and we are inclined to think that it will be followed. Unless we are mis- taken, the general election will be over and the new Parliament in session by thc middle of October. Foi although the last general election was spread over three montis, the means of communica- tion have row so much improved that should the writs be issued on the ist August the hst should be returnable by 15th October without giving ground for any reasonable charge of undue haste.

TUE remainder of the Almora's immigrants were brought up to town yesterday afternoon in the s.s. Folly.

A CONCERT was hold list week for the pur- pose of raiBiog money for the erection of play sheds in thc Fort Cartis School grounds. There will be in hand, after the payment of all expenses, a little over £10.

IK the Supreme Court, in Chambers, on Wednesday last, letters of administration wera granted to the Curator of Intestate EstateB in tho matter af the goods of the late Charles O'Malloy, of leckhampton.

It will be noticed from an advertisement in another column that tenders are invited for the erection of new premises for the Bank of Australasia in Rockhampton. Tenders will be received till noon on Monday, the 9th July.

THE annual tea meeting in connection with the Baptist Church wil bo held at half-past six this evening. After tea has been partaken of, a public meetin; will be held, when addresses will bo delivered by several minis- ters of the gospel, anl choice selections ren- dered by tho choir.

TUE annual distribution of prizes to thc children attending St. Foul's Church Sabbath School will take place on Sunday next. To induce the older scholars to study the Scrip- tures a special prize o: £1 ls. has heen offered for the best essay on the life of Christ, to be competed for by tho first class of boys and girls.

MKSSBS. PARBURY, LAMB, AKB RAFF have got their steam winch in working order, and it was set agoing on Saturday. It worked very satisfactory. On Sunday about mid- night the unloading cf rails from punts at thc wharf was commenced, and they were lauded at the rate of about ten tons au hour. It is calculated that witt double gear the winch will bo capable of lifting a weight of live tons.

Mil. O. K. MALPAB, one of our local photographers, has just returned from a trip to Bundaberg, where he took about ninety views of tho different places of interest in that rising township. On thc return voyage on board the Egmont be photographed a portion of the after deck, and the figures of the officers and mcu at the wheel show very distinctly. The Quetta at anchor taking in cargo was photographed, and also tho entrance to Gladstone with a splendid view of Barney Point. A pretty picture from the Bango completes the Berics of photos handed to us.

WK are informed that the dates of the full day paid parades of the Volunteers for the ensuing financial year will be as follow :-Prince of Wales Birthday, Otb November ; Separation Day, 10th December; St. Patrick's Day, 17tb Mardi ; and Queen's Birthday, 24th May. Tho ciçlit half-day paid parades will bc held on the Inst Saturday in each month, excepting iu July. December, March, and May. Twelve moonlight parades will be ordered by the Commanding Officer on thc drill night nearest thc full moon except in E-istcr week, when the Volunteers are expected to ho in cuuip.

FliOM tho P. D. Telegram wo learn the Clermont sittiugs of tho Central District Court opened before His Honor Judge Miller last week. George Myall was charged with altering thc figures nf a cheque, drawn by Messrs. Mayne Brothers, of Peak Vale, from £2 4s. 7d. to £21 4s. Jd., and further with uttering tho cheque. Tho jury returned a verdict of not guilty, and His Honor in dis- charging him said he had no doubt of his moral guilt, and hoped the escape would ho a warning to him. Thc prisoner attempted to pass the cheque at Thompson aud Cashion's store, but the alteration was noticed. He afterwards pot cash for it in a hotel to the amount of £ > 4s. 7d. Tilomas M'Coll was sentenced to three month-,' imprisonment fur obtaining money hy false pretences fmm Loo Damki:. Thc jury ad ie 1 a ri ler, with which His Honor concurred, that Damke had not

used due discretion in accepting the cheque from a stranger. The civil husinesB was only

of a Dominai oharaoter.

We are informed that P. Larkin, who met with sn accident on board the Egmont, s.s., a few weeks ago, ia progressing ss favourably BB can be expected, considering that he ts suffer- ing from concussion of the brain. He was a member of the Labourer's union, and a sub- scription was raised to provide for his wife and family. The sum of £14 10s. was contri- buted, and Mr. W. li. Holt, the hon. Treasurer, authorised to allow Mrs. Larkin £1 per week. Thus it will be seen the labourers who join the Association receive ample return, when disabled by accideot, for the small weekly sum they contribute to the funds.

A MOB of 250 stores and fats, from River- stone Station, arrived at Mr. W. Pattison's works ou Sunday in charge of Mr. John Bell. Another mob of 250, from Mr. Stuart's Mount Alma Station, are expected to arrive at Mr. Pjttieon's to-night, in charge of Mr. Stirrat ; and 250 from Mr. James Bell's Stowe Station, arc to follow for the same destination. Mr. Ben Hill, who selected the Riverstone cattle, reports the road very bare of grass and water, and that the Boyne River was never known to be so low as at present. Tho Upper Calliope is also dry. Tho feod on Riverstone Station is looking well. AU along the route there is evidence of tho want of rain.

TUB Government Gazette of Saturday last notifies that George Washington Young is to Land Commissioner and Land Agent for the Rockhampton Land Agent's District, in tho room of C. E. Wodehouse, deceased ; and Joseph A. Holdsworth to bo a member of Committee for thc State School at Bogantun- gan. Tho resignations in thc Queensland Volunteer Force, infantry, of Robert Abraham and Ernest Milford have been accepted. The removal of the following ministers of tho Roman Catholic Church have been notified : - Rev. Michael Tynan, from Rockhampton to Ravenswood ; Rev. James Flood, from Ravenswood to Rockhampton ; and Rev. Michael Hackett, from Chartora Towers to Rockhampton.

YENGARIE refinery (says the Marybzrough

Chronicle) commenced full work for tho season at the beginning of this week. Thc extensive machinery worked splendidly, and there is every promise of a highly successful season. Simultaneously most of the fanners on the river who send their cane-juice to Yengarie commenced crushing. A splended crop of cane is being cut at Dedham farm, tho density registering as high as Hi deg». Beaume, and judging by the healthy appear- ance of the cane at Mr. Stewart's, Mr, Clark's and other farms in the same neighbourhood, a high density will be the rule. The mill at Mr. Ferguson's, Lumeah, ia nearly completed,

and will oommence work next week. At Eaton vale Plantation crushing will commence in a few days. Tho Hon. M. H. Moreton intends to make his own sugar this year, so the Eatonvale brand will once more be known in tho market. The splendid crop of cane grown by the same gentleman on his estate at the leland will bo crushed at Katonvalo, the steamer Eveline having becu purchased by the proprietor for the purpose of towiug the cane punts from thc Island to Eatonvale.

AT the Police Court yesterday, before the Police Magistrate, John Kirkwood, charged with drunkenness, was fined 5s. or twenty four hours ; and for using obscene language be was lined 10s. or seven days in the cells. Edward Baird, charged with being drunk and disorderly, was fined 10s. or twenty-four hours, and for resisting the police he was ordered to pay 20s. or go to gaol for seven days. James Duffy, for being drunk, was fined 5s., or twenty-four hours, and for assaulting tho police he was fined 10s. with the alternative of seven days in the calls. A female, charged with drunkenness, was cautioned and discharged. Charles Green was charged with deserting from the schooner Hugh Ewing. Charles Scott, master of the vessel, deposed that he engaged Green for six months, commencing on tho 1st June. Green carno ashoro that morning about a quarter to niue ; he saw him somo time after, and asltod him to goon board the vessel. Green said he would nfter he had seen the Shipping Master s he told him to go on board ; li« refused, and witness then gave him in charge. Green was ordered to return to the ship. The Police Magistrate held that the mau had a right to see the Shipping Master if he had any complaints to make.

The " Rose of Castile," one of Balfe's best compositions, was rendered in tho Theatre last night by the Montague-Tamer company in a very effective manner. As is well known to ever patron of the opera, it contains music of a very taking character, the chief arias being familiar to the ear, and the dialogue somewhat entertaining to the general publio because it verges on the comic without being too broad, and tho situations in which thc principals appear are to say the least of it admirably appreciative. As Elvira, the Rose of Castile, Miss Montague, sustained ber reputation as a vocalist. Her fully cultured voice was heard to advantage in the ballad of the "Couvent Cell" and "I'm but a simple peasant girl." In the latter air the modu- lations of her voice were exceedingly pleasing and the different runB executed with taste and feeling. Uer acting contributed in every way to thc successful rendoriug of those two very difficult songs ; and in the Throne soeno her declamatory utterances were given with true artistic taste. Aa Carmon, Mies Lorne was fairly Rood, and in the opening duct with Miss Montaguo used her voice with judgment. Mr, Turner enacted thc Muletee with hid accustomed success) Thc Muleteer's song and " Could'st thou, dear maid " wcro sung with exquisite taste, and deserved the applause bestowed. As Don Pedro Mr. Browning appeared to advantage ai a conspirator, and gave "Though fortune darkly o'er mc frowns " with such evident SUCCCBS that he narrowly escaped an encore. MeBsrs. Trcvorah and Balfour as Don Florie and Don Sallust saug thc music aliottod to the parts capitally, and with Mr, Browning in tho trio of "Wine, thc Magician thou art," were well received. The minor characters did material justice to the music. The chorus was iu admirable voioe and thc ensemble in each scene very attractive. Tho orchestral accompaniments were played, as usual, with skill under Mr. Delaney's direction. To- night Donizetti's tragical three act opera of " Lucrczia Borgia " will be produced.

LOCKING THE DAHUNU.-In September, 1882, Mr. G. Gordon, hydraulic engineer, Melbourne, was engaged by a Wilcannia com- pany to inspect the Darling betwoen Wilcanuia and Wentworth, and prepare plaue and an estimate of the coast of system of locks, with a view to pennancut navigation. Thc "Western Grazier" announced to-day that Mr. Gordon's report and plans have boen completed; tho work is of a highly practicable nature. Mr. Gordon estimates the cost of locking the river so as to provide nix feet of water at the shallowest part in all «casons at £310,000, Tho distance by the river between the two points in CH milos. Were tho work to be undertaken and accomplished, freights to Port Augusta would not vxeedd Ci per tou, and a vast impetus would bc given to settlement in

the west. 1

Lvuo.NiNd GAS NO .IOKK.-Wo (South Atm 1 milan Aili'rtisur) are informed upon very good authority that a generally unsuspected source of danger exists on board vessels by which nitrons oxide gas, commonly known ns Untiling gas, is imported in this colony. For thc last liv« or six ycirs, it seems, tho dentists of this eily have boen imparting gas condensed so that it is in a liquid form, tho pressure being SOO lb.'. tu tim inch, and in that condition it is very liable to explosion, especially by a high temperature, which would raise tho pressure immensely. Thc betting (if wool near thu «aa might came it to explode, in which case thc VCSJUI would lie lmrst np, and she would ueecr be lic.ird of ajain. Ther* is, we are assured, a terrible possibility of a ship's sides being not only split bat blowu out by Condensed laughing gas, It docs not follow

that thia article should not be carried ia

vessels, but it should bo treated as a very dangerous explosive, and the greatest care should be taken with regard to its position on

board, and the manner in which it ia handled.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, JUNE 26, 1883.
snippet: AT noon to-day the Acting-Governor will deliver his opening Speech to the members of Parliament who will then assemble in the Legislative Council.

articleText:
lllí^OVlUHl)§uUctÍH,

KOCICIIAMl'TON.

FBIDAY. JULY 6, 1883.

IN all the Australian Colonies the feel

trig of disappointment, at the action of the Imperial Government, in regard to the annexation of New Guinea, will be great Though our cablegrams upon the subject are short, and not very per spicuous, there can be no doubt as to their meaning Mr Gladstone s Cabinet have resolved not to confirm the pro cecding of Queensland, in annexing New Guinea m the Queen s name, and ha\e declared they have no fear of the annexation of New Guinea by any foreign nation A despatch embodying these views is now in course of transmission to Queensland The Government in dicate, as one of their reasons (or refus ing to recognise the action of this Colony, that it is null and Void in point of law We are at a loss to know ft hat law has been violated So far as we have read history, it appears to us that from Columbus downwards there has be/n no law on the subject The early explorers took possession of the lands they discovered or coveted by doing as Mr Chester did-unfurling the British flag, and declaring the land to be hence forth a part of the Sovereign's dominion What an individual could do without any authority, surely a Magistrate of a British Colony, acting on a Commission, could perform legally Probably the proceeding has been declared null and void because it was without precedent, and was an infringement of some under stood bul unwritten law 1 he intima lion, that the Government has no fear of New Guinea being annexed by any foreign power, has not been made, we daresay, without good grounds In all likelihood, after the stir which has been made about the matter in European political circles, it has formed the subject of diplomatic notes Political con siderations, of which it is impossible for people m this colony to understand the consequence, have probably had much to do with the determination of the Im penal Government When the topic first came up for discussion we pointed out that the party now in power have been stoutly opposed to that imperialism in politics, which included in its practice the extension of the

Hntisti empire 1 here can be no doubt, moreover, that any influence Britain might have in the Councils of Curope, respecting the action of the Trench in Tonquin and Madagascar, would be greatly weakened were anv uncalled for or illegil annexation of New Guinea sanctioned While called upon to con sider public feeling in the colonies, as expressed through our colonial Govern ments, and our Agents General m London, the Imperial Government could not overlook the opinion of the people of the United Kingdom A large and active section AT Radical politicians

have ' A|^B^^BMLdeQounced the I

annexation, and have received consider able support from the Press By them and the Manchester party the conduct of the Home Government will meet with hearty commendation To the mass of the electors of the United Kingdom the whole affair will possess little interest, and the Government will suffer little either of praise or blame for the manner in which they have dealt

with it

Nevertheless, we are convinced that the subject has not received that amount of consideration tram the Imperial Government, and the press of the United Kingdom, to which it was entitled We are led to this belief by the manner in winch it has be°n dealt with by the lead ing London newspapers The Innes has been maundering on the subject In the weekly issue of May 18th it contains a contribution from "a correspondent of of distinction and experience,' on which it bases an article antagonistic to annexa non The writer in question discusses two distinct questions shall the sove reignty of the Queen be extended to New Guinea at all ? and, if it be so, shall the island be annexed to the exist ing colony of Queensland ? He answers these questions in the negative because of the size of the territory proposed to be annexed, but he proceeds in the belief that Queensland wanted the whole island, and not the Southern portion of it only He argues, more over, that Quehnsland is specially unfitted for the task of governing New Guinea, because the colonists would treat the inhabitants as they do the Australian natives This is an assump lion which is not very complimentary to Queeenslanders But it is ill founded, because, in our intercourse with the natives of the South Sea Islands, the people of this colony have had practical experience and observation of the differences of black races, and on that account would be peculiarly qualified for dealing with the New Gumeans To assume again, as this correspondent of

distinction does, that the Government would treat the land of New Guinea, cultivated as it is by stationary tribes, as we have done that of Australia, which was sparsely occupied by small wander ing, unsettled parties, is an insult to our common sense-not to speak of the wisdom and experience of our Parha mentary representatives It is argued further that the Queensland colonists, " even the most enlightened and humane," look upon natives as an encumbrance on the soil , and, therefore, they would treat the Papuans harshly, cruelly, and un justly Our readers will scarcely believe that this unwarranted reflection on their humanity and intelligence, should be accepted as indisputable by the leading English journal Its untruthfulness calls for no other comment than unqualified condemnation Another argumentagainst annexation, advanced and supported by the leading journal of the United King dom, is that " the island would become available as a recruiting ground for labour without any restrictions, other than those which the Parliament of Queensland itself might think fit to impose " On this very ground our Go vernment have justified the annexation At present New Guinea is in tne same position as the Southern Pacific Islands Labour may be recruited there now As the supply from the South Sea Islands begins to

fail the likelihood of New Guinea being resorted to becomes very evident, To prevent the intrusion of labour traders on its shores our Govern meat proposed to exercise a protectorate over the latter, but this privilege the Imperial Government has denied them So far as the labour traffic is concerned

I there is (ree trade with Papua, and if

some of the chiefs begin to find it is lucrative and exciting, it may soon be cultivated and attain considerable

' dimensions Instead of encovraging,

annexation would have had the effect of discouraging the labour trade

What the result will be of the deter mination of the Imperial Government on this matter, will now form the ground of considerable speculation In the colonies their decision will not bereceived withfavour Judgingfrom what transpired at the opening of the Victorian Parha ment, our neighbours in the South are more excited than we are upon the subject It does not seem to have crossed their minds, that the annexation of New Guinea would not be confirmed, and they apparently took it for granted that their demands respecting the acquisition of the New Hebrides would meet with no serious opposition Their irritation will be in proportion to their disappointment But a little temporary ebullition of feeling on the the part of our colonists will do little harm, and may be mollified, but what effect

the declinature of the British Govern

ment to annex the country will have on

other nations is a more serious matter

Practically, they ha\e declared that New Zealand is to let-rent free, and that any power, which cares to be at the trouble and expense, may take possession of it So long as the dangers, which have been repeatedly pointed out as to be feared in connexion with its occupation of a foreign power, threaten this country, the people will never feel safe or satisfied

On this question the difference of opinion between the United Kingdom

and the Australian colonies is most distinct and decided , nor will liarmonj be secured without annexation
heading: The Morning Bulletin. ROCKHAMPTON. FRIDAY, JULY 6, 1883.

articleText:
CORRESPONDENCE. OUK CANDIDATES.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

SID,-I am astonished that of the addresses wc have heard during the past few days, not one of the speakers have touched on those wider questions, such as "The Federation of 1 the Colonies," " The New Guinea Question,"

or any other groat national subjects. Mr. Archibald Forbes had thoroughly mastered thc characters of many of our legislators when he wrote-"It appears to me now accepted as a thing of course, as a matter uot to he disguised hut universally accepted as a broad fact, that a member goes to Parliament not BO much accredited tn legislate for the good of the commonwealth, as to agitate, struggle, bully, intrigue, for th* constituency that sends him up. He is not an item in the aggregate of a Legislature; he is a delegate from Little Peddlington or Bungorooboora. His function is to obtain that, whether the outlay be needed or not, without regard to tbe para- mount claims of other places and regionB, every pound of every loan that he can log-roll or extort, by fair means or foul, shall be expended on Little Peddlington or Bungoroo

boora."

That Mr. R»es R. Jones, being a native of thc country, should not have spoken one word on these truly national subjects, ia a mystery. However, 1 hope to hear his views on those questions yet. And let the electors bear in mind that so soon as tho people of Queensland are represeuted by natives of Australia, so Boon will foreign syndicates and absentee land- lordism disappear.

Yours, etc..

A PATRIOT.

Rockhampton, August ll, 1883.

P.S.-If it «ore not for the fooliiah custom of forcing all questioners on to the platform I

would have ashed the above questions nt tho I

meetings. It is a pity a man cannot ask a j

question of half a dozen words without being obliged to go through such formalities.
heading: CORRESPONDENCE. OUR CANDIDATES. TO THE EDITOR OF THE MORNING BULLETIN.

articleText:
[ . KOCKHAMl'TON.

MONDAY. AUGUST 27, 1883.

? »

IN English papers, recently to hand, we have an opportunity of becoming acquainted with the details of some of the provisions of a bill, which has been submitted to the Imperial Parliament, having for its object the purification of parliamentary elections. Where the electors are grouped in large masses, as they are in large English towns, and the individuality of voters is on that account difficult of identification, there can be no doubt that impersonation and double voting are more rife than with us. In the United Kingdom electoral rolls are watched more closely by the professional agents of both parties, and as a matter of fact no fresh enrolment takes place without being liable to be challenged. The common practice is to enlist the assistance of the party's agent to prove the title to enfranchisement. Our interest in legislation of this character ought to be excited by events, which, it is said, have lately taken place in our midst. In our recent election it is

commonly reported that impersonation was practised. Some rumours go so far as to say that some dishonest voters recorded their votes in two places in one electorate. It would be comparatively easy for the Return- ing Officer to prevent the last-named abuse, by adopting a system of alpha- betical division of polling places. It is to be hoped we may benefit by the ex- perience so recently gained when the constituency-which is now becoming of considerable numerical proportions-is next called upon to exercise a choice of representatives.

Some idea of the scope and intentions

of the Corrupt Practices Bill may be | gathered from the fact that the punish- ment, launched against bribery and

corruption, is directed mainly at the I

candidate upon whose behalf the pro- ceedings are practiced. It would appear

to be the intention of the framers of the j

measure to throw upon the candidate j the onus of proof of his ignorance of the illegal acts of his agents It will be remembered that Parliament at home is

elected for the btv en )ears, although one seldom exists so long, and this seems to have been the reason for the stipulation that, should the agent of any candidate be guilty of any bribery or malpractices, his principal shall be incapable of sitting as member for that constituency for the seven) earsnextensumg.after the decisi^i of the court establishing the disqualifying

condition The effect of this would be

practically to preclude the candidate, on whose behalf the ict was committed, from securing any advantage from ii, al least till after the next ensuing general election Any candidate who is per sonally guilty of corrupt practices, it is also provided, shall be for ever in capable of being elected for the I constituency in which the offence was

committed, shall be ineligible for ten years for election by any constituency in Great Britain For seven years he shall be deprived of his right to vote at any public election, and if he hold any public office, or official appointment of any kind, he shall forthwith be deprived of it Various punishments for minor offences are provided, ranging from two years' imprisonment downwards, and fines, not exceeding .£200, are scheduled as deterents to agents who may be tempted to lend themselves to promote corrupt practices In some cases fine may be added to imprisonment The definition of corrupt practices includes "treating in all its forms," and it makes the party accepting the "treat " or bribe a partner in the offence Under the

head of illegal practices is included the

conveyance of voters to and from the poll the payment to an elector of any sum of money for posting or ex hibiting bills or notices, or banners on his premises attempting to procure the vote of any unqualified person The Bill prohibits the hiring of any com mittee rooms, m excess of the number which the bill allows, and stipulates that the use of committee rooms in public houses shall be considered as an offence, defined as illegal hiring Although it is perhaps impossible to object to the spirit and intention of so excellent a measure, some difficulty will be experienced in making it immediately operative The conveyance of electors to the polling station has long been illegal m municipalities, but transgressions in this respect are so popular among candidates friends, as to be disregarded The better state of diciphne in which partizan

movements are conducted, and the com-

pleteness of the machinery which is at j

the disposal of local authorities in the old country, may enable them to give

effect to provisions, which would never I

take effect in and newer and less settled I state of society to which we are ac- customed. But, as already hinted, the process of educating the masses to a higher electoral tone, must take years to develope into such a state of purity as that sought to be established by the measure, now before the Imperial Parliament. The endeavour cannot, however, but command the active sympathy of all classes of the community, who desire to see the franchise exercised in an intelligent man- ner, by those who are in possession of so valuable a right of citizenship. Instead of voters requiring to be solicited, can- vassed, circularized, and in other ways cajoled, or coaxed to give their votes; and instead of their being required to be en- ticed or conveyed to the poll, as many are at present, they should come sponta- neously, and with a definite intention of supporting measures and principles by the election of their exponents. The general purpose of this measure is indis- putably to guide public opinion in this direction, and if its provisions make the whipping in, and the conveyance, and the cajolery, and persuasion, now lavished upon electors impossible, it will accom- plish great good. The exercise of voting power should be spontaneous. The man who requires much pressing to cast his vote should be regarded as not taking sufficient interest in the questions of the day to make his opinion upon them of any value to the community. Should the measure become law it will undoubtedly increase the number of absentees, but will nevertheless increase the value of the

decisions of the constituencies. Victory would favour the party whose rank and file were most earnestly impressed with

the wisdom of their leaders intentions, and it would not be unreasonable to hope thal by this means a very beneficial in fluence would be exercised upon the representatives of the people, who would not be slow to ap precíate the advantage of presenting to electors, hating an intelligent, if not a critical interest in the party, an accs.pt able programme, capable of inspiring supporters In the extension of a tendency of the character indicated it is surely not difficult to discover a strong corrective to the disadvantages, which are frequently supposed to arise from the adoption of universal suffrage If there were no inducement for the man, who had not been at the trouble to inform himself upon the politics of the day, and form a definite opinion for himself,

then we are inclined to think that onlv those active politicians would present themselves, who were sufficiently per suaded of the rectitude of their convie lions as to make them earnestly desirous of seeing their views embodied m our statutes, and by that means actively influencing the welfare of the country

articleText:
UOCKIIAMI'l'ON.

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1883.

IN the paper which Mr. Morris read at trie meeting of the Royal Colonial Insti- tute, on the 12th June last, and to which :we referred last week, he made particular references to, what he called the minor industries of tropical agriculture'. Sugar cultivation he spoke of as the major industry. Among the most important of the former are the production of cacao and bananas. These thrive in

exactly the same circumstances, and under the same system of cultivation. They are planted together, and the quickly growing, early fruiting bananas act as nurses of the slower growing, but ultimately more remunerative cacao. When thc banana plants have become exhausted, and no longer yield their bunche^ then the cacao plants begin to bear, and the ground, cleared of inter- mediate rows of the former, is required for the latter. Next to sugar, coffee and cacao are the most important articles of production in the West Indies. In Trinidad, 25,188 acres of land under cacao yielded a gross export value of ^270,906, or an average of upwards of £io an acre. In Jamaica, again, 22,853 acres of land under coffee gave a return of ,£271,449. 1° '872 the value of the cacao exported from Dominica was ¿¡2546 ; and six years afterwards it had risen to .^12,572. These figures merely indicate the rapidity and extent with which trade in these articles is springing up in the sunny islands of the wes-

tern main. But there are other tropical products, which yield a profitable return on the labour and care expended on them. Among these may be men- tioned coco-nuts, limes, pineapples, mangoes, oranges, nutmegs, cinchona, &c. " A coco plantation, we are told, in the West Indies, well established and in full bearing (say at the end of eight years) with sixty trees to the acre, may be safely assumed to be of the annual value of £io an acre. The expense

of maintaining a coco-nut plantation, when once established, is practically nothing ; hence the thousands of acres of land bordering the sea-coast of our West India possessions are capable of immense development." Trie general price for coco-nuts in the West Indies varies from 50s. to 80s. per thousand. In 1880 the value of nuts

exported from Jamacia was ,£20,500, and from Trinidad £14,000. The fruit trade of the islands fosters and strengthens other and more permanent industries. The cultivation of the banana, for instance, enables planters to establish cacoa. The fruit trade with America has become a settled and promising industry. Pineapples, tn the natural state and canned, are exported in large quantities. Swift steamers are now being placed on the routes between the richer islands, and the larger coast towns of the United States, for the purpose of facilitating the trade in coco-nuts, bananas, oranges, pineapples, tamarinds, plantains, mangoes, &c. In 1882 the value of these fruits exported from Jamaica alone reached .¿138,359. In 1873-ten years ago-the value of the fruits shipped from Jamaica was £8750. The demand for them is in- creasing; the wants of the United States and Canada cannot be supplied. Among these minor agricultural industries the production of nutmegs, cinnamon, car- damoms, cloves, black pepper, and

vanilla has been included. The cultiva- tion of cinchona has been fostered by the Government of Jamaica ; and at a cost of £r6,ooo they have made an estate, which has yielded ¿£12,000, and the plantation is valued at £20,000. We are told-"Thc cost of establish-

ing cinchona plantations in Jamaica is estimated at ¿£35 per acre, which

includes tbe purchase of land, and all expenses up to the end of the fourth year, when the first crop of bark may be taken. The total yield of the plantation (deducting the cost of barking, curing, and shipping expenses) up to the end of the ninth year, will probably be not less than ^175 per acre, against an outlay

for planting operations ior that period of : about ,£50 per acre. The estimate of cost is based upon land at about 5s. an acre, and creole labour at existing rates -viz.: men, is. to is. 4j£d. per'day ; women, loj^d. to is. per day." Be- sides producing cinchona, the manufac- ture of the bark into a febrifuge has been commenced, with every prospect of success, as there is a great demand for the article among the fever stricken inhabitants. On the little island of Montserrat a lime juice manufactory has been established, and has been carried on under such favourable circumstances that the export ot the article, crude and concentrated, is now nearly 100,000 gallons per annum. On the lime plantation 1000 acres are planted with 20,000 trees of all ages.

Our agriculture readers, we trust, have anticipated us in the main object we have in view, in calling attention to these facts. It is to point out the capabilities of tropical agriculture in its minor branches as a profitable industry. There is none of the fruits mentioned, which cannot be grown with the smallest amount of cultivation in this colony. In fact, we have seen limes and oranges growing in a semi-wild state. There can be no doubt but by a very little effort, we could establish coco plantations on our coast lands ; that cacao and bananas could be grown together as in the West Indies ; coffee is already being success- fully cultivated ; and cinchona has been found to thrive In our experimental gar- dens. Some of our .readers may be ready to admit at once, 'that there are no natural obstacles

to: the cultivation of any of the products referred to in this colony, but where could they find a market for them. We at once reply in the southern colonies, including Tas-

mania and New Zealand. We see no

reason why we should not pay for the timber and grain we obtain from them,

with our luscious and tempting fruits?" We have quick steamers running to and fro along the east coast of Australia. We have large towns in the adjoining colonies, where thîre would be a steady demand for oar products, could we only create a trade. Let there be production, and distribution is sure to follow. If our selectors will bring forward coco-nuts, oranges, bananas, limes, mangoes, &c, in sufficient quantity to make an export trade profitable, there can be no doubt it will speedily increase in dimensions, and prove of immense advantage to the colony. These minor agricultural in- dustries, it seems to us, ought to com- mand tar more attention from our selectors than they have hitherto showed any disposition to bestow on them.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, Rockhampton. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1883.

articleText:
KOCK I IA MITON.

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1883.

AMONG those who advocate a change in our system of land-leasing and alienation, it is contended that the management of the public estate should not be left lo one Minister. A Board

of Commissioners, it has been suggested, should be appointed to assist in the letting of the public lands, and in the collection of the ¡revenue lo be derived from them. It seems to be considered in many quarters that the Minister for Lands has too much power, and that things are sometimes done that others uninterested cannot recognise to be to the public advantage. Of course, if the Minister for Lands is to be subjected lo a sort of espionage by this means, it will occur to many that other Ministers should be placed under similar super- vision. In this way we have raised the larger question of the establishment of what may be called Hoards of Control at the head of each public depart- ment. A good deal may be said in support of such arrangement. The efficiency of such boards would depend very much on their constitution. Were they composed of men who only held oflicc during the continuance in office of the party from whom they derived their status they would, as Minis- ters are at present, be a ^ood deal in the power of the higher permanent officials. It is patent, we think, to members of Divisional Hoards, of Town Councils, ¡ind of other public bodies, thnt a gre.it deal of the business of our Departments is done by foe Under Secretaries. To appoint men (oliovernwent boards, who should only hold office foi a short time, would be no great advantage. On the other hand, permanent members would

be too apt to usurp the functions of government, without being open to a ready and sufficient check. Boards, therefore, in which the majority of the members mere'.y should hold per- manent appointments would be most , efficient. The permanent members

would possess the requisite amount of technical knowledge of details to enable

them to exercise due control on the con- duct of the officials in the Department ; while the transitory members would prevent the Board becoming too inde-

pendent.

A glane» at the various public Depart- ments will show that others of them

might be more benefitted by a Board of Control than that of the Lands. The amount of public business that is supposed to be under the control of the Colonial Secretary is too much for one man. Embraced in this department are the Immigration service, for which the vote last year was j£t%o,ooo ; the police service, including magistrates, clerks, and constables; the management of gaols, reformatories, hospitals, asylums, volunteers, &c. It goes without showing, we think, that an active politician, who has to guide the affairs of the colony, who has to waKh the run of, events over

adjoining colonies, and that in which he is interest^; who has to meet Patlia mei1., 'and discuss <v.easures of the

first importance in all their details, ! can only perform the duties of this office in a perfunctory manner. In the department of the Attorney-General the business to be attended to is all of one kind, and is not so great as in that of

'ie Colonial Secretary ; but a council of al vice, composed of judges and gentle- men of eminence in the legal profession, would be for the public advantage in many cases. Our Educational Depart- ment is annually becoming burdened with a large amount of business, while there are many questions connected with education, outside ot the usual routine, that call for consideration. In dis-

cussing the latter, and determining points of general management the assistance of gentlemen like Bishop Hale and Rev. C. M'Culloch would be valuable. The relations of the Treasury with our trade and commerce are so numerous and vital, that a Board of Trade would certaily prove useful. A council of the kind suggested is already in existence. Captain Heath is Chairman of the Marine Board, and four gentlemen hold seats on it. An increase in the number of members of this Board would enable it to deal with all matters connected with shipping, as well as customs, and excise. In the Lands Department the business is not so varied as in some of the others. Most of the detail business is done by the land agents and commissioners ; and it does not appear to us the necessity fora Board, in connection with this Department, is so prominent as with some of the others. More than any other would the advan- tages of a Board be apparent in connec- tion with the Works Department. Itis too much for one man to inaugurate the policy, and determine the principles on which our railway traffic shall be conducted,

and at the same time attend to the ad- ministration of the countless details of

j the system. It has been proposed

to establish a railway board in

Victoria. Such a council would be

of immense utility in connection with our

j Works Department, and plenty of occupa-

tion would be found for it, even though it should not attend to the business con- nected with mining, public buildings, roads, &c. The Board of Trade might extend its deliberations beyond things connected with the Treasurer's Depart- ment to those pertaining to the Post and Telegraph Departments, which would

I naturally fall to be considered in making

arrangements for facilitating trade and

commerce.

In permitting so much of the public business to be transacted by permanent civil servants, there is a danger of the country suffering from " officialism." I Our civil servants form a large and intel-

ligent section of the community. They are a power in the State. Especially is this the case with respect to school masters. The education service is repre- sented in every community, and when- ever the teachers' interests are threatened they immediately defend them through the Press. In America the complete change of officials which follows a change of Government is at- tended with many disadvantages, in- cluding the avoidable expenditure of public funds. We have no desire that such a system should prevail in this colony. In the United Kingdom the periodic changes in the heads of Depart- ments have been attended with good

results: and the same have followed the

like constitutional practice in this colony. It is a question worthy of con- sideration, whether we should not go farther, in immitation of the Imperial Government, and appoint, at least, Boards of Trade and Works. This might be done to the great relief of the Ministers interested, to the benefit of the public service, and to the advantage of the colony.
heading: The Morning Bulletin, ROCKHAMPTON. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1883.
